The French news agency Agence France-Presse said Taylor announced a plan to hold elections Oct. 10 when he spoke at a news conference Sunday in Gbarnga, 75 miles northeast of Monrovia. His army invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast in December, accusing Doe of mismanagement and corruption in running the country founded by freed American slaves in 1847. Johnson fought with Taylor's forces early on. But the two men later had a falling-out, and their forces have been battling one another as well as Doe loyalists. They both claim the presidency. In an account in London's Sunday Observer newspaper, a Lebanese merchant from Monrovia said he watched Johnson's men torture Doe after the president was captured during a battle Sept. 9 at the headquarters of a West African army. The regional force was sent by the Economic Community nations to restore peace, but it has been caught up in the fighting. ``Doe's hands were cuffed together and he had been shot in both legs and was bleeding heavily. They were abusing him,'' the merchant, identified only as Joseph, was quoted as saying. ``Then one of Johnson's men took a knife, a machete, and cut off his ear. Then they cut his face like this,'' he told the newspaper, indicating diagonal slashes across the cheeks. ``He was crying and the blood was running down his cheeks from his face and head.'' The man said Doe at one point blew on the blood that had pooled on his body, and ``one of Johnson's men thought he was trying to do some kind of juju (magic), blowing on himself to make himself disappear.'' ``So he shot him again,'' the merchant said. ``He was nearly dead then, anyway, from loss of blood.'' The Observer also quoted a Liberian teacher, identified only as Oliver, as saying he saw Doe's body later in the day. ``They had him in a wheelbarrow and were pushing the body around the town. They were shouting, `We've killed Doe,' and firing their guns in the air. ``People were coming up to the body and cutting it with knives. Slashing at him. He had two fingers, maybe three, missing from one hand and they had cut off his testicles,'' the teacher said. ``Then they took his body to the Island Clinic. For the first two or three days a lot of people were going to see it, but then the smell got too bad,'' Oliver said. Both witnesses were interviewed in Freetown. Their description was reminiscent of an October 1985 scene when Doe put the mutilated body of Brig. Gen. Thomas Quiwonkpa on display in an open car that toured Monrovia. Quiwonkpa has been captured after an attempt to overthrow Doe.

DOC.HEAD: Family Killed in Series of Vehicle Accidents
DOC.TEXT: When their two children were killed two years apart in a car crash and a snowmobile accident, Bernie and Jean Haugen immersed themselves in helping others. Haugen, a municipal judge, was a champion of children and children's rights, friends and neighbors say. He supervised the Richland County juvenile court, taught Sunday school and served as a Boy Scout leader. Mrs. Haugen, an instructor in occupational therapy at North Dakota State College of Science, became active in a support group for parents grieving the loss of a child. The couple also enlisted as foster parents to troubled adolescents. In mid-June, they were driving home from Minneapolis, where they had taken a runaway to catch a flight to Washington, when their car slammed into a bridge. Mrs. Haugen was killed. Her husband of 30 years died Aug. 14 from his injuries. The Haugens - parents and children - now lie buried a few yards from their home in Wahpeton, near the Minnesota line. Residents wonder at how so much sadness could strike one family. ``It's incredible, absolutely incredible,'' said the Rev. Marv L. Hartmann of Bethel Lutheran Church, which the family attended for 20 years. ``Then and now, the whole community is just sick at heart.'' ``The whole community has really been working together on this,'' said Chuck Sheeley, who was a close friend of Haugen's. ``It is tragic. Nobody can understand this because there's no reason for it.'' The couple's son, Donnell, was killed with a friend in an automobile accident near Otter Tail Lake, Minn., in 1981, the night before they were to graduate with honors from Wahpeton High School. Their daughter, Kimberlee, died of head injuries in a snowmobile accident near Brainerd, Minn., two years later. She was a passenger on the snowmobile and was just three months short of graduating from high school. Those who knew the teen-agers remember them as good students, active in sports and other school activities. ``They were excited, enthusiastic about everything,'' Hartmann said. Donnell was an Eagle Scout and a school record-holder in the 3,200-meter run. Kimberlee was a gifted musician and active in youth activities at the church. She won first place in a contest for writing about the person she admired most in the community - her father. She described his work with young people and the church, calling him a man willing to fight for his convictions. ``He was an advocate of abused, deprived and neglected kids,'' said Sheeley, the county probation officer. ``Those were the kind of kids that bothered him the most.'' ``It was almost a lifestyle for Bernie, not a job,'' Hartmann added. Haugen suffered severe internal injuries and broken bones in the crash and later developed pneumonia. He was 51. ``It's difficult accepting this,'' Sheeley said. ``But (Bernie) always told me that life isn't fair. I guess he was right. We're all going to miss him very much.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-S&L Chief Spends Days Alone in LA Jail
DOC.TEXT: Charles H. Keating Jr. isn't allowed to eat, exercise or otherwise mingle with other inmates at the Los Angeles County Jail. Keating, blamed by regulators for the nation's biggest savings and loan failure, spends his days alone in a cell at the cavernous Men's Central Jail. With nearly 7,000 prisoners, the jail is one of the nation's largest. ``We do it because of his newsworthiness. Because of who he is,'' said sheriff's Deputy Bill Linnemeyer. ``We do the same with all personalities for their well-being and safety.'' But that's where Keating's special treatment ends. For him and other inmates, the day begins at 5:30 a.m. when lights in the jail are turned on. It ends at 10 p.m. when the lights are turned off. Keating, 66, is given one hour a day to exercise, watch television or use the phone. Like all prisoners, he's served three meals a day. Linnemeyer said Keating has no better accommodations than other inmates. His cell has a bunk with a mattress and blanket, a toilet and sink. ``It's not the Taj Mahal, but it's comfortable,'' Linnemeyer said. Keating was indicted last week on charges he swindled elderly investors in now-worthless junk bonds sold through his collapsed Lincoln Savings and Loan. Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner set bail at $5 million and refused on Friday to reduce it to $500,000. The judge said Keating has ``significant reasons not to stay around'' while awaiting trial. Keating could get up to 10 years in prison if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Former Rep. Mink Makes a Comeback in Hawaii
DOC.TEXT: Voters returned former Rep. Patsy Mink to the U.S. House for the rest of the year and also nominated the Democrat for a full two-year term. Democrat Daniel Akaka, who was appointed temporarily to fill Sen. Spark's Matsunaga's seat after he died of cancer in April, was nominated Saturday to serve out the rest of Matsunaga's term. Rep. Patricia Saiki won the Republican nomination. Gov. John Waihee, seeking his second four-year term, coasted past three little-known opponents in the Democratic primary. He will face GOP state Rep. Fred Hemmings, a businessman and former world champion surfer, who beat five others in the Republican primary. Mink beat seven other candidates in a winner-take-all special election to fill the three months remaining in Akaka's term. Akaka resigned his House seat in May to succeed Matsunaga. Mink edged business executive Mufi Hannemann in the special election, and also beat Hannemann in the Democratic primary. She will face Republican Andrew Poepoe in the Nov. 6 general election. Mink, 62, an attorney, served in the House from 1965 to 1977 and was a member of the Honolulu City Council from 1982 to 1986. In another U.S. House race, Matsunaga's son, Honolulu attorney Matthew Matsunaga, came in third in a Democratic primary.

DOC.HEAD: Pre-Summit Vigils Held for World's Dying Children
DOC.TEXT: Citizens in 83 countries lighted candles, tolled bells and chanted prayers in an appeal to world leaders to help save the 40,000 children who die each day from disease, crime, hunger and war. The 2,600 sundown vigils around the globe Sunday came less than a week before more than 70 heads of state meet for the U.N. World Summit for Children. The summit aims to reduce death and suffering among children. The vigils followed sunset around the globe, starting with scientists in Antarctica and continuing at refugee camps on the Somalian-Ethiopian border and at 200 Buddhist temples in South Korea. More than 300 people rallied in front of the United Nations, where the summit convenes on Saturday. Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., who attended the vigil, criticized President Bush for not acting on a U.N. treaty that guarantees basic health, education and human rights to the world's children. ``There is no excuse for Bush not to have signed this,'' said Bradley, who sponsored a resolution asking the president to forward the treaty to the Senate for ratification. Bradley said his resolution passed the Senate by a unanimous voice vote Sept. 11. The U.N. Convention on the Rights of Children was adopted by the U.N. General Assembly last year. To be ratified by the United States, the treaty must pass the Senate, then be signed by Bush. More than 500 candlelight vigils took place in the United States. In St. Paul, Minn., about 1,500 people, including many pre-schoolers, gathered on the steps of the state Capitol. They listened to speeches, music and a reading of Dr. Seuss' ``Horton Hatches the Egg.'' In San Francisco, state Superintendent of Public Instruction Bill Honig told a crowd of about 150 at City Hall he found it ``sickening ... that this society, with the riches that we have, can't figure out a way to allow our youngsters to grow up in more decent conditions.'' In New York, the crowd listened to speeches, folk songs and prayers and stood for a moment of silence. n a corner of the plaza, six children knelt around candles and flowers. ``I'm here because there is starvation and death, because they don't have enough food and they're sick. We have to send food and medicines - and love,'' said Ryan DeVeaux, 10. The number of child deaths due to disease could be cut in half by the year 2000 with the help of $2.5 billion - the amount of money spent in a year on cigarette advertising in the United States, said Barbara Charbonnet, coordinator of the New York vigil.

DOC.HEAD: Contractor Claims Obesity Should Qualify Him For City Housing Jobs
DOC.TEXT: A contractor says his weight - 640 pounds - should qualify him as a minority when it comes to bidding on city contracts. Donald E. Keister, 30, has threatened a lawsuit unless Baltimore recognizes him as a minority. Minorities are given preferential treatment in the awarding of housing rehabilitation contracts. ``The city won't even let me apply for minority certification because I am not black or another racial minority,'' said Keister, who has been diagnosed as suffering from morbid obesity. City officials say the minority preference law was intended to help women and members of races who have suffered discrimination - not fat people. Because of his weight, Keister said he cannot go to job sites and must manage employees from his office, which has special chairs and equipment to sustain his weight. ``I went to houses years ago and would fall right through the wooden steps because they couldn't support my weight,'' he said. ``It costs me a lot more money to run my business because of my condition. ... I'm fortunate to have real good people working for me.'' He said he qualifies as a minority under a new federal law, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and has been certified as a minority by several counties, a state council and the state Transportion Department. Keister, who has six employees, specializes in lead-paint testing and removal and also does general contracting and consulting. Under a city program, 15 percent to 25 percent of the work on contracts is set aside for businesses owned by racial minorities and women. Clint Coleman, a spokesman for Mayor Kurt Schmoke, said the law doesn't include handicapped people. The ordinance is under review to bring it into conformance with recent court rulings, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Tourists Buy Lunch for 70 Homeless People
DOC.TEXT: A pair of tourists decided not to just walk on by at the sight of so many homeless and hungry people. Dennis Seifert, 38, Newport Beach, and Howard Hawley, 38, of Corona, invited about 70 street people to lunch Sunday. At first, only 10 street people accepted. But word spread quickly and soon dozens lined up at the counter of a Carl's Jr. fast-food restaurant. The manager, who would not identify himself, at first encouraged the homeless to eat outside, saying he was worried that fleas and ticks from them would infest the salad bar. But Seifert insisted that they eat indoors. One man, who gave his name only as Jack, finished three hamburgers and took one to go. ``Anytime you get to eat free hamburgers, man, it's like winning the lottery,'' he said, patting his stomach. The tab for lunch came to $96.81, but Hawley said the experience was worth much more. ``You walk around and see so many homeless people, it gets to you,'' he said. ``We can't feed everyone, but if we can make a small dent in the problem, well, maybe that is a contribution.''

DOC.HEAD: Sunny Skies Across Plains, Storms in Southwest
DOC.TEXT: Unseasonably warm temperatures prevailed over much of the Plains today and scattered rain and thunderstorms lingered over the Southwest. Today's forecast called for scattered showers in Oregon, California, Idaho, Utah, Colorado, Wyoming, New York, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. Thunderstorms were likely over parts of Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado and Florida. Temperatures in some parts of the Plains were expected to reach into the 80s, as much as 20 degrees higher than Sunday. Temperatures were expected to fall along the East Coast, dipping into the 50s in much of the Northeast and into the 60s as far south as the Carolinas. Sunday, Florida enjoyed unseasonably warm weather, with highs in the 90s. Records for the date were broken from Ft. Lauderdale to Miami Beach to Orlando. Temperatures were expected to fall by as much as 10 degrees today throughout the state. The high temperature Sunday in the Lower 48 states was 100 degrees in Yuma, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against all major foreign currencies today in quiet, early European trading. Gold prices were mixed. Dealers said the dollar was weaker after the Group of Seven weekend meeting in Washington which showed that the seven industrial nation's central bankers and finance ministers were satisfied with current foreign exchange levels. The communique after the meeting called for continued firm monetary policies in the face of high oil prices, but expressed satisfaction with recent major currency moves on foreign exchanges. ``The dollar will continue to fall. The statement showed nobody is too dissatisfied with this,'' said Jeff Earnshaw, deputy head of trading at Natwest Moneycenter in London. Dealers said trading was quiet, with Japanese markets closed for a national holiday and ahead of Tuesday's release of the third and final report on U.S. second quarter gross national product data. Tokyo markets were closed today for Autumnal Equinox Day. In London, the dollar fell to 135.57 yen from Friday's Tokyo close of 137.33 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: -1.5675 German marks, down from 1.5770 -1.3055 Swiss francs, down from 1.3205 -5.2482 French francs, down from 5.2790 -1.7745 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7773 -1,169.75 Italian lire, down from 1,175.75 -1.1510 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1528 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8625, compared with $1.8465 late Friday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $390.15 per ounce at midmorning, from $388.25 bid per ounce late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $390.40, down from $392.20 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.05 to close at a bid $389.42. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.80 a troy ounce, from Friday's $4.81.

DOC.HEAD: Winnie Mandela Arraigned in Fatal Beating Case
DOC.TEXT: Winnie Mandela, looking grim and tired, was arraigned today on charges of assault and kidnapping stemming from a 1988 incident when four youths were allegedly taken to her house and beaten. Mrs. Mandela, holding hands with her husband, African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, said nothing as she arrived at a city magistrate's court. She stood silently in the courtroom as her lawyers conferred with the magistrate and a trial date was set for Feb. 4. Mrs. Mandela, wearing a black outfit, was greeted by about 30 cheering and singing ANC women supporters as she left the court. ``Winnie, Winnie!'' the women chanted as they tried to touch Mrs. Mandela. She smiled briefly before being whisked away by lawyers and aides. One youth was killed and the former head of Mrs. Mandela's bodyguards, Jerry Richardson, has been convicted of murder and sentenced to death in the same case. The sentence is being appealed. Mrs. Mandela has denied any wrongdoing. White and black leaders fear the trial will strain relations between the ANC, the leading anti-apartheid group, and the white-led government as they try to start talks on extending political rights to the black majority. Mandela may be discredited in the eyes of militant young blacks who oppose negotiating with the government and will see his wife's trial as demeaning. Mrs. Mandela faces trial with seven members of her former bodyguard who have been charged on the same counts. Court officials say she faces four charges of kidnapping and four of assault with intent to commit grievous bodily harm. Mrs. Mandela was freed on her own recognizance. Bail for the other defendants was continued. All eight will be tried together. If convicted, Mrs. Mandela could face the death sentence, lawyers said. However, that sentence has never been imposed for kidnapping, they said. Mrs. Mandela has been plunged into a series of damaging public exposures, mainly linked to the actions of her bodyguards, called the Mandela United Football Club. The group, which had little to do with soccer, was composed of about two dozen aggressive teen-agers. In December 1988, four young blacks were kidnapped from a church home in Soweto, according to testimony at Richardson's trial. The four were taken to Mrs. Mandela's Soweto home and assaulted, witnesses said. Stompie Seipei, 14, was killed. The three survivors testified that Mrs. Mandela participated in the beatings. According to testimony, Mrs. Mandela's bodyguards accused Seipei of being a police informer and the three others of having homosexual relations with the white minister who ran the church home where they lived. No evidence has been presented that Seipei was a police spy. The youth was a well-known anti-apartheid activist. The Methodist Church cleared the minister of any misconduct. In other developments, police said today at least 12 people died nationwide in new black factional fighting over the weekend. About 800 people have been killed in such violence in the Johannesburg area since August. The fighting pits Xhosas and other blacks loyal to the ANC against Zulus linked to the conservative Inkatha movement. The two groups oppose apartheid but differ over leadership and aims for a future South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Stevie Ray Vaughan's Last Album Set for Release
DOC.TEXT: The release Tuesday of Stevie Ray Vaughan's ``Family Style'' album will be bittersweet for fans and family of the late blues guitarist. Vaughan and his brother, Jimmie, worked together on the album, their most extensive collaboration. ``It was something they always wanted to do,'' said Charles Comer, the brothers' publicist and a longtime family friend. Stevie Ray Vaughan, a Dallas native, died Aug. 27 in a helicopter crash in Wisconsin following a concert with Eric Clapton. It was not the first time the brothers recorded together. Jimmie joined his brother's band for two tracks on ``Couldn' Stand the Weather'' and they played together on Bob Dylan's newest release, ``Under the Red Sky.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Conflict Could Provide First Test of Women in Combat Positions
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 6th to CORRECT that 1960s laws did not mandate sexual equality in military. Picks up 7th, `Air force....' ^By FRANK POWLEY
DOC.TEXT: ``I knew what I was getting into when I joined the navy three years ago, but naturally I'm nervous,'' said sailor Lill Mortensen the day she shipped out for the Persian Gulf. Ms. Mortensen, 24, is one of 10 female sailors in the 100-person crew aboard the corvette Olfert Fischer, sent to Middle East waters to help enforce a U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq. Norway, Belgium, Canada, Denmark and the Netherlands are the only countries that assign women to offensive combat positions in their armed forces. For the five NATO members, the gulf crisis could provide the first test of that policy. ``Of course it's hard on the family to have to say goodbye,'' said Ms. Mortensen. ``And luckily my boyfriend and I are used to being separated. He's a submariner.'' In addition to the 10 Danes, there are 24 women on board a Dutch frigate that sailed for the gulf last month, and 30 on the destroyer Protecteur, which Canada sent to join the international armada. American women, though they make up 10 percent of the military's personnel, are restricted to non-combat roles. Danish laws enacted in the 1960s mandated sexual equality in the labor market and opened the way for women in the military. But it wasn't until 1988 that women were allowed to train for combat and join fighting units. Air force Capt. Sussie Rasmussen calls sexual harassment or discrimination in the military ``no worse than one finds in other work places where women are introduced for the first time.'' Only two all-male bastions remain in Denmark's military - the cockpit of a jet fighter and aboard a submarine. In Norway, women are assigned to submarines. There are Dutch female fighter pilots, and there are no restrictions on Belgian women's combat positions. Ms. Rasmussen calls the U.S. restrictions on women odd. ``I find it a paradox that U.S. women sail on navy supply and ammunition ships and fly on AWACS reconnaissance planes - all obvious enemy targets in an armed conflict - and yet are kept behind the battle lines,'' she said. ``When it comes to a `your life or mine' situation, the female survival instinct is just as strong as the male's.'' Norwegian women have had equal rights and duties with men in the armed forces since 1985. But women are exempt from the draft. ``Once they have volunteered, they have exactly the same duties as men. If they are in a combat unit, they would go with it anywhere,'' said Col. Per Boethun of the Norwegian Supreme Defense Command. Boethun said Norway has women infantry, sailors and pilots. They fly military transports and would be allowed to fly fighters even in battle, said Boethun. None, however, has qualified as a fighter pilot. Norwegian air force Maj. Berit Ovesen said some leaders hinder women from promotions or more training. ``Also, some leaders think it doesn't pay to train women who are of childbearing age,'' she said. In the Netherlands, women make up about 2 percent of the 120,000-member military, and serve mostly in logistics and operations. Some are in combat units and ``if it comes down to fighting, they will have to fight like men,'' said Dutch army spokesman Wiebe Alkema. A Belgian defense official said his country's 3,000 women volunteers have equal rights to any position or rank, but few seek combat jobs. A Canadian human rights tribunal ruled in 1989 that all armed forces units, except submarine crews, must be open to women. They now account for about 10 percent of the 87,000-member armed forces. ``There has been at least one graduate from infantry training, several from artillery. They have armored people going through training now,'' said Capt. Ric Jones, a Department of National Defense spokesman. Asked whether women would be yanked out of combat in a shooting war, Jones said: ``I can't answer that question, but I don't expect so because when we employ a person, we employ them. They are treated as equals, not specials.''
Editors: No Deaths package will move for Monday PMs.

DOC.HEAD: Khrushchev Thanks Rosenbergs for Bomb Secrets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `The ousted ...' to ADD Krushchev comment about Stalin; INSERTS two grafs after 9th graf, `My comrades ...' to ADD detail on Stalin. Pick up 10th graf, `Many of ...'
DOC.TEXT: Nikita Khrushchev paid tribute to Julius and Ethel Rosenberg for providing information that significantly helped the Soviets develop an atomic bomb. The ousted Soviet leader also said a ``hotheaded'' Fidel Castro wanted the Soviet Union to attack the United States during the Cuban missile crisis and Josef Stalin made a secret attempt to negotiate peace with Adolf Hitler during World War II. Khrushchev remarks are contained in tapes he made during seven years of house arrest before his death in 1971. The tapes were acquired by Time magazine, and excerpts were published in the Oct. 1 issue. ``I was part of Stalin's circle when he mentioned the Rosenbergs with warmth,'' said Khrushchev, who was ousted in 1964. ``I cannot specifically say what kind of help they gave us, but I heard from both Stalin and (Vyacheslav) Molotov, then minister of foreign affairs, that the Rosenbergs provided very significant help in accelerating the production of our atom bomb,'' he said. ``Let this be a worthy tribute to the memory of those people.'' The Rosenbergs' son Robert Meeropol, who has worked for years with his brother, Michael, to clear their parents' name, called Khrushchev's remarks ``wholly absurd.'' ``The U.S. government acknowledged that none of the material discussed at the trial was of any value,'' said Meeropol, a 43-year-old lawyer in Springfield, Mass., who was 6 when his parents were executed in 1953 as spies. Krushchev said Castro, during the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, ``suggested that to prevent our nuclear missiles from being destroyed, we should launch a pre-emptive strike against the U.S.'' ``My comrades in the leadership and I realized that our friend Fidel totally failed to understand our purpose. We had installed the missiles not for the purpose of attacking the U.S. but to keep the U.S. from attacking Cuba,'' he said. Khrushchev said a desperate Josef Stalin made a ``very secret'' overture of peace to Adolf Hitler during World War II. Stalin wanted to reach an agreement with Hitler to let Germany keep territory they occupied in the Ukraine, Byelorussia and certain areas of the Russian federation, Krushchev said. ``I think it was in 1942,'' he said. ``There was never any answer from Hitler.'' Many of the tapes Khrushchev made after his ouster were smuggled to the West and two volumes of memoirs were published in the 1970s. His friends and relatives withheld some of the tapes, fearing he had been too candid. Last year, Time magazine acquired those tapes. Another book, ``Khrushchev Remembers: The Glasnost Tapes,'' is due out next month from Little, Brown.

DOC.HEAD: Stung By Embargo, Iraqis Threaten To Fire The First Shot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5 grafs for 10-11 pvs bgng `At the...' to UPDATE with French reax to Iraqi apology, Kuwait dinar invalid. Picks up 12th, `France responded...'; SUBS last two grafs to UPDATE with Korean aid. ^LaserPhotos NY6,7,8
DOC.TEXT: In their most bellicose statement yet, Iraq's leaders have warned the U.S.-led forces arrayed against them that they would launch an all-out war before allowing the U.N. trade embargo to ``strangle'' the Iraqi people. They seemed for the first time to be threatening a first strike, and mentioned Israel and Mideast oil fields as potential targets. ``America must realize clearly that it is pushing the entire region ... in fact, even the whole world ... to the brink of a bottomless abyss, from which the region will never see light for dozens of years,'' the Iraqi communique said Sunday. It was signed by the Revolution Command Council and the ruling Baath Party but bore the rhetorical imprint of President Saddam Hussein - studded with references to ``poisonous wasps,'' ``evil-doers'' and ``Zionist usurpers.'' ``We will never allow anybody, whomever he may be, to strangle the people of Iraq without having himself strangled,'' the communique said. Last year, Iraq imported 75 percent of the food its people consumed. Now, an international trade embargo ordered by the U.N. Security Council in response to Saddam's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait has prompted the Baghdad government to begin rationing some staples. The Security Council is expected to vote Tuesday on an eighth resolution punishing Iraq for refusing to relinquish Kuwait. The strictest yet, it would block all air traffic in and out of Iraq but planes carrying humanitarian aid. The prospect of being even further cut off and ostracized likely contributed to the Iraqi communique's acid tone: ``Those who wish the flood to overtake the Iraqi people and the nation, and are planning for this, should remember well that the waves of the flood will overwhelm them before they overwhelm the Iraqi people.'' Iraq further consolidated its hold on Kuwait today by declaring the country's currency, the dinar, invalid and withdrawn from circulation. The official Iraqi News Agency said Iraq would reimburse holders of the currency with Iraqi dinars. At the same time, however, Iraq held out a small olive branch to France. It offered a belated apology on Sunday for the Sept. 14 raid on the French ambassador's residence in occupied Kuwait during which the military attache and three other French citizens were arrested. French Interior Minister Pierre Joxe today brushed aside Baghdad's apology for the raid. ``Excuses are fine,'' he said on French radio. ``but we're waiting for Iraq to let captive Frenchmen leave in a normal manner.'' The Foreign Ministry estimates 360 French citizens are held hostage in Iraq and occupied Kuwait, along with about 1,000 Americans and several thousand other Westerners. France responded to the raid by expelling Iraqis from France and sending 4,000 soldiers to Saudi Arabia as part of the U.S.-led multinational force. The troops began arriving on Sunday, and their country's president, Francois Mitterrand, was to address the opening session of the 45th U.N. General Assembly today. Iraq is expected to face a chorus of condemnation in three weeks of speeches by leaders to the world body, which has gained a new vitality in its near-unanimous response to the crisis. But there may be no Iraqis present. Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, said Sunday that Iraq would not participate in the session because the State Department had refused to allow Iraqi Airways to fly Aziz and his entourage to New York. A State Department official said the matter was still being considered, ``but it would seem inappropriate to grant permission for the Iraqi foreign minister to fly his plane to the United States while hundreds of Americans citizens are being held against their will in Iraq and Kuwait.'' A plane carrying 112 evacuees from Iraq and Kuwait landed in Raleigh, N.C., Sunday night from London. The State Department said it was the last U.S.-chartered airlift planned from Iraq, which is holding foreign males as human shields at strategic installations to discourage a possible attack. The Iraqi communique appeared to rule out even the suggestion of compromise, calling the invasion of Kuwait a ``defensive move'' necessary to achieve Baghdad's ``well-known noble objectives.'' It warned that ``dire consequences'' would befall ``back-stabbers,'' an apparent reference to the Arab nations that oppose Saddam. Syria has committed 20,000 troops to the force standing up to Iraq. Egypt has promised 15,000. Three Egyptian navy ships carrying new troops and gear to Saudi Arabia passed through the Suez Canal on Sunday. The Iraqi communique, broadcast by state-run media, threatened to ``render incapable ... the oil area in Saudi Arabia and in other states of the region.'' It said ``the oil, the areas it is in and Israel will be transformed into something different from what they are now.'' The communique said Saddam's Aug. 12 statement that he would only quit Kuwait if Israel turns the occupied territories over to the Palestinians, was the only basis for negotiations. In so saying, it appeared to chide Jordan's King Hussein for trying to broker an Arab-sponsored peace. ``As for the Arabs who are launching good offices,'' the communique said, ``they are urged not to replace the solution that we offered on Aug. 12 with a partial solution.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III, interviewed on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press,'' was asked about the possibility of war. ``We have said many times we hoped there won't be,'' he replied, but added President Bush was not ruling out any options. In another gulf-related developments, South Korea said today that it would donate $220 million in military and humanitarian aid to multinational defense efforts in the gulf. The amount falls short of the reported $450 million originally requested by the United States. South Korea said recent major floods have left it strapped for cash.

DOC.HEAD: Leader of Bulgaria's Governing Party Steps Down
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the governing Socialist Party, a member of the Politburo under the ousted Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, stepped down today under fire from reformers. His announcement came on the third day of a turbulent congress to determine the future of the party that shed its Communist appellation last spring and went on to win multiparty elections. The resigning party leader, Alexander Lilov, had taken over in February as Bulgaria was swept by the wave of reform that toppled hard-line Communist regimes across Eastern Europe. Lilov has disappointed many party members and other Bulgarians who expected him to spearhead swift political change. Political tensions have been exacerbated by an unprecedented food shortage in the Balkan nation and the Socialists' popularity is dwindling. Many store shelves are empty, essential foodstuffs are rationed, and electricity is periodically cut off. In a speech today to the party congress, Lilov acknowledged he had been burdened by his ties to Bulgaria's past. He said he was resigning in favor of a ``more pragmatic '' leader. ``We are still not a new party which thinks, analizes and acts from a new position,'' Lilov told delegates. ``Perhaps we are tired after holding power for over 45 years.'' While warning against any drastic purge, he called for a new and united party turning into a ``strong political organization'' with a rejuvenated leadership. ``I have (to assume) the responsibility for the time during which I was a Politburo member of this party. This has been for more than ten years,'' he said. Lilov and former President Petar Mladenov are among the top officials who held leading posts during Zhivkov's lengthy rule. But Lilov, for many years chief ideologist of the Communist Party, was dropped from the leadership in 1983. He joined it again only after Zhivkov's ouster in November. Lilov's resignation came a day after Premier Andrei Lukanov named four possible candidates to replace him. In heated debate at the congress, heads of four reform factions called for a new, younger leadership. The vote could come late today or Tuesday. Dragan Draganov, a leader of the Radical Change faction, summed up the sentiment of the progressives in a briefing with reporters: ``If no radical changes are made, there will be a gradual disintegration of the party.'' The other candidates for party leader named by the premier are Alexander Tomov, Petar Emil Mitev, and Asen Zhablensky. All are considered to be reformers. Lukanov, the premier, told the congress it should adopt decisive changes. ``The supporters of the party expect a new face, and it would be fatal if we did not accede to this demand,'' he said. Lukanov, who is also a member of the party's top-level presidium, is by far the most popular political leader in Bulgaria. The country's chief of state is President Zhelyu Zhelev, the former leader of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces. In his remarks to the party congress, Mitev, a university professor and sociologist, said ``a main reason for the situation in which the party finds itself now is a lack of political initiative after the elections.'' In Bulgaria's free elections in June, the former Communists won an absolute majority of 211 of the 400 seats in Parliament. ``There will be no diesel, no coal ... there won't even be enough bread in several months,'' Mitev warned.

DOC.HEAD: Church Installs Famed Artist's `Crowning' Work
DOC.TEXT: A huge mosaic of iridescent Tiffany glass worth millions of dollars and considered by the late American artist to be his crowning achievement will be featured in a new church here. Lake Merritt United Methodist Church is constructing its new building around the glittering mosaic, valued in the millions of dollars but donated by another church. The mosaic consists of three 8-by-17-foot panels in the Art Nouveau style, in which Louis Comfort Tiffany crafted his renowned lamp shades and stained-glass windows. Entitled ``Te Deum Laudamus,'' the work depicts crowds adoring Jesus Christ shining above them on a throne. Before he died in 1933, Tiffany was quoted as saying the panels he created 10 years earlier were his ``crowning achievement,'' and critics have hailed the mosaic as his masterpiece. ``(It's) an important art addition to the Bay area,'' said Don Stover, curator of the M.H. de Young Museum in San Francisco. Stover, who arranged an 1981 exhibit of Tiffany's work, said the mosaic was probably the only one by the artist in Northern California. ``I think it's a real coup for Oakland,'' said the Rev. Donald Kuhn, pastor of the Lake Merritt church. His congregation was given the work by the First United Methodist Church in Los Angeles. The three one-ton panels were made for the Los Angeles church by Tiffany Studios of New York in 1923 at a cost of $130,000. They dominated First United's choir loft until 1983, when shrinking membership forced the church's board to sell the building. The board kept the panels in storage until this year, when it decided to give them to Lake Merritt. Selling them was never considered. ``We preferred they go into another church. ... It's a way of preserving them, and we're hoping this way others will be blessed by them, said Grace Keehler, 88, a First United board member who belonged to the church when the panels were installed. The mosaic's worldly value is unknown, but Kuhn guesses it at ``millions of dollars.'' A single Tiffany lamp shade sold for for $550,000 last year, said Patrick Meehan, an executive with Christie's Fine Art Auctioneers in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Bombs Found Atop Korean Markets
DOC.TEXT: Nineteen molotov cocktails were found on the rooftop of one of two Korean-owned grocery stores that have been the target of an eight-month black-led boycott, police said. The crude hand grenades, bottles filled with flammable liquid, were found at 8 p.m. Saturday by police officers patrolling the Red Apple building in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, Sgt. Tina Mohrmann, a police spokeswoman, said Sunday. When asked if the bottles posed any immediate threat, Mohrmann said, ``I believe they would have to be lit. They were just there on the roof.'' They were removed by the bomb squad. About 50 protesters held a demonstration in front of the stores Saturday. Authorities said protesters had been gone from the area for 45 minutes when the devices were discovered. The boycott began after a black woman was allegedly assaulted by a Korean employee inside the Red Apple. The protest has nearly put the Red Apple and Church Fruits, across the street, out of business. On Friday, Mayor David Dinkins bought some fruits and vegetables at the stores and the owners said business picked up over the weekend. Last week, a detail of 400 officers was assigned to the stores after an appeals court ruled that police had to enforce a prior court order to keep protesters 50 feet from the groceries.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Declares Kuwaiti Currency Invalid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to move up that Iraqi currency not convertible. Pick up Pick up 4th graf pvs, `Iraq has...' SUBS final graf to conform. Fixes overline.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today declared the Kuwaiti currency, the dinar, invalid and withdrawn from circulation. It said it would reimburse holders of the currency with Iraqi dinars. Iraq will reimburse those who possess Kuwaiti dinars with the Iraqi currency on a one-for-one basis, the official Iraqi News Agency said. The Iraqi currency is not convertible on international markets. The exchange of currency will be carried out until Oct. 6, after which the Kuwaiti dinar will be considered illegal tender, the Iraqi agency quoted the government's Economics Committee as saying. Iraq has methodically dismantled Kuwaiti institutions following its Aug. 2. seizure and subsequent annexation of the neighboring oil-rich emirate. Baghdad authorities have officially disbanded Kuwait's government, military, foreign embassies and national airline. They refer to Kuwait as Iraq's 19th province, but the United Nations recognizes Kuwait's deposed al-Sabah family as the country's rulers. The al-Sabahs have set up a government-in-exile in Saudi Arabia and still control billions of dollars in assets worldwide. The Iraqi dinar's official value remains the same, but its value for those who use it on the black market is about a tenth of the official rate. Iraq punishes currency smugglers with death. The fall of Kuwait made instant paupers out of tens of thousands of people with assets in Kuwait or Kuwaiti currency. Kuwait's dinar is no longer convertible outside Iraq and Kuwait, except in certain very limited circumstances. Kuwaitis stranded in London, for example, can go to the National Bank of Kuwait or United Bank of Kuwait and receive pounds if they have dinar accounts there and can prove a desperate need. Before Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ordered his army into Kuwait, one Iraqi dinar was worth $3.22 at the official rate, and one Kuwaiti dinar traded at $3.45.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Formally Withdraws From Warsaw Pact
DOC.TEXT: East Germany, once the front-line state in the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, formally withdrew from the alliance today as it prepared for unity with West Germany and membership in NATO. With 10 days remaining before the merger, a protocol on the pullout of East German troops from the Warsaw Pact was signed in East Berlin by Defense Minister Rainer Eppelmann and the Warsaw Pact commander-in-chief, Soviet Gen. Piotr Lushev, the official news agency ADN said. The two Germanys will unite Oct. 3 and the new country will be a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The Soviet Union lifted its objections to NATO membership for a united Germany in July, clearing a major obstacle to unification. East Germany and seven other Soviet-bloc nations founded the Warsaw Pact in May 1955 to counter NATO. But the alliance has crumbled with the fall of the Berlin Wall and revolutions that swept away Communist governments throughout Eastern Europe. East Germany was the Soviet Union's most important ally in the Warsaw Pact, and about 360,000 Soviet troops were stationed in East Germany. The Soviet troops will withdraw over the next four years. Top Soviet strategists have said Moscow would like the Warsaw Pact to evolve into a political alliance. Discord within the alliance has been increasing as its members seek to forge their own defense policies. Albania left the alliance after the 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia, led by Moscow to halt the ``Prague Spring'' reforms. East German troops took part in the invasion of Czechoslovakia. The East German parliament apologized to the Czechoslovak people after the fall of East Germany's Communist government last fall.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Killed While Playing is Third Shot in Three Days
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old girl was killed as she played in the courtyard of a housing project, the third child to be hit by random gunfire in the city in three days. Mayor David Dinkins said he was ``grief-stricken and outraged'' by the death of Laykama Taylor, and he called for a renewed commitment to gun control. Laykama, who had just started junior high school, was shot in the back Sunday afternoon near her apartment in Brooklyn. A 15-year-old girl was hit by a stray ullet and wounded in Brooklyn earlier Sunday and a 12-year-old girl was shot in the chest on Friday while playing in a Harlem playground. The 15-year-old, Salima Brown, said that shooting at people is ``how they have fun'' in her neighborhood, Bedford-Stuyvesant. ``Usually they just shoot to make you run and they start laughing,'' Ms. Brown told the Daily News. She was shot in the left thigh while walking with her boyfriend. The Rev. Jesse Jackson visited the 12-year-old girl, Terez Williams, at Harlem Hospital on Sunday. Jackson had just come from delivering a sermon at Riverside Church in Manhattan. He told reporters that the people of the city - and not the mayor - are to blame for violent crime. ``The people must make a judgment to stop killing each other, to stop selling and taking dope,'' Jackson said. ``All the mayor can do is make moral appeals and make available as much security as the budget allows.'' Seven children have been shot and killed by random bullets between Jan. 1 and Aug. 30, according to Sgt. Tina Mohrmann, a police spokeswoman.

DOC.HEAD: Stunt Plot Dies At Air Show
DOC.TEXT: A veteran stunt pilot died when his plane crashed during a corkscrew turn in front of more than 15,000 people at an air show. Jack Buford Poage, 62, was pronounced dead at a nearby hospital after Sunday's accident in this Baltimore suburb. Poage had been a co-manager of the Carroll County Airport northwest of Baltimore. Poage, a veteran stunt flier, was participating in an air show at the Martin State Airport that drew an estimated 15,000 to 20,000 people. He had been expected to take his single-engine biplane through three corkscrew turns during a nosedive from about 1,500 feet. For an unknown reason, Poage added a fourth turn to the maneuver. The plane belly-landed in a grassy section of the airport next to the main runway. ``About another 20 or 30 feet of altitude, and he would have been okay,'' said Bob Cadwalader, an airline transport pilot from Baltimore who witnessed the accident. Carol Riley, a spokeswoman for the airport, said the accident forced officials to cancel the remaining 11 acts of the air show. Chuck Jackson, a state police spokesman, said that state police, the Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board were trying to determine the cause of the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Sources: Expelled Diplomats Suspected Of Oil Company Break-in
DOC.TEXT: A break-in at Saudi Arabia's biggest oil company two weeks ago is believed to be part of an alleged effort by Jordanian and Yemeni diplomats to gather information about strategic Saudi installations for Iraq, diplomatic sources said today. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the break-in was one of numerous suspicious activities that led the Saudi government to demand Saturday that Iraq, Jordan and Yemen recall most of their envoys to Riyadh. Officials at the oil company, Saudi Aramco, confirmed that two weeks ago there was an incident in which a fence surrounding oil tanks was cut. Aramco officials refused to immediately provide any further details. The diplomatic sources said the perpetrators were spotted by a security sentry after cutting through an outside fence and did not get through an additional inside barrier. ``They were spotted and they ran away,'' said one of the sources. A diplomatic source said the incident coincided with a period in which Yemeni and Jordanian diplomats were monitored traveling in the Eastern Province area that is home to Aramco and most of the troops deployed here to defend Saudi Arabia. Another source said several Yemenis with diplomatic privileges were stopped in the area and questioned by local authorities several days after the fence was cut. The source refused to discuss this aspect further. The sources said they were reluctant to discuss the Aramco incident because they did not want to raise fears among the company's expatriate workers. Most workers sent their families home after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait several weeks ago. One of the sources, who provided a detailed briefing on the alleged suspicious activities of the Jordanian and Yemeni officials, said Saudi intelligence officials placed the diplomats under surveillance immediately after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion. ``The movements of the Iraqi diplomats were immediately restricted so it was obvious they would need help if they wanted to egange in espionage,'' this source said. ``The Jordanians and Yemenis were observed taking long drives to areas in which they had no business,'' including the Eastern Province, the center of the kingdom's oil economy. The source said Saudi officials also monitored a series of meetings between the Jordanian, Yemeni and Iraqi diplomatic officials. Another diplomatic source said Saudi military officials had told him that Jordanian and Yemeni diplomatic aides were monitored taking photographs of Saudi military, government and economic installations, including oil refineries and military bases where American troops are based. ``It appeared to the military to be reconnaissance,'' the source said. In announcing the expulsions late Saturday, the Saudi Ministry of Foreign Affairs said only that the Jordanian, Iraqi and Yemeni diplomats were being asked to leave the country because they ``engaged in activities jeopardizing the peace and security of the kingdom. These activities do not conform with diplomatic rules and regulations.'' The Foreign Ministry statements said the Saudi government complained to the three governments about ``the blatant and flagrant infringements'' but that the suspicious activities continued. The Saudis then demanded that the governments sharply reduce the number of diplomats in Saudi Arabia. Diplomatic sources said 56 Yemenis, 10 Jordanians and 14 Iraqis were covered by the expulsion order.

DOC.HEAD: Blind Man Hiking the Appalachian Trail Treks Toward Maine
Laserphoto CR2
DOC.TEXT: Determined to hike the 2,100-mile Appalachian Trail despite his blindness, Bill Irwin has replaced his lust for wine and women with a devotion to God that guides his every, deliberate step. He has come almost 1,800 miles since leaving Georgia six months ago with his guide dog Orient. Irwin has raversed mountaintops and braved blizzards, craved cheeseburgers and greasy french fries, broken a rib and fallen an estimated 3,000 times. His destination is Mount Katahdin, Maine, more than 300 miles away. If he gets there, Irwin will be the first blind man known to hike the entire Appalachian Trail. In the mountains of New Hampshire, Irwin talked about the days of wine, women and song, when he was an alcoholic, womanizer and smoked five packs of cigarettes a day. ``I was a jet-setter, playboy - the only woman I liked better than my wife was your wife,'' he joked. The Bible replaced booze four years ago, when he didn't think he could sink any lower, he said. Alone and with a six-mile hike and a crash course on survival as training, Irwin began his quest. ``We just set out to come to Maine,'' Irwin said in his Burlington, N.C., drawl. He wandered the Georgia wilderness for four days, not sure if he was lost. ``Starting out on Springer Mountain all alone in the middle of the worst flood in the history of Georgia ... not even knowing how I was going to get down the trail,'' was the scariest portion of the trip, he said. Irwin wears pads to protect his knees from the 15 falls he said he takes daily. But Irwin said he has become proficient at staying on the trail, and knows when Orient has strayed. ``I can tell by the way he turns his head that we are off the trail. Because when he's not certain, he is sniffing the ground and walking with hesitancy,'' he said. Irwin, 50, headed for Mount Washington on Sunday after a day of shopping in Conway. Battered by treacherous hiking in New Hampshire, where the terrain is rougher, Irwin's pace has slowed from 15 miles per day to about six. Though he can't see the magnificent vistas, the trailside sunsets or other views that sighted people experience, Irwin said he finds solace in the silence, beauty in the odors and sensations of nature, and tries to construct images of the landscape. When others are around, he asks them to describe the scene. ``I still rely on visual imagery more than anything else,'' Irwin said. It wasn't always so for this broad-shouldered, lumbering man with scruffy blonde hair. Irwin had normal vision until the age of 28, when he was struck with chorio retinitis, a disease that destroys the retina. Though he has been chased by the media and portrayed in several tabloid magazines - one which had him clutching a sapling, dangling above a gorge - Irwin said he never meant to put himself in the spotlight. ``I'm no great example of anything,'' he said. ``Any blind person that is capable could do the same thing if they wanted to go through the same difficulty.'' The stories and faces will remain long after he finishes the trip and tries to parlay his experience into a business that combines hiking and counseling, Irwin said. Irwin said he won't forget ``The Irish Goat,'' an untidy, crusty hiker who woke everyone one night with his screams. A mouse had perched on the old man's beard and was eating remnants from that evening's meal, Irwin said, bursting into laughter. In New York, the mosquitoes were so bad one day that Irwin tied a bandana over his face. A woman, startled at the sight of a man hiking with his face and eyes covered, asked him if he was crazy, Irwin said. ``Just taking this seeing-eye dog for a training run,'' Irwin replied.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Jolts Iranian City
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake measuring 5 on the open-ended Richter scale jolted the city of Ardebil in Iran's East Azerbaijan province today, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The temblor terrified residents of this northwestern city, who ran out of their homes, said the agency, monitored in Nicosia. There were no immediate reports of loss of life or property, IRNA said, but an earthquake of that intensity can cause considerable damage, especially in populated areas. The quake struck at 10:06 a.m. (2:36 a.m. EDT), IRNA said.

DOC.HEAD: Another Student Burns Self To Protest Caste-Based Quotas
DOC.TEXT: Another college student set himself on fire today in the latest of a series of increasingly violent protests against a plan to give more government jobs to members of lower castes. Earlier today, police used tear gas to disperse a mob near Parliament House, and the police headquarters in the capital was besieged for three hours by angry students. The upper-caste students say reserving desirable government jobs for members of lower castes amounts to reverse discrimination; the government says the downtrodden deserve more opportunities. Witnesses said the 22-year-old student doused himself with gasoline in the capital's busiest intersection and then set himself ablaze. He was badly burned, and a doctor said he was unlikely to live through the night. A report said two other people set themselves on fire in Jaiphur, 180 miles southwest of New Delhi. United News of India said both were being treated for third-degree burns. Today's suicide attempt in the capital took place at an intersection on New Delhi's busy Ring Road. Since Thursday, it has been the site of a protest by hundreds of students. The other demonstrators said they did not know of the student's plans to set himself on fire. ``We were sitting under the tent when we saw a ball of black smoke ... and caught the stench of burning flesh,'' said Kamal Kishore Sharma, who rushed to the aid of the burned student, identified as Singh Chauhan. More than a dozen other students have set themselves on fire in protests, and two suffered serious burns and are in critical condition. During the weekend, a 16-year-old schoolboy killed himself by swallowing insecticide. Hundreds of thousands of students have turned out for demonstrations, and at least 25 students have been killed in street battles with police since the new policy was announced Aug. 7. No political party has supported the students' position, and the army has been sent in to maintain law and order in four cities. Schools and colleges have been closed in many towns. The policy reserves 27 percent of government jobs for people from low castes, who suffered for centuries under India's strict social hierarchy. Another 22.5 percent were previously kept aside for the most backward castes and native tribes. Singh set a further quota of 5 to 10 percent of jobs for poor people irrespective of caste, leaving about 40 percent of the 18 million white-collar government jobs available on merit alone. Hindus, who make up 82 percent of the popluation, are divided into four castes and hundreds of sub-castes. Discrimination on the basis of caste is illegal, but in practice the system permeates much of Indian life, especially in the rural areas.

DOC.HEAD: Mormon President Undergoes Second Operation
LEADS with 2 grafs to ADD date of surgery, Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `On Wednesday ...'
DOC.TEXT: Mormon Church President Ezra Taft Benson was reported in critical condition today after undergoing surgery for the second time in five days to remove excess blood from the brain. The 91-year-old church leader was recovering at LDS Hospital after the Sunday afternoon surgery. On Wednesday, a neurosurgeon removed two blood clots from Benson's brain. Church spokesman Don LeFevre said doctors drained more blood on Sunday. Benson was hospitalized Tuesday after complaining of severe headaches and difficulty swallowing. Benson was agriculture secretary under President Eisenhower. In 1985, he assumed the presidency of the 7.5-million Mormon Church, or The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Because of his frail condition, he has attended but not addressed recent church conferences.

DOC.HEAD: Student Arrested after Burning Israeli Flag To Protest U.S. in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: A student who tried to form a campus chapter of a white supremacists group at his college has been arrested after illegally burning an Israeli flag, police say. Matt Hale, 19, a sophomore at Bradley University in Peoria, and Steven Thornhill, both members of the American White Supremacist Party, were arrested Sunday after they burned the flag. They called it a demonstration against Jewish people and the U.S. military buildup in the Middle East. Hale and Thornhill, both of East Peoria, were charged with violating a city ordinance against public bonfires on a sidewalk and released on $50 bond each. They were scheduled to appear in Tazewell County Circuit Court on Oct. 18. The two men and four other members of the supremacists group went to Pekin to burn the flag after they were threatened with arrest and a $500 fine in nearby Peoria if they burned the blue and white flag there. ``I would have expected this if we had done it in Peoria, but Matt was under the impression it was legal in Pekin,'' said Champaign-area farmer John McLaughlin, a member of the supremacists group.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
IMF Approves Effort to Help Countries Hurt by Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: By MARTIN CRUTSINGER=

The International Monetary Fund gave approval today to an accelerated effort to supply billions of dollars to help countries hurt by the Persian Gulf crisis. The approval by the IMF's policy-making interim committee represented a victory for the Bush administration, which is counting on both the IMF and its sister lending agency, the World Bank, to help in the international effort to isolate Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. In a final communique, the IMF interim committee directed the staff of the international lending agency to ``respond on an expedited basis to present difficulties.'' The communique provided no specifics on how much money would be forthcoming, but U.S. officials have discussed that three countries alone - Egypt, Jordan and Turkey - would need between $13 billion and $16 billion in economic assistance through the end of next year. Canadian Finance Minister Michael Wilson said the lack of specifics did not indicate dissension on the part of the 22 finance ministers on the interim committee, but rather a desire to leave as much flexibility as possible for the IMF to channel aid to countries. ``We recognized the urgency of the needs of the people who are affected,'' Wilson said. ``The urgency is stated, the framework is provided and now it is up to the IMF management to respond.'' MORE

DOC.HEAD: Navy Wants Tuition Repaid by Homosexual Midshipman
DOC.TEXT: A 1987 Naval Academy graduate who says he was forced to quit the Navy because of his homosexuality is refusing demands that he pay for his education. The Navy wants Orlando Gotay to pay $22,949 in tuition because he resigned from the military before completing the five years of service academy graduates must perform. Gotay, who now lives in San Francisco, said he won't pay because officers pressured him to get out early. The American Civil Liberties Union has agreed to represent Gotay in court if the Pentagon pushes the matter. ``First they force me out, end my career as a naval officer, and then they tell me I have to pay them for doing this to me,'' Gotay told The (Annapolis) Capital. A Navy spokeswoman said each midshipman signs a contract promising to repay tuition if they voluntarily resign before finishing the 5-year service obligation. Lt. Beci Brenton said the Navy has sent Gotay three letters asking him to begin payments. Because he has not replied, the account has been turned over to the U.S. Justice Department for collection. In May, the Navy decided to let two gay ROTC cadets keep scholarships after they were discharged from the training corps because of their sexuality. Gotay and his lawyers said they knew of no precedent at the Naval Academy. The Navy said Gotay's case is not the first of its kind. Gotay, 26, was serving as a machinery officer aboard the USS Belknap, flagship of the 6th Fleet, when he learned in June 1989 that he was under investigation for homosexuality. The inquiry did not prove any sexual misconduct, although Gotay admits now that he is gay. The U.S. armed forces prohibit homosexuals from military service. A month later, Gotay said, he was charged with fraternization, or social contact, with enlisted personnel. His commanding officer dismissed the charge, however, and issued him a mild reprimand. But Gotay said word spread about his sexual preference, making life aboard the guided missile cruiser a nightmare. ``What I went through, the mental abuse and the psychological strain, was far worse than even plebe summer,'' Gotay said, referring to the strenuous training that academy inductees receive their first summer in Annapolis. In November, Gotay got a letter from the chief of naval operations informing him that administrative hearings on alleged misconduct were being prepared against him, and that he could either stand trial or resign. He resigned. Last March, Gotay was given an honorable discharge. Because of this voluntary resignation, the Navy ordered Gotay about a week after his discharge to pay the tuition. Gotay said he was not aware of his own homosexuality until his final year at Annapolis. He was aware of the military policy toward homosexuals and kept his preferences to himself, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Tank Cars Derail Near Downtown
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to identify chemical leaking, other cargo, warehouse closed, highway reopened; CORRECTS Johnn to John; ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A freight train derailed near the city's downtown today, forcing authorities to close a major highway during morning rush hour because of a potential chemical leak. Five tanker cars and three box cars of the CSX train derailed. One tanker leaked liquid sodium hydroxide, a caustic chemical, said fire Battalion Chief Mark Devine. One of several warehouses in the area, Ohio Periodical Distributors, closed for the day as a precaution. A two-mile stretch of Ohio 315, a major north-south artery that dissects the city just west of downtown, was closed after the derailment about 4:30 a.m. but was reopened about 9 a.m. Other streets also were closed as a precaution. Devine said two of the derailed tankers contained chlorine gas, but they did not leak. One derailed box car contained non-toxic plastic beads, used in injection molds. Authorities did not immediately know what the other derailed box cars and tankers were carrying. They also did not know the train's origin or destination. Franklin County Emergency Management Services spokesman John Ross said other cars on the train carried isopentane and ammonium nitrate.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Overrules Acquittal of Settlement Leader, Raps Lower Court
DOC.TEXT: In a harshly worded ruling, a court has overturned the acquittal of a Jewish settlement leader and convicted him of assaulting an Arab family, the Justice Ministry said today. The ministry said the three-judge District Court found Rabbi Moshe Levinger guilty of assault, trespass and insulting a soldier in the occupied West Bank town of Hebron in 1988. Jerusalem Magistrate Yoel Tsur acquitted Levinger and the state prosecution appealed. According to the charge sheet, Levinger entered the home of the Samooch family house in Hebron after his daughter claimed one of their children had insulted her. Levinger was charged with assaulting Mrs. Samooch and attempting to assault their 7-year-old daughter. He also disobeyed a soldier's orders to leave the house, shouting at him, ``you contaminate Israel, PLO agent.'' The Jerusalem District Court ruled Sunday that in acquitting Levinger, Tsur ``failed to see the forest for the trees.'' It ordered a magistrate's court to sentence Levinger, saying the acquittal was ``illogical.'' A Justice Ministry statement called the ruling ``one of the rare instances in which the court of appeals intervened in factual evidence and in determining the credibility of witnesses.'' Levinger founded Hebron's Jewish community after Israel captured the town from Jordan in 1967. In August he completed a five-month jail term for fatally shooting a Palestinian merchant in Hebron in 1988. He plea-bargained a manslaughter charge down to death by negligence, claiming he fired in self-defense against Arab stone-throwers.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Campaigns for GOP Mayoral Candidate
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs graf 2, It is, to include that Turner is Republican candidate.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today urged District of Columbia voters to support former police chief Maurice Turner for mayor, saying Turner ``is dead set at getting the deadwood out of city government.'' ``It is time for a change,'' Bush said at at $250-per-plate breakfast fund-raiser for Turner, the Republican mayoral candidate. ``It is time to put Chief Turner in charge of the entire city.'' The president also praised Turner for his 32-year police career and service to the nation's capital. ``He's got a strong message for the criminals who create a climate of fear and the drug dealers who prey on our children - `You can run, but you can't hide,''' Bush said. ``Help Maurice Turner turn this city around. No one is more dead set at getting the deadwood out of city government.'' Turner thanked Bush for his support, and predicted that he will defeat the heavily-favored Democratic nominee, Sharon Pratt Dixon. The two are vying for the seat held by Marion Barry, who was recently convicted on one misdemeanor count of possession of cocaine and did not seek re-election. ``I did not enter this race merely to make a good showing,'' Turner said. ``On Nov. 6, I will be the next mayor.'' Republicans in the nation's capital believe that Turner's popularity provides their best chance ever to win the mayor's chair in this heavily Democratic city. Many Republican party officials believe that Turner, who is black, can help the GOP attract minorities. When Turner, a lifelong Democrat, switched parties last year, the event was publicized in an Oval Office photo opportunity with Bush. And when Turner announced he would run for mayor, he did so with pledges of fund-raising and strategy help from the GOP. But Turner differs with the president on local and national issues - Bush is against statehood for the nation's capital, while Turner advocates it. The former law enforcement official also favors abortion rights. Turner faces an uphill battle to defeat Dixon, the upset winner in the Democratic mayoral primary. Dixon, who has never held elective office, defeated several veteran city council members Sept. 11 by pledging to clean up local government following Barry's drug and perjury trial. She has concentrated on portraying Turner as a member of Barry's administration, and has sought to blame him for the heavy increase in drug-related crime that occurred while he was police chief. But the crucial factor in the race may be voter registration - Democrats outnumber Republicans by a 9-1 margin in the district.

DOC.HEAD: Obscenity Trial Opening Today
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Equal numbers of police and demonstrators gathered outside a courthouse today at the opening of the obscenity trial of an art gallery and its director for showing Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs. Jury selection was scheduled to get under way this morning in the trial of the Contemporary Arts Center and Dennis Barrie. The case has become a rallying point for artists, First Amendment activists and those who believe the indictments are part of a wider effort to intimidate homosexuals. ``We think the prosecution is motivated by homophobia,'' said Scott MacLarty, spokesman for the Gay-Lesbian March Activists. ``We think it is motivated by hatred for artists.'' MacLarty was among 50 people who gathered outside the Hamilton County Courthouse to demonstrate against prosecution of the gallery. About the same number of police patrolled on foot, on horseback and on motorcycles. ``In Cincinnati, artists risk criminal prosecution. If they succeed here, they will spread their inquisition elsewhere,'' MacLarty said earlier. But Monty Lobb Jr., president of Citizens Concerned for Community Values, an anti-obscenity activist group in Cincinnati, said the Mapplethorpe prosecution is necessary in order to safeguard the community's moral standards. ``People should understand Cincinnati. The material that's been indicted and is before the court now, there's nothing like that available in Cincinnati. You don't have it in videotapes, you don't have it in magazines, books - nothing here in Cincinnati,'' Lobb said in an earlier interview. ``To say nothing about it would be a form of acceptance. We don't want that. The people don't want that.'' The seven-week exhibition of photos by Mapplethorpe, who died of AIDS in 1989, drew a record crowd of more than 80,000 to the gallery last spring. But a grand jury indicted Barrie and the gallery, concluding that seven of the 175 photos violated community standards. One photo shows a man urinating into another man's mouth. Others show oral sex and anal penetration with objects. Barrie, 43, and the gallery are charged with pandering obscenity and with using children in nudity-related material. The second charge stems from two photos, one of a boy and one of a girl, their genitals exposed. If convicted, Barrie could get up to six months in jail and a $1,000 fine on each count. The gallery could be fined $5,000 on each count. Municipal Judge David Albanese earlier ruled each photo can be considered separately. He rejected defense arguments that the entire exhibit be considered as a whole, including Mapplethorpe's portraits and floral studies. Defense lawyers have argued that the gallery is a museum and is thus protected from obscenity laws. But Albanese said the Contemporary Arts Center does not fit the definition of a museum, since it has no permanent collection. The exhibit was canceled at the Corcoran Art Gallery in Washington last year because of a furor over government funding of art deemed obscene. The National Endowment for the Arts has since adopted a policy requiring grant applicants to certify their awards will not be used for work that might be deemed obscene. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., had pressed for the policy. The Mapplethorpe exhibit has appeared in several U.S. cities without incident. It is on display now at the Institute for Contemporary Art in Boston. Barrie, who has been director of the Contemporary Arts Center since 1983 and holds a doctorate in American cultural art from Wayne State University, has said the indictments reflect the thinking of a small group of conservatives. ``I think these are all attempts to limit the First Amendment. It scares some of these groups who want only one point of view - their point of view,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Depression Adrift in Mid-Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: The 12th tropical depression of the Atlantic hurricane season lost speed overnight and was drifting on a northwesterly course today with no immediate threat to land, forecasters said. At 6 a.m., tropical depression No. 12 was centered about 700 miles west-northwest of the Cape Verde Islands off West Africa, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. The system was drifting to the north-northwest near 3 mph with a top sustained wind speed of 35 mph. It was expected to pick up some forward speed by Tuesday morning, but little change was expected in its top sustained wind speed during that time, the center reported. Sunday evening, the season's 11th tropical depression dissipated in the mid-Atlantic, losing its center at about 700 miles east-northeast of the Leeward Islands. Tropical depressions are redesignated tropical storms if their maximum sustained wind speed tops 39 mph. Storms become hurricanes if wind speed reaches 74 mph. The Atlantic hurricane season lasts from June 1 to Nov. 30. Storms are normally most active in September.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Takes Iraqi Threat ``Seriously and Gravely''
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister David Levy said today Israel is taking the Iraqi military threat seriously and ``will do what we have to do'' if attacked. Levy's comments came a day after Iraq named Israel as a possible target it Baghdad continues to be ``strangled'' by sanctions. It said Israel would be be included ``in all actions that affect the owners of the homeland in which the forces of evil and occupation have settled.'' Levy, who is visiting New York, told Israel radio his government ``is taking these threats seriously and gravely ... and if Israel is endangered or, God forbid, attacked, we will do what we have to do.'' In Jerusalem, the Foreign Ministry issued a statement today warning that Israel would ``respond appropriately'' to an Iraqi attack. The statement, read to reporters by spokesman Moshe Raviv, described Iraq's threats as a sign of ``isolation and weakness'' and said Saddam Hussein had underestimated the West's will to respond to his invasion of Kuwait. ``Likewise, he may underestimate the capacity and resolve of Israel,'' Raviv said. ``Israel has proved in the past that it knows how to defend itself and, if attacked, it will not hesitate to respond appropriately.'' The foreign minister said Israel would give Iraq no pretext for an attack, but said the multinational buildup in the Persian Gulf ``is liable to accelerate the carrying out of the threat against Israel and we need to take this into account.'' Meanwhile, the Israeli newspaper Yediot Ahronot's military correspondent, citing an assessment by senior Israeli officials, said war in the region ``is inevitable, and everything is now a matter of time and the Americans choosing suitable targets.'' The officials were not identified.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Marcos Will Testify With Immunity
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos will testify with immunity this week in a federal investigation of allegations that Westinghouse Electric Corp. paid a $17.3 million bribe to the Philippines government, her lawyer said. Attorney James Linn said Mrs. Marcos was assured of immunity by Theodore Greenberg, deputy chief of the U.S. Justice Department's fraud division. Both Greenberg and Westinghouse spokesman Paul Jones declined to comment on the grand jury proceedings. The panel is scheduled to question Mrs. Marcos on Tuesday. It is investigating allegations that Westinghouse bribed the Philippines government to obtain a contract to build a nuclear power plant when Mrs. Marcos' late husband, Ferdinand, was president. Last week, Westinghouse said it paid $17 million in commissions during 10 years to sales representatives who handled the reactor contract. Two previous federal investigations of the payments found no evidence of wrongdoing, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported. Mrs. Marcos has been subpoenaed to bring all documents related to payments made to Westinghouse and Burns & Roe Enterprises Inc. of Oradell, N.J. Westinghouse built the $2.3 billion power plant about 60 miles west of Manila in the early 1980s. Burns & Roe was a subcontractor. The plant has never been operated. Mrs. Marcos also was asked to bring records the government kept on Herminio Disini, who is charged with receiving the bribe. Disini was married to a cousin of Mrs. Marcos. Mrs. Marcos has records neither about the payment nor Disini, Linn said.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Knocks Out Power in Central Rome
DOC.TEXT: A fire in an underground power station knocked out electricity in a wide area of central Rome today, darkening offices and apartments and snarling traffic. Power was restord in the area, extending from the Pantheon to the Colosseum, after about five hours. Extra police were called in to patrol intersections when traffic lights went out. No one was reported injured in the blaze.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Arrive In North Korea
DOC.TEXT: A group of 15 Japanese politicians arrived in North Korea today on a visit Japan hopes will help thaw icy relations between the two Asian neighbors. In a sign of a positive reception from North Korea, its official Korean Central News Agency reported the group's arrival without the usual virulent references to Japan. The delegation of legislators from Japan's governing Liberal Democratic and Socialist parties was met at Pyongyang's airport by Kim Yong Sun, secretary of the central committee of the Worker's Party of Korea, the Communist nation's ruling party, KCNA said in a report monitored in Tokyo. The delegation is led by Shin Kanemaru, one of the Japanese governing party's most influential leaders.
