Kanemaru was expected to seek the release of Japanese seamen being held in North Korea as a first step toward closer ties between the two countries, which have no formal diplomatic relations. Kanemaru also was expected to carry an apology from Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to the North Korean people for Japan's 1910-45 occupation of Korea. Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto said the mission's aim was to ``pave the way for the release of two seamen and to help open dialogue between the two countries.'' The Japanese seamen have been held in North Korea on espionage charges since November 1983. Pyongyang has pressed for the return of a North Korean defector in exchange for their release, but Japan has refused the demand. North Korea is one of the few countries with which Japan has no diplomatic relations, although only 350 miles of sea separate the two nations. Pyongyang has long maintained that South Korea, Japan and U.S. ``imperialists'' are planning an invasion. The Japan Socialist Party, along with the Japan-North Korea Parliamentarian Goodwill League, has acted as a bridge between the two countries. The mission flew directly to Pyongyang aboard a Japan Airlines chartered jet, rather than taking the usual route through Beijing. Japan ruled Korea as a colony from 1910 to the end o World War II in 1945, when the Korean peninsula was divided into the communist North and capitalist South.

DOC.HEAD: Jane's: Saddam Secrecy Undermines Iraqi Military
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein's obsession with secrecy has undermined the military strength of Iraq, but his tank and artillery forces remain formidable, military analysts said in a report today. During the eight-year war against Iran, Saddam and his high command rarely passed information to divisional commanders, said the analysis in a special issue of Jane's Soviet Intelligence Review. It said this secrecy made ``all-out attacks a virtual impossibility.'' Given Saddam's ``autocratic tightening of control since then,'' the report said, the situation is likely to have worsened. It added that although much of Iraq's military equipment is obsolete by Western and Soviet standards, the more modern weapons were ``capable of inflicting damage'' on the multinational forces that have gathered in the gulf region since Iraq seized Kuwait Aug. 2. Iraq has about 5,000 battle tanks, including about 200 British-made Chieftain and Vickers tanks seized in Kuwait, said the report. On air power, the report cited Iraq's Soviet Badger strike aircraft, with a combat range of nearly 2,000 miles, as among its most potent weapons. But the report said the Iraq air force had been used relatively little during the Iran-Iraq war and its capabilities remained uncertain.

DOC.HEAD: Israel to Demolish Palestinian Houses, Shops in Soldier's Death
DOC.TEXT: Israel will demolish houses and shops to punish the Palestinian refugee camp in the occupied Gaza Strip where an Israeli soldier was stoned to death and then burned in his car, military officers and Arab reports said today. Israel also is considering the deportation of Palestinians suspected of involvement in the killing. The soldier, Sgt. Amnon Pomeranz, 46, was stoned to death on Thursday in Gaza's El Bureij refugee camp after his car hit a donkey cart, injuring two Palestinian teen-agers. The Palestinian mob then set his car on fire with him inside. Arab reports said the army ordered at least 20 families in the camp to remove their belongings from their homes. Such orders usually precede the demolition of houses. They also said the owners of 13 shops and one gas station were ordered to vacate their premises, apparently in advance of demolition. The gas station apparently was the one from which Palestinians obtained gas-soaked rags that they threw on the soldier's car to set it on fire. Hasham Mahamid, a member of the Israeli parliament, said after a one-hour visit to the camp that he saw the owner of the gas station and at least a dozen shopkeepers removing goods from their shops. ``People told me there might be 37 houses and shops demolished and that they expected it to be soon,'' Mahamid said. Pomeranz was the 48th Israeli to die in the 34-month Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israeli soldiers and civilians have killed 730 Palestinians, and 264 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israel. The El Bureij camp, home to 20,000 Palestinians, was under curfew today for the fifth day while soldiers combed the area for suspects. Associated Press reporters were turned away from the camp by soldiers because of the curfew. Defense Minister Moshe Arens was quoted in the Hebrew daily Hadashot today as demanding the deportation of those involved in the murder ``if there is not enough evidence to bring the suspects to trial.'' The newspaper said Arens ordered the army's legal officers to check out ways to speed up the deportation process, which can take months because of appeal procedures. Defense Ministry spokesman Dan Naveh declined comment on the report, saying he could not discuss ``specific actions that are going to be taken.'' Israel has deported 61 Arabs for ``instigating and perpetrating anti-Israeli violence'' since the uprising began in December 1987. The last deportation was in August 1989.

DOC.HEAD: vietnam's Deputy Prime Minister Meets Chinese Premier
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam's deputy prime minister met today with Chinese Premier Li Peng in what appeared to be a bid to smooth over longstanding strains between the two nations. Vietnam's Communists were backed by the Chinese during the 1960s and 1970s. But when Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978 and ousted the Beijing-backed Khmer Rouge, China responded by attacking Vietnam. A brief, bloody border war was followed by a decade of verbal and occasional military sniping. However, relations have improved over the past year as the two sides have worked to resolve the fighting in Cambodia. The nationally televised evening news showed a smiling Vo Nguyen Giap shaking hands and chatting with Li. ``I'm very pleased to meet Premier Li Peng,'' Giap was quoted by the television news as saying. ``It's been more than 10 years since I've met such a high-level Chinese leader.'' Giap was in Beijing for the opening of the Asian Games. Early this month, Vietnamese Communist Party chief Nguyen Van Linh secretly visited Beijing for talks with Chinese leaders on the Cambodian conflict and Sino-Vietnamese relations. His delegation included Prime Minister Do Muoi and senior party advisor and former premier Pham Van Dong, according to Thai officials and Western diplomats. Giap conveyed greetings from top Vietnamese leaders, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. Neither news report gave details of their discussions.

DOC.HEAD: Greenpeace Activists Board Vessel
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen people arrested during a protest of a study of marine mining potential off the Oregon Coast were released from jail early today. The Coast Guard made the arrests Sunday after an activist from the environmental group Greenpeace chained herself to a crane on the research vessel Aloha, about a mile off the mouth of the Rogue River at Gold Beach. A spokesman at the Curry County jail said the 13 were released before dawn. Seven of those arrested were Greenpeace activists. Sunday's protest was led by the 181-foot Greenpeace flagship Rainbow Warrior and included about two dozen local fishing boats. Local fishermen and Greenpeace oppose the research, saying mining the sea floor would destroy fisheries. The Aloha began a two-week, government-sponsored cruise last week. The Rainbow Warrior remained anchored off Gold Beach this morning, said crew member Rien Achterman. He said the vessel's plans for today had not been announced. Greenpeace spokeswoman Cynthia Rust said she expected protests to continue even after the Rainbow Warrior leaves. ``The local fishermen are part of this protest,'' she said. ``I doubt very seriously their opposition to offshore mining will stop just because the Greenpeace boat leaves.'' Two Greenpeace activists boarded the 143-foot Aloha about noon Sunday. One, Diana Desnoyers, 30, climbed an A-frame crane at the stern of the Aloha and chained herself 15 feet above the deck. Coast Guardsmen cut her loose and arrested her about an hour later. The Coast Guard seized three Greenpeace inflatable boats and the 32-foot Top Gun, a sea urchin diving vessel based in Port Orford. The arrests and boat seizures came because the vessels violated a 500-yard, federally-ordered safety zone around the Aloha, Coast Guard Lt. Doug Stephan said. Stephan said five Coast Guard vessels and a helicopter remained in the area. ``It's apparent to us now that we're going to have to enforce that safety zone as long as the Aloha is there,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Welcomes De Klerk
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 5 grafs new with meeting underway, de Klerk quote; picks up 3rd graf pvs, Bush was; will be topped after 1:30 p.m. EDT departure
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: President Bush welcomed South African President F.W. de Klerk to the White House today in a show of political support for his efforts to guide South Africa toward a post-apartheid democratic system. ``It's marvelous being here,'' the South African leader said at the outset of one-on-one talks with Bush in the Oval Office. Both presidents, sitting in wingback chairs by the fireplace, declined to answer questions from reporters allowed to witness the opening moments. After a brief explanation from Bush on his practice of refusing to answer questions at photo opportunities, de Klerk said, ``I think I shall abide by the Oval Office rules.'' ``I'm going to do this the president's way,'' said de Klerk, smiling broadly. It was the first-ever meeting between the two leaders. After their private session, they were meeting with top aides, then repairing to the White House's residential quarters for a working luncheon. Bush was intent on paying tribute to de Klerk for the leadership he has provided in beginning to dismantle white supremacist rule in South Africa. Their discussion was partly aimed at devising ways the United States can help speed the process. No South African head of state has visited Washington since 1945. As recently as the Reagan administration, the two countries were barely on speaking terms because of the sanctions Congress imposed on South Africa in 1986. But the U.S. attitude toward South Africa changed dramatically with the liberalizing steps de Klerk has taken, including freeing African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela from prison and lifting bans on democratic political groups. Still, de Klerk's visit is less triumphal than many had hoped because of the recent upsurge in violence in South African black townships. The death toll is estimated at about 750. The violence may have contributed to the Congressional Black Caucus' decision to cancel a scheduled meeting with de Klerk. The announcement on Saturday gave no specific reason for the cancellation. Mandela has sought to hold pro-apartheid security elements of the police and military responsible for the violence, a possibility that South African officials do not dismiss. Mandela has said that Americans should demand from de Klerk an explanation for the increasing violence. The Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, a Washington-based private group, has challenged de Klerk to ensure that ``police and military assassination squads are fully exposed and completely disbanded.'' De Klerk said on his arrival Sunday he was bringing a message of hope for the future of his country and for all of southern Africa. ``We are proceeding irreversibly on the road to a new South Africa, where justice, the guarantees of constitutional democracy and the rule of law will bring lasting peace and prosperity to all our people,'' said de Klerk. He is staying in Washington until Tuesday night. An administration official who briefed reporters said de Klerk's visit is not designed to bring about an end to U.S. sanctions. South Africa has fulfilled some, but not all, of the conditions required by law for the sanctions to be lifted. De Klerk said Saturday the sanctions will not be a major focus of his visit. ``I'm not going hat in hand with the particular objective of getting sanctions lifted,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Kills 2 at State University
DOC.TEXT: A bomb being manufactured by leftist students exploded in their offices at the state university, killing two students and wounding three others, police said. The explosion occurred Sunday night in the offices of the National Union of Revolutionary Students. Police said they found a large quantity of gunpowder and other explosives in the building, which was destroyed. Maj. Gen. Ramon Mota Paulino, head of the national police, said a preliminary investigation indicated the students intended to place bombs in supermarkets and other businesses. The bombings were to coincide with the scheduled start Tuesday of a three-day strike to protest the government's economic austerity program. Under the program, the prices of many basic consumer items such as gasoline and flour rose sharply in August. There was no immediate comment from officials of the student organization.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Factory Explosion Kills Five
DOC.TEXT: A carbide oven exploded at a chemical plant in Transylvania on Monday, killing five people and injuring 10 others, state radio said. The explosion occurred in Tirnaveni, about 250 miles north of the capital. Six people were hospitalized with severe burns, two in critical condition, radio said. State radio quoted the plant's chief engineer as saying that the explosion badly damaged the building and its mechanical and electric equipment. Hot chemical material spewed around the area and prevented workers from removing the debris, it said. A second fire broke out but was extinguished. It was the third explosion at a chemical plant in the past two months. All occurred in Transylvania, a region of tense tensions between ethnic Romanians and a sizable ethnic Hungarian minority. Explosions have occurred before in Romania's huge chemical industry, but were not publicized under the late Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's regime, which was toppled last December.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Release Names of Nazi Victims
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 10th graf, The service... to explain reference to Magen David Adom
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has made available copies of documents captured at the end of World War II that contain the names of 400,000 people who died or were interned in Nazi concentration and forced labor camps. The American Red Cross said today it has opened a Holocaust and War Victims Tracing and Information Center in Baltimore to help people learn the fate of friends or relatives. The announcement said the International Red Cross had received from the Soviets copies of archival material recovered by the Soviet Army during the liberation of the camps at the end of the war. The material includes 46 books containing nearly 70,000 death certificates from the Auschwitz concentration camps. Also included are the names of 130,000 prisoners used for forced labor in various German firms, and 200,000 names of victims in other camps, including Dachau, Sachsenhausen, Gross Rosen and Buchenwald. The documents are being housed at the International Tracing Service, an agency of the International Committee of the Red Cross, in Arolsen, West Germany. There were already 13 million names on file at Arolsen. The Red Cross said the Baltimore center can help people obtain certification of incarceration, forced labor or death of family members. It also can help survivors who were interned receive compensation and may in some cases result in reunification of family members, the organization said. ``We hope that this tracing service will bring some closure to the pain felt by so many people who don't know what happened to members of their family,'' said Stephen H. Richards, executive vice president of the American Red Cross. People wishing to learn the fate of family members were urged to contact their local chapters of the American Red Cross. Local caseworkers will send the information to the center in Baltimore, where it will be translated into German and forwarded to Arolsen. ``We want people to be aware of the availability of this important new information,'' said Richards. He cautioned, however, that the tracing process is slow because of the cross-referencing needed, because of various spellings of names and because of possible inaccuracies in the records. He said people who ask for help will get interim reports as the work proceeds. The service is a collaborative effort of the Central Maryland Chapter and American Red Cross International Services, working with the International Committee of the Red Cross, other national Red Cross and Red Crescent societies, and Magen David Adom, the Israeli counterpart of the American Red Cross, the organization said. Those wishing more information were urged to contact their local Red Cross chapters or call the Red Cross toll-free hotline at 1-800-848-9277.

DOC.HEAD: Cranston Announces Opposition to Souter; Heflin Endorses Nominee
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 2 grafs to show Cranston was first senator to announce opposition to Souter. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, I will.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alan Cranston said today he will vote against the nomination of Supreme Court nominee David Souter. He was the first senator to go on record against the New Hampshire jurist, whose confirmation is widely seen as assured. Cranston complained that Souter, in three days of testimony to the Senate Judiciary Committee, refused to back abortion rights. ``I will vote `no' because Judge Souter will not reveal his views on a fundamental constitutional issue - the right of privacy,'' Cranston, of California, the assistant Democratic leader, said in a floor speech. After Cranston stated his opposition in a floor speech, Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., stood up to announce his endorsement. He said he believed the 51-year-old New Hampshire jurist possesses the ``endearing quality of being willing to listen, to be fair and impartial.'' The statements came as the Senate Judiciary Committee prepared to vote on President Bush's selection to replace retired Associate Justice William Brennan on the nation's highest court. That vote could come as early as Thursday. A vote by the full Senate is likely soon after that, perhaps in time for Souter to take his seat when the Supreme Court returns to the bench Oct. 1. Cranston had stated his intention in an interview Sunday. ``I cannot support a nominee who refuses to acknowledge that a woman's right to choose to terminate a pregnancy is a fundamental right or that the right of individuals, married or unmarried, to use contraceptives to prevent a pregnancy, is a matter of settled law,'' Cranston said. ``I cannot support a nominee who regards these issues as open questions,'' he said. ``My view of my responsibility under the Constitution to the generations of Americans who will be affected by those decisions, particularly the millions of young women whose very lives may well depend on the right to choose whether or not to carry a pregancy, compels me to vote `no' on this nomination,'' Cranston said. Souter said during his confirmation hearings that he has not made up his mind on how he would vote if he, as a justice, was asked to overturns the 1973 decision in Roe vs. Wade that legalized abortion. Heflin is one of three senators who usually hold the balance of power between the liberal and conservative wings of the Judiciary Committee. In 1987, he opposed President Reagan's nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court. While some groups have opposed Souter because he refused to discuss his views on abortion, Heflin said today he thinks it wrong to demand that nominees express their ``precise opinions'' on such issues before confirmation. After listening to Souter's testimony before the Judiciary Committee, Heflin said, he is satisfied Souter understands the importance of judicial restraint and prior court interpretations of the Bill of Rights and the due process and equal protection clauses of key constitutional amendments. ``Judge Souter will not bring a scorched-earth philosophy to the court, but he will bring a sense of historic perspective and a clear-headed approach to the analysis of legal issues,'' said Heflin, a former Alabama chief justice.

DOC.HEAD: Second-Oldest National Park Celebrates 100 Years
DOC.TEXT: Sequoia celebrates its centennial Tuesday as the second-oldest national park with its superintendent hoping the home of the world's biggest trees will be even better 100 years from now. A 13,255-foot mountain, one of thousands in the Sierra Nevada range that forms California's spine, will be named Centennial peak during a brief ceremony honoring both Sequoia and its slightly younger cousin, Kings Canyon National Park. However, most of the celebration was on Sunday when people were invited to visit the adjacent parks free and learn about their history and future. Sequoia, 150 miles northeast of Los Angeles, became a national park six days before Kings Canyon and their more celebrated neighbor 80 miles north, Yosemite. President Benjamin Harrison signed legislation on Sept. 25, 1890, making Sequoia the second national park. Yellowstone was established in 1872. At first, only 500 people a year visited the California parks because they were so remote in the days before cars. Now, more than 1.6 million people a year visit Sequoia and Kings Canyon. That has caused park officials to start reducing human impact by moving public facilities out of Sequoia's Giant Forest area, a process that will take at least until the beginning of the 21st century. ``We want to avoid designing facilities that lure people to one spot and cause a crowd,'' Superintendent J. Thomas Ritter said as he stood near the General Sherman tree, the largest living thing in the world at 272 feet tall and containing 63,664 cubic feet of lumber. The goal, he said, is to disperse people to points of interest and programs spread throughout the park. ``If we are successful today and the next 100 years, we will have overcome our biggest potential problem,'' he said. Ritter noted that the task of dispersing people is easier over the large area of Sequoia-Kings Canyon than at Yosemite, where almost all the 3 million visitors a year want to visit narrow Yosemite Valley. Visitors to Kings Canyon can travel to Grant Grove and look at the General Grant Tree, officially the Nation's Christmas Tree, or camp and hike along the John Muir Trail to high country lakes formed by melting snow. Others can head south through the tall pines and firs of Sequoia to the even taller and broader trees, many of them growing since before Jesus was born. People can take a healthy hike a few hundred feet up to Moro Rock and look over the western divide or a much longer, harder hike up Mount Whitney, at 14,495 feet above sea level the tallest mountain in the contiguous 48 states. ``The people clearly have to come on the natural terms of the park,'' Ritter said. ``But the geography is in our favor.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Release Norwegian Environmental Group's Ship
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet coast guard Monday released a Norwegian ship it had detained for a border violation during an anti-nuclear protest in the arctic, an environmental group said. Also Monday, Finland announced that it, Norway and Sweden will clean up pollution caused by nickel plants on the Soviet Kola Peninsula. The industrial plants annually emit more than 670,000 tons of sulfur dioxide, a chief cause of acid rain, and are polluting northern Europe. The Soviet coast guard seized the Norwegian ship MS Genius on Friday. It claimed the five environmentalists on board violated Soviet territory by taking test samples near a nuclear weapons test site on Novaya Zemlya island in the Soviet arctic, said Norway's Bellona environmental group. The 90-foot Genius was escorted out of a 200-mile Soviet economic zone Monday and returned to the Norwegian arctic port of Kirkenes, the group said in a statement. Activists had positioned the ship near Novaya Zemlya for more than two weeks. Bellona claims the Soviets plan to resume nuclear weapons testing on the island, last used in 1988. ``We are satisfied with having hampered the Soviet test blast,'' said Frode Haaland, of Bellona. The Soviet Embassy has said there were no immediate plans for a test. Novaya Zemlya, a primary Soviet nuclear test site from 1958 to 1963, is about 370 miles from Norwegian territory. Unconfirmed reports that testing was to resume on the island have prompted protests from Nordic governments and environmental groups. In announcing the pollution cleanup plan, Finland said it would provide funding and technology for 50 percent of the $750 million program, due to be completed in 1994. Earlier this month, the Norwegian government set aside $50 million. Sweden and possibly Germany also will participate, the Finnish government said. Finland's President Mauno Koivisto discussed the cross-border pollution with Mikhail S. Gorbachev when the Soviet president came to Helsinki Sept. 8 for a summit with President Bush. Finnish researchers have warned that the pollution is destroying Lapland, an area that stretches across northern Finland, Sweden and Norway, and is considered to be the last wilderness in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta Celebrates Olympic Victory With Ticker Tape Parade
DOC.TEXT: Olympic fever was rampant in the Georgia capital today as Atlanta staged its first ticker tape parade to celebrate its designation as host of the 1996 Summer Games. Thousands of spectators lined the parade route, pelting Mayor Maynard Jackson and other dignitaries with confetti and streamers as they rode by. ``I'm the guy who's got to clean this stuff up,'' Jackson laughed as he and his wife, Valerie, tried to brush the paper from their hair. Glo Ruiz of suburban Kennesaw brought her two children downtown 2{ hours early to get a front-row seat for the noon parade. ``I'm originally from Texas, where we know what parades are all about. This is my first parade in Atlanta, and I'm sure its going to be just as good,'' she said. ``It's the biggest thing I've ever seen in Atlanta,'' said 63-year-old Leonard Johnson Sr., a lifelong resident. Police estimated that 50,000 people had gathered for the parade by 11:30 a.m. Atlanta schools excused children from class to see it, with parental approval. Organizers used trucks to pass out 34 tons of confetti to the waiting crowd, and 100 miles of ticker tape was thrown from buildings along the route. Other dignitaries riding in the parade included Gov. Joe Frank Harris, Sen. Sam Nunn and 85-year-old Fred Alderman, Georgia's oldest Olympian.

DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand Condemns Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to ADD report that Iraq rejected a deal to allow Iraqi plane to land if Americans were freed, Mitterrand quote, details, trims. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: French President Francois Mitterrand today condemned Baghdad for its invasion of Kuwait, calling Iraq a warlike state and stressing that the sovereignty of Kuwait is not negotiable. ``How could we not be disgusted by the taking of thousands of hostages?'' he asked the General Assembly. Iraq's ambassador to the United Nations listened silently, but high-level Iraqi officials including Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz were absent. Iraq said today it had rejected a U.S. offer to allow an Iraqi plane to fly the Iraqi delegation to New York - if about 1,000 Americans held in occupied Kuwait and Iraq were allowed to leave. ``In order to prevent this anarchy and theory of might makes right, and avoid a situation in which one powerful person might be replaced by another, I can't find any other answer than the rule of law, of right,'' Mitterrand said. Speaking of Kuwait, he said: ``the sovereignty of that country is not negotiable.'' He also pointed out the danger to other Persian Gulf nations, ``these neighboring peoples, who if things get out of control, will depend on the expansionist determination of one man, on one warlike state.'' The French president expressed outrage over Iraq's raids on European diplomatic compounds in Kuwait on Sept. 14, when diplomats were detained temporarily and three Frenchmen seized. Iraq made a belated apology Sunday, saying its soldiers had made a mistake. After the raids, France immediately called for an emergency meeting of the 15-member U.N. Security Council, which unanimously denounced Iraq. But Mitterrand said that was unacceptable, and noted that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has not yet made any gesture or move to defuse the crisis. Brazil provided the first speaker at today's session - President Fernando Collor de Mello. ``The crisis that has befallen Kuwait presents an unexpected and serious threat to collective peace,'' he said. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze speaks Tuesday. Both President Bush and Aziz of Iraq are scheduled to address the 160-member assembly on Oct. 1. Aziz said Sunday, however, that his government would not participate because the United States had prevented him from flying to New York in an Iraqi Airways plane. Iraq said today it rejected a U.S. offer to allow an Iraqi plane to fly Aziz to New York if about 1,000 Americans could leave Kuwait and Iraq. The official Iraqi News Agency said the offer was made after Aziz complained to U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar that Washington refused to allow his plane to come to New York. Perez de Cuellar said Sunday that he planned talks with Aziz in the near future on Iraq's position that it will never give up Kuwait, which Saddam's forces seized on Aug. 2. The French president had been expected to express outrage over Iraq's raids on European diplomatic compounds. After the raids, France immediately called for an emergency meeting of the 15-member U.N. Security Council, which unanimously denounced Iraq. That resolution also warned Iraq that the Security Council would adopt other measures to punish Baghdad. The measures are expected to be passed at an extraordinary council meeting on Tuesday and include a proposal to impose an air embargo on Iraq, the first ever by the world body against a member. Under the sanctions, flights from Iraq and occupied Kuwait would be limited to those carrying refugees. Flights bound for Iraqi-held land would be inspected and allowed only to carry shipments of food or medicine approved by the Security Council's sanctions committee. Other countries would be required to deny Iraq-bound flights permission to refuel, land, or fly over their territory. Force would not be allowed, but planes could be ordered to land. In addition, nations breaking the air embargo would be subject to secondary sanctions. ``I think this will be a genuine turning point in human history,'' said Brian Urquhart, the former U.N. undersecretary-general in charge of peacekeeping, who retired in 1986. ``This will be the test of whether collective security is a valid response to aggression.'' Unlike the Security Council, the General Assembly has no enforcement powers. However, the assembly speeches and resolutions are a powerful expression of the will of the world community.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Cancel National Day Celebrations
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia has scrapped its annual National Day celebrations at embassies around the world to show solidarity with the people of Kuwait, the embassy announced Monday. Lavish receptions had been scheduled for Monday evening at all major Saudi embassies. The embassy here, located next to the famed Watergate office and apartment complex, made cancellation calls over the weekend to hundreds of invitees. Saudi Arabia ``has taken this step in solidarity with the brotherly state of Kuwait, due to the painful calamity it faces because of the brutal Iraqi aggression....'' The suffering inflicted by the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait affects all ``governments of the Arab and Islamic world, as well as the whole world community,'' said the Saudi statement. A multinational force including 150,000 U.S. troops has been deployed in Saudi Arabia in recent weeks to prevent an Iraqi invasion and prepare a possible attack against President Saddam Hussein. Saudi Arabia has been hosting Kuwait's ruling al-Sabah family since it fled the invading Iraqi forces. The wealthy desert kingdom has also taken in thousands of Kuwaiti refugees. The National Day reception in past years has been a lavish affair, with senior U.S. government officials, diplomats, corporation heads and socialites in attendance.

DOC.HEAD: Four Dead as Plane Crashes on Approach to Local Airport
DOC.TEXT: A private plane crashed in a field as it approached an airport through heavy fog today, killing at least four people, authorities said. ``We have four confirmed dead, but the flight plan indicated there were five aboard,'' said Fred O'Donnell, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The twin-engine Cessna Citation, en route from Van Nuys Airport, was preparing to land at San Luis Obispo Airport when it apparently clipped some trees and tumbled in a ball of flames, said police Sgt. Ron Brown. The pilot made his last standard communication with the airport tower at 7:03 a.m., and crashed three minutes later about three miles northwest of the airport, O'Donnell said. The identities of the victims were not immediately available, said San Luis Obispo County sheriff's Detective Mike Wasley.

DOC.HEAD: ABC News to Begin Pre-Dawn News Show in January
DOC.TEXT: ABC News said today it will start in January a pre-dawn newscast that will air each weekday from 1 a.m. to 6 a.m. The show will have two anchors, but they have not been chosen. The newscast, which has not been given a name, marks the second time ABC News has tried a late-night program since the establishment of ``Nightline'' as a regular series 10 years ago. The new program, in the planning stages for months, will be competing with the 24-hour Cable News Network and CBS' taped ``Nightwatch,'' which emphasizes interviews and began in 1982. ABC's show is the second network news operation scheduled to start in January. NBC also plans then to begin its 24-hour NBC News Channel, serving NBC affiliates with international, national and regional stories for use in their own local newscasts. The executive producer of ABC's new newscast will be John Armstrong, now assistant bureau chief at ABC News' Washington bureau. ABC said the new series is being started at the request of its more than 200 affiliates, who now run syndicated shows or movies, or go off in the air in the time period the new show will occupy.

DOC.HEAD: States of Confusion: Building Five New Lands From One Old Country
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `Heinrich Vogel ...' to remove extraneous words from title.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BER1
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: This is one in a series of stories about the unification of Germany.

What is now East Germany will spin aimlessly in limbo for weeks after Germany unites, then slowly emerge from the remains of the old nation as five distinct lands. But experts say it could take years of drastic reform to forge truly effective, functioning states from the political and bureaucratic rubble of the former Communist regime. Perhaps more important than the Oct. 3 date of German unification is what happens after Oct. 14, when East Germans elect the first governments of the new states their nation will become. Until those governments take office and begin operating, eastern Germany essentially will be a territory, a frontier with only inexperienced local governments chosen last May and a federal government far away in the western city of Bonn. Because of the speed of unity, much of East Germany will be wiped out politically and legally before the states are operating at an adequate level, experts say. ``As far as the (regional) legislative and executive powers are concerned, (East Germans) will live in a lawless period for perhaps a quarter of a year,'' said Klaus Kuehne, a top official for the East German Ministry for Regional and Community Relations. There will be only two or three temporary officials in the interim assigned to each state until their governments and state administrations materialize. ``Before these states are even functional in the slightest way, 1991 will have passed,'' Kuehne said. ``This doesn't even take into account the quality of government when they are in place. There is a dearth of qualified people.'' These states, cut from remnants of German principalities and Prussian provinces, will be in charge of the same things the 11 states in West Germany oversee: schools, law enforcement, some social services and transportation. They will face the monumental task of creating those entities from the centralized Communist framework that once controlled all aspects of East German society, from apartment rents to school curriculums. The first step toward decentralizing will happen Oct. 3, when more than 200,000 federal bureaucrats in East Berlin alone will be out of work, from ministers to office clerks. The states, however, are still in the early throes of the local campaigns for the Oct. 14 elections. Scores of candidates are competing for the governorships and state legislatures. The elections could be the last hurrah for the reformed Communists, who are given little chance of winning seats when a united German parliament is chosen Dec. 2, but may have a chance at regional seats on Oct. 14. The newly coalescing states also are beginning to fight over boundaries, to claim cities near the tentative borders and to debate which city should be the state capital. Heinrich Vogel, a political analyst and East German specialist with the Cologne, West Germany-based German Institute for Eastern Research and International Studies, said what is happening in the emerging states is political evolution at its most primeval. ``There are all kinds of grabbing instincts that are part of the political game,'' he said. In what is now East Germany, the sparsely populated farmland of the north will be Mecklenburg-Lower Pomerania, where the cities of Schwerin and Rostock are competing to be the state capital. The eastern-central section of the country will be Brandenburg, a former Prussian province that will surround Berlin, the capital of a united Germany that will have a separate status. The central-western section is Saxony-Anhalt, where the industrial cities of Magdeburg, Halle and Dessau are vying to be the capital. The southwest corner is Thuringia, and the region in the southeast, bordering Czechoslovakia, is Saxony. The five were German provinces given to the Soviets after World War II. The Soviet Union created the German Democratic Republic - East Germany - in 1949 and declared the provinces dissolved in 1952. The Communists created a system of districts where power emanated from the capital, East Berlin. They also created a national police force that will have to be broken up into state agencies. West German states are supplying considerable manpower and expertise to help create a federal system in the east, said Manfred Preiss, minister for regional and community relations. Because they have a virtual monopoly on administrative experience, many of the 2 million public employees in East Germany's 8.8. million workforce may move to administrations of the states, Vogel said. But Vogel said the ingrained attitudes of Communist bureaucracy will require substantial West German help. ``It's going to take quite awhile,'' he said. ``What we need is a real transfer of know-how, of federalist behavior.'' Education is another great concern. Vogel said it could take years to alter the old educational system, in which teachers were the bulwark of Communist ideology. Most teachers remain on board, along with many headmasters. The legal system will basically be scrapped, since it is radically different from the West German system. There is essentially no civil court system. ``The legal apparatus is almost nonexistent,'' Vogel said. ``Those who have been judges, they're gone. Forget about the attorneys. This is a sector that will primarily have to be filled up by the West.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Soar Over $38 Per Barrel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with later prices. No pickup. Version also moved on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices soared past $38 per barrel this morning and gasoline and home heating oil both topped $1 a gallon amid fear that war is imminent in the Persian Gulf. ``I can't believe it,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``People in the market are talking about $40 a barrel as being the next target.'' Light sweet crude was trading late this morning on the futures marketat $38.80 per barrel for November contracts, up $3.37 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil sold above the $37 mark for the first time since the crude futures began trading on the exchange in 1983, and within hours it had shot above $38 per barrel. At one point today, oil reached as high as $38.90 a barrel. At the pump, the average price of a gallon of gasoline has hit an all-time high of more than $1.38, an industry analyst said. The price has gone up from around $1.18 in late July, shortly before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, and jumped 2.91 cents in the two weeks since the previous survey, said the nationwide Lundberg Survey of 18,500 gas stations. Iraq's leaders warned over the weekend that they would launch an all-out war before allowing the U.N. trade embargo to ``strangle'' their nation. The statement was viewed as the first time that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had threatened a first strike, with Israel and Mideast oil fields mentioned as potential targets. Recent estimates have put the price of oil at $60 per barrel if a shooting war develops in the gulf. Crude's surge this morning helped pull up the prices of refined products. Home heating oil shot up 9.79 cents to $1.07 per gallon for October delivery. Unleaded gasoline rose 8.70 cents to $1.06 per gallon for October contracts. Fears of supply shortages have helped keep the products high. Natural gas also rose sharply today, with November contracts going up 7.3 cents to $1.945 per 1,000 cubic feet. Hittle said today's rise in oil prices was partly attributable to the effects of the boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. The international embargo of their crude was put in place shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, but the effects were not immediately felt because it took ships that were already loaded several weeks to arrive. ``Basically, the whole world now has gotten the last of the Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude,'' Hittle said. ``First, the Far East was affected and then Europe and now the U.S. is feeling it.'' Oil's previous high price on the Mercantile Exchange was $35.60 per barrel, which came on Friday to cap a string of records set last week. The cash price of oil has traded at $40 amid the early 1980s oil crisis that followed the Iranian invasion, but oil futures were not traded on the exchange at that time.

DOC.HEAD: Saints Are Marching in to the T-shirt Business
DOC.TEXT: It's a heavenly marketing idea. Two nuns from Miami Shores, Fla., seeing what pictures on T-shirts, posters and the like have done to raise the profile of Bart Simpson, decided to do the same with the Virgin Mary, St. Francis of Assisi and other heavenly heroes. Sister Kathy Hollywood said she and Sister Lorraine Hale of the Sisters of the Presentation of the Blessed Virgin Mary got the idea while working on doctorates on Catholic schools. ``During visits to Catholic schools, we asked the kids who the teachers told them to be like,'' she recalled. ``They said Jesus and the saints. But the kids wanted to be like Madonna.'' The nuns responded with shirts containing colorful decals of popular saints as a way to ``revitalize Catholic tradition in a contemporary way,'' said Sister Kathy. She sold some of the shirts at the Catholic Education Conference here Friday. The nuns also are working on saints' greeting cards and have developed games, quizzes and puzzles for kids. They wouldn't be unhappy if their merchandise gives animated anti-hero Bart Simpson a run for his money. ``We want to portray Catholic values,'' Sister Kathy said. ``I don't think Bart is helping us. We hope in some way to balance out Bart.''

DOC.HEAD: S&L Issue Lacks `Political Pop' With Texas Voters
With AM-Neil Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The savings and loan crisis, which has taken its biggest toll in Texas, isn't getting much mileage on the campaign trail there. The issue doesn't have much ``political pop'' in Texas, said Richard Murray, a University of Houston political scientist and pollster. ``It's been such a massive problem here, banks going under right and left, people are almost immune to the thing,'' said James Dyer, coordinator of the Texas Poll at Texas A&M's Public Policy Research Laboratory. No one mentioned the crisis as an issue during a Texas Poll of state races this summer, he said. ``The average person, especially in South Texas, does not have money invested in savings and loans or stocks and bonds,'' said Juan Hinojosa, a political scientist at the University of Texas-Pan American. ``They're barely staying alive and trying to survive. They don't see it as touching them.'' The state's gubernatorial candidates, Democrat Ann Richards and Republican Clayton Williams, both have made campaign pitches trying to link one another to the S&L crisis. And Hugh Parmer, the Democratic challenger to GOP Sen. Phil Gramm, is complaining that Gramm has incomplete campaign records and may have accepted more thrift-related donations than he reported. But such direct attacks appear to mean little to Texans. Texans less frequently than other Americans specifically point blame at President Bush, President Reagan, key congressional figures or financial managers, Murray said. Instead, he said, their tendency ``to blame it on all these folks is high.'' On Capitol Hill, in floor speeches and newsletters home, members of Congress often vent their anger over the crisis by blaming Texas. And that put-upon feeling may be turning many Texans off the issue, analysts say. Layne Hoppe, a political scientist at Texas Lutheran College, suggested Texans feel a collective embarrassment about the failures of thrifts and banks. ``If there were a reaction against it here, it would be, in a way, a reaction against ourselves, insofar as there's a Texas identity,'' he said. Texans are less likely than people in other states to get angry about tax dollars covering deposits at troubled Texas thrifts. ``Some of the things that drive it as an issue nationally don't work so well here, like resentment at shipping oney to Texas,'' Murray said. Texans also may view the collapse of the state's economy differently. ``There's a wider sense in Texas that the price of oil wrecked the economy,'' Murray said. ``It's easier here to explain away the crisis without blaming it so much on the politicians.''

DOC.HEAD: Suspects in Killing of Utah Tourist Denied Bail
DOC.TEXT: Eight suspects in the subway knifing murder of a Utah tourist were denied bail today at their arraignment on murder and robbery charges. Acting Justice Herbert Adlerberg denied a request by attorneys for Yull Gary Morales, 18, and Luis Fernando Montero, 22, for a ``reasonable bail'' for their clients. The other lawyers did not request bail. Morales' attorney, Joel Lutwin, argued that his client had lived in Queens all his life and had ``no significant criminal record.'' Assistant District Attorney Tom Schiels argued that Morales made oral, written and videotaped statements about the Sept. 2 killing of Brian Watkins, 22, of Provo, Utah. Watkins was knifed to death at a midtown subway station after the youths allegedly robbed Watkins' father of $200 and some credit cards, slashed his pants with a box cutter and then punched and kicked his mother. His murder touched off a wave of outrage among residents who are concerned at the growing number of murders and violent crimes in the city. The family, in town to attend the U.S. Open tennis tournament in Queens, had attended the tennis matches in the afternoon and were on their way to dinner when the robbery occurred. Schiels said Morales, whose street name is ``Rocstar,'' ``admitted he did the stabbing.'' He said the group robbed the family to get money to go dancing at a Manhattan disco. The prosecutor said the murder weapon, a double-bladed butterfly knife, was found in Morales' home the day after the murder and pants and a T-shirt allegedly worn by the suspect had human blood on them. Schiels also argued that Morales organized the robbery and showed others in the group the knife before the alleged mugging. ``This case is going to try the City of New York,'' Lutwin said outside the courtroom. ``It's going to try the city because we're going to see if we can get a fair and just trial despite the fact that my client has already been convicted in the media.'' All eight suspects, who range in age from 18 to 22, were arraigned on second-degree murder and first-degree robbery charges. The next court date was set for Oct. 3 before Justice Edwin Torres.

DOC.HEAD: Consensus Elusive for Solving Philadelphia Fiscal Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Everyone agrees this city is in deep fiscal trouble. Everyone disagrees on what to do about it. Philadelphia faces a $206 million deficit by June 30, the end of the fiscal year, and Wall Street has turned up its nose at short-term notes to keep the city's bills paid through May. On Friday, Mayor W. Wilson Goode announced a hiring freeze and delays in pension fund payments and tax refunds, freeing up $122 million. But the city still expects to go broke by Dec. 1. ``If Philadelphia has even a temporary period without sufficient cash, the result will be a legal, political and public safety nightmare,'' Finance Director Betsy C. Reveal said in a recent memo to Goode. Political and business leaders are calling for a consensus, but state elections this year and next year's city elections seem to have stifled creativity. No invited city or state officials joined a Greater Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce summit on the crisis last week, except Goode and the city's elected controller, Jonathan A. Saidel. Several elected officials, including Gov. Robert P. Casey, sent representatives. ``The only consensus you can get out of people in an election year is that `it's not my fault, it's his fault,''' Saidel said at an earlier luncheon with business and community leaders. Saidel, a lawyer and accountant, said that when he first learned city officials wanted to borrow a half-billion dollars to keep the city afloat until May, he asked what permanent solution they had in mind. ``They told me that they didn't have a plan,'' he said. ``In the end I decided it was not good public policy in Philadelphia to borrow this money. I believed it was forestalling an inevitable decline in Philadelphia and forestalling the cash problem doesn't solve anybody's problem.'' In any case, the city earlier this month couldn't find banks to guarantee the notes, and Wall Street showed little interest. Bond-rating services now rate Philadelphia's $1.3 billion in outstanding debt as risky as junk bonds. Few taxes can be raised or added without state approval. The wage tax already is nearly 5 percent for city residents and 4.3 percent for commuters, among the highest rates in the nation. The City Council spurned Goode's request last spring to raise wage taxes on city residents to 5.5 percent. That would have raised $58.8 million a year, officials said. Philadelphia hasn't levied a sales tax since the early 1930s. A proposal to impose a half-cent tax on top of the state's 6 percent tax was passed by the City Council but awaits action in election-wary Harrisburg. The increase would raise $45 million a year, officials say. Budget cuts are another option, but many expenses are locked in by long-term labor contracts. ``I'm not convinced that they can solve this problem by cuts alone,'' said Colleen Woodell, a vice president for Fitch Investors Service Inc. in New York. City Councilman James J. Tayoun proposed a financial oversight board similar to one that helped New York City avoid bankruptcy in the 1970s. Councilman David Cohen urged withdrawal of city deposits from four local banks that refused to back loan notes. Organized labor also weighed in. A coalition of unions representing 60,000 city workers recommended closing tax loopholes, adding cigarette and unearned-income taxes and imposing a services fee on suburban residents. Goode had warned for years that the city's finances were shaky, saying in 1989 a tax increase was needed to avoid a $305 million deficit by mid-1991. Several tax increases he has proposed have stalled in the City Council or the Legislature. State voters rejected a tax reform measure in 1989 that would have given Philadelphia an option for a sales tax. And there seems to be no mandate for any major change. ``I don't sense that the great majority of folk in Philadelphia yet realize the seriousness of the problem,'' said John B. Neff, president of Frankford Hospital. ``So long as they're not personally affected by it - inertia's a wonderful thing - it could go on forever.''

DOC.HEAD: Swiftly Pass the Years: Chileans Finally Allowed to See Fiddler on the Roof
DOC.TEXT: The government on Monday lifted a 16-year-old ban on the movie Fiddler on the Roof, condemned by the former military regime for its alleged Marxist content. The new civilian government said its decree was necessary ``because the nation has started a time of real implementation of the principles of democracy and freedom.'' It was not immediately known whether Fiddler on the Roof will be shown soon in movie houses in Chile. The government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet imposed the ban in 1974.

DOC.HEAD: Military Swamped With Gifts for Servicemen
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Members of the Air Force's 1st Tactical Fighter Wing don't have to worry about satisfying a sweet tooth while on duty in Saudi Arabia. ``The guys tell me, `We're cookied out,' '' said Sgt. Dana Flores, a spokeswoman for the wing stationed at Langley Air Force Base in Hampton. Americans have opened their hearts - and their baking ovens - to military personnel involved in Operation Desert Shield. Among the offerings: 3,500 peanut butter cookies baked by the 14 nuns of the Monastery of Poor Clare. The nuns said many of the airmen deployed last month have volunteered to help around the monastery. Ms. Flores is responsible for seeing that donations from the public get to the wing while it is stationed overseas. Sometimes that means not sending everything that comes in, she said, especially if the offering could clash with Saudi culture. ``What people might not realize is that our troops are working side-by-side with the Saudis. One of our people might put down a book and a Saudi pick it up and read it and perhaps be deeply offended by some part. It could lead to an incident,'' she said. So Ms. Flores has been going through the thousands of donated paperbacks, weeding out those that might be a problem. The books are judged by their covers, suspected contents and author. ``The Saudi culture is a very religious one with very serious proscriptions against alcohol, pork and what is perceived as pornography,'' said Mary Anne Tetreault, an associate professor of political science at Old Dominion University in Norfolk. ``Anything of a political nature, especially anything to do with Israel, is also banned,'' said Ms. Tetreault, who has spent several years in Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. Ms. Flores has had to discard numerous paperbacks whose covers are adorned with women wearing racy outfits. Magazines, especially those with sexually suggestive advertisements, are another headache, Ms. Flores said. ``One young lady tried to send a pair of lacy panties to her man. I'm afraid that just won't get through Saudi customs,'' she said. However, packages sent to sailors and Marines aboard ships stationed in the Red Sea or Persian Gulf do not have to go through Saudi customs, said Major Tom Johnston, a spokesman for the Navy's Atlantic Fleet. The Air Force has been flying donated supplies to the fighter wing as space allows, Ms. Flores said. Johnston said the Navy has been encouraging people interested in sending things to the troops to write directly to them. ``When you're overseas, you're always looking for a letter from home, even if you don't know the person who sent it. I know from personal experience what an empty feeling mail call can be when you don't get anything,'' he said. Johnston recommends a small set of checkers or chess, a deck of cards or science fiction or western paperbacks for the Navy men and women. However, Ms. Flores asked that no more paperbacks be sent for the airmen. ``We're covered up in books right now. ... What they are asking for is drink mixes ... anything powder they can mix with the water. Drinking straight water is apparently getting pretty boring.'' Talcum powder, sports equipment and personal hygiene items also are appreciated, Ms. Flores said.

DOC.HEAD: Health Officials, Doctors Team Up To Trace Progress of Virus Causing AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials are collaborating with several hundred physicians in the United States and Canada to gather more information about the progression of the infection that leads to AIDS. The study will give medical researchers a better picture of which symptoms and diseases are most common in different groups of patients infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS, officials said in announcing the study Monday. It also will provide information on what treatments patients are using and will help researchers identify medical changes that occur as HIV infection progresses towards acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said the study was expected to ``result in the most comprehensive collection of information on HIV-infected persons amassed in the history of the AIDS epidemic.'' Patient confidentiality will be protected, he added. ``The more information we have about HIV-infected persons, the faster we can advance our AIDS research,'' said HHS Assistant Secretary for Health James Mason. The study will allow researchers to compile a data base on a broad spectrum of HIV patients and will help physicians identify patients who can participate in clinical trials of experimental drugs, officials said. More than 30 community-based clinics and programs in the United States and Canada will participate in the study. They include 18 sponsored by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and 15 sponsored by the American Foundation for AIDS Research. Several hundred physicians will be able to enroll patients they see at these clinics and programs, as well as patients they see in their private practices. These physicians care for more than 60,000 HIV-infected patients, according to the research foundation. Every three to six months during a regular clinic visit, physicians will ask all patients in the study a set of questions about their health and the drugs they are taking.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 900 Americans Are Still Hostage In Iraq, Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: At least 900 American men, women and children are trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, the State Department said today as it again accused Saddam Hussein's government of barbarism. At least 93 of these U.S. hostages, including many with serious medical problems, have been detained by the Iraqi government. Nine were seized over the weekend, one as he tried to board what could be the last evacuation flight sanctioned by Baghdad. Most of the adult male Americans in Iraq and Kuwait are in hiding, said Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman. For the sake of their safety she declined to provide exact figures. More than 1,900 American citizens and their foreign-born family members have been evacuated from the two Persian Gulf countries since Iraq seized Kuwait Aug. 2. Remaining behind, Ms. Tutwiler said, are 600 to 700 American citizens in Kuwait and 300 to 350 in Iraq. ``We find it particularly deplorable that the Iraqis have not only ignored our request to evacuate Americans with serious medical problems, but are now beginning to detain them,'' the U.S. official said. She called the detention of sick people, some of them with terminal illnesses, ``barbaric.'' Iraq has said it was using American men as human shields to deter a U.S. attack on oil refineries and other strategic installations. President Bush and senior U.S. officials have not ruled out force as a means of compelling Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait. Basically, however, the administrttion is hoping an embargo on Iraqi commerce authorized by the U.N. Security Council on Aug. 6 will prompt him to relent. On Sunday, the Iraqi leader threatened to attack Saudi Arabia, other Arab countries and Israel if Iraq was ``strangled'' by the economic sanctions. Ms. Tutwiler called it ``another outlandish, outrageous statement.'' And yet, she said, ``we have not seen any responsible statement towards doing what the world is saying he must do, which is withdraw from Kuwait and let the restoration of the legitimate government in Kuwait go back.''

DOC.HEAD: Closing Arguments Scheduled in Bitter Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf pvs., `Closing arguments ...' with 1 graf to CORRECT that closing arguments scheduled for Tuesday, sted today. Picks up 4th graf pvs., `Each side ...'
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Rodney Dangerfield has not found much to laugh about in his bitter court battle with Caesars Palace, the hotel where he headlined until an alleged steam room accident 2{ years ago. Dangerfield filed a $5 million lawsuit against his former employer after Caesars balked at paying him for shows he missed following the alleged accident in March of 1988. Testimony was scheduled to resume today. Closing arguments were scheduled for Tuesday. Each side blames the other for eye problems the comedian claims he suffered from a burst of steam from a faulty steam bath mechanism. Caesars contends the injuries were a figment of a ``comedic imagination.'' If Dangerfield was looking for respect, he found little of it in the two-week trial before U.S. District Judge Roger Foley. Dangerfield, 68, was portrayed as a vindictive, foul-mouthed malingerer by Caesars attorneys, who raked both the comedian and his case over the coals. ``You're trying to make me out to be a liar and I'm not,'' Dangerfield said at one point during three days of combative testimony. Dangerfield testified he was wronged by Caesars executives, who didn't fully believe he was injured by the steam. The comedian skipped four performances, claiming his eyes were too sensitive to light to perform. After returning for two shows, he walked offstage without performing on closing night, miffed at Caesars for wanting to defer his $45,000-per-show pay for the nights he missed. ``I just couldn't be funny for these people,'' said Dangerfield, who advised the showroom crowd of 1,200 to get refunds for both their seats and for any tips they gave showroom workers. Caesars, in an effort to prove Dangerfield wasn't hurt as badly as he claimed, introduced evidence showing Dangerfield went to the fights one night he was to perform, and to see a comedy show another night. A doctor who examined him following the steam bath incident said he thought Dangerfield could perform. Eye specialists testified Dangerfield had eye problems since the mid-1970s and may have hurt himself further by his repeated use of a topical anaesthetic used in surgery on his eyes.

DOC.HEAD: Police Kill Man Who Allegedly Fired on Car
DOC.TEXT: A gunman who opened fire at a passing car before barricading himself inside his house was fatally shot Monday by police, authorities said. The man's grandmother, who also was in the house, was rescued unhurt, police said. The trouble began shortly after midnight when Clifford Gordon Keeling, 31, fired at a car, said police Sgt. Pat Kolstad. The motorist fled and Keeling retreated to his house, Kolstad said. The sergeant said police surrounded the house and tried to negotiate, but Keeling disconnected his telephone and refused to talk. A SWAT team entered the house around dawn and used two explosive charges to distract Keeling, Kolstad said. The sergeant said the man was shot when he confronted the officers, but declined to say if Keeling fired on the officers.

DOC.HEAD: Governors Say States Will Have to Take Lead in Health-Care Fight
DOC.TEXT: States will be forced to take the lead in fighting spiraling health-care costs because Congress isn't likely to act soon, leaders of a national governors' conference said Monday ``The problem is becoming so severe that if we don't steer ourselves toward a solution, the problem is going to steer us toward bankruptcy,'' said Nevada Gov. Bob Miller. Washington Gov. Booth Gardner, chairman of the National Governors' Association, said he was optimistic the states would handle the problem ``because we have no choice.'' Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis said the governors want to determine why the United States is wasting money on health care. ``This country is spending twice as much on health care as West Germany, the United Kingdom, Japan or France,'' Dukakis said. ``And 25 percent to 30 percent again as much as Canada. Yet, those countries provide quality health care and we don't. ``We have to understand whey we are spending twice as much for less,'' he said. Gardner said Congress was unlikely to legislate a health care program for several years, but that states are addressing the problem because of state-budget shortfalls. ``Health care is analogous to the Pac Man of state government,'' he said. ``It is consuming a greater and greater share of state government.''

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Research Lab to Honor Mapplethorpe
With AM-Mapplethorpe Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs, which have prompted obscenity charges against a Cincinnati art gallery and its director, are getting a far warmer reception here. A top AIDS research lab plans to honor its namesake at a benefit next month, and attempts to shut down an exhibition of Mapplethorpe's photographs in Boston fizzled weeks ago. Jury selection began Monday in the trial of director Dennis Barrie and the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati, where the seven-week exhibit was shown last spring to record crowds. Friends and family of Mapplethorpe, who died of AIDS in March 1989, will gather Oct. 4 to launch a fund-raising campaign for The Robert Mapplethorpe Laboratory for AIDS Research at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. The hospital is hoping to raise $1.5 million to expand and renovate its AIDS research lab. ``I'm finding people are focusing on AIDS research and treatment as opposed to the controversy surrounding the exhibit,'' said benefit coordinator Tom Egan. The Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation, which funds AIDS research and photography projects, gave a $300,000 grant to the hospital in March. Mapplethorpe died at age 42 while being treated at Deaconess, a Harvard teaching hospital. Physicians at Deaconess are trying to identify new drugs to treat AIDS, which exposes the body to infection by crippling its immune system. ``I think the research is something that a lot of people want to support - the whole idea of a cure or a treatment in the future,'' said Egan. ``It's very long-term oriented.'' The fund-raiser will coincide with the final showing of ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment'' at Boston's Institute of Contemporary Art. Boston Municipal Clerk Magistrate Rosemary Carr denied three complaints early this month against the exhibit, which would have prompted an investigation by the district attorney. Although the exhibit was canceled at the Corcoran Art Gallery in Washington, D.C., because of a furor over government funding for the National Endowment for the Arts, it has appeared in several other cities without incident.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Gubernatorial Hopeful Calls for Armed Vigilantes in New York City
DOC.TEXT: Maverick GOP gubernatorial candidate Pierre Rinfret on Monday called for armed vigilantes to battle crime in New York City. ``What I really want is a vigilante system with people carrying guns, unknown to anybody,'' said Rinfret, ``so anybody who comes along and mugs somebody may have, standing next to him, a man who's been authorized.'' Aides later said the Manhattan-based economist envisioned a volunteer corps of up to 100,000 police-trained vigilantes. A spokesman for Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo, Rinfret's opponent in the November election, dismissed the proposal as dangerous. ``Every law enforcement official in the world would agree that his idea is absurd and irresponsible,'' said James Flateau, Cuomo's chief spokesman on criminal justice issues. Rinfret is trailing Cuomo badly in opinion polls and has been getting little financial support from Republican leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Four More Students Burn Themselves to Protest Job Quotas
DOC.TEXT: Four people including a teen-ager set themselves ablaze Monday in growing violence over the government's plan to set aside nearly half of its jobs for low-caste Hindus. Police hurled tear gas shells to disperse a mob near Parliament, and police headquarters in the capital was besieged for three hours by rampaging students who burned government vehicles, buildings and train coaches. United News of India said Prime Minister V.P. Singh asked Communications Minister Janeshwar Mishra and a senior party leader, S.R. Bommai, to open talks with the students to explain the job policy. But Singh must rescind the policy before they will talk, said the students, who claim the job quotas amount to reverse discrimination against upper-caste people. In New Delhi, Surinder Singh Chauhan, 22, doused himself with gasoline from a motorcycle in the midst of thousands of students and set himself on fire with a match, witnesses said. Kamal Kishore Sharma, who rushed to Chauhan's aid, said: ``We were sitting under the tent when we saw a ball of black smoke ... and caught the stench of burning flesh.'' Safdarjang Hospital's acting chief, Dr. B. Chakravarty, said Chauhan suffered burns over his entire body and had ``no chance of survival.'' A doctor at the hospital said on condition of anonymity that an 18-year-old was admitted to another New Delhi hospital with burns over 70 percent of his body. Two other people attempted self-immolation in Jaipur, a town 180 miles southwest of New Delhi, United News of India said. Both were treated for third-degree burns, it said. The traffic intersection where Chauhan set himself afire has been taken over since Thursday by thousands of students. At least 25 people have been killed in street battles with police since Wednesday, and scores of students have attempted suicide by burning to protest the new government job policy. The government employs 18 million people nationwide, and Singh announced on Aug. 7 that 49 percent of the prized jobs will be reserved for people of low castes, who have been suppressed for years by India's rigid social system. In that past, 22.5 percent of the jobs had been set aside for low castes and native tribes. Under the new policy, another 5 percent to 10 percent of government jobs will be reserved for the poor, regardless of caste. A doctor at the hospital said on condition of anonymity that an 18-year-old was admitted to another New Delhi hospital with burns over 70 percent of his body. Two other people attempted self-immolation in Jaipur, a town 180 miles southwest of New Delhi, United News of India said. Both were treated for third-degree burns, it said. Student leaders Sunday vowed not to lift the siege of the road intersection, one of New Delhi's busiest, ``even if we have to face military bullets.'' A tent tied to traffic signals and lampposts is the nerve center. Street fences are ripped out and thrown across the streets to block traffic. Despite growing student opposition to the job quotas, no political party has announced support for or opposition to the policy. Political analysts say the issue cannot threaten Singh's minority government unless it gains the support of an established political group. This is unlikely because political parties fear alienating the low castes, which comprise more than 50 percent of India's 880 million people, the analysts say. Many opponents of the job program say it is aimed at securing votes rather than rendering social justice. Hindus, who make up 82 percent of the population, are divided into four castes and hundreds of sub-castes, which decide a person's social standing. Discrimination on the basis of caste is illegal, but in practice the system permeates much of Indian social life, especially in villages.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Facing Public Hearing on S&L Conflict Charges
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's son Neil goes before a judge Tuesday in Denver for a rare public hearing that could lead to his being barred from working for a bank or savings and loan. Federal regulators have accused Bush, 35, of conflict of interest in his former role as a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, a Denver thrift that failed in late 1988 at an estimated cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. The hearing before an administrative law judge is the centerpiece of the government's complex proceeding against Bush, which has taken the form of a paperwork battle since the Office of Thrift Supervision filed the charges in February. The OTS is seeking an order against Bush, an oil and gas developer, to effectively bar him from working for a bank or a savings and loan. The agency contends that Bush failed to adequately disclose to Silverado his business relationships with developers Kenneth M. Good and Bill L. Walters, two big borrowers from Silverado who defaulted on their loans. Bush could have avoided a public hearing by agreeing not to dispute the conflict-of-interest charges, as other S&L officials have done in nearly all such previous cases. By fighting the government, he has taken the case out of attorneys' and regulators' offices into a public forum. ``The swords are drawn,'' Bush's attorney, James Nesland, said recently. Bush plans to testify in his own defense at the hearing, which is expected to continue through most of the week. Although such a public hearing is almost unprecedented, the participants don't expect any fireworks or courtroom drama. In fact, Nesland said, ``This is going to be an extraordinarily boring hearing.'' That's because it will mainly be a replay of written testimony already submitted to the administrative law judge, Daniel J. Davidson. Regulators and outside experts will be cross-examined on that testimony by attorneys for the two sides. The judge won't issue an opinion for some time and the government isn't expected to issue a ruling in the case until spring. Earlier this year, five other former directors and officers of Silverado, including former chairman Michael R. Wise and loan officer Russell Murray, agreed not to dispute the OTS' administrative charges against them. Bush also faces a separate $200 million lawsuit filed last week against him and other Silverado directors by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The civil suit accuses the directors, including Bush, of ``gross negligence'' that contributed to Silverado's collapse. Since he appeared in May before a congressional committee investigating Silverado's collapse, Bush's fight with the regulators has consisted mostly of briefs and counterbriefs submitted to Davidson. Now regulators, journalists and Davidson himself have trekked from Washington to Denver, Bush's home turf, for the hearing starting Tuesday in a federal courtroom. The hearing before Davidson is being held in Denver because the now-defunct Silverado was based there. Bush is scheduled to be the final witness of 11 - eight for the government and three for Bush. Davidson is expected to make his recommendation by Dec. 6 to OTS Director Timothy Ryan. The law judge could recommend that the regulators' proposed cease-and-desist order against Bush be issued, or he could advise against it. The order would bar Bush from engaging in future actions that would involve a conflict of interest. Davidson also could recommend a stronger prohibition order, OTS Chief Counsel Harris Weinstein said last week. The cease-and-desist order proposed by OTS would stop short of banning Bush from the financial institutions industry, but could impose strict conditions on his holding such a job. A prohibition order would be an ``absolute bar,'' Weinstein said. A draft internal document written earlier this year by OTS staff members recommended that a prohibition order also be issued against Bush. But the thrift agency later found there wasn't sufficient evidence to support a prohibition and the less serious cease-and-desist order was proposed, an OTS spokesman has said. Under the administrative timetable, Ryan would make his decision by April 8. Bush would have the right to appeal the decision, most likely to the U.S. Court of Appeals in Denver.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Party Leader Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the governing Socialist Party resigned Monday under pressure from reformers, mounting social tensions and Bulgaria's economic crisis. Alexander Lilov, a member of the Politburo under ousted Communist hard-liner Todor Zhivkov, said he was stepping down in favor of a ``more pragmatic'' leader. Several members of the former Communist hierarchy who helped engineer Zhivkov's ouster last November have since had to relinquish senior posts. Premier Andrei Lukanov, 52, is the only senior Communist from the Zhivkov era who still holds a top state post. The Communists renamed themselves the Socialists last spring and went on to win June's first free elections in 58 years with 211 seats in the 400-seat parliament. Since then, however, their popularity has declined as Bulgaria's economic crisis has worsened. Basic foods such as sugar and cooking oil are rationed, and power is cut regularly. The Socialists were forced to end weeks of deadlock over who should become state president by agreeing to the election of Zhelyu Zhelev, leader of the democratic opposition, in August. But political tension continued to mount. An angry crowd attacked, burned and looted the Socialist Party headquarters on Aug. 26. That attack reportedly was provoked by the Socialists' refusal to remove a red star from its headquarters. On Monday, the congress voted to remove all such symbols of the communist era from party buildings nationwide and adopted a new emblem - a white rose on red background - and new flag. Lilov, 57, became party leader only last February. Knowledgeable Bulgarians say he has split, rather than united, the party. The party congress decided Monday that a new leader would be chosen by the whole congress, and not just the party's council, a leadership body with about 150 members. The election was expected late Monday or early Tuesday.
