In announcing his decision to step down, Lilov cited his links with the now disgraced Zhivkov regime as one factor. ``I have the responsibility for the time during which I was a Politburo member of this party ... for more than ten years,'' he told delegates. ``We are still not a new party, which thinks, analyses and acts from a new position,'' Lilov said. ``Perhaps we are tired after holding power for over 45 years.'' ``The party needs a leader who is worthier and more pragmatic than I am - in short, a better leader,'' he said. Lukanov on Sunday identified four reformers as possible successors to Lilov. They were Dragan Draganov, Alexander Tomov, Petar Emil Mitev and Asen Zhablensky. All belong to reform factions and none is associated with the Zhivkov era. Lilov served as chief ideologist of the Communist Party until being dropped from the leadership by Zhivkov in 1983. He rejoined the top ranks after Zhivkov's ouster. Former President Petar Mladenov and former Defense Minister Dobri Dzhurov also lost their government posts this summer, despite having engineered the Communist Party coup against Zhivkov in November. In heated weekend debates at the congress, the leaders of four reform factions in the party called for a new, younger leadership. ``If no radical changes are made, there will be a gradual disintegration of the party,'' Draganov said Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Sentencing Hearing Starts for Cult Leader's Son
DOC.TEXT: Defense attorneys on Monday urged a jury to spare the life of a cult leader's son who was convicted in connection with the ritualistic killing of a family of five. Damon Lundgren, 19, was found guilty Tuesday on four counts each of aggravated murder and kidnapping in the April 17, 1989, shooting deaths of Dennis Avery and his three young daughters. He was acquitted in the kidnapping and murder of Avery's wife, Cheryl. Lundgren's father, Jeffrey, who describes himself as a prophet, was sentenced to death last week following his conviction on five counts of aggravated murder and kidnapping. Jeffrey Lundgren has admitted to actually shooting the family, but Ohio law allows prosecution of someone who participates in a killing, even if he didn't directly cause the death. The same Lake County Common Pleas jury that convicted Damon Lundgren began hearing testimony Monday in a proceeding to decide his penalty. The jury's choices are the death penalty, life in prison with parole eligibility after 30 years, or life with parole eligibility after 20 years. Damon Lundgren's attorneys argue that he was coerced into the crime by his father. ``Damon's undoing was that he honored and obeyed his father,'' defense attorney Charles Cichocki said. ``And for that, he should not be put to death.'' The Averys' bodies were found in January buried under a barn at a cult farm about 30 miles east of Cleveland. Each of the Averys had been bound and gagged with duct tape, then shot and dumped in a common grave. At his sentencing hearing, Jeffrey Lundgren called himself a prophet. He said he considered the Averys, also members of the cult, to be faltering in the sect's beliefs. He said he found messages in the Bible and other Scriptures telling him the Averys should die. His wife, Alice, received five life sentences for conspiracy, complicity and kidnapping roles in the Avery deaths. Other cult members await trials or have pleaded guilty to reduced charges.

DOC.HEAD: Railroad Tank Cars Derail Near Downtown Columbus, Small Chemical Leak
DOC.TEXT: A freight train derailed near downtown early Monday, spilling a small amount of a caustic chemical and blocking traffic during the morning rush hour. Eight cars of the CSX train cars overturned about 4:30 a.m. One tanker leaked about five gallons of sodium hydroxide. Fire Battalion Chief Mark Devine said the spill of the caustic liquid, which he likened to drain cleaner, was not believed to be hazardous. Ohio 315 - the only major north-south highway in the city not clogged by construction - remained closed until 9 a.m. while hazardous-materials officials determined that chlorine gas in two of the overturned tanker cars was not leaking. One of several warehouses in the area was closed for the day as a precaution. One firefighter was treated for injuries suffered when he slid down an embankment, and one was taken to a hospital because of heart problems, Devine said.

DOC.HEAD: Irate Elephants Block Trains After Calf Killed on Tracks
DOC.TEXT: A herd of elephants blocked rail tracks for several hours after a passenger train knocked down and killed an elephant calf Monday, United News of India reported. Elephants roaming in the surrounding forests came rushing after they heard the calf's cries and sat around its body on the tracks, the news agency said. After futile attempts to dislodge the animals, the crew took back the train to its origin, Mettupalayam, 1,162 miles south of New Delhi in southern India, UNI said. The train was on its way to Ootacmund, a popular hill resort in the Nilgiri mountains, 18 miles away. UNI quoted the railways as saying that ``the calf was killed as it suddenly appeared on the tracks.'' Train service between Mettupalayam and Ootacmund was affected for more than 12 hours, UNI reported but did not say when the elephants left the site.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Hale Remains Hospitalized for Tests
DOC.TEXT: Clara Hale, called an American hero for her work on behalf of orphaned and drug-addicted children, remained hospitalized Monday for treatment of chest pains. ``A series of tests conducted over the weekend showed she is in good condition,'' said hospital spokeswoman Jean Brett. Family members thought Mrs. Hale would be released Monday, but hospital officials said she was staying for more tests. ``It is anticipated she will be released soon,'' Brett said. Mrs. Hale, 85, was hospitalized Friday. She founded Hale House in 1941, and it has served since as a haven for thousands of parentless and drug-addicted children. But she recently found herself battling City Hall when Mayor David Dinkins' administration told her that under state regulations it must shut down group nurseries for abandoned infants by the end of this year. The city had been sending infants to Hale House and providing funds for their care. ``I am not going to give it up,'' Mrs. Hale said recently. ``These are God's children and he intends them to be here and for me to take care of them.'' Mrs. Hale was lauded by then-President Reagan in 1985 as an ``American hero.''

DOC.HEAD: Mail Carriers Learning Crime Prevention Techniques to Foil Thieves
DOC.TEXT: Mail carriers in south Florida are being trained in crime prevention techniques to combat a wave of mail thefts, a U.S. Postal Service spokesman said Monday. The training includes suggestions that mail carriers park their trucks in highly visible spots and that they cover their unattended mail so it isn't visible to thieves. The post office is also asking residents for help. ``We're asking our customers to look out for anything suspicious in the neighborhoods,'' said Costa Ayers, a spokesman for the Miami division of the U.S. Postal Service. Postal officials say that during the last five months, criminals have smashed the windows on more than 100 U.S. Postal Service vehicles and have pilfered mail bags and trays.

DOC.HEAD: Sailors Take on 136-Year-Old California-Boston Record
DOC.TEXT: In the tradition of the tall-masted clipper ships that once raced across the oceans, two sailors are taking aim at a 136-year-old record this fall in a San Francisco-to-Boston sweep around treacherous Cape Horn. Skipper Richard Wilson, who has suffered from asthma most of his life, says he's in it to raise money for lung research and to find out what happens ``when you're cold and wet and tired and scared ... and you've got another 24 hours to go.'' Wilson and Steve Pettengill will be shooting for the record of 76 days, 6 hours set by the clipper Northern Light, which roared into Boston Harbor in 1853 loaded with animal hides, copper, silk and fruit. Oct. 22 is the tentative departure date for the 14,000-mile trip on the 60-foot trimaran ``Great American.'' ``If we don't beat it then the experience will still be extraordinary. I don't think there's anything else like this in sport,'' Wilson said. ``We won't stop and there aren't any repair ships along the way. ``There aren't any substitutes coming off the bench when you get tired. There aren't any timeouts.'' Gale-force wind, seas over 100 feet and stretches of agonizing calm are likely in store for the 2{-month trip, Wilson said. ``I'm certain we'll have some horrendous weather. One of the great challenges is to just keep going, day in and day out,'' he said. To raise money for the cost of the expedition and for the American Lung Association, which has named Wilson one of its ``SuperAchievers,'' the two will make daily progress reports accessible by calling 1-900-820-BOAT. Calls cost $3.50. Several attempts in recent years to beat the times of the old speedy skippers are tribute to the continued fascination modern-day sailors have for the graceful clipper ships that ruled the seas from about 1840 to 1870. The clipper captains were motivated by the financial rewards of rushing supplies out to gold-rich California or whisking fragrant teas and spices back from the Orient to get the best price before a competitor reached port. Today, the lure of the long, grueling trips is the challenge of beating the elements, said Rich Boehmer, who keeps track of sailing records at his Sail Performance Center in West Bridgewater. ``They're extremely competitive people. That's how they feel that they can becomeknown,'' he said. Once begun, the life of a long-distance sailor is hard to relinquish, Boehmer said. ``People that do those kind of the things - the rest of your life is boring,'' he said. Wilson, 40, said he got the idea for the record attempt after sailing in a single-handed trans-Atlantic race in 1988. ``I thought that was the greatest experience I ever had, but somehow there (had) to be a way to extend the benefit to other folks,'' he said. Wilson, who taught school briefly in Boston, is a participant in the Student Ocean Challenge Program, and will visit schools before and after his trip to talk about geography, history and seagoing life. Pettengill is from Grand Rapids, Mich. The voyage did not draw a corporate sponsor, and Wilson said he hopes to convince the public that there is more to yachting endeavors than the America's Cup races every four years. He said the San Francisco-Boston trip probably won't be his last crack at the record books. ``You get great satisfaction. You get a great experience that you can't get on land. You gain knowledge, you gain confidence, you get in tremendous physical shape. You get a lot of things,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Gets Special Powers to Switch to Market Economy
LaserPhotos MOSB1,2,4
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Soviet legislature voted Monday to move toward a Western-style market economy and gave President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sweeping new powers to make the switch. Despite warnings by some lawmakers that the special powers would make Gorbachev a virtual monarch, the legislature passed a resolution allowing him to issue decrees on property, wages, prices, the national budget, the financial system, and law and order. Gorbachev promised to exercise the powers with care. ``It's a responsibility,'' he told the legislature. ``It's not a tea party.'' After rancorous debate, the lawmakers were unable to agree on a specific, step-by-step program to move away from the central planning system that they blame for technological backwardness and shortages of housing, food and consumer goods. Instead of choosing one of the three plans presented in the past two weeks, the Supreme Soviet set up a committee to combine them and report back by Oct. 15. Despite disagreement on how to make the switch, the Supreme Soviet's vote marked the first time it has committed the country to a market-based system and was a departure from seven decades of Communist economics. Since the 1920s, ministries in Moscow have kept a tight grip on the economy, issuing detailed five-year plans that told thousands of factories, farms and businesses what to produce, where to sell it and how much to charge. The most radical reform proposal, written by economist Stanislav Shatalin, calls for junking the central planning system and moving to a market economy within 500 days by selling factories to private owners and breaking up collective farms. The most conservative proposal, backed by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, would leave the government in control of most of the economy while moving gradually to allow free enterprise. Gorbachev has backed a compromise that contains many elements of the 500-day plan but would not move as fast. He also wants a national referendum to decide whether to return land to private farmers. Before and during theSupreme Soviet's meeting, protesters gathered outside the Kremlin and at Pushkin Square in downtown Moscow to condemn the decision to give the president additional powers. They said Gorbachev did not deserve such authority because he was not elected by direct vote of the people. ``The people don't trust Gorbachev!'' shouted a group of demonstrators outside the Kremlin's Spassky Gate. They held signs saying, ``A President - Not an Emperor'' and ``All Decrees of the President are Battles Against Democracy.'' Gorbachev was elected to a five-year term as president by the Supreme Soviet in March. Previously, his power had come from his position as general secretary of the Communist Party, which he has held since 1985. The legislature voted 305-46, with 41 abstentions, to allow Gorbachev the special powers until March 31, 1992. The time limit was intended to cover a 500-day economic reform plan, should one be approved. The action put the Supreme Soviet on a collision course with the parliament of the Russian Federation, the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 constituent republics. On Saturday, Russia's President Boris Yeltsin and other leaders of the Russian parliament declared that Gorbachev's request for additional power was ``unacceptable'' because it would allow him to infringe on the republic's sovereignty. The Russian parliament has adopted Shatalin's 500-day plan and threatened to put it into effect on its own. The Supreme Soviet was ambiguous about the extent to which it will review Gorbachev's decisions. Its resolution said he would have the right to issue urgent decrees ``if the Supreme Soviet does not find it necessary to establish other rules, or does not recommend that the president change or replace his decisions.'' Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak, a lawyer, objected to the word ``recommend'' and urged the legislature to adopt clearer language requiring its review and approval of all presidential economic decrees. But his amendment was defeated on a vote of 211-94 with 70 abstentions. Another legislator from Leningrad, Yuri Boldyrev, complained the resolution gave Gorbachev ``absolutely unlimited powers,'' and a lawmaker who did not identify himself told the legislature it would make the president into a ``monarch.'' But the legislature rejected a series of amendments designed to limit the president's new powers. Ryzhkov, the prime minister, later told reporters there was ``no possibility that Gorbachev will become a dictator.'' ``Gorbachev is the first really parliamentary leader in Russia,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto Ordered to Stand Trial on Second Corruption Charge
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto today was ordered to stand trial on a second corruption charge involving gas contracts and alleged nepotism. A special one-judge court ruled that the army-backed caretaker government presented enough evidence to indict the former premier and set a trial date of Oct. 9. Ms. Bhutto is accused of canceling lucrative contracts for the distribution of liquified gas and giving them to friends and relatives. Justice Rashid Aziz Khan ruled there was enough evidence for a trial. On Sunday, he ordered Ms. Bhutto, 37, to stand trial on Oct. 2 on another corruption charge, this one involving the alleged illegal sale of government-owned land to a company owned by a cousin. If convicted of either charge, Ms. Bhutto could be barred from the Oct. 24 elections and from participating in politics for up to seven years. She was not immediately available for comment. Her aides said she had been locked in meetings with lawyers at her fortress-like home in Karachi since Sunday's ruling. One of her lawyers, however, said he was confident the government would not be able to substantiate the charges. The lawyer, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Ms. Bhutto had not decided whether she would appear before the tribunals but hinted that she probably would. Legal experts say Ms. Bhutto could be tried in absentia and held in contempt of court, possibly facing a fine or arrest. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, using his constitutional powers, dismissed Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government on Aug. 6 on charges of corruption, political incompetence and abuse of power. The caretaker government has filed four corruption charges - two in Lahore and two in her hometown of Karachi. The Karachi charges still are pending. Ms. Bhutto won election in November 1988 and became the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation. She now is a candidate for five seats in the 217-member National Assembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament. Her aides say Ms. Bhutto ran for more than one post in case she is disqualified from one seat. Since her dismissal, Ms. Bhutto's military-backed opponents have begun a campaign to portray her administration as the most corrupt in Pakistan's 43-year history. But several Pakistani and foreign diplomats have criticized the special tribunals hearing the charges as one-sided.

DOC.HEAD: Rate Changes Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Changes in interest rates on short-term Treasury securities were mixed in Monday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $9.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.32 percent, down from 7.39 percent last week. Another $9.2 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.33 percent, up from 7.30 percent last week. The rate for three-month bills was the lowest since they were sold for 7.23 percent on Aug. 6. The rate for six-month bills was the highest since they averaged 7.34 percent on Sept. 10. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.56 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,815.00 and 7.72 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,629.40. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 7.77 percent last week, up from 7.75 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf At-A-Glance
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis: --- The United Nations General Assembly session opened with condemnations of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. French President Francois Mitterrand called Iraq a warlike state whose aggression could lead to anarchy. Other leaders, including Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and President Bush, are to speak in coming days. --- Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said he would fight for ``a thousand years'' to keep Kuwait, and said the United States was the real aggressor in the region. The official Iraqi News Agency said he made his remarks to a group of Islamic clerics. --- Oil prices soared as high as $38 per barrel and gasoline and home heating oil both topped $1 a gallon. Light sweet crude was trading Monday on the futures market at $37.75 per barrel for November contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil sold above the $37 mark for the first time since the crude futures began trading on the exchange in 1983. At one point, it hit $38 for a record price. --- Iraq said Monday it had rebuffed an offer from the United States to allow an Iraqi Airways plane to land in New York - if Baghdad releases more than 1,000 Americans being held in Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, has so far stayed away from the U.N. General Assembly, saying he will not follow U.S. advice to take a commercial flight instead. --- Israel responded Monday to threats made by Iraq a day earlier. Baghdad had said Israel would be a target if the gulf crisis came to all-out war. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Israelis were ready to ``confront, prevent and ... defend ourselves'' against Iraq. --- The International Monetary Fund approved an accelerated effort to supply billions of dollars to help countries hurt by the embargo against Iraq. In a communique on Monday, the IMF's policy-making interim committee directed the staff of the international lending agency to ``respond on an expedited basis to present difficulties'' of such countries, including Iraq's former major trading partners. --- Iraq tightened its grip on Kuwait by abolishing the country's currency, the dinar, and replacing it with Iraqi dinars. The Iraqi currency is not convertible on the international market. --- Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said Syrian President Hafez Assad was extending his stay in Tehran. Assad, Saddam's arch-enemy, came to Iran for talks that were to include inquiries about the Western hostages in Lebanon and Iran's intentions regarding the U.N. trade embargo against Iraq. Assad met for the third time in three days Monday with Rafsanjani.

DOC.HEAD: IMF Will Aid Nations Hurt by Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The International Monetary Fund gave its support Monday to an accelerated effort to supply billions of dollars to poor countries harmed by the Persian Gulf crisis as the Bush administration worked behind the scenes to flesh out details of the assistance package. The approval by the IMF's policy-making interim committee was announced in a communique that stressed the international lending agency would respond on an ``expedited basis to present difficulties.'' The IMF approval followed promises by World Bank President Barber Conable that his agency stood ready to increase its lending as a result of the Mideast turmoil. The Bush administration is counting on both the IMF and the World Bank to provide significant support to bolster the trade embargo against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. In addition, President Bush earlier this month dispatched Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and Secretary of State James A. Baker III on global fundraising missions seeking pledges of support from individual countries. So far, the administration has received commitments of $20 billion divided equally between support for the U.S. military buildup in the Mideast and assistance for the so-called front line states of Egypt, Turkey and Jordan. The administration is concerned that the trade embargo against Iraq will not succeed without significant aid flowing to countries harmed economically either by the loss of export markets or a jump in oil prices. The IMF communique provided no specifics on how much money would be forthcoming but did list a variety of IMF programs that could be tapped for money including a compensatory fund used in the past to aid nations hit by earthquakes and hurricanes. Canadian Finance Minister Michael Wilson, the chairman of the IMF interim committee, denied that the lack of specifics reflected any dissension among the 22 finance ministers who spent Sunday and early Monday crafting the IMF policy. ``We recognized the urgency of the needs of the people who are affected,'' Wilson told reporters. ``The urgency is stated, the framework is provided and now it is up to the IMF management to respond.'' Echoing remarks made by Conable last week, IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus said he believed the emergency aid could start flowing early in 1991. The Persian Gulf crisis has become the central focus of the annual meetings of the IMF and World Bank, being attended by representatives of the 152 nations that are members of the two institutions. President Bush was scheduled to address the finance officials on Tuesday. The administration held a series of meetings behind the scenes Monday in an effort to tie up loose ends of the financing packages. Treasury Department aides were meeting with representatives from Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada, Italy, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, South Korea and the 12-nation European Community in an effort to reach agreement on financing details. These working-group meetings were to be followed on Wednesday with discussions at a higher level led by Treasury Undersecretary David Mulford. Horst Koehler, an official in the West Germany Finance Ministry, said that the discussions were being held to settle on an exact dollar amount of required assistance. But U.S. officials said the talks were covering a broader range of issues including the mechanisms to be used to funnel the aid to needy countries. Just three weeks ago, the administration said it wanted to raise $10.5 billion to meet the needs of Egypt, Jordan and Turkey through the end of next year. However, U.S. officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Monday that the range now being considered was 12 billion to $14 billion in economic assistance to the three front-line nations with changing economic circumstances such as higher oil prices blamed for the revised figure. In addition to this assistance, the United States is also seeking billions of dollars in additional contributions to other countries hurt by the jump in oil prices. Nations mentioned for this group include the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, which are about to lose their access to cut-rate oil from the Soviet Union, as well as such Third World countries as the Philippines, India and Brazil.

DOC.HEAD: Assad Extends Stay, Holds More Talks With Rafsanjani
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Syrian President Hafez Assad held his third meeting in three days with President Hashemi Rafsanjani on Monday after extending his visit to Tehran, the official Iranian news agency said. Assad's talks are believed to have focused on Iran's role in the United Nations embargo against Iraq, and on the plight of 13 Western hostages held in Lebanon. The Islamic Republic News Agency provided no details about Assad and Rafsanjani's latest meeting. Assad, who arrived in Tehran Saturday for what was to have been a three-day visit, decided to stay longer than scheduled ``due to the importance of the issues under discussion and the need to complete consultations,'' IRNA said. Assad is Iran's key Arab ally and an archrival of Iraq's Saddam Hussein. His visit to Tehran followed talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker III in Damascus earlier this month. Washington apparently wants Assad to use the leverage he gained from supporting Iran during its eight-year war with Iraq on the hostage and embargo isses. Tehran has hinted that it would allow ``humanitarian shipments'' of food and medical supplies into Iraq regardless of the embargo, imposed by the U.N. Security Council after Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait. However, IRNA reported Monday that Iranian authorities had arrested 29 smugglers accused of trying to move foodstuffs across the border into Iraq to circumvent the U.N. embargo. Iran has criticized the invasion of Kuwait. But it also has deplored the U.S.-led Western forces deployed in Saudi Arabia and the region. Assad has stressed to the Iranians that the U.S. military presence in the Persian Gulf is not permanent and that it would end if Saddam relinquished Kuwait. Assad himself sent some 4,000 troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force in Saudi Arabia, and has pledged to send another 15,000 men. Iraq abruptly moved to make peace with Iran after the invasion of Kuwait. The move freed up Iraqi troops that had occupied Iranian border areas since fighting ended in the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. Diplomats in Damascus and Tehran have said the plight of the 13 Western hostages in Lebanon is a main topic on Assad's agenda in Tehran. Most of the six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian, are held by Shiite Moslem factions linked to the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God. It is Tehran's main ally in Lebanon, where Syria is the major power broker. The longest-held hostage is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Five Measures Not Eligible for Ballot
DOC.TEXT: Five statewide voter initiatives, including a far-reaching proposal to allow tax credits for church-sponsored schools, aren't eligible to be on the Nov. 6 ballot, a judge ruled Monday. Marion County Circuit Judge Richard Barber's ruling could lead to removal of all eight initiatives from the ballot. Because of printing deadlines, Barber said the measures could stay on the ballot but that votes for or against could not be counted. Barber said the proposals no longer qualify for the ballot because they won't be accompanied by financial impact statements as required by state law. The measures would limit property taxes, shut down the Trojan nuclear plant, ban some non-recyclable packaging, establish a pilot work in lieu of welfare program and allow tax credits for sending children to private schools. The school funding measure would grant state income tax credits of up to $2,500 a year for pupils at private schools, including church-supported schools, and for children taught at home. It also would allow parents to send their children across district lines to any public school. Barber's decision was an outgrowth of earlier Marion County Circuit Court rulings that the fiscal statements couldn't appear on the ballot because they weren't certified by state officials by a legal deadline. Barber said the Legislature intended that measures not appear on the ballot without the required statements of financial effects. State officials were considering an appeal of Monday's ruling.

DOC.HEAD: Deficit, at Record Level in August, Could Ease by Fiscal Year's End
DOC.TEXT: The federal budget deficit jumped $52.8 billion to a record $241.7 billion in August, but could be reduced before the fiscal year ends Sept. 30, the Treasury Department reported Monday. The 67 percent surge over the comparable 11 months of 1989 boosted the spending imbalance well over the record of $221.1 billion posted in fiscal 1986. The August total, however, fell short of the one-month record of $53.3 billion set last March. ``We used to have years that were that bad,'' economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch said of the August deficit. The department said about $25 billion of the August deficit reflected a shift of payments normally made in September such as military pay and Social Security checks to the previous month to avoid Labor Day weekend delays. ``This will affect September's results by $25 billion as compared to last year,'' it said in a statement. Still, without the $25 billion early payment, the deficit so far this fiscal year would have totaled $216.9 billion. The deficit in September 1989 was $6.1 billion. The Bush administration had forecast a $218.5 billion imbalance for all of fiscal 1990. White House and congressional negotiators are trying to reach agreement on reducing the deficit by $50 billion in the fiscal year starting Oct. 1 and $500 billion over the next five years. Without an agreement, the White House estimates the fiscal 1991 deficit will total $232.3 billion. Revenues in August totaled $78.5 billion, up 3.1 percent from the comparable month in 1989. But the receipts were offset by $131.2 billion in outlays, a 33.5 percent gain over August 1989. In addition to the early payments, the spending bill included $2.6 billion for the Resolution Trust Corp., the government agency charged with bailing out the savings and loan industry. The S&L bailout cost $3.2 billion in July and $37.8 billion so far this year. The government hopes to regain much of the bailout cost by selling real estate, loans, securities and other assets from failed thrifts. That would help reduce the deficit in future years. ``It's just a continuation of the trends we've been seeing,'' Steinberg said. ``Receipts are not that strong because the economy is weakening.'' Revenues for the first 11 months totaled $928.6 billion, up 4.2 percent from the first 11 months of last year. Spending during the period totaled $1.2 trillion, 12.8 percent over the comparable period of 1989. As usual, the biggest spending categories were the military, Social Security and other programs of the Department of Health and Human Services and interest on the national debt. Military spending totaled $27.8 billion in August and $269.2 billion so far this year. It is projected to total $290.2 billion for the entire fiscal year. Social Security payments amounted to $41.2 billion for the month and $244.2 billion for the year. They are projected to total $244.9 billion for the year. Other HHS payments, including Medicare and Medicaid, totaled $18.3 billion in August and $179.7 billion for 1990 so far. They are projected to total $192.4 billion in fiscal 1990. Interest on the national debt amounted to $18.9 billion for the month and $247.6 billion so far this year. Such interest is projected to total $261.1 billion for the entire year.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Goods Vanished While Leaders Dithered on Economy
With AM-Soviet-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While their leaders hedged and debated an economic rescue plan, Soviet consumers have lost patience with dwindling supplies of even basic goods such as bread, cigarettes, matches and paper. Last week, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev admitted the Soviet Union had run out of time as well. ``We must move and act,'' Gorbachev scolded legislators Friday when they failed to muster a quorum to act on economic reform. ``Don't wait.'' After months of indecision over what path to take, the Soviet parliament voted Monday to accept in principle a plan to move to a free market economy and reject central planning. But the journey Soviet officials have taken to the market this year has been a slow one, with reverses and setbacks. In the spring, Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov drew up an economic reform plan that called for continued central planning, a strong central government and a slow transition to the market. But it was quickly rejected by the parliament and returned to him for reworking. Its call for doubling and tripling prices on some basic consumer goods also set off a wave of panic buying. When Ryzhkov's reworked plan was submitted to lawmakers earlier this month, it was criticized as little different than the original. A radical plan drawn up by economist Stanislav Shatalin also was submitted to parliament this month. It proposes a 500-day transition that includes sovereignty for the 15 Soviet republics, sale of state property to private owners, decollectivization of farming, land reform, cutting the military and KGB budgets, and deregulating most prices while freezing the costs of 150 essential goods. The Shatalin plan was passed by the parliament of the Russian Republic - the nation's largest political subdivision - on Sept. 11. A committee appointed by Gorbachev then put together a compromise that has many elements of Shatalin's plan but rejects some key provisions, including those on decollectivization and sovereignty for the republics. While the various proposals have been hammered out, things have worsened. Gorbachev himself says the nation has entered an ``economic depression,'' and frustrated shoppers have become more agitated. After an acute shortage of cigarettes all summer, the nation's smokers began to register their anger with demonstrations and strikes. They began in the smaller cities of the Russian republic and spread to Leningrad and Moscow, where protesters blocked the streets until truckloads of cigarettes arrived. Hundreds of people demanding better supplies of food, tobacco, alcohol and consumer goods rioted in the Ural Mountains city of Chelyabinsk in August. Bread rationing was instituted in one city near Moscow at the end of the summer, and the capital's supplies of the traditionally plentiful Russian staple ran short for about two weeks. ``We are sick and tired of empty shops and devalued money; we want no more crises,'' Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov, an opponent of Gorbachev's, told thousands of people rallying at the Kremlin on Sept. 16. Factories and farms in some cities suffering through shortages have refused to ship their goods to other cities or republics. Ryzhkov went on nationwide television Sunday night and told of a ``very serious'' shortfall in the current harvest of potatoes and other vegetables, with only a third of the crop collected. Such a warning is ominous as the nation prepares for winter. But even Monday's first step toward the market was not without disagreement, debate and further delay. The economic blueprints before lawmakers will be merged into one plan by a committee of legislators and economists by Oct. 15, a further wait of three weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Eds.: SUBS 4th item to UPDATE with disorderly conduct charges dismissed Bobby Brown.
DOC.TEXT: Disorderly conduct charges were dismissed Monday against recording artist Bobby Brown, who was arrested after he intervened in a restaurant confrontation between his brother and a police officer. Court officials said neither Brown nor his brother, Tommy Brown, 29, attended the hearing before Municipal Court Judge Howard Johnson. Tommy Brown was scheduled to appear in court Oct. 9. Bobby Brown's attorney, Paul Howard, said the singer was ``very embarrassed to be associated with an incident that caused him to have to come into contact with the criminal justice system in this way.'' Brown, 23, and his brother were arrested early Sunday at the Beautiful Restaurant in southwest Atlanta. According to police, the elder Brown had been arguing with another man, then cursed and threatened a police officer when the officer tried to calm him. ``Bobby Brown apparently attempted to intercede on behalf of his brother and complained about the officer's treatment of his brother,'' said police Sgt. R.G. Christian. ``The officer felt he was interfering with his duties, and he charged both men with disorderly conduct.'' Brown's 1988 solo album, ``Don't Be Cruel,'' sold more than 5 million copies. He has a house in Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Detain `Several' in Slaying of Soviet Priest
DOC.TEXT: Several people have been detained on suspicion of killing a prominent Russian Orthodox priest whose grisly slaying provoked national outrage, Tass reported Monday. Father Alexander Menn, a writer who was persecuted under previous Soviet leaders for his evangelical activities, was bludgeoned to death with an ax while on his way to church Sept. 9 near his house in Zagorsk, 50 miles northeast of Moscow. The 55-year-old priest bled to death from the blow, authorities said. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who noted Menn's death in the national parliament, has demanded a ``thorough investigation'' of the slaying. The official Tass news agency, without quoting any sources by name, said in a brief report it had learned ``several'' peoptained on suspicion of killing Menn. The case is being investigated by the le have been deInterior Ministry of the Russian republic, Tass said, under a unit headed by Deputy Interior Minister Vyacheslav Pankin. After his death, Menn was praised by the government newspaper Izvestia as a ``pastor to many human rights champions, prisoners of conscience, those persecuted by the authorities.'' A theologian and a church historian, Menn wrote several books and articles, as well as a children's book. His popular history of comparative religion was publishedan hour last Tuesday. Hogan said that because of the two major summer blackouts, the media is reporting minor problems that previously would have been ignored. Edison has blamed the West Side blackouts on a problem at a generating plant, and other failures on damaged cables and animals chewing power lines. Still, Hogan said Edison maintains ``a 99.98 percent reliability factor.'' ``We don't have any reason to believe the total infrastructure is in jeopardy,'' Hogan said. Even so, the Daley administration insists a buyout is a real alternative. ``This is not a bargaining chip,'' Daley spokeswoman Carolyn Grisko said Friday. ``This is a possibility.'' The current agreement gives the city the right to purchase Comm Ed's system within the city's limits - an option first given serious consideration in 1985 under the late Mayor Harold Washington's administration. But other issues besides the buyout are on the table, including how much money the utility pays the city for the right to operate here. Currently, the utility pays Chicago 4 percent of its gross receipts - which last year was in excess of $72 million, Hogan said. Consumer groups, such as Citizens Utility Board, are asking the city to consider a new franchise that would require Commonwealth Edison to work harder to cut customer costs. Residential Commonwealth Edison customers paid 10.7 cents per kilowatt hour for electricity in 1988, compared with a national average of 7.5 cents, according to the power association. Edison financial analysts say the utility also has a lot to lose in the talks. Chicago represents ``a large portion of the company's sales,'' said Linda Byus, a utility analyst for Duff & Phelps in Chicago. Its image also is linked closely to the city, which may help forge an amicable agreement between the two, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Kaunda, In Major Policy Switch, Clears Way for Multiparty Vote
DOC.TEXT: President Kenneth Kaunda, surrendering to opposition demands, said Monday he would clear the way for multiparty elections after almost two decades of one-party rule. Zambia is the latest of several African nations to move toward multiparty elections following popular demonstrations against authoritarian regimes founded mainly on Eastern European models. Kaunda told top ruling party officials he was recommending constitutional amendments that would allow other political parties to contest parliamentary and presidential elections next year. He said he was also asking his United National Independence Party to scrap a referendum scheduled for next August on Zambia's political future. Instead, the party will campaign against opposition parties in elections for 150 seats in parliament, he said. Opening a five-day meeting of the party's top policy-making body, a 600-member council, Kaunda also called for a new constitution permitting more than one candidate to run for the presidency and creating the post of vice president for the first time. He told the council he was confident his party would win free elections. ``I am more than ready to lead UNIP in an election against any party or parties in this country. We are not afraid,'' he said. Kaunda, 66, established a one-party state in this southern African nation in 1973, nine years after leading the former British colony of Northern Rhodesia to independence as Zambia. After food riots and violent anti-government demonstrations earlier this year, Kaunda acknowledged the need for political reforms in Zambia, one of Africa's poorest nations. A pro-democracy opposition group was legalized in July to campaign for a vote on whether to return to a Western-style multiparty system. The Movement for Multiparty Democracy attracted to its rallies the largest crowds in Zambia's political history.

DOC.HEAD: Winnie Mandela Ordered to Stand Trial in February
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with six bodies found in incidents not involving Mandela case. Picks up 4th graf `During Richardson's' with minor editing to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JOH1,2
DOC.TEXT: Winnie Mandela and seven former associates will stand trial in February on charges of kidnapping and assaulting four young men, a magistrate decided Monday. The wife of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela stood silently during her arraignment in the Protea magistrate's court in Soweto. Dozens of supporters chanted her name and danced outside the building. Also on Monday, police found six bodies of young men along railroad tracks between Johannesburg and Soweto black township. All bore multiple injuries, indicating the victims may have jumped or been thrown from a train, police Capt. Eugene Opperman told the South African Press Association. More than two dozen people have died in attacks on trains in the Johannesburg area in recent weeks. The charges against Mrs. Mandela stem from a December 1988 incident in which 14-year-old Stompei Seipei as killed. The former head of Mrs. Mandela's bodyguards, Jerry Richardson, has been convicted of murder and sentenced to death in the case. During Richardson's trial, the other three victims testified they were abducted by members of the Mandela United Football Club - Mrs. Mandela's bodyguards - and taken to her Soweto home. They said Mrs. Mandela beat them with a whip, and the others also assaulted them. Mrs. Mandela and the other defendants face four counts each of kidnapping and four of assault with intent to commit grievous bodily harm. She has denied any wrongdoing. She was freed on her own recognizance. The other seven defendants, former members of the now-disbanded club, had their bail continued. If convicted, Mrs. Mandela could face anything from the death sentence to a suspended sentence for kidnapping, lawyers said. The death sentence has never been imposed for kidnapping in South Africa, they said. Her lawyer, Ismail Ayob, argued Monday that the original Oct. 30 trial date gave Mrs. Mandela insufficient time to prepare. Magistrate T.F. Veldman set a new date of Feb. 4. Dressed in a conservative dark suit, Mrs. Mandela and her husband walked hand in hand through dozens of ANC supporters to enter the building. After the hearing, the crowd chanted ``Winnie! Winnie!'' when they came outside. Neither made a statement to a pack of waiting reporters. White and black leaders fear the trial will strain relations between the ANC and the government as the sides try to start talks on ending apartheid. Monday's arraignment was the latest in a series of controversial or damaging incidents involving Mrs. Mandela. Many have been linked to the soccer club she formed and that served as her protection. The two dozen teen-agers played few matches and were accused of terrorizing the Soweto neighborhood where Mrs. Mandela lived. According to testimony at Richardson's trial, Mrs. Mandela's bodyguards accused Seipei of being a police informer and the other three victims of having homosexual relations with the white minister at their church home. No evidence has been presented that Seipei was a police spy. The Methodist Church cleared the minister of any misconduct. In other developments Monday: -Police said at least 12 people died nationwide in black factional fighting over the weekend. About 800 people have been killed in the violence, which erupted Aug. 12 in black townships around Johannesburg. -Protests mounted against 9 p.m.-to-4 a.m. curfews scheduled to begin Tuesday night in some townships. The ANC has said the curfews would leave blacks defenseless against vigilante attacks. -Soweto officials signed an agreement to end a five-year rent boycott in the sprawling township of 2 million people southwest of Johannesburg. The protest was against living conditions and the local authorities, considered to be linked to the white-led government. Under the agreement, more than $200 million owed by the residents would be written off. Residents would pay $10 a month in rent, plus a metered electricity charge.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl: Germans Not `Preoccupied Only with Their Own Affairs'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD Kohl comment on unification, SUB grafs 11-12 pvs, bgng `He also' with 6 grafs. Pickup 12th graf pvs, `He rebuffed...'
DOC.TEXT: Helmut Kohl, who will lead a united Germany within two weeks, on Monday dismissed claims he is too busy with unification to become seriously involved in global affairs such as the Persian Gulf crisis. In a meeting with the AP board of directors, Kohl maintained that German unity will ``release fresh energies'' for assisting Third World nations and for helping maintain world peace. ``The Germans are by no means preoccupied only with their own affairs,'' Kohl said in a written statement prepared for The Associated Press. The West German chancellor also answered AP board members' questions, elaborating on many of the same themes, but said his comments during the meeting were not for publication. Kohl becomes chancellor of all Germany when the East and West unite on Oct. 3. He stands a good chance of being re-elected on Dec. 2, the date of the first all-German elections in 57 years. Kohl spoke with the AP board of directors for nearly two hours at the Chancellery. He released a written statement to the board containing his latest views on a united Germany's role in world politics and other matters. Many of Kohl's remarks focused on the global responsibilities of a united Germany and how they mesh with the political integration of Europe as a whole. The chancellor expressed deep gratitude to President Bush for being the first Western leader to affirm the Germans' right to unify. ``I wish to single out in particular the contribution made by the United States of America,'' Kohl said. He also said he and Bush are both interested in seeing serious economic reform succeed in the Soviet Union. The Germans have committed themselves to providing large sums of money to help out the Soviets. ``A successful outcome to these reforms serves us all,'' he said. Kohl, destined to go into the history books as the architect of German unity, rejected charges by his political rivals that he rushed unification to advance his own career. He said the East Germans determined the pace. Kohl said a mammoth challenge lies ahead because the German nations followed drastically different paths after their separation four decades ago. Germans will have to ``show great empathy and understanding in order to overcome both the physical and the mental divisions between us,'' he said. People in the impoverished East cannot ``expect us to create equal standards of living'' for them overnight, Kohl added. He rebuffed criticism from some U.S. congressmen and officials in other nations that the Germans don't want serious global responsibilities. The accusations were made after West Germany said its constitution barred it from sending soldiers to assist the U.S.-led multinational forces deployed in the Persian Gulf after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Since then, West Germany has promised a large financial package to help in the gulf crisis. Kohl argued that his policies do have global implications. For example, Kohl said, he is committed to the political union of Europe. ``We are striving for tangible progress towards a common external and security policy'' within the 12-nation European Economic Community, he said in his statement. He said a united Germany would not seek the ``leading role in Europe'' but intends to ``live up to our responsibility in Europe and in the world.'' ``My government will therefore continue to support the international efforts to curb Iraq's policy of expansion and to restore the territorial integrity of Kuwait,'' he said. ``The unification of Germany and its commitments in a changing Europe will not prompt us to neglect problems in other parts of the world,'' Kohl said. ``On the contrary, German unification will release fresh energies.'' ``In the long run Germany and Europe as a whole will possess additional resources for contributing to economic and social development in the Third World and to the safeguarding of peace worldwide,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait's Currency Declared Invalid by Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq, underscoring its control over Kuwait, has declared Kuwait's currency invalid and set a deadline for all who hold it to exchange it for Iraqi money, the government said Monday. Iraq will reimburse those who possess Kuwaiti dinars with Iraqi dinars on a 1-for-1 basis, the government said. Those who hold Kuwaiti dinars have until Oct. 6 to exchange it for Iraqi currency, said the announcement, carried by state Iraqi News Agency. After that date, Kuwaiti dinars will be considered worthless, the Baghdad government said. Iraq has methodically dismantled Kuwaiti institutions following its Aug. 2 invasion and annexation of Kuwait. Iraqi authorities have officially disbanded Kuwait's government, military and national airline, and call Kuwait Iraq's 19th province. The currency measure was taken ``to facilitate transactions throughout Iraq and ending duality in the monetary dealing,'' the government said. Before Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ordered his army into Kuwait, one Iraqi dinar was worth $3.22 and one Kuwaiti dinar traded at $3.45 at official rates. But the Kuwaiti currency was convertible on international markets while the Iraq dinar was not. The Iraqi currency remains inconvertible. The decision was also expected to eliminate the black market for the Kuwaiti dinar. Although the Iraqi dinar's official value remains the same, its value to buy goods or foreign currency on the black market was about one-tenth the official rate. Iraq punishes currency smugglers with death. In the first days of the invasion, the Kuwaiti dinar fell from $3.45 to about one-fifth its value before international currency exchanges suspended trading of the Kuwaiti currency. ``No banks will accept to quote or trade either Iraqi or Kuwaiti dinars,'' a Banque Francaise du Commerce Exterieur official said Monday. That would be forbidden under the freeze on Kuwaiti and Iraqi assets adopted by France and the other European Community countries, the Paris-based official said in an interview. He said even if there were no economic embargo, no one would trade the Kuwaiti dinar because there is no longer any central bank to guarantee its value. Anyone with Kuwaiti dinars outside the country would effectively be holding useless paper, the banker said. There are exceptions in extremely limited circumstances. Kuwaitis stranded in London can go to the National Bank of Kuwait or United Bank of Kuwait and get British pounds for their dinars if they have dinar accounts there and can prove that they are in desperate need of funds, according to a financial source in Bahrain. The Banque Misr, or Bank of Egypt, in Cairo has not been instructed to stop accepting the Kuwaiti dinar, an official of the bank's foreign exchange department said. The currency was quoted in Monday's fixtures as usual, though at $2.86. When the crisis erupted, the Egyptian-Saudi Finance Bank allowed Kuwaitis to exchange 500 dinars at the old rate for two days. Any other funds had to be exchanged at the reduced rate. The practice appeared part of the exile aid program run by the Kuwaiti government, itself in exile in Saudi Arabia, the financial source in Bahrain said. Certain local banks may have been given a guarantee by Kuwaiti embassies allowing them to exchange dinars to needy Kuwaiti citizens, the source said. But it would be impossible for the Kuwaiti government-in-exile to honor all dinars, because Iraq could then try to convert the huge stocks of Kuwaiti cash its soldiers plundered during the invasion, the source noted. The fall of Kuwait made instant paupers out of tens of thousands of people with assets in Kuwait or Kuwaiti currency. H. Zahreddin, a wealthy Lebanese businessman doing business in Kuwait, flew home to Lebanon the day before Iraq overran Kuwait to throw a lavish wedding party for his daughter at a plush Beirut hotel. ``I went to bed a millionaire and woke up in debt,'' Zahreddin said later. ``The hotel refused to accept my Kuwaiti dinar check to settle the bill.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman Dies After Falling 18 Stories
DOC.TEXT: A woman who playfully asked her husband for a piggyback ride fell 18 stories to her death from a balcony after standing on a chair to climb on his back, authorities said Monday. The chair tipped and Cindy McNeely, 32, of Woodstock, Ga., went over the railing Saturday night at Sundestin Condominiums in this Florida Panhandle resort town, said Rick Hord, a spokesman for the Okaloosa County Sheriff's Department. Her death has been ruled an accident pending an autopsy, Hord said. He said investigators have no reason to doubt the account given by her husband, Richard McNeely, also 32, a certified public accountant. They had put their three children, girls 6 and 4 and an 18-month-old son, to bed before going out on the balcony, Hord said. After about 20 minutes they decided to go in. McNeely told investigators his wife then suggested that he carry her in on his back and climbed on the chair, Hord said.

DOC.HEAD: `The Civil War' Hits Big in Overnight Nielsen Ratings
DOC.TEXT: Ratings for ``The Civil War,'' the 11{-hour, landmark documentary playing this week on public television, were the highest for a series debut on the Public Broadecasting Service, PBS said Monday. The two-hour premiere, ``The Cause: 1861'' scored an average 9.0 rating and a 13 share in the A.C. Nielsen Co. overnight sample of 24 markets. In addition, the debut earned an 11.2 rating and 16 share in the top four markets. ``This is equivalent to an estimated national audience of 13.9 million people,'' PBS said. ``Any time PBS gets into double figures is very impressive,'' said John Marks, an analyst for the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency. He said the 24-market sample would be more representative of the series' nationwide average. ``Cosmos,'' PBS' previous top-rated debut, averaged a 9.1 rating and a 13 share in 1980, and was sampled only in the top four: New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and San Francisco, the public television network said. Each rating point equals 931,000 homes. A share is the percentage of television sets in use tuned to a show in its time period. ``The Civil War,'' by filmmaker Ken Burns, is being broadcast in 2{-hour seqments on consecutive nights through Thursday. The series will be rerun in January and July 1991, PBS said.

DOC.HEAD: Capital Has Treatment Slots For Less than 1 Percent of Drug Abusers
DOC.TEXT: The District of Columbia has room for less than 1 percent of its drug abusers in its comprehensive city-run treatment programs, according to a study released Monday. ``This study shows that the city has not waged a war on drugs,'' said Emanuel Chatman, an accounting professor at the University of the District of Columbia, who compiled the report with two fellow UDC professors. ``The city is woefully behind on the treatment end of the equation, and the commander in chief has not been in charge,'' Chatman said. The report - which also predicted that the city will set another homicide record this year - comes less than two months after Mayor Marion Barry was convicted of a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge. In the weeks following Barry's arrest on drug charges in January, the mayor enrolled in private substance abuse treatment centers in Florida and South Carolina. City officials have estimated that there are 76,000 drug abusers in the nation's capital. But there are only 460 beds available in city run drug-treatment centers, plus 700 more in post-recovery, or relapse, treatment centers, the study found. ``Given the number of drug addicts, the number of beds for detoxification is extremely small,'' said Ann Hughes, an urban studies professor who also worked on the 18-month survey of 37 city-run programs. The report also says that of the $500 million city officials say is being spent to fight drugs in the district, treatment programs receive just $10.3 million. ``It is clear that our priorities need to be reversed,'' said UDC political science professor Joseph Drew. ``Money for this should be considered from the other $490 million being spent in the war on drugs.'' The researchers predicted that if the current homicide rate continues, the city will have 471 murders in 1990, compared with 438 last year. Through Sept. 22 this year, the city had suffered 342 homicides, compared with 325 at the same time last year. Police blame drugs, particularly turf battles among crack cocaine dealers, for more than 60 percent of these killings. The study recommended that the city establish minimum standards for prevention and education and do a better job of publicizing available services. The report was based on unannounced visits paid to city drug clinics. ``We wanted to surprise them, to keep them from cleaning up their acts and getting ready for us,'' said Hughes. Annette Jones, who chairs the mayor's advisory committee on drug abuse, said Barry had reviewed and accepted the group's conclusions.

DOC.HEAD: White Supremacists Arrested After Burning Israeli Flag
DOC.TEXT: Two white supremacists who say the military buildup in the Persian Gulf is a scheme to protect Israel's interests were arrested for allegedly burning an Israeli flag, police said. Matt Hale and Steven Thornhill, both of East Peoria, were arrested Sunday for investigation of creating a bonfire on a public sidewalk. They were freed on $50 bond each and ordered to appear in Tazewell County Circuit Court on Oct. 18. Hale, 19, a Bradley University student who has tried to form a white supremacy group on the campus, contended the United States is using Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait to protect Israeli interests. ``We oppose white people dying for rich Jewish bankers,'' he said as a small group of protesters waved an American flag and shouted racist slogans. The two men and four other members of the American White Supremacist Party went to Pekin to demonstrate after they were told they'd be arrested in nearby Peoria if they burned Israel's flag there.

DOC.HEAD: Birds Shatter Windshields of B-1 Bomber
DOC.TEXT: A low-flying B-1 bomber struck three birds, cracking its two windshields and obscuring the crew's view so badly they had to be talked through a landing. The bomber, assigned to the 28th Bombardment Wing's 77th Bomb Squadron at Ellsworth, was flying 610 mph about 1,000 feet off the ground at night on Sept. 19 when it hit the birds over northern Montana. The plane's commander, Capt. Paul Dow, said Monday he assumes the birds were ducks. ``For September, we're starting to move into a heavy migratory period of migratory fowl,'' he said. After the impact last week, Dow took the craft up to 17,000 feet to make sure it didn't hit anything. Because of the many cracks in the layers of plastic, ``There really wasn't any way we could see out at all,'' Dow said. The impact also broke a utility light in the cockpit, causing sparks. Landing conditions at Ellsworth were bad because of rain and low clouds. The instructor pilot, Maj. Tom Owskey, had to take over the controls because he had the best view. Ground crews directed the landing by radio. The broken windscreens were ``reflecting three or four different runways,'' Owskey said. ``I basically had to be talked down - to the left or right of the center line - and I was maneuvering to make a safe approach.'' It was the first time the crew of four had flown together. ``They obviously did a great job, when you think what they had to handle,'' said wing commander Col. Ron Henderson. ``They were very calm throughout the entire emergency. Everybody was. ``It was a team effort on the ground, with a lot of people involved.''

DOC.HEAD: Torrential Rains Leave 45 Dead in Northern Mexico
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to raise death toll to 45, note that floods were flash floods; CORRECTS dateline to Chihuahua, sted Chihuahua City. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY31
DOC.TEXT: Rescue workers searched collapsed low-income homes Monday for more victims of flash floods that left at least 45 dead, the Red Cross said. At least 30 others were missing. ``There are still more dead,'' said Alfonso Magallanes Contreras, a Red Cross paramedic and rescuer. More than 5,000 people were left homeless by the weekend storm, the worst to hit the northwestern city in 90 years, authorities said. More than 5 inches of rain had fallen since Saturday, and the rain continued Monday. Gov. Fernando Baeza Melendez declared an emergency in and around Chihuahua, the state capital, which was hardest hit by the flash floods, which on Sunday thundered down gullies and a normally nearly dry river that cuts through the mountain city. ``This tragedy that brought mourning to many Chihuahua families will be a mark in history. But we will know how to act. We are going to provide all the help needed to those who have lost their homes,'' Baeza Melendez said. Rescue workers estimated about 240,000 people in the city of about 600,000 were virtually without water, power or telephones. Sewers in many areas were overflowing, posing health hazards. Baeza Melendez said that of the 45 victims, 32 had been identified. More than 350 homes were destroyed, and 1,000 more were damaged, Baeza Melendez said. ``Some homes disappeared completely by the floodwaters from one of the streams,'' Red Cross radio dispatcher Heriberto Perez said in a telephone interview. In the Colonia Villa neighborhood alone, on the north side of the city, more than 150 houses collapsed, a report from the governor's office said. About 300 automobiles and other vehicles were also wrecked by the flood. ``A state of alert has been declared, but everything is quiet,'' Perez said, adding that in some places, the water was between 3 feet to 9 feet deep.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Factory Explosion in Romania Kills Five
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with probable cause, new law asked, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A carbide oven exploded at a chemical plant in Transylvania on Monday, killing five people and injuring 10, state radio said. Two of the injured were reported in critical condition. Experts ruled out sabotage and said early findings indicated the explosion in Tirnaveni, 240 miles north of the capital, was probably caused by a mixture of air and carbon monoxide gases that collected near the furnace. The blast came as the furnace was being prepared for operation after five weeks of routine maintenance checks, the radio quoted sources at the plant as saying. It said damage could total $1 million. The government later called urgently for a law to form a special military corps to guard important industrial plants nationwide, the state news agency Rompres reported. However, the decision seemed to arise from increased pilfering at state-owned works. Government officials have indicated that the theft of spare parts or damage to plants during break-ins could lead to major industrial accidents like Monday's. The explosion was the third in wwo months at chemical plants in Transylvania, but a government statement said the number of industrial accidents was half of last year's.

DOC.HEAD: Angola To Allow Food Deliveries To The Hungry
DOC.TEXT: In what U.S. officials are describing as a breakthrough, the Angolan government has agreed to allow ``the prompt and efficient delivery'' of food supplies to tens of thousands of Angolans who face starvation because of drought. The Bush administration's expert on foreign disaster relief, Andrew Natsios, revealed Monday the Angolan commitment that had been made in a joint statement U.S. and Angolan officials agreed to last Wednesday. Angolan officials had snubbed Natsios in Luanda two weeks ago, but the leftist government apparently then underwent a change of heart. Last week, Natsios met with Angolan Gen. Antonio Dos Santos Ndalu at an undisclosed location and received assurances of the Angolan government's willingness to allow relief supplies under United Nations auspices to reach hungry Angolans both in government- and rebel-held territory. A civil war has raged in Angola since 1976, and the United States has provided aid to the UNITA rebel group since 1986. Natsios told reporters he saw the effects of the drought during a visit to the affected areas. At one location, he saw children who had eaten only two or three meals in a week. At another village, five children had had only mice to eat in the preceding days. He described the Angolan commitment as a breakthrough but said he would withhold further judgment until the plan is implemented. Angolan officials have said that 2 million people live in the drought-affected area. UNITA officials have indicated that the number of hungry Angolans could be 750,000. Natsios said a more precise estimate of the number of Angolans whose lives are at risk would have to await a report by a U.N. assessment team. The U.S.-Angolan statement said the two sides ``agreed on the need for prompt and efficient delivery of relief supplies to all affected populations in Angola. The U.S. side reiterated its commitment to join with other donors in the U.N.-led effort to provide the necessary assistance to Angola.'' Angola has been wary about outside food aid because of concern that the United States might try to use food shipments as a cover for weapons earmarked for anti-communist rebels. A U.S. official, insisting on anonymity, said the Angolan government may be showing flexibility on the humanitarian aid issue to influence pending congressional deliberations about future aid to UNITA. The Angolan government strongly opposes such aid. The communique also said the Angolan side advised the U.S. side that relief supplies would be allowed to enter Angola ``from neighboring states by the fastest and most efficient routes.'' The Namibian government has agreed to let food shipments be sent to Angola through its territory. Another possibility is deliveries through Zimbabwe, which has a food surplus, Natsios said.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Pastor Returns to Pulpit, Church Members Give Support
DOC.TEXT: A minister and two church members accused of trying to ``beat the devil'' out a depressed man have been convicted on false imprisonment charges. The Rev. James D. Price, pastor of the First Assembly of God Church, returned to the pulpit Sunday - two days after his conviction - cried and called his trial a ``time of storm.'' Price, 42, was convicted Friday by a State District Court jury in Hondo along with Robert L. Nixon Jr., 43, and Alvin R. Nixon, 32, who are brothers. All are from Devine, 30 miles southwest of San Antonio. They are to be sentenced Oct. 29. Evertt ``Ray'' Weimers, 44, also from Devine, testified the three restrained and beat him last January as part of a religious rite, scratching and bruising his face and separating his right shoulder. Dr. Ricardo Castillo, who treated Weimers, testified the victim was depressed and confided to Price about marital and financial problems. ``The preacher told him the reason he was feeling that way was that he had the devil in him and needed to be exorcised,'' Castillo said. ``Then the preacher went to get some more parishioners to beat it out of his system.'' During his sermon Sunday, Price said ``we hold nothing against anyone, the judge, Mr. Weimers, anyone.'' Several church members said they support their pastor. ``I haven't seen him (Price) do anything improper,'' said church member Mary Craig. The three face a maximum possible sentence of 10 years in prison and $5,000 fines. ``I don't think it will go that far. The judge was shocked,'' said Mrs. Craig. ``He couldn't understand why the verdict went that way.''

DOC.HEAD: Webster's Dictionary Among Books Challenged
With AM-Mapplethorpe Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: What do Dr. Seuss, Stephen King and the editors of Webster's dictionary have in common? Theirs are among the scores of books banned or challenged in the past year, the American Library Association said Monday in launching Banned Books Week. ``We need to bring to the attention of American public the fact that our First Amendment rights are under attack,'' said Judith Krug, director of the association's Office for Intellectual Freedom. A Webster's Dictionary edition was challenged in the Upper Pittsgrove Township, N.J., school district because parents objected to the definition of sexual intercourse as ``the sexual joining of two individuals,'' said Paul Whitman, secretary of the school board. The 1986 dictionary - an edition edited especially for teen-agers - was removed from fourth and fifth grade classrooms last fall, but continues to be used in upper levels, he said. Whitman said he didn't know what portion of the definition provoked the challenge. ``The Lorax'' by Dr. Seuss' was challenged in a Laytonville, Calif., school district last September. Parents working for a local logging company said the book portrayed their industry negatively. The book remained on the second-grade required reading list after the challenge, but teachers voluntarily moved it to an optional list the following spring, said Superintendent Brian Buckley. Stephen King's ``The Stand'' was restricted to ninth-grade students with parental consent at Whitford Intermediate School in Beaverton, Ore. after some parents objected to violence and sexual language. And another King novel, ``Christine,'' was pulled from the library at Washington Middle School in Meriden, Conn., after a parent complained about offensive passages. These are only a few of the incidents reported to the 51,000-member educational association between May 1989 and May 1990, Krug said, calling Banned Books Week ``a celebration of our freedom to read.'' The week runs through Sept. 29. It's part of a national effort to draw attention to the more than 1,000 instances of challenging or banning books reported last year, Krug said. ``Only 15 percent of censorship attempts ever reach the light of day,'' Krug said. ``We've proven time and time again that censorship dies in the light of day. We want to have the opportunity for the public to look at the issue from all sides.'' ``We're here to help librarians, teachers and other concerned citizens keep reading materials available to the public,'' she said. ``There's a lot of covert censorship going on.'' Krug said she advises librarians and teachers to set specific policies and procedures on censorship, but professionals aren't the only ones who should be involved in the issue. Concerned parents, she said, should make their views known at school board meetings or in letters to newspaper editors. ``As individual citizens we have to stand up and be counted,'' Krug said. ``We have to join the battle.''

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Missiles Had Fuel Leaks
DOC.TEXT: Nuclear test missiles sent to K.I. Sawyer Air Force Base were leaking jet fuel and posed the danger of explosion, according to a report to Congress. The report by the General Accounting Office says 10 of 25 test missiles delivered to the northern Michigan base developed fuel leaks. Seven were returned to the manufacturer for repair and three were repaired at Sawyer. The report said the Strategic Air Command ordered Sawyer to isolate the missiles from other weapons because of the potential for explosion. Sawyer officials refused Monday to comment on the report, referring questions to SAC leaders in Omaha, Neb. ``It's SAC's program. We haven't even seen the report,'' said Saywer spokeswoman Sgt. Anita Bailey. Program spokesman Capt. Harry Edwards at SAC headquarters' media affairs office in Omaha said he has never seen the GAO report and could not comment. In an appendix to the report, David J. Berteau, a principal deputy to the assistant Air Force secretary for production and logistics, said the leaks have been corrected with the development of new fuel bladders. The GAO report, which was finished in April and released in early September, maligns the Advanced Cruise Missile program as costly and unreliable. The missile, an updated version of the air launched cruise missile, can be armed with a nuclear warhead and uses ``stealth'' technology to evade radar detection. The main contractor for the missiles is General Dynamics Convair Division. The report says the Air Force may have wasted $50 million on the $424 million program, including $30 million spent on construction at an unspecified Air Force base that will no longer handle the missile. An Air Force response printed with the report defends the program, saying its reliability ``compares favorably to that of other cruise missiles at the same period of development.''

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in Hikers' Slayings Wanted on Murder Charge in Florida
DOC.TEXT: A man accused in the slayings of two Appalachian Trail hikers in Pennsylvania is wanted on a murder charge under another name in Florida, authorities said Monday. Pennsylvania authorities want David ``Casey'' Horn extradited to face charges in the Sept. 13 slayings of hikers Molly LaRue, 25, of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Geoffrey Logan Hood, 26, of Signal Mountain, Tenn. In Bartow, Fla., Horn is wanted under the name Paul David Crews on charges of first-degree murder, robbery and unlawful flight in the July 1986 stabbing death of a 56-year-old woman, said Bartow Detective Sgt. Robert Schott. ``He's been on the run for over four years,'' Schott said. Horn, 38, was being held without bon at the Eastern Regional Jail, said Berkeley County Corrections Officer Gary Reed. No date for an extradition hearing had been set. Horn still didn't have a lawyer, Reed said. Horn's fingerprints, photo and a tattoo on his shoulder match those of Crews, FBI spokesman Larry Curtin said from Tampa, Fla. FBI officials said agents in Lakeland, Fla., were tipped to his whereabouts by a newspaper story on the Appalachian Trail slayings. ``They said `that sounds very much like the way Paul Crews operated here,' '' Curtin said. Horn was arrested Friday by U.S. Parks Service rangers as he arrived in Harpers Ferry. Authorities said he was wearing one of the hiker's boots and carrying one of their backpacks. LaRue and Hood were hiking the 2,160-mile trail from Maine to Georgia. They were killed in their sleeping bags during a pre-dawn attack near Duncannon, Pa., a rural community about 10 miles north of Harrisburg. Authorities said Hood had been shot repeatedly and LaRue had been stabbed.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Start Anti-Government Mobilization
DOC.TEXT: The leftist Sandinista Front on Monday announced a new round of strikes to block the government's plans to sell state-owned companies and lay off civil servants. After a meeting Saturday of the 103-member Sandinista Assembly, the front said staggered, partial strikes would begin this week and build to nationwide demonstrations on Oct. 1. ``We are against the attitude of the government that is intent on imposing an economic plan that makes the rich richer and the poor poorer,'' the Sandinistas said in a communique. Public transportation employees were the only ones who walked out on Monday. Workers seized control of government bus depots and burned tires outside them, sending black plumes of smoke into the air. Only a few police were patrolling the depots. The government has been reluctant to try to call in the Sandinista-controlled police to restrain the strikes. The Sandinistas still control the army as well. Since losing elections in February, the Sandinistas have been intent on showing they can ``rule from below,'' in the words of former President Daniel Ortega. General strikes in May and July temporarily paralyzed the country with street marches and takeovers of state businesses and industries. After 10 years in power, the Sandinistas can quickly mobilize thousands to back their programs. The government coalition has no such grass-roots organization and as a result is blocked from carrying out programs the Sandinistas oppose.
