Government officials, business leaders and some independent trade unions met last week to work out a social pact to rescue Nicaragua's economy. On Monday, the currency was devalued for the 37th time since Mrs. Chamorro was inaugurated April 25. The official exchange rate of the cordoba fell from 1.12 million cordobas to the dollar to 1.18 million. Weekly devaluations are part of Mrs. Chamorro's effort to stabilize the economy. Her government also is attempting to decentralize the economy, reduce the fiscal deficit and increase production. Those goals entail laying off thousands of public employees, privatizing unproductive state enterprises and cutting off subsidies for public services. The Sandinistas haven't offered any alternative economic plan to the one Chamorro's government is following.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Exports Expected to Fall
DOC.TEXT: Farm commodity exports are expected to drop next year as foreign production competes with U.S. sales of grain and other products, the Agriculture Department said Monday. The department's Economic Research Service said a drop in corn exports in the fiscal year that will begin Oct. 1 will help lead the overall decline. ``U.S. corn exports are expected to fall 7 million tons (more than 275 million bushels) as overseas customers replace U.S. corn with competitors' feed wheat,'' the report said. ``Wheat prices are expected to average lower in 1990-91 due to larger crops. But higher soybean prices will help offset some of this decline,'' it said. Overall farm exports in the current year are estimated at about 148.5 million metric tons worth about $40 billion, both up slightly from 1988-89. The report didn't include any figures to show U.S. export values and volume in 1990-91. The department's first official export estimates for next year will be issued in late November.

DOC.HEAD: Bush: Palestine Issue No Distraction
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS grafs 3-7 bgng: ``The president,'' to give further quotes, particularly Palestinian ``legitimate rights'' sted self-determination paraphrase; INSERTS 14th graf: ``Department officials,'' no knowledge claimed of landing-for-hostages deal
DOC.TEXT: President Bush declared Monday ``I'm not going to be distracted'' by Iraq's Saddam Hussein's efforts to link the Persian Gulf crisis with the Israeli-Palestinian dispute. ``First we've got to take care of the situation that exists right now, naked aggression of one country against the other. That cannot be permitted to stand,'' Bush told a group of Arab-American leaders. The president said that the United States ``simply cannot'' link the Kuwaiti takeover by Iraq with the Palestinian issue. The Iraqi leader has suggested that one way to ease the crisis would be for Israel to withdraw from the Arab territories it has occupied since 1967, where many Palestinians live. The United States, Bush said, is committed to peace in the region, and ``once the Gulf crisis is on its way to resolution,'' wants to ``go forward with the peace process.'' Any ultimate solution, he said, must include recognition of Israel by Arab nations ``and legitimate political rights for the Palestinians.'' Bush, telling members of the audience that they understood the tensions in the region better than most people, said: ``To permit Saddam Hussein to link these two questions and approve of his aggression that way, we simply cannot do it. We are going to resist his attempts to justify what he did based on other regional concerns. So, I think these are merely, on his part, an effort to create additional pretexts so that he can stay in Kuwait.'' In a lively question-and-answer session, Bush was asked why the United States would not negotiate with Iraq. He answered with a description of U.S. policy. ``No negotiations,'' Bush said. U.S. policy, he continued, ``remains clear: Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait completely, immediately and without condition. Kuwait's legitimate government must be restored, the security and stability of the Persian Gulf assured and American citizens abroad must be protected.'' Asked why the United States was depriving the children of Iraq of food in the international trade embargo, Bush said that the Iraqi regime would not permit relief organizations to send in supervised food shipments. ``I am much less interested in feeding Saddam Hussein's army at this point,'' Bush said. He said he was concerned about the plight of women and children, including Asian refugees stranded in Kuwait. The State Department, meanwhile, said at least 900 American men, women and children remain trapped in Kuwait and Iraq, and 93 have been detained by Iraq authorities. Some of those detained are ill, and their captivity is ``barbaric,'' said the department's principal spokeswoman, Margaret Tutwiler. Iraq has said it is putting American men in strategic installations to deter attacks. Department officials said they had no knowledge of a claim by Iraq that the United States rebuffed an offer to release the captive Americans in exchange for permission for the Iraqi foreign minister to land in New York in an Iraqi plane to attend United Nations meetings. The department has refused landing permission, saying the official could take a commercial flight. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater characterized Saddam's new threat to blow up oil fields in the Middle East part of ``a daily diatribe from Saddam.'' ``We won't get into responding every day to Saddam's statements,'' he said. Bush was grilled by the audience, made up of 150 Arab-American business executives and others, on U.S. policy in the Middle East. Despite the tough questioning, he received a standing ovation at the end of the 20-minute session. Bush spoke out forcefully about discrimination against Arab-Americans and what he called ``appalling acts of hatred'' by ``a few hatemongers.'' ``It is simply not fair to lump the outrageous behavior of a dictator halfway around the world into how people are treated here at home,'' he said. Bush defended America's de facto alliance with Syrian President Hafez Assad, whose country is officially called a sponsor of terrorism by the United States. To a Lebanese-American man who objected sharply to the partnership, Bush said: ``Out of this, there could well be a new world order and part of this must be a peaceful resolution of the division of Lebanon.'' On Saddam's calls for Israel to give up its occupied territory, Bush said: ``I'm not going to be distracted by this.'' A Arab-American car dealer from Detroit told Bush he had his own peace plan to pressure both Iraq and Israeli to give up occupied lands. ``The Kuwait crisis must be taken care of first,'' Bush said. Bush stayed twice as long as planned after he began taking questions. Participants were waving their hands for recognition even before he concluded his prepared remarks. One man commented that a billion Moslems live under tyrannical monarchs and asked why the United States was trying to restore the emir of Kuwait, Bush said crisply, ``The objective is to see that naked aggression does not pay off, sir.''

DOC.HEAD: Autumn Reaches Southeast With Record Lows
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures dropped to record lows Monday across the Southeast, normally milder at this time of year, while at least one record high was posted on the northern Plains. Record lows were 56 at Apalachicola, Fla.; 45 at Atlanta; 41 at Birmingham, Ala.; 42 at Greenville, S.C.; 53 at Jacksonville, Fla.; 43 at Meridian, Miss.; 50 at Mobile, Ala.; 46 at Monroe, La.; 65 at Orlando, Fla.; and 46 at Shreveport, La. Daytona Beach, Fla., tied its record of 62 and Montgomery, Ala., tied its record of 47. A frost warning was posted overnight over western Maryland's Garrett County. At the opposite extreme, Rapid City, on the edge of the Black Hills in western South Dakota, warmed to a record high of 89, one degree above the previous record set three years ago. Afternoon rain and occasional thundershowers extended only over southern Florida, western Texas, northern Maine, and from southwestern Oregon into northern California. Some Texas streams continued running high after heavy weekend rain. A few rural roads in southwestern Texas were blocked by high water, the National Weather Service said. Flood warnings were posted along the Rio Grande from Presidio, Texas, through Big Bend National Park to near Langtry, Texas, the weather service said. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 33 at Falls City, Neb., and West Yellowstone, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 47 at Massena, N.Y., to 95 at Yuma, Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: South Dakota Governor Asks For Wounded Knee Memorial
DOC.TEXT: South Dakota Gov. George Mickelson asked Bush administration officials Monday to designate Wounded Knee a national monument before the end of this year, the 100th anniversary of the massacre there. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan did not indicate a position on the request during a meeting with Mickelson but his aides were ``favorably disposed,'' the governor said later. ``What I asked (Lujan) to do was to support the idea of the president by executive order creating a national monument at Wounded Knee,'' Mickelson said. ``My purpose in being here today was to express the urgency of it ... It would be the culmination of a great year.'' The National Park Service, however, must first study the site to see whether the monument designation would be suitable and feasible, said Ben Moffett, a park service spokesman in Denver. ``We wouldn't do that (conduct a study) until Congress asked us to do it and provided funding for it,'' Moffett said. Mickelson, who designated 1990 the Year of Reconciliation in South Dakota, will testify Tuesday at a Senate Indian Affairs Committee hearing where descendants of Wounded Knee victims will ask for an apology and reparations from the government as well as a national monument. Mickelson said Monday that he did not support legislation seeking the apology and compensation because he feared those issues would slow down the effort to get the site designated a national monument. Federal troops killed 300 Sioux warriors, women and children in 1890 on the Pine Ridge Reservation in southwestern South Dakota in the last major battle between Indians and the army on the northern plains. Mickelson, who is chairman of the Western Governors Association, also met White House representatives and officials from the Energy Department and Environmental Protection Agency to express concerns about waste disposal in western states. ``The message I'm going to convey is that they need to appreciate that we in the West are willing to share our share of the responsibility, but we have no intention of accepting waste from all over this nation where they have not done a good job of protecting their environment,'' Mickelson said.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Whose License Lapsed Says He's in `Driver's Seat'
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate John G. Rowland, who drove without a license for 16 months, is using humor to respond to revelations about the lapse. Rowland showed up at a recent news conference sporting a lapel badge that said ``I'm in the driver's seat.'' His staffers wore badges identifying themselves as Rowland drivers. Rowland last week acknowledged that he had been driving without a license since it expired in May 1989. His excuse was that he had never received a renewal notice. ``I don't think it's a big deal,'' Rowland said. ``It's an honest mistake. I think people understand it's human nature. It has nothing to do with the governor's race.'' Rowland said he renewed his license and joked that he also checked his auto emissions stickers, the dog license and his children's vaccinations. ``Everything is in order,'' he promised.
DOC.HEAD: Arizona Poll Shows Democrat Goddard Leading GOP Rival
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Terry Goddard is leading Republican Fife Symington in the Arizona governor's race by a margin of 49 percent to 32 percent, according to a survey of registered voters. Four percent of respondents said they planned to vote for someone other than Goddard or Symington, and 15 percent were undecided, according to the survey conducted by The Arizona Republic. GOP incumbent Rose Mofford is not running. For the survey, 601 registered voters throughout the state were interviewed by telephone Sept. 13-16. The margin of error was plus or minus 4 percentage points. Symington, a developer making his first run for public office, said he was not surprised to find himself behind. ``I think it's about right because Terry has better name (identification),'' said Symington, who won a five-way GOP primary. ``When I announced my intentions to run for governor, all the political pundits said Fife Symington had no chance to win. Well, look what happened. Now, it's Round 2,'' he said. Goddard, the former Phoenix mayor who swept to an easy victory in the two-man Democratic primary, said, ``I don't get either overjoyed or displeased over polls, but this one is pretty nice. ... I always run like I'm behind, and that's what I'm doing right now.''
DOC.HEAD: Richards' Former Rival Offers Advice on How to Beat Williams
DOC.TEXT: Texas Attorney General Jim Mattox believes he has some winning advice for Ann Richards, who defeated him in a bruising battle for the state's Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Richard ``needs to cause the voters to laugh at Clayton Williams and not laugh with Clayton Williams,'' Mattox said of Richards' Republican rival. ``We've allowed him to be just a good-natured, old country boy that in effect hides the real Clayton Williams,'' Mattox said Monday. Mattox said there is still time before the Nov. 6 general election for Richards to reverse Williams' double-digit lead in the polls. ``She needs to have leaders in the business community to come out and tell the public how regretful it would be to have Clayton Williams as the spokesperson and symbol for Texas,'' Mattox said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Hears Appeals For Restrictions On Diet Pills
DOC.TEXT: A couple whose daughter died after years of diet pill abuse asked a congressional panel Monday to push for restrictions on non-prescription weight loss drugs. ``She might have had a chance had these products been denied her as a child,'' said Anthony and Diana Smith, of State Center, Iowa. Noelle Smith, 20, died a year ago of cardiac arrest after struggling since she was 14 with the eating disorder anorexia nervosa, which is an avoidance of food, and bulimia, which involves binging and purging. ``She was constantly sneaking diet products into the house,'' said Mr. Smith. ``Every time we found and took from Noelle a box of diet pills, laxatives or diuretics, she would go to the corner store and buy a new supply.'' Jessica McDonald, 20, of Washington, D.C., said she suffered from the same eating disorders as a teen-ager and regularly consumed whole boxes of non-prescription diet pills at a time. ``Even though I went to the drug store practically every day to buy pills or some other product to help me lose weight, no one ever tried to stop me or asked what I wanted the pills for,'' said McDonald. She said that ``at the very least there should be an age restriction to prevent young people from buying these drugs.'' Vivian Hanson Meehan, president of the National Association of Anorexia Nervosa and Associated Disorders, said at least one of 10 adolescents engage in dangerous eating disorders as they try to diet. ``The adolescent whoreduces food amounts to starvation levels is playing havoc with his or her body's viability,'' said Meehan. ``Children who begin dieting at an early age may delay or prevent menstruation because females need 18 to 22 percent of body fat for this purpose.'' Meehan also decried the availability of diet pills. ``Diet pills containing the drug phenylpropanolamine, or PPA, pose an additional and very serious health risk to adolescents,'' she said. The drug is in most of the numerous, popular non-prescription diet products used by about 10 million consumers a year. Many medical authorities say it can cause high blood pressure, kidney disease, heart muscle damage, heart rhythm abnormalities and seizures. The Smiths, McDonald and Meehan were among witnesses testifying before the House Small Business subcommittee, which has been investigating the weight loss industry. A report from the subcommittee staff noted a University of San Francisco study of 500 girls which showed almost half the 9-year-olds and 80 percent of those age 10 and 11 were dieting, even though just 17 percent of the group was overweight. ``Our investigation found that juveniles are dieting more obsessively than ever, and that many are suffering adverse health effects and even death,'' said the staff report. Chairman Ron Wyden, D-Oregon, has been after the Federal Trade Commission and the Food and Drug Administration to crack down on shady diet practices. He said the FTC has 14 investigations under way of diet companies and diet programs. But he criticized the FDA for being lax on enforcement. ``For almost a decade, the FDA has dawdled over regulations that would make it illegal to sell diet products containing about 100 ineffective ingredients,'' said Wyden.

DOC.HEAD: Sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg Term Khrushchev Remarks `Absurd'
DOC.TEXT: The sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg said Monday their parents didn't help the Soviet Union develop an atomic bomb, and dismissed Nikita Khrushchev's memoirs thanking them as ``totally absurd.'' Robert and Michael Meeropol, who have worked for years to clear their parents' names, said they weren't shaken by the remarks by the ousted Soviet leader, contained in tapes he made during seven years of house arrest before his death in 1971. ``This stuff has been going on all the time,'' said 47-year-old Michael Meeropol, a professor at a small private college here. ``I'll tell you what the big shock was, the first shock when I was 7 years old listening to `The Lone Ranger' when the FBI arrested my father. After that, you know, shocks don't happen to us. We expect them.'' Khrushchev says in the memoirs that he heard from both Soviet leader Josef Stalin and Vyacheslav Molotov, then minister of foreign affairs, that the Rosenbergs ``provided very significant help in accelerating the production of our atom bomb.'' ``Let this be a worthy tribute to the memory of those people,'' he said. ``My reaction to (the implication of help) is that it's wholly absurd,'' said 43-year-old Robert Meeropol, a local lawyer. The Rosenbergs, who maintained their innocence, were executed June 19, 1953, for conspiracy to commit espionage. Their sons, who took their adoptive parents' last name, have used the Freedom of Information Act to force the release of hundreds of thousands of pages of classified documents in the case. They said their research of their parents' trial and execution turned up affidavits by scientists who said none of the evidence brought by the government amounted to substantially useful information about the atomic bomb. ``One of the things that we have discovered both in talking to scientists and securing affidavits and looking through the FBI files is that there were no major secrets,'' Robert Meeropol said, noting that his parents were convicted on conspiracy charges rather than direct espionage. ``We know from looking at all this that if there was any help, and I deny that there was, it was insignificant, so anything like this where someone is reporting that significant help was given just doesn't make sense in terms of the record,'' he said. The brothers said Khrushchev may have misunderstood Stalin or Stalin may have been lying to create the impression of having a huge network of spies. They also suggested that ``significant help'' could be interpreted as the Rosenbergs' refusal to implicate others. Washington author Michael Beschloss, who is working on a book about Khrushchev, said Khrushchev's earlier oral histories have held up well, but it is difficult to gauge the merit of the Rosenberg comments because the Soviet leader was old, ailing and didn't have his records when he made them. ``Although this is an important piece of evidence, it certainly is not a smoking gun,'' he said. ``We want to get all the facts out,'' Robert Meeropol said. ``I am convinced that when that's done that we'll discover that what Khrushchev said is either wrong or untrue.''

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Kills 3 at University in Dominican Republic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with third person dead, identities of victims, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded while it was being manufactured in the offices of a leftist student group at the state university, killing three students and wounding two, police said Monday. The blast Sunday night destroyed the offices of the National Union of Revolutionary Students. Police said they found gunpowder and other explosives there. Maj. Gen. Ramon Mota Paulino, chief of national police, said a preliminary investigation indicated the students intended to plant bombs in supermarkets and other businesses in this Caribbean nation of 7 million people. He said the bombings were to coincide with the scheduled start Tuesday of a three-day strike to protest a government austerity program which sent the prices of many basic consumer items soaring in August. No immediate comment came from officials of the student organization. However, Ramon Almanzar, spokesman for the strike organizers, said the strike was planned as an orderly protest and disassociated his group from any terrorist activity. Police identified those killed as Pedro Ovidio Garcia, 30, a veterinary student; Eduardo Antonion Marmol, 24, a law student; and journalism student Hallanay Defrank.

DOC.HEAD: Baltimore Red Cross Opens Center For Tracing Holocaust And War Victims
DOC.TEXT: A center devoted to tracing the fates of people held in Nazi concentration camps opened here Monday to handle flood a requests expected now that the Soviet Union has released records on 400,000 prisoners. The Holocaust and War Victims Tracing and Information Center, run by the American Red Cross, offers hope to people still wondering about their loved ones 45 years after the end of World War II. The latest documents, which were recovered by Soviet soldiers when the camps were liberated at the end of the war, include nearly 70,000 death certificates from the Auschwitz concentration camp in Poland. Also included are the names of 130,000 prisoners forced to work in Germany and 200,000 names of victims in other camps, including Dachau, Sachsenhausen, Gross Rosen and Buchenwald. ``It offers the opportunity for closure - to allow people to finally say `Now, I know what happened,''' said Emmy Hubert Mogilensky, a 67-year-oldPikesville, Md., woman who learned that her parents died in a concentration camp from a message the Red Cross sent her brother in 1946. ``The pain of not knowing where they were. If they were murdered in the camp. Did they die in the cattle cars on the way to the camp? It haunts you. It does not let you rest,'' Mogilensky said. She sympathized with people still searching for answers. ``Can you doubt the value of these 400,000 records? Can you imagine after 45 years still wondering, still not knowing?'' she asked. ``Each one of these records could be a blessing.'' Millions of people, mostly Jews, were imprisoned during Adolf Hitler's Third Reich and an estimated 6 million Jews were killed. Western allies released concentration camp documents soon after the war. But Soviet authorities kept the records sealed, despite repeated requests. Finally, the Soviet government began releasing them last year. Since the end of the war, available documents have been stored at the International Tracing Service in Arolsen, West Germany, a branch of the Central Tracing Agency of the International Committee of the Red Cross. There are 46 million documents on file on about 13 million people. ``When I viewed a room filled with 46 million index cards, I knew that the scope of our mission was beyond anything imaginable,'' said Alfred Himmelrick Jr., a 57-year-old Baltimore businessman who visited the Arolsen center while planning the Baltimore office. ``These people, their children, their brothers, their sisters, their cousins, aunts and uncles were no longer able to give voice to say, `Here I am.' It was then that the 13 million people on file became real, not abstract,'' he said. The Arolsen center has helped 1.8 million people find information about missing relatives. People wishing to learn the fate of relatives or friends can contact local American Red Cross chapters. Local caseworkers will send the requests to the Baltimore center, where they will be translated into German and forwarded to Arolsen.

DOC.HEAD: 18 Children Among 20 to Drown in Boating Accident in Argentina
DOC.TEXT: Eighteen children and two adults drowned after their boat capsized in a pond near this northwest Argentine city, according to news reports Monday. Police said 20 children and two adults were on board the craft Sunday when it began to take on water. Everyone crowded to the other side but the boat tipped over, the authorities said. Some of the victims were trapped under the boat and most of the others apparently did not know how to swim. Two children were rescued when they grabbed inner tubes from tires thrown from shore, local news agencies reported.

DOC.HEAD: Government Files Reverse Discrimination Suit Against Maryland Lottery
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department filed an unusual reverse discrimination lawsuit Monday, accusing the Maryland lottery of bias against white men in 1983 when it set aside several top positions for women and minorities. The civil rights suit alleged that Maryland and its lottery agency violated Title VII of the 1964 Civil Rights Act by refusing to hire qualified white males for the four positions set aside for minorities in 1983. The lawsuit was denounced by a state official as an unwarranted attack on a one-time effort by Maryland to recruit more minorities into the lottery agency. Two black men, a black woman and a white women were recruited ``in response to a Maryland Human Relations Commission investigation and determination that the lottery agency was not doing enough to meet affirmative action requirements,'' said Dennis Sweeney, deputy state attorney general. The lawsuit states that the state's governor, then Harry R. Hughes, directed the lottery agency to set aside four senior-level positions for women or members of a racial minority. The hiring policy was investigated by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which referred complaints of discrimination to the Justice Department, according to the complaint filed in federal court in Baltimore. Ten white men complained to the EEOC in 1985, said Justice Department spokeswoman Amy Casner. The EEOC referred the case to the Justice Department in 1988, she said. The lottery agency, which employs 108 people, has 12 senior-level positions, she said. The suit seeks an injunction barring the state of Maryland from reserving lottery agency positions for women or members of a minority. It also seeks compensation for white men who were the victims of the alleged discrimination. Sweeney said the Justice Department has rejected overtures to settle the case out of court, but federal officials were insistent on obtaining a consent decree. ``We don't see the profit in going to this archaeological dig of attempting to reconstruct this event in 1983,'' Sweeney said. ``All the actors are all now either dead or retired from state government.'' ``We are hoping we can still talk about these issues and reason will prevail because, quite frankly, I think the federal courts have more important things to do,'' he said. Justice Department officials have sought back pay of less than $15,000 for two men who were not hired, Sweeney said. Reverse discrimination lawsuits are unusual, but the Justice Department has filed them in the past when it determines that whites have been the victims of racial bias.

DOC.HEAD: Rally Sends Off Trucks Bound for Iraq With Food
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final four grafs after graf 16 bgng `The Palestinian' to ADD two grafs with comment from taxi driver, DELETES anonymous quote. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A convoy of trucks loaded with food rolled out of Amman on Monday bound for Baghdad with horns honking, flags flying and hundreds of Jordanians cheering the violation of the U.N. embargo. The 30 trucks, hauling rice, powdered milk and other foodstuffs rationed in Iraq, were decorated with red, green and black Jordanian and Iraqi flags. Banners declared the food a gift ``from the Stone Children, the Heros of the Intifadeh in Palestine to the Children of Iraq.'' The convoy was a small but clear violation of the U.N. embargo banning shipments to Iraq unless cleared by the Security Council, and a symbol of the enthusiastic support Iraq enjoys here. Many in the crowd were of Palestinian origin - like about half of Jordan's 3 million residents - and had donated food and money and brought their children to the late afternoon rally. Posters showing Iraqi President Saddam Hussein being kissed by a brown-haired boy while hugging a wide-eyed girl were among the dozens of pro-Saddam, anti-American signs, banners and leaflets in the crowd. ``We are for any Arab child and any Arab regime which is against the Americans. We're with him because he's against the United States, that's all,'' said Mona Bitar, who brought her five daughters to the rally. ``I am teaching my children that Arabs should be unified.'' Mrs. Bitar said that on a daughter's birthday a week ago, she asked all the children to bring a bag of rice for the children of Iraq instead of a present. They all complied. Outspoken popular support for Saddam in Jordan - whose King Hussein has been a U.S. ally - has mystified and infuriated the United States. But here, across the Jordan River from the West Bank, it seems perfectly logical. Palestinians see Saddam as the only man standing up unequivocally for their cause, which they feel has been ignored by the rest of the world. They are angered by the United States insisting on U.N. resolutions demanding Iraq withdraw from Kuwait while failing to insist that Israel end its occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip and give up its claim to Jerusalem, as required under older U.N. resolutions. ``I think Saddam Hussein is a hero in a way. He is an Arab leader fighting for Arab rights,'' said a woman in the crowd who declined to give her name. One popular poster carried by member of the crowd depicted the troika of Saddam, King Hussein and Yasser Arafat, chief of the Palestine Liberation Organization. ``The poster speaks for itself,'' said the father of 8-year-old Mutaz Khalil, who let go of one corner of the poster, pulled on his father's pant leg and said something softly in Arabic. ``He's saying he's against the Jews,'' the father explained. ``Of course he is, he's Palestinian.'' The Palestinians see American support of Israel as the reason for their stateless status and misery. Taxi driver Mortagi Farhan, watching the rally from the roadside Monday, said he sided with the activists and the intefadeh uprising. ``My uncle was killed by Israelis. Two friends were killed in Israel and six cousins are in jail. Saddam is now the No. 1 leader standing up for the Arab cause. We will support him to the end.'' Many Jordanians privately say they do not approve of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait but they worry about the Western-led military buildup in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Northern Ireland Extremists Kill Wrong Man In Pub
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 5 `Hours earlier' to ADD victim's name. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Police said...'
DOC.TEXT: An illegal Protestant paramilitary group said Monday it had killed the wrong man a day earlier in a pub shooting. The Ulster Freedom Fighters apologized to the family of 48-year-old construction worker William Allister, saying they had intended to kill a man they believe is a police informer. A friend of Allister's who was injured in the shooting in Lisburn, southwest of Belfast, was also not the intended target of the group. The man was in critical condition in a Lisburn hospital. The shooting occurred Sunday evening when at least one gunman burst into the County Down Arms, singled out the two men and opened fire on them, police said. Hours earlier, masked men shot and killed Colin McCullough, a 22-year-old part-time soldier parked in a car with his girlfriend at Lough Neagh near Lurgan, about 25 miles southwest of Belfast, the Royal Ulster Constabulary said. Police said the woman was not hurt. Suspicion fell on the Irish Republican Army, which has targeted the security forces in its fight to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the mainly Protestant province with the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republic. The soldier was the seventh member of the locally recruited Ulster Defense Regiment to die in Northern Ireland this year. He and the pub patron were the 41st and 42nd victims of political and sectarian strife in the province this year.

DOC.HEAD: Olympic-Crazy Georgians Celebrate With First Ticker-Tape Parade
DOC.TEXT: At least 300,000 Olympic-crazy Georgians waged a friendly confetti war Monday in downtown Atlanta as the city staged its first ticker tape parade to celebrate landing the 1996 Summr Games. The parade-goers showered 34 tons of shredded paper on the heads of the boosters who persuaded the International Olympic Committee to give the games to the city. The decision was announced at a meeting last week in Tokyo. ``I got Andy Young good,'' said Debra Jackson, 29, of Atlanta, after she hurled a handful of confetti at the face of the former mayor, who rode in a convertible. The crowds, 10 deep along some sections of the parade route, cheered as Young and other leaders of the city's Olympic committee rode past and marching bands belted out the Olympic theme song. Police estimated at least 300,000 people showed up for the event. The three local TV network affiliates carried the parade live, and The Atlanta Journal slapped a huge banner headline on its front page that read: ``WELL DONE!'' Police said they arrested at least six juveniles for creating disturbances after the parade. Maj. W.W. Holley said the disturbances were caused by groups of youths from rival schools. Students in the area were allowed to miss a day of school if they had their parents' permission. Vendors set up booths along the parade route, selling Olympic T-shirts, red-and-white Olympic flags and bumper stickers that read: ``Great Job Andy and Billy.'' The stickers referred to Young and Atlanta Organizing Committee president Billy Payne. ``It's so exciting,'' said 24-year-old Traci Hodge, who took the day off from work without telling her boss. ``The fact that we got the Olympics is incredible.'' Local historians said it was the city's first ticker tape parade, and many children along the parade route watched in awe as an estimated 34 tons of confetti and 100 miles of ticker tape rained down upon them. ``It's like it's snowing or something,'' said 8-year-old Donta Hayman of Atlanta. Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., played with the children along the route, jumping out of his parade car and hurling confetti back at them. Among other dignitaries riding in the parade were Gov. Joe Frank Harris, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., and 85-year-old Fred Alderman, Georgia's oldest Olympian. Afterward, confetti blanketed two downtown streets and was piled several inches deep in places. ``Everybody needs to get a broom and get to it,'' said Linda Slach, 35,. ``I've done my part in the cleanup. I picked some confetti up and threw it back out again.'' Within minutes after the parade ended, city employees were out starting the cleanup. But Cedric Maddox, director of the city sanitation department, said it would take awhile because confetti is difficult to pick up. ``Hopefully, we'll be through by the morning,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Journal: AmEx Officials Were Behind Smear Campaign of Swiss Banker
DOC.TEXT: An American Express Co. executive orchestrated a smear campaign against a Swiss banker at odds with the financial services giant, The Wall Street Journal reported Monday. Harry L. Freeman, then an executive vice president with close ties to company chairman James D. Robinson III, approved the hiring of a private detective and a public relations executive who investigated Swiss banker Edmond J. Safra and spread rumors about him, the Journal said. ``Company officials privately blamed the incident on a handful of unnamed low-level employees,'' the newspaper said. ``But a lengthy investigation by this newspaper reveals evidence suggesting the effort to smear Mr. Safra was in fact overseen from Mr. Freeman's office, only steps away from Mr. Robinson's.'' False news stories about Safra began to surface in early 1988, linking him to drug dealers, money laundering and the Mafia, the Journal said. The newspaper said there was no concrete evidence that Robinson knew of the campaign against Safra, although the American Express chairman had regular contact with one of Freeman's operatives, Susan Cantor. Last year, American Express publicly apologized to Safra, admitting that people acting on its behalf had tried to discredit him. American Express paid $8 million to charities of Safra's choice to make amends. Freeman later retired from the company, accepting responsibility for ``mistakes made on my watch.'' Larry Armour, an American Express spokesman, said Monday ``it's senseless to respond to old news, no matter how colorfully someone chooses to repackage it.'' The Journal said American Express and Safra began to fall out soon after Robinson decided in 1983 to buy Safra's Geneva-based Trade Development Bank and combine it with American Express Bank. The styles of the two men differed sharply, and in 1984 Safra resigned from the company. The split between Safra and Robinson deepened during negotiations on a settlement package, and matters grew worse as American Express Bank officials began to suspect that Safra, who was planning to begin another Swiss bank in 1988, was hiring away American Express employees, the Journal said. Robert Smith, former chairman of American Express Bank, told the Journal he told Robinson he had hired detectives to follow the former American Express workers. Smith said he became obsessed with stopping Safra, the newspaper said. His anger spread to other company officials, especially Freeman, it said. The company tried in vain to block Safra's attempt to get a new banking license in Switzerland in 1987, the newspaper said. The next year, after Safra opened his new bank, reports appeared in newspapers in Europe and South America linking Safra to the Mafia, now-deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega, South American drug traffickers, the CIA and the Iran-Contra scandal. During the course of a libel suit Safra filed against a French newspaper, Minute, a lawyer for Safra found that a Life magazine article about the Mafia had been faxed to Minute from American Express headquarters in New York, the Journal said. Safra's investigators eventually pegged Antonio Greco, an elusive businessman with homes in Spain and New York City, as the source of the articles. Greco was an investigator working for American Express, the Journal said. He also had an arrest record in the United States and Italy going back to 1962, and had been convicted on charges including theft, conspiracy and handling stolen goods, the newspaper said. The Journal said Greco's link at American Express was Susan Cantor, now a senior vice president at American Express Bank and before that an employee in the American Express public relations office, working under Harry Freeman, the Journal said. Freeman was convinced that Safra wanted to destroy American Express Bank and had been collecting rumors about him, the Journal said. At first, Freeman used Ms. Cantor, a former ABC News employee, to gather information on Safra but her task evolved to spreading rumors and negative news stories about him, the newspaper said. In a statement to the Journal, Ms. Cantor said she ``never intended or sought to disseminate false information concerning Edmond Safra to anyone, and I never instructed, asked or engaged anyone to spread such information.'' The Journal said it interviewed dozens of people for the story including private detectives and 15 current and former American Express executives.

DOC.HEAD: Jane Pauley Gets New Contract, Mid-Season Series
DOC.TEXT: Jane Pauley, enjoying life in prime time since leaving 13 years of pre-dawn wakeups on ``Today,'' is assured of a new midseason series and a new five-year contract, NBC said Monday. The series' title, ``Real Life With Jane Pauley,'' also was the title of five Pauley specials broadcast in prime time this summer. All did well in the ratings, averaging a 21 percent share of the audience, NBC said. Terms of her new contract weren't disclosed. Pauley, who turns 40 on Oct. 31, left ``Today'' in December after a series of changes and turmoil there led to her departure. She was succeeded as co-anchor by Deborah Norville. Pauley's series and new contract were announced earlier Monday to NBC News staffers in a memo from NBC News president Michael Gartner. The memo also contained potentially bad news for perhaps as many as 25 employees. In it, Gartner said there will be an increase - no number was specified - in the news division's work force and some employees shifted to ``new shows.'' However, he warned, ``others whose skills don't match those needed for the new shows or for any show, perhaps as many as 25, may be laid off.''

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Hussein's TV Message To US Expected To Arrive Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's videotaped message to the American people will be released sometime Tuesday morning, CBS News said Monday. The Iraqi Embassy in Washington said it will turn the tape over to CBS News, which will serve as a distribution pool, CBS said. CBS said it had not yet received the tape, but expected it to be delivered Tuesday morning. Saddam's speech is believed to be a rebuttal to Bush's message to the Iraqi people, which was shown on Iraq's state-controlled TV on Sept. 16. The Bush administration has refused to offer any guidance to the networks about airing the Saddam speech, but Bush on Friday ridiculed Saddam's request for 30 minutes of air time to address the American people. ``That would just finish him off in the United States. I don't know about the rest of the world. Nobody could stay awake.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Destroys Palestinian Homes to Punish Suspected Killers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Two grafs SUB for 4th graf `The army' to UPDATE with army communique. Picks up 5th graf, `Reserve Sgt.'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli army bulldozers razed shops and houses on Monday to punish Palestinians suspected of killing a soldier in a Gaza Strip refugee camp, Arab reports and U.N. officials said. A dozen buildings were destroyed before a Supreme Court restraining order halted demolition, they said, including the gas station where the soldier was stoned to death. Farayeh Abu Meddin, chairman of the Gaza bar association, said army bulldozers leveled at least six shops Monday night. An official with the U.N. Relief and Works Agency, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said five houses and one shop were torn down earlier in the day. An army spokesman issued a statement saying Defense Minister Moshe Arens had approved proposals from the General Staff to ``widen the area for security and military reasons.'' ``The state and military prosecutor will on Tuesday seek cancellation of the restraining order,'' it added. Reserve Sgt. Amnon Pomeranz, 46, was stoned to death in the Bureij refugee camp Thursday after his car hit a donkey cart, injuring two Palestinian teen-agers. The Palestinian mob set his car and body afire with gasoline-soaked rags. Bureij residents said the bulldozers came in under protection from scores of soldiers. They said generators were used to provide light after electricity to the camp was cut. A retaining wall at the camp entrance also was demolished, they said. The U.N. official said about 20 shops had been cleared of furniture and goods in anticipation of the destruction. Supreme Court Judge Theodore Orr issued the temporary restraining order in Jerusalem at the request of the Association for Civil Rights in Israel. The association's legal adviser, Joshua Schoffman, said Orr ruled that Bureij residents should be given time to petition the military governor of Gaza and the Supreme Court regarding the demolition orders. Shimon Peres, leader of the opposition Labor Party, told Israel TV, ``Gaza is a collective punishment to Israel and, if we carry out collective punishments in Gaza, it won't make things easier for Israel. We have to decide what will happen to Gaza in the future.'' Israeli newspaper reports said the government also was considering deporting Palestinians suspected of involvement in the slaying. The Bureij camp, home to 20,000 Palestinians, was under curfew Monday for the fifth day while soldiers searched the area for suspects. In Nusseirat camp, across the highway from Bureij, people waited in fear that soldiers would enter to search for men who fled Bureij. Newly painted graffiti declared Nusseirat's solidarity with Bureij. ``Salute and praise our heroic camp El Bureij,'' said one slogan, signed by the Palestine Liberation Organization-backed leaders of the Palestinian uprising. Pomeranz was the 12th Israeli soldier killed since the uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip began in December 1987. Forty-eight Israelis, including Pomeranz, have been killed in the uprising. Israeli soldiers and civilians have killed 730 Palestinians. At least 264 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboratng with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Hu Sen Agrees To Resume Talks with Cambodian Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: A guerrilla official said Monday that peace talks should resume between Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen and guerrilla groups now that a dispute over the makeup of a transitional goverment has been settled. The three factions of the guerrilla coalition met Sunday and agreed to resistance leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk's proposal that they give the government another seat on the Supreme National Council. Hun Sen then agreed to resume the talks, the guerrilla official said, speaking on condition he not be identified. He said the guerrillas want the next meeting to elect Sihanouk as council chairman and appoint a delegation to represent Cambodia at the United Nations. On Sept. 10, six government members and six guerrilla members formed the transitional council, which under a U.N. peace plan is to help guide Cambodia to democracy through new elections. The council's first meeting collapsed in Bangkok last week after the guerrillas demanded that Sihanouk, Cambodia's former ruler, be its 13th member and chairman. Hun Sen agreed that Sihanouk could preside over the council, but said an additional seat for a government representative should be added. On Friday, Sihanouk urged his guerrilla allies to yield to Phnom Penh's demand, so the new council will have 14 members. The guerrillas now hold the U.N. seat but are ready to transfer it to the council. The deadline for presenting new credentials is Oct. 18. Sihanouk sat out the last round of negotiations but said he will attend the next meeting after he is elected chairman. Hun Sen's government is battling the forces of Sihanouk and two allied guerrilla groups - the Khmer Rouge of Khieu Samphan and the Khmer People's National Liberation Front of former Prime Minister Son Sann. The war began with Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia in late 1978, and the ouster of the Khmer Rouge. During the Khmer Rouge rule from 1975-1978, hundreds of thousands of Cambodia's 8 million people died from executions, famine and civil unrest. Thailand was frustrated by the failure of the first council meeting, and said it will play host to another meeting only if it is clear beforehand that it will result in agreements.

DOC.HEAD: Six Years Later, Goetz Takes Stand in Subway Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Subway gunman Bernhard Goetz testified under oath for the first time Monday about the December afternoon six years ago when he shot four youths on a Manhattan subway train, paralyzing one of them. But exactly what his testimony means depends on is describing it. Goetz, acting as his own lawyer, moved successfully to get the media banned from his deposition in a $50 million civil suit filed by victim Darrell Cabey. Ronald Kuby, the paralyzed plaintiff's attorney, said Goetz had undermined his case on the stand, while Goetz said the case could be dismissed later this week. ``Mr. Goetz made it clear he intended to destroy Darrell Cabey, to end his life. If anything, Bernie Goetz convicted himself with his own mouth,'' said Kuby. But Goetz, when the three-hour hearing was over, said the key to his testimony was that he fired three times at Cabey on Dec. 22, 1984. Why did he shoot? ``I was being mugged,'' Goetz told reporters. The subway gunman wouldn't go any further in describing his appearance, but Kuby said Goetz claims his first shot missed Cabey, now 22, and the second one struck the plaintiff. When Goetz then told Cabey, ``You don't look so bad, here's another,'' and fired again at the youth a third time, there was no bullet in the chamber. Kuby said that doesn't matter because it clearly shows intent to injure. The soft-spoken Goetz saw things differently. Goetz said he intends to move for a dismissal of the case on Wednesday after he questions Cabey in the same state courtroom. ``I believe Darrell Cabey is going to say he doesn't remember why he was shot or what happened on that subway. Darrell Cabey is going to pretend he's a mental vegetable. Everybody knows Darrell Cabey is faking,'' said Goetz. Goetz, 42, was acquitted of attempted murder in the shooting but convicted of a weapons possession charge; he never took the stand at his trial. He served 8{ months in prison on his conviction. Goetz was subsequently sued for $50 million by Cabey, who also reportedly suffered brain damage due to the shooting. The three other teens Goetz shot all recovered.

DOC.HEAD: Haitian Political Parties Withdraw Opposition to Early Elections
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - The likelihood of elections in Haiti this year increased Monday when three major political parties agreed to participate in voting organized by the country's current administration. Bolstered by the support of the parties - including the Haitian Communist Party - and by an infusion of foreign aid, the independent electoral council was expected to hold the election in mid-December. Louis Dejoie Jr., chief of the moderate National Industrial and Agricultural Party, said, ``We are going to launch our election campaign. The armed forces have taken steps which should give voters confidence in safe elections.'' The council earlier postponed elections planned for Nov. 4 because of lack of money. Also, many politicians were refusing to participate. They claimed that interim President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot had done little to investigate political murders, reform the notoriously corrupt and brutal military, or resolve Haiti's grave economic problems. ``We still insist on minimum security conditions and the arrest and trial of criminal supporters of dictatorship,'' said Jean-Claude Bajeux of the socialist Congress of Democratic Movements. ``If the voters are threatened, we will withdraw from the race. But to refuse to compete while Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot is in office is political suicide.'' Communist leader Rene Theodore said that while he opposes Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, politicians here are ``handicapped by the lack of an alternative to her power which is acceptable to all.'' The three parties are the largest among seven in the 12-party Unity Assembly, which last month demanded that Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot resign. The assembly appointed her president in March. A Council of State, set up to share power with Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, accused her of being an ``obstacle'' to credible elections. Council members said she made decisions without consulting them and mismanaged the economy. On Saturday, former President Jimmy Carter said during a visit that the international community believed the Pascal-Trouillot administration could hold fair elections. The United States and Canada recently sent money to the electoral council. Haiti's last attempt to hold democratic elections collapsed on Nov. 29, 1987, when thugs supported by the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters at polling stations. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot heads the fifth government since dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier fled in 1986, ending a 29-year family dictatorship.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Releases Cancer Estimates
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS last two grafs with one graf to clarify that New Augusta, Miss. mill should not have been listed
DOC.TEXT: People who regularly eat fish taken from streams near pulp and paper mills that discharge dioxin run a increased risk of developing cancer, the Environmental Protection Agency said Monday. The EPA made public the results of a study showing that dioxin concentrations in fish downstream from 19 such mills ``may be high enough to pose an increased cancer risk greater than one in 10,000'' to average consumers of fish caught there. ``The estimated cancer risk is potentially higher for avid sports fishermen and subsistence level fishermen because their consumption of fish is generally higher than that of average consumers,'' the EPA said. The EPA said its risk estimates are based on the consumption of fish - such as catfish, bass, suckers and squaw fish - that spend their entire lives near a paper mill and accumulate greater concentrations of dioxin in their tissues. The risk estimates do not apply to migratory fish, such as salmon, that spend only a short portion of their lives in the contaminated waters. The one-in-10,000 estimate is an upper bound. Any risk, if present, could be lower. The agency generally tries to act against risks this large, and treats smaller risks with less concern. The average risk in the United States of dying of cancer from any source is about one in five. The cancer risk for fish taken from waters below the International Paper Co. mill at Georgetown, S.C., could be as high as one in 50, the EPA said. There are 104 paper mills operated by 38 companies that produce paper bleached with chlorine compounds and that discharge dioxin. Dioxin, a byproduct of the bleaching process, is a powerful cause of cancer and birth defects in laboratory animals. The EPA lists it as a probable cause of cancer in humans, but there has been no proof it actually causes human cancers. The EPA said it is issuing waste water discharge permits, over the next two years, to 66 mills to limit dioxin discharges. Many of the permits will require mills to reduce the use of chlorine, and the 66 mills will have to comply no later than June 1993. The environmental agency said it is also developing national guidelines and standards to limit dioxin contamination from the manufacture of bleached paper products, and will seek cooperation from industry and the states for further pollution reduction initiatives. It said that the new standards will likely focus on changes in the bleaching process to prevent the formation of dioxin in sludge and pulp as well as waste water. Many of the 104 mills have already reduced dioxin discharges, some of them significantly, the EPA said. Here are the mills posing a maximum likely risk of greater than one in 10,000. After each mill is the risk estimate and whether an advisory against eating fish from the stream has been issued. Boise Cascade, Rumford, Maine, one in 10,000, yes. International Paper, Jay, Maine; one in 10,000, yes. Westvaco Corp., Covington, Va.; one in 1,000, yes. Union Camp, Franklin, Va.; two in 1,000, no. Georgia-Pacific, Palatka, Fla.; six in 10,000, no. St. Joe Paper, Port St. Joe, Fla.; one in 10,000, no. International Paper, Moss Point, Miss.; three in 10,000, yes. Champion International, Canton, N.C.; two in 10,000, yes. Wyerhaeuser, Plymouth, N.C., two in 1,000, yes. International Paper, Georgetown, S.C., two in 100, yes. Buckeye Cellulose, Perry, Fla., two in 1,000, no. Georgia-Pacific, Crosset, Ark.; two in 10,000, no. Boise Cascade, Deridder, La., one in 10,000, no. International Paper, Texarkana, Texas; two in 10,000, no. Temple-Eastex, Evadale, Texas, three in 10,000, no. Simpson Paper, Anderson, Calif., one in 10,000, yes. Simpson Paper, Fairhaven, Calif. one in 10,000, no. Wyerhaeuser, Everett, Wash. one in 10,000, no Wyerhaeuser, Cosmopolis, Wash., one in 10,000 The agency's announcement identified a mill operated by the Leaf River Forest Co. at New Augusta, Miss. as posing a cancer risk from fish of greater than one in 10,000, but an accompanying table appeared to state a lower risk. Sean McElheny, the agency spokesman on the issue, said the table was correct and the mill should not have been listed in the statement.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Born Anti-Arab Rabbi Charged With Rioting
DOC.TEXT: Rabbi Meir Kahane went on trial in a Jerusalem District court Monday on charges of disturbing public order for leading an anti-Arab rally after the stabbing deaths of two Israelis last year. Kahane, a U.S. native, was also charged with sedition for calling Arabs ``cancer spreading in our midsts'' during a separate incident. The national Itim news agency reported he denied both charges. Kahane led a group of his anti-Arab Kach Party down one of Jerusalem's main avenues after a Palestinian stabbed and killed two elderly Israelis waiting at a bus stop. Kahane's group marched down the road shouting ``Death to the Arabs!'' Police dispersed the group with tear gas when they tried to enter an Arab section of Jerusalem. Seven other Kach activists were also charged with disturbing public order. Judge Yehudit Tzur set the date for the next hearing in December.

DOC.HEAD: Honda to Have Driver and Passenger Side Air Bags as Standard in '94
DOC.TEXT: Honda will put air bags in all its cars by the 1994 model year, joining the Big Three U.S. automakers in announcing plans to make the safety devices standard equipment the next few years. Currently, Chrysler Corp. equips all of its U.S.-made cars with driver-side air bags, and General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Corp. have announced they will follow suit by the middle of the decade. Honda, which now puts automatic seat belts on its cars, announced Monday it will install driver- and passenger-side airbags. Nobuhiko Kawamoto, new president of Honda Motor Corp., made the announcement to reporters Monday during a U.S. visit. Air bags inflate in a crash to keep a car's occupants from being flung into the dashboard, steering wheel and windshield. Japanese automakers have been comparatively slow to install air bags. Chrysler has made it's fleet-wide air bags an important part of its advertising. Though all Chrysler's its U.S.-made cars have driver-side air bags, the cars it receives from other companies, notably Mitsubishi Motors Corp., don't have the safety devices. General Motors Corp. announced recently said it will expand the use of driver and passenger side air bags to all of its domestically designed cars by late 1995 for the 1996 model year. Ford Motor Co. has said that by the mid-1990s it would equip all of its cars with driver and passenger side air bags.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Debates Bill Requiring More Fuel Efficient Cars
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with Senate votes, editing
DOC.TEXT: The Senate narrowly rejected a proposal Monday night to aid autoworkers laid off in any required shift by automakers to higher-mileage cars. In debate on a bill to require cars to average 40 miles per gallon, the Senate voted 49-46 to reject an amendment by Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., that would have provided special unemployment assistance for those workers. A vote on whether to close off debate on the bill was scheduled for Tuesday. ``The passage of this amendment will doom this bill,'' declared Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash., a co-sponsor. Later the Senate agreed, 55-40, to a include in the legislation new incentives for automakers to produce vehicles that can run on alternative fuels such as methanol, ethanol or natural gas. The measure would allow manufacturers to claim credits against fuel efficiency requirements if they produce such vehicles. Similar fuel economy legislation has been introduced in the House but has yet to emerge from committee. In earlier debate on the legislation, opponents argued that the higher fuel economy requirements would be a death blow to the midsize family sedan and force automakers to produce only small cars. Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., chief sponsor of the legislation, disputed such claims, arguing higher fuel efficiency can be achieved without sacrificing the six-passenger automobile. ``It means smaller cars, it means less safe cars,'' declared Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., who has led efforts to block consideration of the measure. The legislation's supporters maintained that manufacturers have shown in the past that they can come up with technologies to improve fuel efficiency greatly and still provide customers with a broad range of vehicle models. In aiming to reduce the nation's dependence on foreign oil, the bill would would require cars to achieve on a fleet average 35 mpg by 1995 and 40 mpg by 2001. He said that would eventually save 2.8 million barrels of oil daily. The automakers have said they can't meet those goals without making cars dramatically smaller and stopping production of midsize and large vehicles. Bryan read statements by auto industry executives in the early 1970s predicting the demise of the family sedan as a result of fuel efficiency requirements then under consideration. ``That just didn't happen. The six-passenger vehicle is here just as it was before,'' said Bryan.

DOC.HEAD: Sources: Expelled Diplomats `Spying' for Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT one graf after 6th graf `A company' to UPDATE with Aramco wire-cutting memo. Picks up 7th graf, `The diplomatic' with minor editing to trim
DOC.TEXT: Jordanian and Yemeni envoys expelled from Saudi Arabia this week were monitored photographing strategic oil, military and government installations and later meeting with Iraqi diplomats, diplomatic sources said Monday. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Saudi officials believed an attempted break-in at the kingdom's largest oil company two weeks ago was part of the alleged espionage campaign for which the Riyadh government expelled most Iraqi, Yemeni and Jordanian diplomats. Some of the expelled diplomats had been seen earlier in the area of the oil company, Saudi Aramco, and also at another major Saudi oil field and installation at Safaniya, the sources said. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has threatened to destroy Middle East oil fields in any war with U.S. and other forces deployed to the region following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Aramco officials confirmed that an outside fence at its complex was cut two weeks ago by unidentified intruders who fled when a security guard turned a light on them. These officials, who also spoke on the condition of anonymity, said an additional security fence closer to the tanks never was breached. A company spokesman did not immediately return telephone calls seeking additional information. An internal Aramco memo written several days after the fence-cutting refers to the incident as ``terrorist'' and says Aramco compound security has been improved and access to the compound restricted. The diplomatic sources said they were reluctant to discuss the Aramco incident in detail because the government did not want to raise concern among American and other expatriate workers. Most of those workers sent their families home after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Saudi Arabia ordered the diplomats expelled Saturday, saying they had ``engaged in activities jeopardizing the peace and security of the kingdom.'' A Saudi Foreign Ministry statement said complaints were made to the three governments about ``the blatant and flagrant infringements'' but the diplomats did not halt their improper activities. Diplomatic sources said the order affected 14 Iraqis, 56 Yemenis and 10 Jordanian envoys. Earlier, Saudi Arabia said it was ending its practice of allowing unrestricted entry to the kingdom from neighboring Yemen. The expulsions were also seen as a sign of Saudi displeasure with Yemen and Jordan's failure to take sides against Saddam. On Monday, diplomatic sources said numerous Palestinians and Jordanians also have been told to leave the kingdom in the seven weeks since the invasion of Kuwait. The sources said these moves were for ``security reasons,'' but refused to be more specific and said they could not provide exact numbers. The sources said the Jordanian and Yemeni diplomats were placed under strict surveillance immediately following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Saudi Arabia had immediately restricted the movements of Iraqi envoys to Riyadh. ``It was obvious they would need help if they wanted to engage in espionage,'' one source said. This source and another diplomatic official familiar with the situation said Saudi internal security monitored a sudden flurry of unusual activity by Yemeni and Jordanian diplomats, including long drives to areas of the Eastern province ``in which they had no business.'' The Eastern province is home to Aramco, Safaniya, other major oil installations and to Saudi military bases and camps now being used by American, British and other foreign troops here for the multinational defense effort. One source, who reported receiving a briefing on the activities from Saudi military officials, said the Yemenis and Jordanians were monitored taking photographs of the strategic facilities in the Eastern province and also of government buildings in Riyadh. ``The first rule of terrorism is to stake out the targets,'' one of the sources said. Still, this official said the Saudi government had no concrete evidence linking the suspicious activity to the attempted break-in at Aramco. Two sources said Saudi authorities monitored meetings between the Jordanians, Yemenis and Iraqi diplomats who are restricted to Riyadh. Security in the Eastern province area has been increased, with armed patrols driving along highways and coastal roads throghout the night. Saudi officials said the increased security is partly attributable to the recent suspicions about the diplomats' movements but also because of fears Iraq-sponsored terrorists might have slipped into Saudi Arabia when Iraq opened the Kuwaiti border for several days last week.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Five Measures Ineligible for Ballot
DOC.TEXT: Five of eight voter initiatives, including one that would have allowed tax credits at parochial schools, are ineligible for the November election, a judge ruled Monday. Three other statewide measures on the Nov. 6 general election ballot could be disqualified under the ruling by Marion County Circuit Judge Richard Barber. Among them is a measure, which if approved, would outlaw most abortions in the state. Barber said the five initiatives do not qualify because they won't be accompanied by financial impact statements as required by state law. The statements - estimating each measure's fiscal impact on the state - were earlier declared invalid because they weren't certified by deadline. Both the state and a group backing the education measure said they would appeal Barber's decision to the state Court of Appeals, which could send the case to the Oregon Supreme Court without ruling. The education measure would allow tax credits of up to $2,500 a year each for pupils at private schools, including church-supported schools, and for children taught at home. That measure, which drew the interest of educators across the country, also would have allowed parents to send their children across district lines to any public school. ``It would be a travesty and an injustice if the public weren't allowed to vote on a measure because state officials didn't do their job,'' said Steve Buckstein, spokesman for Oregonians for Educational Choice. The other measures affected by Monday's ruling would limit property taxes to 1.5 percent of value, shut down the Trojan nuclear plant about 40 miles northwest of Portland until waste disposal requirements are met, ban some non-recyclable packaging and establish a program to put able welfare applicants to work. Barber's ruling ``strikes at the heart of the initiative process,'' Secretary of State Barbara Roberts said in announcing the state's plan to appeal. It means that a ``legal technicaltiy can take away a constitutional right,'' she said. About 84,000 registered voters signed petitions to get the educational initiative on the ballot, while the measure on the nuclear plant required about 63,000 signatures. Because of printing deadlines, Barber said the five measures could stay on the ballot but that votes for or against them would not be counted. Barber's decision was an outgrowth of earlier Marion County Circuit Court rulings that the fiscal statements were invalid. State law specifies that the secretary of state, state treasurer and the directors of the Executive and Revenue departments certify the fiscal impact statements. State Elections Director Jack Graham said those officials were polled on the Aug. 8 deadline and that three of four agreed to the statements. But the statements weren't signed until after the deadline. If the ruling stands on appeal, three more measures lacking fiscal impact statements also would have to be disqualified, he said. Those measures would outlaw most abortions, require parental notice of abortions involving minors and change taxation of some public employee pensions. If all eight are disqualified, three measures would be left on the ballot: two legislative housekeeping measures and one that would require seat belt use. They didn't require financial impact statements.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturers Hanover Has Problems with Phone Company Takeover Bid
DOC.TEXT: Manufacturers Hanover said Monday it may not have enough cash and debt papers in time to take over Argentina's state telephone company by the Oct. 8 deadline. ``There are some difficulties in complying with the time-frame,'' said Pablo Leclerc, a spokesman for a consortium financed by the U.S. bank. However, Leclerc denied published reports the group is backing out of the ENTel phone company deal or cannot meet the deadline. The consortium is still planning ``to take over the operation of the north zone,'' he told Radio Mitre. On June 28, the consortium that includes Bell Atlantic Corp. of Philadelphia was awarded 60 percent of the northern half of ENTel in return for $100 million cash, $2.2 billion in debt papers and $178 million in notes payable over six years. Another consortium that includes Citibank and Spain's national communications company Telefonica was awarded the southern half for $114 million in cash, $2.7 billion in debt papers and $202 million in notes. Each sector under the agreement gets half of the Buenos Aires area and the northern or southern half of the country. Total value of the deal to provide telephone service in this country of 32 million residents is about $1.34 billion. ``This is the largest privatization project going on anywhere in the world. It shouldn't come as a shock that there are problems,'' said David Frost, Bell Atlantic's operations manager in Argentina. ``It is clear that the government wants us to move as quickly as possible in wrapping up the various loose ends,'' Frost said. ``But it is also clear to us that Bell Atlantic is the company the government wants to manage operations in the north.'' Frost declined to comment on how close Manufacturers Hanover and its Argentine partners are to meeting the down payment and debt titles. The key date is Oct. 8, he said, ``and we're doing everything we can to meet that deadline.'' If Manufacturers Hanover fails to make the deadline, another consortium that includes J.P. Morgan and Co. and the Italian telecommunications company STET reportedly would step in. The consortium was runner-up to Manufacturers Hanover in June 28 bidding. President Carlos Menem said Monday that the Oct. 8 date is ``unmovable'' and if Manufacturers Hanover fails to fulfill its obligations, the government will award the bid to STET, according to the private news agency Diarios y Noticias. The state carrier Aerolineas Argentinas also is supposed to be formally taken over on Oct. 8, by a consortium that includes the Spanish national carrier Iberia and the Argentine airline Cielos del Sur. That sale, too, has come close close to stalling for lack of funds. The consortium apparently intended to buy the airline with funds raised by selling planes and leasing them back. The government insists the buyers use more of their own capital.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Prime Minister Meets Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's prime minister met with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on Monday and reiterated her refusal to sign a treaty of union that Moscow is negotiating with the 15 Soviet republics. Gorbachev reacted ``skeptically'' to her declaration, Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene was quoted as saying by the Tass news agency. The Soviet Union is preparing a treaty tying together its splintering republics as a loose confederation with strong economic links. Gorbachev has said the accord is vital to his plans to move the nation to a market economy. Tass quoted Mrs. Prunskiene as saying negotiations with the Kremlin on Lithuanian independence could begin by the end of this week. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis has accused Soviet authorities of delaying the talks. Lithuania declared its independence March 11, but agreed to suspend the declaration in exchange for the lifting of an oil and natural gas embargo that Gorbachev had imposed in May, and Gorbachev's agreement to hold negotiations on the issue.

DOC.HEAD: North American Emigrants in Israel Mourn Their Fallen Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Widows, elderly parents and friends wept or bowed their heads on Monday in remembrance of the 157 North Americans who died fighting in the Israeli army. The president of the Association of Americans and Canadians in Israel, Sherwin Pomrantz, said the annual ceremony is held to point up the contribution the 80,000-member community of North American Jews has made here. ``It is an opportunity for us to stop and say these are people who came here and really gave their last full measure of devotion as North Americans to Israel,'' Pomerantz said. Two names of fallen Americans were added to the bronze plaque this year. One, Ze'ev Traum, 40, moved to Israel from the Bronx borough of New York City following the 1967 Middle East war. He was serving in the reserves last November when Arab guerrillas ambushed his jeep in the occupied Gaza Strip fire, killing him and another soldier. Traum's heart was later transplanted into a Palestinian man in Arab east Jerusalem. ``For our generation it was a choice between fighting in a tragic and badly motivated war in Vietnam or coming to Israel, to your own country, to your own people,'' said Neil Hassid, 42, a close friend and army buddy of Traum's. ``That kind of choice should have been obvious to all of us. It was to me and it was to Ze'ev.'' Al Liebman, the father-in-law of Joe Berniker, 35, the second fallen soldier, lighted the memorial torch on this windswept mountaintop forest of young cedars about 15 miles west of Jerusalem. Berniker, 35, moved to Israel from New Orleans in 1974 and was a member of a communal farm near Israel's border with Lebanon. Berniker was also serving in the reserves when a stray artillery shell killed him and and four other soldiers last July during a training exercise. Col. Raanan Gissin praised the North American contribution and lauded their service to the only Jewish army in the world. ``I think there is a sense and a feeling that this is their army. It is not just the army of the United States but the army of the Jewish people,'' he said. For Israelis, military service is the one bonding experience they will most likely share. But for American immigrants, who have grown up without the draft, service can be a disconcertingly quick access to the network that makes one fully Israeli. Rena Genn lost her husband, Eli Solomon, in the 1973 Yom Kippur War after emigrating from New York City. She said it takes time to become part of this country ``until one day it is not them but us.'' ``Unfortunately, the event that made me 100 percent part of it all was a knock on the door.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebel, Doe Commanders Meet, Set Up Talks on Cease-fire
DOC.TEXT: Commanders of slain Liberian President Samuel Doe and rebel leader Charles Taylor reportedly met Monday in Monrovia, their nation's capital, and arranged for talks on the cease-fire now in effect. It was the first such meeting since the two sides went to war nine months ago. Taylor declared a unilateral truce that took hold Saturday, and other warring factions have honored it. No contact had been reported between fighters of Taylor and rival rebel leader Prince Johnson, or a five-nation West African army sent to enforce a cease-fire. West African officials said Sunday that Taylor and Johnson will meet Friday in Freetown, Sierra Leone, for talks with U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen. Cohen arranged the talks in meetings with the two rebels last week, they said. The French news agency Agence France-Presse reported that Col. James Freeman of Doe's mansion guard and Taylor rebel commander Albert Zoegba Paye met on Monday 300 yards from the presidential residence. ``They congratulated each other (on the truce) and broke into a joyful discussion to the point where it was difficult to see which one of the two commanders was more relieved,'' reported the agency, which has a correspondent traveling with the rebels. It said they arranged for Taylor to meet with the commander of Doe's presidential guard, Brig. Gen. David Nimley, on Tuesday at City Hall, less than 100 yards from the mansion where remnants of Doe's army have holed up. Taylor and Nimley both declared themselves president of Liberia after Doe was wounded and captured by Johnson's men on Sept. 9 and tortured to death the following day. Also claiming the presidency are Johnson and professor Amos Sawyer, a former lecturer in political science at MIT who was named head of an interim government by Liberian opposition parties, businessmen and clergymen. Johnson and Nimley have agreed to proposals by the Economic Community of West African States to install Sawyer as part of a government that would organize fair elections. There was no sign Monday of the 3,000 soldiers from the five-nation West African army the economic group sent to help install Sawyer's government. Freeman told reporters the West Africans had withdrawn to their headquarters at Monrovia port, less than four miles from the executive mansion. West African planes bombed Taylor's artillery batteries Sept. 15-16 after his rebels shelled their headquarters. But they have not engaged the forces of Doe or Johnson, which approve of the West African plans. Taylor says Sawyer is a puppet of the West Africans, and announced Sunday he was holding elections Oct. 10 for representatives to participate in a government that he will lead.
