Tom Woewiyu, Taylor's chief spokesman, said Monday that the government would be a temporary administration to re-establish conditions for holding proper general elections. Taylor, who accused Doe of corruption and nepotism, started the civil war on Dec. 24 when his forces invaded from Ivory Coast. Johnson later split with Taylor and formed his own rebel faction. More than 5,000 civilians have been killed in the fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Guatemalan Guerrillas Start Peace Talks in Ecuador
DOC.TEXT: Guatemalan religious leaders began a dialogue in a downtown hotel with leftist guerrillas Monday in the latest in a series of talks aimed at resolving Guatemala's 30-year-old war of insurgency. The Guatemalan National Revolutionary Unity, an umbrella group for four rebel armies, was to meet for two days with 14 representatives of Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish religious orders. The talks were organized in the framework of a 1987 meeting in Esquipulas, Guatemala, at which five Central American presidents committed themselves to ending decades-long civil wars and regional conflicts. Rebel commander Gaspar Ilom said his group had come ``with the objective of finding just and democratic solutions'' to the situation in Guatemala, but didn't intend to stop fighting without some hope of progress. ``Guatemala is worthy of a new and better destiny,'' he said. ``It would have little meaning to reach a state of peace which consolidated recalcitrant and old-fashioned points of view.'' Roman Catholic Bishop Alvaro Ramazini said the church was hoping to promote further talks.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Joins Investigation
DOC.TEXT: The FBI has joined the investigation of the murder of a political columnist for a Vietnamese magazine who was shot to death with his wife in a Washington suburb, a law enforcement source said Monday. The murders of Triet Le, 61, and his wife, Tuyet Thi Dangtran, 52, may have been committed by enemies in the Vietnamese exile community, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Le and his wife were found shot to death Saturday night in their car, parked outside their home, authorities said. The killings occurred 10 months after another employee of the magazine was shot to death in similar execution-style fashion. Fairfax County police are trying to determine if there is any link between the two killings, said spokesman Warren Carmichael. Le wrote feisty political columns under the pen name Tu Rua for Tien Phon, a magazine based in Arlington, another Washington suburb. Last November, Nhan Trong Do, a page designer for the magazine, was found shot to death outside his home in Seven Corners, Va. No arrest has been made in that case. Magazine staff members at the time speculated Do's slaying might be related to Tien Phong's staunchly anti-Communist articles. The magazine was founded in Saigon in 1955 and moved to the United States in 1975 after the defeat of South Vietnam by North Vietnam. It has become controversial among its readers because of its criticism of prominent community leaders and of actions by North and South Vietnamese officials during the Vietnam War. ``Some of (Le's) criticisms were really down on people,'' said Bach Hac Nguyen, who recently began publishing a Vietnamese-language newspaper. ``He embarrassed a lot of people. But I'm shocked. A lot of people liked the way he wrote,'' he said. Buy My Linh Solang, a lawyer who had been the subject of a Le column, said, ``He abused the privilege of the media. He had more enemies than friends.'' Carmichael said authorities are investigating all possible motives. ``Logic dictates that (the magazine) would be one of them,'' he said. Neighbors said one body was lying in a pool of blood just outside the passenger door, and the driver was shot while still at the wheel. They said they could not see who was in the driver's seat. Members of the Vietnamese community said the couple were returning from a barbecue. Le had been concerned with security from the moment he moved into the neighborhood about 10 years ago, neighbors said. Their house was equipped with a security camera to monitor the door and carport and had exterior lights that turned on whenever sensors detected movement. A sign warned passersby of the couple's large guard dog.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International: End Killings and Torture of Children
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International called Tuesday for an end to the killing, torture and arbitrary imprisonment of the world's children. As world leaders prepared for this weekend's World Summit for Children, the London-based human rights organization described violations in 19 countries including Iraq, Israel, South Africa and the United States. ``Of all the victims of human rights violations, children are among the least able to stand up for their rights. Governments must therefore be particularly vigilant in protecting those rights,'' Amnesty said in an appeal. UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund, is organizing the summit that will discuss ways of improving the lot of millions of children whose lives are threatened by poverty, disease or malnutrition. At least 60 heads of state, including President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, will meet Sept. 29-30 at the United Nations headquarters in New York. Amnesty said children are used as pawns to get their parents to turn themselves in or to make confessions, and often are victims of political and military unrest. ``All too often children are victimized simply because of where they live or who their parents are. Sometimes their age alone makes them targets for abuse,'' it said. In Iraq, it said, hundreds of children had disappeared or been tortured. ``In Iraq, too, hundreds more children have died in chemical weapons attacks on Kurdish communities, which claimed the lives of thousands of people,'' Amnesty said. In Israel, it said, Palestinian children have been victims of rights violations ``virtually daily since the beginning of the intefadeh,'' the Palestinian uprising. Of the more than 600 people shot dead by security forces, 153 have been children, Amnesty said. ``In an alarmingly high number of incidents, the children did not appear to have been involved in any life-threatening activity,'' it added. In Liberia, Amnesty said children have been among the thousands of civilians arbitrarily killed or mutilated by government forces and their armed opponents. During the states of emergency in South Africa from 1985-87, it said, an estimated 10,000 children were detained without charge or trial, some for more than a year. Amnesty said children are often deliberately targeted for rights violations because they are seen as a social or political threat. ``In Brazil and Guatemala, where the number of street children has grown dramatically in recent years ... they are tortured and extrajudicially executed by police ... often in the name of `cleaning up the streets','' Amnesty said. In China, it said, children were among more than 1,000 people killed when troops fired on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing in June 1989. The international rights group said the United States was one of seven countries that has reportedly executed minors the past 10 years. The United States ``has 35 prisoners on death row who were under 18 when they committed their crime. One such prisoner, Dalton Prejean, was executed this year,'' Amnesty said. Amnesty also gave examples of violations in Albania, Argentina, Bolivia, Chad, El Salvador, Mauritania, Burma, Nigeria, Peru, Philippines, Sri Lanka and Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Think They've Got Saddam Hussein's Armored Limo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to ADD color of car.
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein may have Kuwait, but he doesn't have his bomb-proof, $300,000 armored Cadillac limousine. The black limo, fitted with tear gas dispensers and bulletproof tires, is being held at a repair shop in this Detroit suburb on order of the U.S. Customs Service, agents announced Monday in Chicago. ``We have reason to believe that this car might have been used by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein,'' said Donald Watson, Customs' assistant commissioner of enforcement in Chicago. ``In any case, he's not going to get it back.'' The Customs Service titled its press release on the car, ``Is Saddam Hussein walking?'' The Customs Service said it ordered the car held under authority of President Bush's executive order freezing Iraqi assets in the United States. The government of Iraqbought the car in 1988 from O'Gara-Hess & Eisenhardt, a maker of armored vehicles in Cincinnati, the Customs Service said. It said the car, shipped to Baghdad in November 1988, is bomb-proof, able to withstand military rifle blasts and is equipped with bullet-proof tires and tear-gas dispensers. The limo was returned to this country in June for routine maintenance and was ordered held in Livonia, where its engine is being rebuilt by E.C.S. Roush Co.

DOC.HEAD: Moonshine Kills One, Sickens at Least 16
DOC.TEXT: A 19-year-old man was charged with involuntary manslaughter after moonshine killed a 13-year-old girl and left seven other teen-agers hospitalized, authorities said Monday. Six youths remained at area hospitals Monday. At least nine others received medical treatment after drinking the illegal whiskey, but were not hospitalized, officials said. Belmont County Sheriff Tom McCort said more arrests were expected in adjacent Harrion County, where investigators believed the alcohol was made. Officials said the moonshine, made of ethanol and methanol, was served at a party Friday or Saturday night. McCort said Jody Morris, 19, of Jewett, was charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of 13-year-old Jami Krenzlak of Bethesda, a freshmen at Union Local High School. Morris did not make the alcohol but allegedly sold it at the party, McCort said. Richard Doan, spokesman for Barnesville Hospital, said Miss Krenzlak was dead on arrival Sunday evening. McCort said alcohol made illegally in this area of eastern Ohio is usually a mixture of ethanol and a small amount of methanol, added for taste. The ratio was apparently reversed in the lethal batch, he said. Methanol, or methyl alcohol, also known as wood alcohol, can shut down the liver and kidneys and cause blindness and death. It is used in automobile fuel and copying machine fluid. Ethanol is a corn-based alcohol.

DOC.HEAD: Briton Completes Round-the-World Voyage via Northwest Passage
DOC.TEXT: David Cowper sailed into the River Tyne on Monday to end a four-year around-the-world voyage that included the first solo navigation of the Northwest Passage. The 48-year-old British surveyor was greeted by a flotilla of small craft, a band playing Rule Britannia and a flag-waving crowd as his converted former lifeboat moored in Newcastle upon Tyne on England's northeast coast. Cowper holds three records in The Guinness Book of Records 1990 for previous circumnavigations of the globe. A Guinness spokeswoman said the publisher was awaiting information on his latest trip to see if there would be a new record. Cowper's 30,000-mile journey in the 42-foot converted lifeboat Mabel E. Holland took more than 50 months, making it the slowest of his four lone circumnavigations since 1979. He opted to reach the Pacific via the frozen waters of the 2,200-mile Northwest Passage around the Arctic coasts of Canada and Alaska but was stopped three times by the winter. ``It has been a most rousing welcome which gave me quite a lump in my throat. I am most relieved to get the boat back - at times I feared she wouldn't make it,'' he said. Despite facing numerous dangers, Cowper hinted his taste for epic travel had not been satisfied, but he said he was keeping his next venture a secret in case anyone else beats him to it.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises de Klerk's Efforts to End Apartheid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 7-9: ``Later, Foreign,'' with Botha remarks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday that South Africa's campaign to abolish white supremacist rule is irreversible and assured President F.W. de Klerk that he would oppose new conditions for lifting economic sanctions. ``These conditions are clear-cut and are not open to re-interpretation. And I do not believe in moving the goalposts,'' Bush said, referring to requirements South Africa must fulfill before the sanctions will be suspended. The sanctions were imposed in 1986 over then President Reagan's veto. Bush also said all political groups in South Africa ``have a special responsibility to support the process of peaceful transition.'' De Klerk, the first South African leader to visit the United States since 1945, assured Bush that the process of reform is irreversible, and Bush echoed that sentiment. ``We will not turn back,'' de Klerk said. The leaders met at the White House for two hours, first in the Oval Office and again over lunch. The meeting was a showcase of U.S. political support for de Klerk's efforts to guide South Africa toward a post-apartheid democratic system. Later, Foreign Minister Pik Botha said Bush's characterization of the dismantling of apartheid as ``irreversible'' should help persuade European governments to lift sanctions. He said he understood the Bush administration would have difficulty in changing sanctions written into law by Congress. ``Wre are aware of the sensitivities constraining the U.S. administration and we are not here to as the U.S. to do anything about it at this stage,'' Botha said. More than 100 anti-apartheid demonstrators marched outside the White House during the visit. ``Bush is an accomplice to a colossal public relations fraud which attempts to portray F.W. de Klerk as a moderate reformer,'' said Randall Robinson, head of TransAfrica, a private anti-apartheid group. Robinson said de Klerk's trip ``sends a false and dangerous message that South Africa is on its way to change.'' Bush praised de Klerk at a farewell ceremony in front of the sun-drenched South Lawn. ``Clearly, the time has come to encourage and assist the emerging new South Africa,'' Bush said. Behind the leaders, a black Marine held the flag of South Africa; a white Marine held the American flag. But Bush said that despite ``the dramatic progress that we salute here today,'' South Africa hasn't moved far enough to meet the conditions for removing economic sanctions. South Africa has not released all political prisoners and has not lifted the state of emergency in the Natal province. Further, it has not repealed a population registration act that requires citizens to be classified by race - a key part of the apartheid system. On the other hand, Bush said, ``the move away from apartheid toward a new political reality is indeed irreversible and much has already happened.'' Bush's statement goes beyond the assessment of most European leaders. ``I don't think it's that far ahead. ... I imagine that by the end of the year, they (European leaders) will have reached that conclusion,'' Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen said at briefing for reporters. Cohen said the United States accepts the conclusion that South Africa won't repeal the population registration measure until apartheid is totally dismantled. Bush, he said, could act to suspend or modify sanctions if all other conditions are met. Bush cited the release from prison of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, the removal of outlaw status for the African National Congress, plans to release remaining political prisoners and removal of media restraints as improvements. ``Who among us, only a year ago, would have anticipated these remarkable developments?'' Bush asked. De Klerk promised Bush his government would replace its white supremacist system with a new structure with ``a vote of equal value to all South Africans.'' Bush and de Klerk both noted that the process of reform has been plagued by a recent upsurge in black-against-black violence in South African townships. The death toll is estimated at about 750. Bush urged South African blacks to cooperate during the period of transition. ``The government has a special responsibility to maintain order,'' Bush said, ``but all political parties and groups have a special responsibility to support the process of peaceful transition.'' Mandela has sought to blame pro-apartheid security elements of the police and military for recent violence, a possibility South African officials don't dismiss. In his remarks, de Klerk praised Bush for his leadership in the Persian Gulf crisis and said South Africa would support him.

DOC.HEAD: More Deadly Attacks by Shining Path Guerrillas in Peru
DOC.TEXT: Guerrillas of the radical Shining Path movement murdered five militiamen and looted and burned houses in their village, police said Monday. The rebels also assassinated a former government minister and kidnapped a congressman in Lima over the weekend. About 30 people have died in the last two weeks of a decade-old war that has claimed about 20,000 lives. The militiamen were slain Sunday night after about 100 rebels swept into tiny San Juan de la Vinaca, high in the Andes about 230 miles southeast of Lima. Four others were injured and houses were burned, police said. The attack was typical of actions carried out by the Shining Path, which hopes to dissuade peasants, through terror, from taking up arms against it. The Shining Path is fighting for a radical transformation of Peru into a peasant-controlled society. Many of its victims have been peasants believed to support the government. Five other rural people died and three were kidnapped in two separate rebel attacks near Huancayo, an Andean city 120 miles east of Lima, police said. On Saturday night, former Labor Minister Orestes Rodriguez and his 22-year-old son were assassinated. On Sunday, the Shining Path kidnapped Gerardo Lopez, a congressman for the Cambio 90 movement of President Alberto Fujimori, who took office in July.

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Compares Mohawk Standoff Site to Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson made a quick one-day trip Monday to the Montreal area to gather material for a U S. TV report on the Mohawk land dispute crisis at Oka, and compared the standoff in Quebec to Kuwait. ``Military occupation is military occupation,'' he said. He was referring to Canadian army control in Kahnesatake that includes limiting news media activities and allowing into a nearby drug and alcohol treatment center - where the army has penned in about 50 Indians - only as much food and supplies as deemed necessary. Jackson, a civil rights activist and politician, mingled with locals at the Kahnesatake food bank, but was kept from talking to the natives at the treatment center there. Maj. John Paul Macdonald of the Canadian Forces said Jackson was treated like any other journalist and refused entry to the compound, which has been sealed to reporters for two weeks. Jackson complained, ``When the free press is cut off and denied access to all parties involved, then it undercuts the character of democracy. Both sides here are interested in face-saving, honor and dignity. But, somehow, face-saving has to give way to life-saving and communications must be resumed.'' The black activist wore a trenchcoat in the cold, rainy weather and carried a notepad, but spent much of his time shaking hands, kissing babies and signing autographs. He was accompanied by Grand Chief Joe Norton of the Kahnawake Mohawk reserve and a dozen other people, including a production crew from his syndicated television show in the United States. However, he left many Canadians confused as to just what he hoped to accomplish in the confrontation between Mohawks and authorities. Jackson visited the food bank in the Mohawk community after being turned back at the treatment center. He refused to say he was in the Montreal area in any negotiating capacity, but suggested his experience might be ``a factor in facilitating an end to this impasse.'' The dispute arose over plans by Oka community, 18 miles west of Montreal, to expand a golf course onto land the Mohawks claim as ancestral. Mohawks and police fought a gun battle on July 11 when police tried to tear down an Indian barricade. An officer was killed, but blame in the death has not been fixed. Jackson's credentials include a trip to Syria in 1984, where he persuaded President Hafez Assad to release an American navy pilot who had been shot down by the Syrian air force. The American black leader also went to Premier Robert Bourassa's office. However, the premier wasn't there and Jackson ended up speaking to his chief of staff, John Parisella, and Native Affairs Minister John Ciaccia.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Says 29 Arrested for Smuggling Food to Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iranian authorities arrested 29 smugglers trying to move foodstuffs across the border into Iraq to circumvent the U.N.-imposed embargo, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported Monday. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said they were members of two gangs that usually are involved in smuggling other contraband across the mountainous border in northwestern Kurdistan province. The smugglers were delivered Sunday to an Islamic revolutionary court in Sanandaj, capital of Iranian Kurdistan, the news agency said. It said police seized rice, dates, raisins, tomato sauce, vegetable oil, flour, sugar and powdered milk. Iran has announced it will enforce economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations after Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But Tehran newspapers have also suggested Iran may send ``humanitarian shipments'' of food and medicine to Iraq, its foe in the 1980-88 gulf war. Under most interpretations, such shipments would be exempted from the sanctions. Syrian President Hafez Assad was completing a four-day visit to Tehran on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Questions AZT Study; AIDS Advocate Wants Probe
DOC.TEXT: A news story raising questions about clinical trials that led to widespread use of the anti-AIDS drugs AZT touched off a flap here Monday, with one activist calling for a federal probe. The Miami Herald's Tropic Magazine published a story Sunday on the role of Dr. Margaret Fischl, a prominent researcher who helps run the University of Miami AIDS program, in the 1987 study that brought AZT to prominence. The article quoted some researchers as criticizing the methods used in the study, questioning the accuracy of the figures, and suggesting that AZT's effectiveness was overrated by the doctor. ``We demand a suspension of her official activities and a complete investigation of her and her involvement with Burroughs Wellcome,'' activist Bob Kunst, director of Miami-based Cure AIDS Now, said Monday. ``This is just a monstrous conspiracy - openly, fraudulently misleading the public on AZT.'' Kunst noted Ms. Fischl sits on the 10-member AIDS Clinical Trials Group, which directs the government's $100 million research effort, and said he has written Congress asking for an investigation. He said his group, along with many others AIDS-victim advocates, has not promoted AZT use for several years, saying the benefits appear to disappear quickly and that side effects are deadly. Ms. Fischl has connections with the British company making AZT, Burroughs Wellcome, which chose her to run the clinical trials here, the newspaper said. Ms. Fischl denied any impropriety in the study or her relations with Burroughs Wellcome. ``I do not own stock in pharmaceutical companies,'' she said. ``I have never gotten a `kickback' from Burroughs Wellcome, if that's the terminology.'' The University of Miami-run Jackson Memorial Hospital, where the trials were run, did not immediately respond to the article Monday. Dr. Bernard Fogel, dean of the UM medical school, strongly defended Ms. Fischl, saying she gets a flat $120,000 salary through the school, and receives no direct payments from Burroughs Wellcome. Ms. Fischl was principal author of first research published on AZT and now promotes the drugs in television spots and literature distrubuted to physicians by Burroughs Wellcome, the article said. The researcher, whose work attracts $10 million in government and private grants for the university, said she isn't compensated for the endorsements. The Herald Tropic story detailed what it said were numerous questions about the 1987 study, which Ms. Fischl interrupted after saying the initial results were so striking that it would have been immoral to continue giving placebos to half the subjects. Much of the criticism has been aired previously at scientific conferences. The initial positive results for AZT may have been the result of blood transfusions given along with the drug, Dr. Joseph Sonnabend said in the article. The South African researcher who was among the first to study AIDS. Ellen Cooper, medical researcher with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration who analyzed Fischl's AZT study in 1987, expressed concern that subjects were being treated with numerous other drugs. That would violate normal scientific procedures and cloud the conclusions, she said. The article said the final death toll of patients using AZT was far higher than in the initial announcements. An ongoing Veterans Administration study and a European study published in Science magazine have failed to confirm the Fischl study's results, the newspaper said. The newspaper said Ms. Fischl claimed that the study was a double-blind, meaning neither the patients nor those giving the drug knew who was receiving AZT. But researchers have now acknowledged that they knew which patients received AZT, because lab blood tests clearly showed the difference, and the drug, which causes anemia, required that recipients undergo transfusions, the Herald said.

DOC.HEAD: State's Black Mayors Spurn Mitchell, Endorse Campbell
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Carroll Campbell, running for re-election against a Democrat seeking to become the state's first black governor, has won the endorsement of South Carolina's black mayors. The South Carolina Conference of Black Mayors endorsed Campbell, a Republican, at a conference last week attended by 20 black mayors. In delivering the endorsement for Campbell, the mayors spurned state Sen. Theo Mitchell, who is black. Mitchell said he wasn't surprised Campbell received the endorsements, and chalked it up to practical politics. Campbell ``is the man who has the power; this is the man who has doled out grants; this is the man who put some money in some of the hands of some of the mayors to address their problems,'' Mitchell said. Mayor Joe Montgomery of Atlantic Beach echoed Mitchell's assessment, saying he supported Campbell ``because of what he's done and what he can do. He's helped our towns, and based on his record, we're going to support him. I'll tell Theo that.'' Mayor Franklin B. Goodwin of Santee said Campbell ``is doing a lot for the state. He's given us opportunity.'' As for Mitchell, Goodwin said, ``Theo ... never did contact me.''

DOC.HEAD: Tutu: de Klerk Deserves Credit But Sanctions Should Stand
DOC.TEXT: Archibishop Desmond Tutu said Monday he hoped President Bush would encourage South African President F. W. de Klerk to ``get on with the business'' of negotiating an end to white rule. ``I think they really ought to get into the negotiating mode quickly because that's the only way in which results will happen which will then lead to the lifting of sanctions,'' the South African prelate said after receiving an honorary degree from the University of Missouri-Kansas City. De Klerk, the first South African leader to visit the United States since 1945, met with Bush Monday in Washington. Tutu praised de Klerk's reforms as steps toward dismantling South Africa's apartheid, a system of racial separation under which the country's black majority is ruled by the white minority. ``It is important that some recognition be given for the things he has done, and recognition for his courage,'' said Tutu, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984 for his work against his country's system of racial separation. However, Tutu said it was too early to ease U.S. economic sanctions against South Africa. The sanctions helped push de Klerk toward change, he said. In Washington Monday, Bush said that despite dramatic progress, South Africa has not met conditions for ending the sanctions. Among de Klerk's reforms was the legalization of the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups. In February, ANC leader Nelson Mandela was freed after more than 27 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Called `Warlike State'; Saddam Vows to Fight For 1,000 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with late U.N. developments, CLARIFIES U.S. stand re Iraqi landing rights claim. Picks up 13th graf, `How could...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHA3
DOC.TEXT: World leaders opened a U.N. General Assembly session Monday by condemning Iraq as a warlike state for its invasion of Kuwait, as Iraqi President Saddam Hussein vowed to fight for ``a thousand years'' to keep the oil-rich emirate. While the world body prepared to tighten sanctions on Iraq, the economic repercussions of the Persian Gulf crisis spread and strengthened. Oil prices closed at a record $38.25 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where oil futures have been traded since 1983. Gasoline and home heating oil both topped $1 a gallon. The International Monetary Fund, meanwhile, moved to help poor countries whose economies are being devastated by the conflict. The stock market in New York fell to a 14-month low Monday, battered by rising oil prices and trouble in the banking industry. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 59.41 points to 2,452.97. French President Francois Mitterrand delivered the first of a series of condemnations of Iraq, warning that Iraq's aggression could lead to global anarchy. Leaders from Brazil, Argentina, Poland and Indonesia joined the chorus of condemnation that opened the 45th session of the General Assembly, while the Iraqi U.N. ambassador watched in silence. The speakers set the stage for a Security Council vote Tuesday on extending sanctions against Iraq to include an air embargo. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze speaks Tuesday, and President Bush is to address the 160-member assembly next Monday. Bush said in Washington on Monday ``I'm not going to be distracted'' by Saddam's efforts to link the crisis with the Israeli-Palestinian dispute. ``First we've got to take care of the situation that exists right now, naked aggression of one country against the other. That cannot be permitted to stand,'' Bush told a group of Arab-American leaders in Washington. Saddam has suggested one way to ease the crisis would be for Israel to leave the Arab territories it has occupied since 1967. Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, was to address the United Nations the same day as Bush, but he has insisted on traveling to New York aboard Iraq's flag carrier, Iraqi Airways. The United States has not approved landing rights. In Washington, the State Department said Aziz had U.S. permission to attend the U.N. session. But it was not clear what was meant by the U.S. decision, reported by department spokeswoman V. Kim Hoggard, to allow Aziz to come to the United States ``commercially.'' Iraq said Monday it had rebuffed an offer from the United States to allow the plane to land - if Baghdad releases more than 1,000 Americans being held in Iraq and Kuwait since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion. ``Iraq categorically rejects any link between this issue and any other issue,'' said the official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Cyprus. State Department officials said they had no knowledge of such a claim by Iraq. Aziz was not on hand as Mitterrand assailed the Baghdad government and said the international community would not retreat from its demand that Iraq give up Kuwait. ``How could we not be disgusted by the taking of thousands of hostages?'' Mitterrand asked, referring to the 290 French citizens and other Westerners being held in Iraq and Kuwait. France, a former friend and arms merchant to Iraq, sent 4,000 troops to the gulf region after Iraqi soldiers raided the French ambassador's residence in Kuwait on Sept. 14. About a dozen foreign missions in the emirate are still resisting a month-old Iraqi order to close down. Iraq on Sunday offered a belated apology for the raid. It was spurned by France. ``Excuses are fine,'' Interior Minister Pierre Joxe said on French radio, ``but we're waiting for Iraq to let captive Frenchmen leave in a normal manner.'' At the United Nations, Mitterrand pointed to the dangers posed by the ``expansionist determination of one man, of one warlike state.'' ``In order to prevent this anarchy and theory of might makes right ... I can't find any other answer than the rule of law, of right,'' he said. The U.N. Security Council is expected to vote Tuesday on what would be the strictest resolution yet against Iraq. It would block all air traffic in and out of Iraq except for planes carrying humanitarian aid. Iraq warned Sunday it might target Israel and the oil fields of the Mideast if it is ``strangled'' by the sanctions and other steps against it. Israel said Monday it took the threat seriously, and warned Saddam not to underestimate its readiness to react. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Israelis were ready to ``confront, prevent and ... defend ourselves'' against Iraq. Saddam, meanwhile, accused the United States of being the aggressor in the gulf crisis. ``America poses a threat to mankind, emerging as a new tyranny in the world,'' the official Iraqi News Agency quoted him as telling a group of Islamic theologians. Saddam also insisted his armies would never pull back. ``Kuwait belongs to Iraq and we will never give it up even if we have to fight over it for a thousand years,'' he said. The global sanctions aimed at driving Iraq out of Kuwait are hurting other countries by depriving them of trade with Baghdad. The IMF on Monday approved an accelerated effort to supply billions of dollars to help them. The communique from IMF's policy-making interim committee gave no specifics on how much money would be forthcoming, but U.S. officials have said Egypt, Jordan and Turkey alone would need up to $16 billion in assistance through the end of next year. In other gulf-related developments Monday: -A convoy of 30 trucks loaded with food rolled out of Amman, Jordan's capital, bound for Baghdad with horns honking and flags flying. Hundreds of Jordanians cheered the violation of the U.N. embargo that bans shipments to Iraq unless cleared by the Security Council. The convoy was a symbol of the support Iraq enjoys in Jordan. -Iraq tightened its grip on Kuwait by abolishing the country's currency and replacing it with Iraqi dinars. The Iraqi currency is not convertible on the international market. -Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said Syrian President Hafez Assad was extending his stay in Tehran. Assad, Saddam's archenemy, came to Iran for talks that were to include inquiries about the Western hostages in Lebanon and Iran's intentions regarding the U.N. trade embargo against Iraq. -Three Indian ships, including one carrying food and medical supplies, docked at Umm Qasr in southern Iraq, shipping executives reported. They are to begin shuttling 100,000 stranded Indian nationals to the Persian Gulf port of Dubai.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins in Mapplethorpe Obscenity Trial
LaserPhotos CS1-3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 18th graf pvs, `A grand...,' to ADD that experts believe this is the first prosecution of its kind. Pick up 19th graf pvs, `Albanese denied...
DOC.TEXT: Potential jurors in an obscenity trial involving Robert Mapplethorpe's sexually explicit photos were asked Monday whether they look at Playboy magazine or attend arts fund-raisers. Many questioned during the first day of jury selection said they'd seen such adult magazines as Playboy, Penthouse and Hustler, but said they didn't subscribe. None acknowledged having taken an art class or attending a fund-raiser for the arts. The Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, were charged in April with pandering obscenity and displaying nude photos of children. The photographs were from the exhibit ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment.'' The seven-week exhibition of photographs by Mapplethorpe, who died of AIDS in March 1989, attracted a record crowd of more than 80,000 people to the gallery last spring. About 150 gay-rights and anti-censorship demonstrators protested the trial outside the Hamilton County Courthouse from mid-morning through the noon hour Monday. They sometimes disrupted traffic, but there were no arrests. The charges are both misdemeanors. If conviced, Barrie, 43, faces a possible fine of $1,000 and six months in jail on each count. The gallery could be fined $5,000 on each count. A panel of eight jurors and two alternates will be chosen to hear the trial in Hamilton County Municipal Court. Jury selection was expected to continue through Tuesday, with testimony lasting into next week. A pool of 50 prospective jurors was assembled Monday, but attorneys got less than halfway through questioning the first group of eight. ``Would you avoid a homosexual art display?'' the gallery's attorney, Marc Mezibov, asked one prospective juror. ``I wouldn't put out money to see homosexual art,'' the man responded. Mezibov also told prospective jurors that testimony will deal with Mapplethorpe's homosexuality. Prosecutor Frank Prouty asked prospective jurors whether they had seen Playboy, Penthouse or Hustler magazines and whether they had taken art classes or attended an arts fund-raiser. Judge David Albanese asked all 50 prospective jurors if they had any personal contact with the art community. One person said she was a member of the Contemporary Arts Center, and three said they had seen the exhibit. Protesters outside denounced the trial as homophobic intimidation. They chanted, ``Art on trial,'' and carried signs that said, ``Stop gay bashing'' and ``Art today, your bedroom tomorrow.'' Demonstrators, accompanied by mounted police, walked 10 blocks through downtown, twice passing the gallery. Some people lay in the street, briefly halting traffic. Catherine Adams, a lawyer for Gay-Lesbian March Activists, said she told city and county authorities last week that some members of the group had AIDS. About 50 officers, some of them wearing rubber gloves, set up barricades and patrolled the area. A grand jury indicted Barrie and the gallery, concluding that seven of the 175 Mapplethorpe photos violated community standards. One photo shows a man urinating into another man's mouth. Others show oral sex and anal penetration with objects. Officials of the American Civil Liberties Union and the Association of Art Museum Directors have said this is the first case they know of an obscenity prosecution of an art museum. Albanese denied a defense motion to declare a mistrial based on pretrial news reports, particularly use of phrases such as ``child pornography.'' He also denied a motion to limit potential jurors to Cincinnati residents. Because of the structure of the Hamilton County Municipal Court, the jury pool is drawn from residents of Cincinnati and its suburbs. The judge denied a motion to allow individual questioning of potential jurors and denied a defense request to increase the number of pre-emptory challenges.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 44 Killed as Gas Truck Crashes, Explodes in Bangkok
DOC.TEXT: A gas truck overturned and exploded at a busy Bangkok intersection, engulfing cars, shops and a women's dormitory in flames that killed at least 44 people, police said Tuesday. Another 97 were injured, many seriously, said Col. Wanlop Watjanapooka, the deputy commander of northern Bangkok police. He said the 10-wheel truck overturned near the railway crossing at New Petchburi Road shortly after 10 p.m. Monday. Liquified gas gushed out of its tanks and burst into flames that swept over 43 cars and a total of 30 shops and other buildings on both sides of the street, including the dormitory. There was no immediate information on where most of the 44 fatalities occurred. It also was not immediately known how the truck overturned.

DOC.HEAD: Toddler Kills Brother While Playing `Cowboys and Indians'
DOC.TEXT: A 5-year-old boy died Monday after being shot by his toddler brother while they played ``cowboys and Indians'' with loaded pistols, police said. Changxue Thao died at University of Wisconsin Hospital in Madison of wounds inflicted when his two-year-old brother, Vangleng, shot him in the forehead with a .22-caliber revolver Sunday night, police said. The shooting took place in an upstairs bedroom where the loaded guns had been hidden. The boys had been punished once earlier this month for playing with the guns, police said. ``It looks like the two kids were playing cowboys and Indians when one of the guns went off,'' Police Inspector Gerald Christianson said. The boys' parents, Xay and Seng Thao, were out. A 15-year-old sister was downstairs watching three other children when the shooting took place, police said. Marathon County District Attorney Greg Grau said he didn't expect to file charges in the case but would make a final decision once the investigation and autopsy are completed.

DOC.HEAD: French Warn Iraq that Kuwait Invasion Will Not be Tolerated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with steps toward peace advanced by French president. Picks up 7th graf, `Soviet Foreign...'
DOC.TEXT: French President Francois Mitterrand on Monday denounced Iraq as a warlike state and warned Baghdad the international community would not retreat from its demand that the Iraqis give up Kuwait. He and other speakers set the stage for a Security Council vote Tuesday afternoon on extending trade sanctions against Iraq to include an air embargo. At the same time, however, Mitterrand also held out an olive branch. He said ``if Iraq were to withdraw its troops and free the hostages, everything might be possible'' - and suggested that other areas of discord in the Middle East could be helped toward peace. Leaders from Brazil, Argentina, Poland and Indonesia joined the chorus of condemnation of Iraq that opened the 45th session of the General Assembly, while the Iraqi ambassador watched in silence. Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati broadened his criticism to include the United States, saying its military buildup was aimed at backing imperial U.S. designs - not defending the nations of the Persian Gulf. The French president flew to New York on the Concorde for a brief appearance here, speaking in French through a translator. Mitterrand told the 159-nation General Assembly, ``Let us be clear about this. There is no compromise as long as Iraq does not comply with resolutions of the Security Council and withdraw from Kuwait. The sovereignty of that country is not negotiable.'' He later held out the possibility of peace, outlining these three general steps toward that goal: -Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and freeing of thousands of Westerners held captive by Iraq; -International guarantees for withdrawal of foreign military forces, restoration of the legitimate government of Kuwait and the democratic will of the Kuwaiti people; -``Replacing confrontation with the dynamics of good neighborliness and security and peace for each country.'' He said this could ultimately spread a spirit of reconciliation to Lebanon, the Palestinian people and Israel but did not elaborate. Mitterrand also said a later stage would involve agreed mutual reductions of armaments in the area. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd told reporters they expected the air embargo resolution to be adopted Tuesday. ``We want action. There is no other way,'' Shevardnadze said through a translator. Hurd, asked about recent bellicose comments by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, said: ``His statements will remain uncompromising until the day he decides to leave Kuwait, or he is thrown out of Kuwait.'' On Sunday, Saddam hinted he would make Mideast oil fields and Israel his targets if Iraqis were ``strangled'' by sanctions and other steps. Shevardnadze called those comments ``inadmissable'' and added: ``Any attacks would unleash a war and that would mean disaster.'' The Security Council on Monday adopted a brief resolution calling for aid to about a dozen nations suffering economic hardship as a result of the embargo against Iraq. Mitterrand, whose government has denounced Iraq for invading French and other diplomatic premises in Kuwait, was unsparing in his condemnation of the Baghdad government. Iraq's U.N. ambassador, Abdul Amir Al-Anbari, listened impassively from his seat as the French president spoke. Iraq has apologized to France for the raid on its ambassador's residence, but Mitterrand rejected Iraq's apology, saying Saddam has offered ``not one gesture, not one word'' to defuse the crisis. He said French ships and troops would remain in the Persian Gulf until ``our mission is accomplished.'' The United States has not given its permission for an Iraqi Airways flight to land in New York with an Iraqi delegation from Baghdad. U.S. officials have advised them to take commercial flights instead, Iraq said. Aziz said in Baghdad that his government would not participate in the three-week debate of world speakers because of the U.S. restrictions. Iraq said Monday it had rejected a U.S. offer to allow the plane to land in exchange for the freeing of Westerners, including 1,000 Americans, trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. In his speech, Mitterrand said Iraqi aggression against Kuwait is an example of the ``law of the jungle.'' ``How could we not be disgusted by the taking of thousands of hostages?'' he asked. ``Kuwait is a sovereign state, a member of the international community. In the name of what can one decide that this state has ceased to exist? In the name of the law of planes, tanks and trucks?'' The French president warned that neighboring nations were endangered by the ``warlike state'' of Iraq. The assembly's annual parade of world leaders, which began Monday, was dominated by the Persian Gulf crisis. Brazilian President Fernando Collor de Mello, the first speaker, said the crisis ``presents an unexpected and serious threat to collective peace.''

DOC.HEAD: New Orleans Publisher Elected President of SNPA
DOC.TEXT: Ashton Phelps Jr., president and publisher of The Times-Picayune of New Orleans, was elected president of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association at the group's 87th annual convention Sept. 17. Phelps succeeds James F. Urbanski, president of the Tampa (Fla.) Tribune. Urbanski was elected president of the SNPA board of directors. W. deBerniere Mebane, president of Multimedia Newspaper Co. of Greenville, S.C., was named president-elect. Edmund O. Martin, vice president and general manager of Oklahoma Publishing Co. of Oklahoma City, was elected treasurer. New directors elected were William C. Green Jr., publisher of The Huntsville (Ala.) Times and News; David E. Easterly, president of Cox Newspapers of Atlanta; Ed Livermore, publisher of the Edmond (Okla.) Evening Sun; George B. Irish, publisher of the San Antonio (Texas) Light; and Walter Rugaber, publisher of the Roanoke (Va. ) Times & World-News. Frank McDonald, president of the Chattanooga (Tenn.) News-Free Press, was elected to the board to fill the unexpired term of Harry H. Browning, who resigned as the director from Tennessee when he became publisher of the Palladium-Item of Richmond, Ind. R. Sidney Crim, president of The State of Columbia, S.C., was elected chairman of the board of trustees of the SNPA Foundation. John C. Ginn, publisher of the Anderson (S.C.) Independent-Mail, was re-elected vice chairman of the foundation. Elected treasurer was Harold R. Lifvendahl, president and publisher of The Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel.
DOC.HEAD: Industry Leaders Recommend SPJ Changes
DOC.TEXT: A panel studying the Society of Professional Journalists recommends the group adopt a simple mission statement that focuses on freedom of information issues. The Industry Advisory Committee will deliver its report to the SPJ board of directors at the society's annual convention next month in Louisville, Ky. The group recommends creating a new board to govern SPJ, and creating a special class of non-voting members to include public relations workers and former members who are no longer journalists. Committee members include: David Lawrence, publisher of The Miami Herald; Paul Steinle, president of Steinle Communications and former president of United Press International; John Seigenthaler, chairman and publisher of The Tennessean in Nashville and editorial director of USA Today; Katherine Fanning, former editor of The Christian Science Monitor; Russell Pulliam, an editorial writer for The Indianapolis News; Jean Gaddy Wilson, executive director of New Directions for News, a newspaper industry think tank at the University of Missouri; Paul Davis, news director of Chicago's WGN-TV; and Jean Otto, associate editor of the Rocky Mountain News in Denver. Fanning said the recommendations are ``an opportunity to become relevant to the news industry into the 1990s and the next century, a very integral, important element.''
DOC.HEAD: Washington Post Defends Reporter Arrested While Working on Story
DOC.TEXT: The managing editor of The Washington Post says a reporter broke no law when he was arrested for allegedly contributing to the delinquency of a minor while working on a story. ``I'm particularly concerned that the police pursued this after the reporter identified himself and his purpose, and that the police took his notes,'' said Managing Editor Leonard Downie, Jr. Michael J. Ybarra, 23, a reporter with the Post's Metro staff was arrested late Sept. 21 while working on a report about a new curfew for minors in Quantico, Va. He was taken into custody and his notes confiscated while conducting an interview of two 12-year-old boys in a restaurant in the Virginia town about 30 miles south of the nation's capital. The Quantico Town Council recently imposed a 10 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew for youths under age 18 following recent vandalism in the area. Ybarra is the second adult charged in connection with a curfew violation, but no youths have been arrested. ``I believe that the reporter was trying to do his job and just got mixed up at the wrong place and the wrong time,'' said Leo Rodriguez, Quantico's police chief. Rodriguez said the reporter's notes were held as evidence but a copy would be made available to the Post. Ybarra, who was released on his own recognizance, is to be arraigned in Prince William County Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court on Sept. 25. The charge carries a maximum penalty of one year in jail and a $2,500 fine. Ybarra's supervisors said the reporter was not available for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Iowa High Court Backs Sales Tax Exemption for Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: A law applying Iowa's 4 percent sales tax to magazines while exempting newspapers was upheld by the state Supreme Court. The court found ``no censorial threat, motive, or element'' imposed by the state's tax policy and rejected a constitutional challenge by Hearst Corp., publisher of Cosmopolitan, Good Housekeeping, Popular Mechanics, Harper's Bazaar, Sports Afield and Town and Country. ``The focus is not on the content of the journalism,'' the court said Sept. 19. ``Rather, the form and frequency of the publication are the primary factors for determining whether a publication qualifies for the Iowa sales and use tax exemption.'' Hearst had argued the tax law violated First Amendment guarantees of freedom of the press. Giving the state the power to tax different publications at different levels or to exempt some amounts to granting censorship powers, the company argued. Under Iowa tax laws, newspapers do not pay the 4 percent sales tax that magazines and other periodicals are required to pay. Regulations spell out the definitions of ``magazine'' and ``newspaper'' for tax purposes, the most crucial centering on how often they are published. The court conceded a tax exemption is a government subsidy but said legislators were within their rights in providing such a subsidy as long as it doesn't discriminate between similar media and ``is not impermissibly directed at a publication's content.'' Hearst also had said the tax policy violated equal protection provisions, but the court rejected that argument, saying that while legislators cannot use a taxing power to block press organizations, they are not required to help them either. ``The constitution does not require that the government remove all obstacles in the path of the exercise of a person's rights,'' said the opinion. ``Where government subsidies are not aimed at the suppression of dangerous ideas, its power to encourage actions deemed to be in the public interest is necessarily far broader.'' Hearst also contended the tax law favored Iowa-based companies, but the court rejected that, saying newspapers were exempt from the tax no matter where they were published.
DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Establishes Unit To Oversee Magazines, Books
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. has appointed magazine group boss Reginald K. Brack Jr. to head a new publishing unit that will oversee both its book and magazine divisions. The new unit will be called Time Warner Publishing Inc., an announcement said Sept. 19. It will oversee Time Inc. Magazine Co., with about $2 billion in revenue a year, and Time Inc. Book Co., with more than $1 billion in annual revenue. Time Warner, which also has interests in films, television, cable TV systems and recorded music, generates about $11 billion a year in revenue. Brack will be chairman of the new unit while retaining his titles as chairman, president and chief executive of the magazine company. Its titles include Time, Life, Sports Illustrated, People and Fortune. Brack has headed the magazine operations since 1986 and previously was chief executive of the book operations. Kelso Sutton remains as chairman and president of the book company but will report to Brack. The book company includes Little, Brown; Warner Books; Time-Life Books; and Book-of-the-Month Club.
DOC.HEAD: Councilman Charged With Assaulting Newspaper Writer
DOC.TEXT: A city councilman was charged with attacking and choking a newspaper reporter during a public meeting at a community center, police said. Council Vice Chairman Yusuf Hakeem, 41, was arrested and charged with assault Sept. 20 after he allegedly grabbed Carl Patton by the throat during the meeting. The incident occurred at the Carver Community Center and was witnessed by those at the meeting, where Hakeem was explaining council decisions to people in his district. Witnesses said Hakeem became upset at persistent questions from Patton, who writes for the Chattanooga News Weekly. Hakeem was arrested on a warrant signed by Patton and was released on $500 bond. Patton's paper has been critical of Hakeem in news stories and editorials. Hakeem was among four blacks elected last spring to the new nine-member City Council after a federal judge declared the old five-member City Commission discriminatory. Patton, who also is black, unsuccessfully ran for mayor in the same election.

DOC.HEAD: Audio, Video Equipment Banned at Neil Bush Hearing
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators say audio and video recording equipment won't be allowed at the Sept. 25 public hearing on Neil Bush's role in the failure of Silverado Banking savings and loan. Bush, who faces charges that he acted improperly as a director of Silverado, was scheduled to testify. He was an outside director of Silverado from 1985 until shortly before the thrift was seized by regulators in 1988. Bush has been accused of conflicts of interest in his dealings with former developers Ken Good and Bill Walters, two major Silverado borrowers. The decision not to allow recording equipment angered Rep. Pat Schroeder, D-Colo., and the Colorado Broadcasters Association. Dan Buck, an administrative assistant to Schroeder, said he understood the federal Office of Thrift Supervision wanting to avoid turning the hearing into a circus. ``But the taxpayers have already bought $1 billion worth of ducats to the Silverado failure, and they should be able to see the investigative process,'' he said. Past administrative hearings have been closed to the public entirely. In July, because of interest in the national savings and loan fiasco, the policy was changed, but recording devices still are not permitted at Office of Thrift Supervision hearings. The broadcasters' association sent a letter to the agency's director, Timothy Ryan, requesting at least one television camera inside the Neil Bush hearing. The association also asked Ryan to move the hearing from Denver's federal courthouse building, where video equipment never is permitted. He suggested other hearing sites that allow cameras, including the University of Denver and state and county courtrooms. ``The broadcast media makes a judgment in terms of what they believe the public is most interested in,'' said Andrew Low, an attorney for the association and KUSA-TV in Denver. ``It is beyond question that Neil Bush's involvement in the failure of Silverado is of considerable public interest, particularly in Colorado where Neil Bush lives,'' Low said.
DOC.HEAD: FCC Chairman Says Budget Hearings May Delay Cable Bill Vote
DOC.TEXT: Legislation to re-regulate the cable television industry may not get a final vote by Congress this year, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission told broadcasters Sept. 18. Alfred C. Sikes said the continuing House-Senate negotiations on the federal budget could cause the delay. The House has passed a cable bill but a vote on a similar measure in the Senate still is pending. He made the remarks in responding to questions posed at a lunch held by the International Radio and Television Society in New York. Only a month ago, Sikes said, he would have said he felt ``there was a substantial likelihood'' of a final vote by both houses this year. But now, ``I think that in some ways the fate of the cable legislation is tied to (federal) budget negotiations,'' he said. As the talks drag on and if negotiators ``tighten the rules on floor action in Congress, it would seem to me that the cable legislation will run out of time'' for a final vote before the current session of Congress ends, he said. The Bush administration strongly opposes the House bill, saying Congress should instead encourage new forms of competition to cable. That industry was largely freed of regulation by Congress in 1984. Among other things, the House measure, passed in response to increasing complaints about overpricing and shoddy cable TV service, would impose federal price limits on basic cable service. It also would give the FCC power to order price rollbacks on the worst offenders and boost competition to cable, which now serves 58.9 percent of the nation's 93.1 million homes with TV, according to Nielsen estimates.
DOC.HEAD: Newton Will Appeal NBC Libel Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Wayne Newton asked a federal appeals court to reconsider a ruling that overturned his record $5.2 million libel judgment against NBC News for a 1980 broadcast linking him to organized crime. Lawyers for Newton said the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ``overlooked or misconstrued'' some evidence and interpreted other evidence unfairly in favor of NBC in its Aug. 30 ruling. In a petition asking for a rehearing, the attorneys said that failing to overturn the verdict would ``chill the rights of public figures to bring defamation suits against powerful media defendants.'' Newton attorney Morton Galane said Sept. 20 that he filed the petition. A jury in Las Vegas found that NBC's story falsely implied that organized crime figures had helped Newton buy the Aladdin Hotel and Casino in exchange for a hidden interest. It awarded Newton $19.3 million, but that was later reduced to $5.2 million, mostly in punitive damages

DOC.HEAD: Man Gets Five Years in Extortion Plot Against Anchorwoman
DOC.TEXT: A man who tried to extort $30,000 from a local anchorwoman to block publication of nude photos that did not exist was sentenced to five years in prison. ``He's a leech,'' KTLA-TV anchorwoman Jann Carl said after Superior Court Judge Jacqueline Connor imposed the maximum penalty on Gilbert Cabot. A jury convicted Cabot, 44, of attempted extortion and conspiracy in connection with the 1988 plot. Prosecutors described Cabot as a veteran con artist. They said Cabot called Carl and told her a woman planned to sell nude photos of the anchorwoman to a national magazine. Cabot said that the photos were taken from a sexually explicit videotape and that he could block their publication by paying the woman $30,000, prosecutors said. Carl, knowing the video did not exist, went to the police, who arrested Cabot in a sting operation. Defense attorney Rowan Klein contended Cabot did not attempt to extort money.
DOC.HEAD: FCC Gives Chicago License to `More Qualified' Applicant
DOC.TEXT: The owners of WSNS-TV in Chicago lost a lengthy license renewal battle Sept. 19 when the Federal Communications Commission, in a rare move, said a competing applicant was more deserving to run the station. The commission granted Monroe Communications Corp. a license to build a new TV station on channel 44. It said Monroe was more qualified than the current licensee, Video 44, which had switched the station's format to a subscription movie service. Monroe, which began seeking the license in 1982, also claimed Video 44 had broadcast obscene material, but the FCC did not reach a decision on that allegation. The FCC almost never denies license renewals to incumbents and already had given Video 44 a renewal in 1989. But the commission reconsidered the case under orders from a federal appeals court in Washington. Video 44 may appeal the decision to the appeals court. Otherwise, it must discontinue operations 90 days after the FCC formally releases its renewal order, which could occur sometime in the next week or so, FCC spokeswoman Maureen Peratino said.
DOC.HEAD: Jury Indicts 4 in TV Station Pit-Bull Case
DOC.TEXT: A television reporter was indicted Sept. 20 along with two cameramen on charges they staged pit-bull fights for a news story and lied about it to a grand jury. The Jefferson County grand jury also indicted Guy Walker, the owner of the dogs, on two counts of dog fighting. The three KCNC-TV employees have resigned from the station. Reporter Wendy Bergen was indicted on two counts of perjury, one count conspiracy to commit perjury, three counts of dogfighting, two counts of promoting a dogfight and one count of hindering prosecution. Cameraman James Stair was charged with one count of perjury, one count of dogfighting, one count of promoting a dog fight and one count of hindering prosecution. Scott Wright, another cameraman, was indicted on one count of perjury and one count of hindering prosecution. The indictment alleges Bergen and Walker staged dog fights last September and October. A third dog fight was staged by Bergen and Stair in March of this year, it claims. Dog fighting is illegal in Colorado and is punishable by up to four years in prison and a $1,000 fine. Conviction on a perjury charge carries a maximum penalty of eight years in prison and a $500,000 fine. Prosecutors had investigated allegations Bergen arranged the fights to show during a so-called ``sweeps'' ratings period, when competition for viewers is especially high. The four-part series on pit-bull fighting was broadcast April 30 to May 2 and featured a fight between two unmuzzled dogs. KCNC-TV had said earlier that an anonymous person mailed a videotape of the fight to the station, but later revised its statement to say its employees attended the fight, but did not stage it. In a statement Sept. 21, however, the station said certain segments of the story ``represented as actual dog training sessions were, in fact, staged re-creations of dog training activities, but were not identified as such.'' The station said it was looking into the charges further.
DOC.HEAD: Commercial News Show Signs 4,200 Schools in 45 States
DOC.TEXT: Producers of the Channel One commercial news show for students say they are more than halfway toward a goal of signing 8,000 schools. Meanwhile, a daily news program without commercials, produced by CNN, is gaining ground. More than 12,000 schools have indicated interest in using CNN Newsroom, Turner Broadcasting System Inc. says. Other cable TV networks, such as C-SPAN, The Discovery Channel and The Learning Channel, are either producing shows or stepping up efforts to promote existing ad-free services for use in the classroom. Channel One delivers 12 minutes a day of topical teen-oriented stories to classrooms, along with pitches for candy, sneakers and chips. The show is produced by Whittle Communications of Knoxville, Tenn., nd seen in 45 states. Whittle tested its program in the spring of 1989 and made it available to schools nationwide starting last March. Schools that agree to show the program to all of their students every day get a loan of videocassette recorders, TV monitors for every classroom and wiring to tie the system together. They get to keep the equipment as long as they keep showing the program.

DOC.HEAD: Claiborne Named VP at Park Communications
DOC.TEXT: Jack Claiborne, associate editor of The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer, has been named vice president and assistant to the chairman of Park Communications Inc. Roy H. Park, chairman and chief executive officer, announced the appointment Sept. 19. Claiborne succeeds Walter W. Borton, who is leaving to become executive vice president and chief operating officer of The Pacific Group, a Los Angeles management consulting firm. Claiborne joined the Observer in 1948 as a sports writer. He is the author of several books, including ``The Charlotte Observer: Its Time and Place, 1869-1986,'' published on the newspaper's centennial.
DOC.HEAD: Wood Named President and Publisher of Peninsula Papers
DOC.TEXT: Robert E. Wood will become president and publisher of the Peninsula Times Tribune and president of Peninsula Community Newspapers on Oct. 1. Wood, formerly the publishing director of Modern Maturity magazine, succeeds Peter E. Heraty, who resigned. Wood began his career as a reporter with the Los Angeles Times and was a member of the newspaper's editorial board when he joined Cowles Media Co. in 1978 as president of its regional printer, Information Publishers Inc. In 1982, he moved to the American Association of Retired Persons as director of publications. The Palo Alto Times and the Redwood City Tribune were merged into the Peninsula Times Tribune in 1978. Peninsula Community Newspapers is a group of 12 weekly papers published in Santa Clara and San Mateo counties.
DOC.HEAD: Roberts To Be Senior Editor of Washington Journalism Review
DOC.TEXT: Eugene L. Roberts Jr. has been named to the advisory position of senior editor of the Washington Journalism Review. Roberts will take the position next September when he joins the faculty of the University of Maryland journalism school, which publishes the magazine. Roberts announced his retirement from The Philadelphia Inquirer in July. The newspaper won 17 Pulitzer Prizes during the 18 years he was there.
DOC.HEAD: Wilkerson Resigns Times Herald Post
DOC.TEXT: Ray Wilkerson, managing editor of the Dallas Times Herald, announced his resignation Sept. 19, saying he will take a vacation and pursue other career options. Wilkerson joined the newspaper in 1982 and was named managing editor in 1988. ``Ray is an old friend, a valued colleague and one of the finest journalists I have known,'' said Editor Roy E. Bode. Wilkerson, a former Times Herald assistant managing editor, left the paper in 1986 to become managing editor of The North Jersey Herald & News under Bode, who was editor of the Passaic, N.J., newspaper. Wilkerson began his newspaper career at the Omaha (Neb.) World-Herald in 1968. He later held various editing posts at Knight-Ridder newspapers in Miami and Wichita, Kan.
DOC.HEAD: Reuters Announces Board Changes
DOC.TEXT: Reuters editor-in-chief Mark Wood and deputy finance director Rob Rowley were appointed executive directors of Reuters Holdings PLC on Sept. 19. Both were previously alternate directors. Rowley also became finance director, replacing Nigel Judah, who remains company secretary.

Lewis W. Coleman, a ongtime Oklahoma radio station owner and manager, died Sept. 20 of a heart attack. He was 61. Coleman had been general manager of KIKM-FM in Sherman since 1988. During his career in Oklahoma, he managed and owned radio stations in six cities. Survivors include a brother, one son, six daughters and 10 grandchildren.

Thomas J. Hooper Sr., a former writer and editor at the Newark Evening News, died of a stroke Sept. 18. He was 71. Hooper joined the News in 1947 after serving as an Army journalist during World War II. He became editorial writer in 1968 and was acting editor of the editorial page when the News folded in 1972. After the paper closed, he began a 16-year stint as a public information officer for the state treasury and insurance departments. Survivors include his wife, nine children, a sister and 17 grandchildren.

Lucien ``Lou'' Parlin, an editorial writer for the St. Paul Pioneer Press and the St. Paul Dispatch for 23 years, died Sept. 19. He was 92. Parlin was named city editor of the St. Paul Dispatch in 1938. He later became political writer for the paper and was its Washington, D.C., correspondent. He was named an editorial writer for both St. Paul papers in 1951 and associate editor of the editorial page in 1958. He retired in 1975. Survivors include his wife, two daughters, six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

Robert Rodale, who built a publishing empire from his father's magazines Prevention and Organic Gardening, died Sept. 19 in a car accident in Moscow. He was 60. Rodale was in the Soviet Union to set up a Russian-language edition of The New Farmer, one of numerous publications of Rodale Press Inc., which is based here. Survivors include his wife, mother, three daughters, a son, seven grandchildren and two sisters.

Al Schriner, who rose from messenger boy to editorial art director in a 45-year career at The Pittsburgh Press, died of complications from an aneurysm Sept. 22. He was 61. Schriner began working at the Press in 1945 as a messenger in the dispatch room. Eight months later, he switched to the editorial art department. He became assistant manager of the art department in 1963 and manager six years later. In 1981, he was named editorial art director. Survivors include his wife, three daughters and two sons.

Lord Swann, the governor and chairman of the British Broadcasting Corp. from 1973 to 1980, died Sept. 22. He was 70. The cause of death was not given. Michael Meredith Swann had a distinguished scientific career as a biologist before joining the BBC and served on a number of government and scientific committees. When his term as chairman of the BBC ended, he became provost at Oriel College, Oxford. He is survived by his wife, two sons and two daughters.

Dao Tung, editor in chief of the official Vietnam News Agency, died Sept. 15 in Hanoi, the agency announced. He was 65. The cause of death was not reported. He was a member of the National Assembly and vice president and secretary-general of the Vietnam Journalists Association.
DOC.HEAD: Trudeau, Vidal Honored
DOC.TEXT: American cartoonist Garry Trudeau and author Gore Vidal were honored Sept. 22 for political satire and literature. Trudeau, creator of the ``Doonesbury'' comic strip, was given Italy's Forte dei Marmi Prize for satire. Vidal, best known for his historical novels ``Burr'' and ``Lincoln,'' received the literary award for his book ``Hollywood.''

USA Today founder Al Neuharth has simple advice for publishers hit by the slumping retail economy: ``Put more news in your newspapers and charge more for it.'' Neuharth spoke at the convention of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association in Colorado Springs, Colo. ``Every public newspaper company could have avoided or curtailed the current profit slump if management stopped blaming advertisers and instead prudently priced its products to the reader. Compared to other small ticket items, any good newspaper in the USA today should be selling for 50 cents or more.'' . . . Writer George Plimpton has played a quarterback in the pros and pitched to major leaguers, but he said his most frightening experience in ``participatory journalism'' was playing percussion with the New York Philharmonic. ``In music, you can't make a mistake,'' Plimpton said. ``In music, if you make a mistake, you destroy something - you destroy a piece of art.''
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is readying a plan to provide weapons needed immediately to protect oil-rich Saudi Arabia and the American soldiers serving there, says Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The first phase of a two-part package will be sent to Congress for approval early this week, Baker said Sunday. Baker refused to put a price tag on the package, but other sources said the first installment will total $10 billion, with the full plan valued at around $21 billion. The second part is expected to be sent to Congress early next year. President Bush agreed to submit the weapons proposal in two installments after members of Congress, particularly those close to Israel, objected to the size of the deal. But Baker, appearing on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press,'' insisted Bush was not revising his plans for the Saudis. ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - A court decision allowing audio tapes of counseling to be used in a murder trial has mental health professionals worried that the ancient tradition of patient confidentiality is in danger. California courts opened the door to the psychotherapist's office a bit wider with a decision Aug. 6 allowing tapes of counseling to be used against brothers Lyle and Erik Menendez in the slaying of their parents. Jose and Kitty Menendez were shot repeatedly at close range in their Beverly Hills mansion in 1989. Six months later, police arrested Lyle, 21, and Erik, 19, alleging the young men coveted their parents' $15 million estate. Prosecutors argued that tapes of the brothers' counseling sessions with therapist L. Jerome Oziel, in which they reportedly confessed to killing their parents, could be used as evidence. Superior Court Judge James Albracht agreed, saying the tapes were not covered by laws guarding patient-therapist communication. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The Japanese admiral who planned the Pearl Harbor attack got the idea from a British novel, says a new book examining U.S. and Japanese strategy in World War II. Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto - who insisted on the 1941 surprise raid that destroyed much of the U.S. Pacific Fleet at its base in Hawaii - based his strategy on a book that had Washington buzzing when Yamamoto was Japanese naval attache here from 1926 to 1928, says author William H. Honan. The 1925 novel, ``The Great Pacific War'' by Hector C. Bywater, begins with a surprise Japanese attack in 1931 that wipes out much of the U.S. Asiatic fleet. Honan's book, ``Bywater: The Man Who Invented the Pacific War,'' went on sale earlier this month in England. It is due for U.S. publication in February with the title ``The Man Who Knew Too Much: How Hector C. Bywater Invented the Great Pacific War.'' ---= ENGLISH, Ind. (AP) - The people of English, fed up with floods, are packing up Main Street and moving to higher ground. In one of the most ambitious projects of its kind, the town plans to tear down or move more than 70 homes as well as the library, the bank, the newspaper and about 30 other businesses. A new downtown is planned a mile away on a hillside now covered by cornfields and trees. The town of 650 people in one of the state's poorest counties hopes to raise $6 million for the move from a half-dozen state and federal agencies. ---= PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Everyone agrees this city is in deep fiscal trouble. Everyone disagrees on what to do about it. Philadelphia faces a $206 million deficit by June 30, the end of the fiscal year, and Wall Street has turned up its nose at short-term notes to keep the city's bills paid through May. On Friday, Mayor W. Wilson Goode announced a hiring freeze and delays in pension fund payments and tax refunds, freeing up $122 million. But the city still expects to go broke by Dec. 1. ``If Philadelphia has even a temporary period without sufficient cash, the result will be a legal, political and public safety nightmare,'' Finance Director Betsy C. Reveal said in a recent memo to Goode.
