DOC.TEXT: This time novelist Jackie Collins can't whine about the way some screenwriter handled her work. Collins wrote her own screenplay for the three-part drama ``Jackie Collins' `Lucky-Chances','' scheduled for Sunday, Monday and Tuesday on NBC. It's taken from two books that follow the lives of Gino Santangelo and his daughter, Lucky. ``I wanted to get involved because I hate writers who whine about how their work's treated,'' said Collins, who recalls an unhappy experience when her novel ``Hollywood Wives'' was given to other writers for a miniseries in 1985. This time she was not going to stand by and see another writer adapt her two novels for the 6-hour miniseries based on ``Lucky'' and ``Chances.'' ``I'm pleased, and I think I captured its humor and vitality,'' she says. ``I can't whine to anybody, because I did it. ``This is more fun than `Hollywood Wives.' That miniseries was not like the book at all. `Hollywood Wives' had 12 major stars, all playing the wrong roles. They had Angie Dickinson as the agent. To cast her as a woman who couldn't get a date was ridiculous.'' Collins says that for ``Lucky-Chances'' she had an equal hand in casting with executive producer Susan Baerwald and director Buzz Kulik. Vincent Irizarry stars as Gino, a tough street kid who builds an empire that includes Las Vegas casinos. Nicollette Sheridan stars as Lucky, who threatens to take it all away from him. The glitzy miniseries, awash with passion and intrigue in the sun-drenched haunts of the rich and powerful, also stars Anne-Marie Johnson, Michael Nader, Eric Braeden, Stephanie Beacham, Mary Frann, Leann Hunley, David McCallum, Sandra Bullock, Phil Morris, Harold P. Pruett, Audrey Landers, Tim Ryan, Luca Bercovici and Shawnee Smith. Collins' latest book, ``Lady Boss,'' in which Lucky Santangelo takes over the last privately owned movie studio, is also attracting attention as a possible miniseries on NBC. Collins has spent the last 20 years writing about sex, love, beautiful people and exotic locations. She writes from the inside. She is the sister of television vamp Joan Collins, who recently wrote her own best seller. Jackie Collins' husband, Oscar Lerman, is owner of the Tramp Club in London. ``That's where I got all the wonderful gossip for `Rock Star,' my last book before `Lady Boss,''' she says. As for her sister, she says, ``Joan lives in France and I only see her when I get to Europe. We're the best of friends, contrary to popular belief.'' Despite an abundance of sex in her books, Collins contends that's not what makes them best sellers. ``They're not successful because they're lusty,'' she says. ``Sex alone doesn't sell, believe me. I think they're successful because of the humor. They're a great send-up. People do read them for other reasons, but my true fans read them for the humor. They also love a good story, good relationships and good characters.'' Collins says she still writes the old-fashioned way. ``I write with a pen in a book,'' she says. ``I write 10 to 12 pages a day. My secretary puts them on the word processor and I make the changes.'' She contends that ``Lucky-Chances,'' which begins in the 1930s, is based on reality. ``You're not getting the front pages of the tabloids,'' she says. ``You're getting the truth, but I'm protecting the innocent. It's an American drama of a street kid who rises to fame. He looks around to see who the heroes of the day are, and they're gangsters. He becomes a gangster with a heart of gold and he has a daughter who becomes his rival.'' The books have all the ingredients of the genre: the prostitute who becomes a society lady, the son from the secret liaison, the Greek shipping magnate, and the woman who marries for money and gets it all when her husband suddenly dies. The miniseries will be up against the American and National League baseball playoff games on CBS. The games Sunday and Tuesday will be played in prime time on the East Coast. ``Am I nervous being up against the playoffs?'' she says. ``Who's going to watch baseball when you can have Nicollette Sheridan?'' Collins, who has published 13 books, including several best sellers, says she began writing at the age of 8. ``I made up stories,'' she says. ``It's like when you were around the campfire and told stories. I was thrown out of school a 15 for waving to the resident flasher. And I smoked in my school uniform and was truant a lot. I had a lot of adventures. You have to have adventures to be able to write. I was a wild child and when I started to write in my 20s, I knew plenty. ``I find it interesting that so many people try to copy my work. They think if you're a woman and good-looking you can write. They don't realize the amount of work that goes into it.''

DOC.TEXT: Timberlake Wertenbaker's new play, ``Our Country's Good,'' is taking the regional theater circuit by storm. The drama celebrates a real-life event, the first theatrical performance in Australia. That was in 1789 when a group of English convicts staged George Farquhar's early 18th-century comedy, ``The Recruiting Officer.'' Does that sound unpromising and esoteric? Not to the London critics who cheered when ``Our Country's Good'' premiered at the Royal Court Theater in 1988 and later won the Olivier Award for play of the year. And not to artistic directors on the regional theater circuit in the United States and in Canada. They have made it one of the most-produced new plays of this season. ``Our Country's Good'' had its American premiere last fall at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles and then in April it was done at the Remains Theater in Chicago. The Repertory Theater in St. Louis has just finished a production, while Hartford Stage in Connecticut has a version directed by Mark Lamos now running. Other productions are planned for the New American Theater in Rockford, Ill.; the Oregon Shakespeare Festival in Portland; California's Berkeley Repertory Theater and A Contemporary Theater in Seattle. In Canada, there will be productions in Edmonton, Montreal and Halifax this season. ``The play has wonderful insights into the ideas of making theater and that's always interesting to people like me,'' says Lamos, artistic director at Hartford Stage, where the play is on view through Nov. 3. ``On a larger level, it's about the power of education. How education can transform people's lives.'' ``Our Country's Good'' originally was inspired by ``The Playmaker,'' a novel by Australian writer Thomas Keneally. ``It would be unfair to the novel to say that the play is an adaptation,'' Wertenbaker said in a telephone interview from a New Hampshire vacation retreat. ``There are characters that don't appear in the novel, and the plot is slightly changed.'' The Keneally book was brought to her in London by Max Stafford-Clark who runs the Royal Court, that shrine of modern British drama which first gave the world such classics as John Osborne's ``Look Back in Anger.'' ``I said I wouldn't adapt `The Playmaker' but I would be very interested in doing something on the same subject,'' the playwright recalled. Wertenbaker used the novel as well as ``The Fatal Shore,'' a history of an Australian penal colony by Robert Hughes, as the taking-off points for her play. She also did a lot of research at the British Museum into the journals of the real-life main character, an idealistic lieutenant who directed the convicts in the Farquhar comedy. Wertenbaker and the actors who eventually were cast in the play at the Royal Court also interviewed former prisoners who were involved in theater. ``What interested me was the notion of the redemptive power of theater which is in the novel and I suppose was something I believed in anyway,'' the playwright said. ``We would ask them about what theater had meant to them. They had found a great deal of freedom by being involved in theater during their prison sentences.'' ``Our Country's Good'' is a big play - 22 characters and 22 scenes. ``I wanted to follow quite a lot of characters,'' Wertenbaker said. ``And that's always difficult to construct, to keep the characters straight and to keep their stories going throughout the play.'' Wertenbaker wrote the play under deadline pressure. It already had been scheduled to open and run in repertory with a revival of ``The Recruiting Officer,'' with the same actors appearing in both plays. ``So we had to work very fast in rehearsals,'' she recalled. ``I was getting up at 5 o'clock in the morning to rewrite and I would bring in a scene which they would then rehearse that morning. It was quite something.'' Wertenbaker went to Connecticut briefly in mid-September to attend rehearsals of ``Our Country's Good'' at Hartford Stage and to answer any questions the American actors might have about her play. Wertenbaker did encourage the American actors not to use strong, 18th-century accents. ``We don't really known what 18th-century accents were like anyway,'' she said. ``The play is not written in a lot of local dialects. I'm a modern playwright. I've just given some rhythms to certain characters. Actors should just use their natural voices and accents and then push it a little bit.'' Wertenbaker is more guarded about her private life than she is about her public writing. The playwright has described herself as an ``Anglo-French-American'' who lives in north London, grew up in the south of France and went to school in the United States. Wertenbaker had her first play produced in 1983. Since 1984, she has been a resident writer at the Royal Court, earning recognition there with a play called ``The Grace of Mary Traverse.'' She has also had works done by the Royal Shakespeare Company. Right now, she's laboring on a new play commissioned by the Royal Court. No details were revealed but she did say her deadline is December. ``I sit down every day,'' she said. ``I have a little study in the back of my house that looks out over a garden. I have privacy. ``I take very precise notes - the scene, who's in the scene, what they are doing in the scene. I do that in longhand. Then I write on a word processor. But I don't write dialogue until the last minute. Not until everything else is sorted out in the scene.''

DOC.HEAD: History Casts Sharp Eye on Germany Today
DOC.TEXT: In an open field in the center of Berlin, a low mound of debris over Adolf Hitler's ``Fuehrer bunker'' rises near traces of the Berlin wall - the rubble of Germany's bitter past. Neither is a monument. No bronze plaques instruct visitors how to think about the mingled symbols of the fascist German Reich and the Cold War division of Europe. Yet, the questions they pose about the future are now rising as the lens of history tries to keep pace with the leap to unity of East and West Germany on Oct. 3, recreating a country of almost 80 million people, by far the largest in Europe. The new Germany, like it or not, will have to prove again and again that it is different, because in being big, rich and powerful, it will look somewhat like the bad old Germany. A half-century ago, German militarism - already carrying a long history of making trouble for Germany's neighbors - forced Blitzkrieg on Europe. Invasion, the bombing of cities, occupation, captive people and Holocaust death camps to exterminate Jews all sprang from Germany. World War II is ``useful to remember,'' said Nicholas Ridley a few months ago in the interview that led to his resignation as Britain's trade and industry secretary. Germans today are ``uppity,'' Ridley said, they are taking over Europe by economic power, and he thought a lot of people in Europe agreed with him. Ridley exited the political stage and the fuss was only a ripple in the headlong rush to unify Germany. Yet it served as a reminder of the resentment Germany has earned repeatedly since Bismark united the Germans under the Prussian flag in 1871. There's ample evidence that Germany is conscious of a need to work off the evil legacies of the past. West Germany has paid $52 billion to the state of Israel and to survivors of the Holocaust. There are numerous public monuments to the victims of Naziism and memorials at death-camp sites. Still, some Germans are tired of thinking about it. Germans ``want to be glad. They don't want to walk around stressed, confronted from morning till evening with the burden of history,'' Chancellor Helmut Kohl told British journalist David Marsh of the Financial Times. West German author Patrick Sueskind wrote in the weekly Der Spiegel of his confusion on seeing Kohl raise a toast ``Auf Deutschland'' - ``To Germany'' after negotiations in Moscow. Sueskind hadn't ever heard anyone toast Germany, and what sprang to his mind was Auschwitz and the war. ``But that's not what the chancellor meant,'' Sueskind wrote. ``He didn't have the old, aggressive Germany in mind, but rather the present and future Germany, peaceful, civilized, bound up into Europe.'' Will the united Germany be up to the political standards of the emerging new world order? The 61 million West Germans have had 45 years experience in democracy, but the 16.6 million East Germans languished since the war under a Communist police state. Many collaborated, most were passive, few resisted. They weren't told much about the Holocaust. ``We had to have a crash course in democracy,'' says Tino Schwierzina, who became mayor of East Berlin last spring as East Germany held its first free elections. ``I think we've done a good job.'' Yet East German political life has been about as chaotic as the East German economy since the peaceful revolution in the fall of 1989. Twelve of 22 cabinet members have quit or been fired, due to incompetence, political strife or because of alleged ties to the once-dreaded Stasi secret police organization. The poison in the Stasi's 6 million files will still haunt the country after unification. How hard should the police seek out those who committed crimes under orders from East Germany's Communist bosses? Can murder prosecutions be brought against those who killed approximately 200 people trying to cross the East German-West German border, including the Berlin Wall in the 28 years it stood before last Nov. 9? Such issues are only a few of many facing the Germans after they vote on whether to stay with Kohl's center-right government, or go for Oskar Lafontaine's leftist Social Democrats. Other big domestic issues: -Rebuilding substandard industry and infrastructure in the East, and other costs of unification, may require the government and private sector to invest an estimated $775 billion over five years, says Elmar Pieroth, an economics expert from Kohl's party, the Christian Democratic Union. -Social subsidies will be crucial to retain the good will of East Germans, said Gerhard Behrendt, an undersecretary in the East German environment ministry. Like many, Behrendt doesn't know if he will have a job after unification. ``It was common to have two workers in a family, and you got only an average living standard,'' he said. ``If production decreases now and jobs disappear, someone must still earn money, but how?'' -The East Germans may have 2 million unemployed soon as one enterprise after another collapses. West Germany is a luxury-loving land where incomes are more than double the $765 a month reported in East Germany's official but dubious statistics. West Germans are cruising through East Germany in their BMWs looking to reclaim family properties confiscated decades ago by the Communists. The prospect of wealthy West Germans ousting jobless Easterners from low-rent housing highlights the trouble looming for the next government over the disparity between East and West German living standards. -Money, indeed, will be an issue. West Germany is rich, but can it afford all that reconstruction money? And $9.5 billion to Moscow to finance the withdrawal of 370,000 Soviet troops from East Germany? And $3 billion for the Persian Gulf crisis? -A flood of refugees is testing how different today's Germany is from the fascist one that created a flood of refugees leaving Germany. A stream of Soviet Jews applying to come to Germany is of great historical irony; perhaps true to historical form, the Bonn government has temporarily halted processing of applications from Jews citing an apparently unmanageable wave, with 10,000 applicants in Kiev alone. This year West Germany expects a record 120,000 asylum applicants, and 50 percent more next year. The refugees and ``guest workers'' from Turkey and southern Europe have changed the face of Germany. Especially in the cities, Germany today is a cosmopolitan mixture of Turks, Yugoslavs, blacks and Asians with their own bakeries, restaurants and, for the Turks, a TV channel in their language. -East Germany's environment, in worse shape than the West's, was poisoned by industries that were competitive only because they burned cheap, foul brown coal and dumped untreated wastes into rivers. The clean-up bill will be enormous. One of the hottest topics in Berlin can be identified as ``Berlin as the future European metropolis.'' Now a city of 3 million, spacious Berlin will become the German capital - Bonn was always West Germany's ``interim'' capital. Berlin is where the heart of the new Germany beats strongest, where unity came in the heady rush of a popular and peaceful rebellion last autumn. From an isolated capitalist island in a sea of Communists, Berlin has become a symbol of hope. It will be the major European city between Paris and Moscow, a gateway to the eastern neighbors who were inspired to push aside Communist governments after the East Germans showed that their regime was a paper tiger.

DOC.HEAD: Some East Germans Dread the Coming of a United Germany
DOC.TEXT: Some of the East Germans who helped open the door to German unity are reluctant to step inside. Dissident professor Peter Boethig fled the country just a few months before its remarkable transformation to a free nation. Now that he's back, he's not sure he belongs. Katje Havemann endured house arrest for more than two years and fought a lonely fight for change long before huge crowds joined her on the streets. Now that the Communists have been overthrown, Havemann presses on with protests against the new government. Carl Ordnung works for that government, which won East Germany's first free elections by promising fast capitalism and quick unity. But Ordnung now worries about a rise in nationalism and consumer fever, and says his nation has shifted too far to the right. The three are by no means typical of most East Germans, who passively endured four decades of Soviet-imposed rule, then quickly embraced a fast merger with West Germany. But each to varying degrees took part in what East Germany is now, a sovereign nation with a democratic government. And each feels, in some way, opposed to what it will soon become, a transplanted territory of West Germany. ``In the beginning I was angry,'' Boethig said. ``It was a pity a basic democratic movement was overtaken by a unification movement. The sudden materialism, the nationalism. ``But I can imagine now why they wanted what they wanted.'' The 32-year-old Berliner taught German literature at East Berlin's prestigious Humboldt University and quickly moved into circles actively opposed to the old Communist government. He edited an underground literary journal from 1984-88, working with writers barred from official publications. One day the secret police came to the university ``and said I had to go,'' Boethig said. ``After I left, I couldn't find a job. I drove cabs, worked in construction. I realized I would have to do that for a long time.'' He applied to leave, and like many people considered troublemakers, was granted a visa in March 1989. Six months later he got a job teaching German at the University of Pittsburgh. Two months after that, his former colleagues were leading nationwide demonstrations. The Communist government convulsed and collapsed. In May he came back to work with a West Berlin literary society. The East already had been transormed. The university invited Boethig back to complete his doctoral dissertation. He plans to accept, but finds little in common with East Germany today. The issues his old activist friends are involved with seem remote, the consumerism of the freed society saddening. ``I had mixed feelings after I returned,'' he said. ``What will dominate the next years is Germany will be busy with itself.'' While Boethig spoke last week, Katje Havemann was doing what she did a decade ago: waging war on the government, this time the new government. Mrs. Havemann is one of East Germany's most lionized activists. Her husband, Robert, a philosophy professor, renounced the government in the 1970s and became its most famous dissident. The Havemanns spent 2{ years under house arrest, their home surrounded by secret police. He died in 1982, and she carried on to help form New Forum, the activist group that led the autumn revolt. Mrs. Havemann was among 22 activists who occupied the headquarters of the former secret police Sept. 4 to keep the files from being turned over to West Germany's intelligence service. The group went on a hunger strike Sept. 12. ``Many people are concerned now with their social problems,'' she said, referring to the joblessness that followed the nation's plunge into capitalism. But she said she said she fears the united German government would become too much like the old Communist government if it took control of the 6 million secret dossiers of the old administration. She said she sees no problem with the small crowds that attend New Forum's rallies these days, compared with the hundreds of thousands last year. ``The big difference between now and last fall? Last fall has already happened,'' she said. New Forum never came up with a clear program for a future East Germany. But the Christian Democrats, an approved party by the Communists, reshaped itself after their powerful West German namesakes. The Christian Democrats espoused conservatism and unencumbered capitalism, quick unity and Western lifestyles. They won the free elections handily. Carl Ordnung, 62, joined the party in 1951 and helped reshape it last year to fit the new era. He now works as a foreign policy adviser to Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere and will, like the government, be out of work Oct. 3. But Ordnung, a Methodist lay preacher, said the party and nation have swung too far to the right. He had hoped for a socialist democracy more sympathetic to poor people and foreigners, less devoted to a market-driven economy. ``I hope East Germans, after they have consumed Western goods, will see that to consume is not all of human life,'' he said. Ordnung's life has paralleled East Germany's. He was married four days before the nation was created and will celebrate his 41st anniversary the day it dissolves. He was a German army conscript at the end of World War II and went home to recuperate after he was injured in a training accident. His mother burned his uniform before the Soviets came. He enjoyed travel privileges because of his role in church circles, but his son, then 16, was imprisoned for 2{ years in 1973 for trying to flee. Ordnung believed Germany's division was God's penalty for two world wars. Unification, he said, is a result of public will. ``You should respect the will of the people,'' he said. ``But we should remember there is another world besides Germany.''

DOC.HEAD: German Leaders at a Glance
With BC-Germany Today
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at German political leaders: --- Helmut Kohl: West Germany's chancellor and head of the conservative Christian Democrats crowns his political career when he becomes leader of a united Germany on Oct. 3. Kohl, 60, must emerge victorious from all-German elections Dec. 2 to keep the post. --- Lothar de Maiziere: East Germany's prime minister, also a Christian Democrat, loses his job Oct. 3, but is scheduled to become a Cabinet minister without portfolio after unity. De Maiziere, 50, worked as a lawyer before his election as East German leader earlier this year. --- Hans-Dietrich Genscher: West Germany's foreign minister takes charge of the defunct East German foreign service Oct. 3 and will continue to be a major player in world affairs as the top diplomat of a nation of 80 million. --- Wolfgang Schaeuble: West Germany's interior minister is being tipped as a future Christian Democrat candidate for chancellor following his smooth handling of negotiations that clinched the unity treaty, the fundamental document that merges the legal systems of the two German states. --- Guenther Krause: Another Christian Democrat, Krause conducted the unity treaty negotiations for de Maiziere's government. He is considered a rising star and will get a spot in Kohl's government after unity.

DOC.HEAD: Brief Portrait of Unified Germany
With BC-Germany Today
DOC.TEXT: Here at a glance is a portrait of the united Germany that will be created Oct. 3: --- THE LAND - Germany will cover 137,743 square miles, more than half the size of Texas. It combines West Germany's 95,975 square miles with 41,768 square miles of East German territory. It is bordered to the north by Denmark and the North and Baltic Seas; by the Oder-Neisse River, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Austria in the east; by Austria, Switzerland and France to the south; and France, Luxembourg, Belgium and The Netherlands to the west. --- THE PEOPLE - Germany will have at least 77.6 million people, 61 million from West Germany plus 16.6 million in East Germany. Berlin, with 3 million residents, is the largest city and its capital, as stated in the treaty uniting the Germanys. Bonn will be the interim seat of government. The all-German parliament to be elected Dec. 2 will decide if the seat of government stays in Bonn or moves to Berlin. --- ECONOMY - Germany will consist of the most powerful economy of Western Europe and the most powerful of the East bloc. Restructuring East Germany's economy to bring it to Western standards may cost $775 billion. Unemployment in what is now East Germany could reach 2 million as formerly state-subsidized firms go bankrupt. Germany has pledged to pay more than $7 billion to the Soviet Union to pay for the withdrawal of the Red Army from East German territory. --- GOVERNMENT - Germany will be a federal democracy, run by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Vice-Chancellor and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and President Richard von Weizsaecker. The three now hold those posts in West Germany. --- HISTORY - East Germany and West Germany were founded in 1949 after the victorious World War II Allies divided Germany. West Germany makes up the German territory occupied by the United States, France and Britain. East Germany is composed of territory occupied by the Soviet Union. Germany was first united in 1871 under Kaiser Wilhelm I. The Weimar Republic replaced the imperial government at the end of World War I. Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler replaced the parliamentary government in 1933 and ruled until his defeat in 1945.

DOC.HEAD: Africans are Main Victims of the Global Spread of AIDS
DOC.BYLINE: By JOHN EDLIN and DIDRIKKE SCHANCHE
DOC.TEXT: By the time Ronnie Mutimusekwa was 15, he was sleeping regularly with three different girls. A few years later, the number had grown to 15 and he was proud to think any woman he asked would go to bed with him. ``I guess I made sex a hobby,'' said the 34-year-old. A deadly hobby. Mutimusekwa, from Zimbabwe's southern city of Bulawayo, contracted AIDS. He does not know who gave it to him, nor does he know who may have caught it from him. Behavior like his has contributed to the rapid spread of the disease in Africa, and has helped make the continent the AIDS center of the world. Two-thirds of the world's estimated AIDS cases are in Africa, and most of those are concentrated in about 12 countries across the continent's central, eastern and southern regions. The problem only threatens to get worse, according to medical experts. Infection rates, unlike those in most other areas of the world, are rising in Africa. If current trends continue, millions of African infants will be born with the deadly disease, and Africa's population growth rate - now the world's highest - will be cut as AIDS kills those in what should be the most productive time of their lives. The Geneva-based World Health Organizaton estimates that in sub-Saharan Africa, one of every 40 adult men and women is infected with the HIV virus that causes AIDS. In the United States, which has recorded about half the world's known cases of AIDS, one of every 75 men and 700 women has HIV, WHO estimates. Because of under-recognition, under-reporting and delays in reporting, WHO estimates only a fraction of the world's cases of AIDS and HIV have been recorded. As of mid-1990, about 65,000 AIDS cases had been reported from Africa. But WHO estimates closer to 500,000 adult AIDS cases probably exist - more than half the estimated global total. In what it calls a conservative estimate, the organization says 5 million Africans may be HIV carriers. ``AIDS and HIV are becoming more and more a disease of the developing world,'' said Michael Merson, WHO's anti-AIDS chief, in a telephone interview from Geneva. ``By the year 2000, we expect 80 percent of the cases to be in the developing world.'' The organization says about 20 million cases worldwide are expected by the end of the century. Merson includes Latin America when he speaks of AIDS and the developing world, but WHO statistics show the severity of the disease in Africa far outstrips any other continent. Today, AIDS is the leading cause of death among young adults in many African countries, said Merson. The average African victim, however, differs from his American or European counterpart, who is usually a homosexual or an intravenous drug user. In Africa, most AIDS casualties are heterosexuals. Because of this, the number of women infected roughly equals the number of men. And because many of the infected women are in their prime, HIV transmission from mother to child is an increasing problem. Already this year, about 500,000 children carrying the HIV virus have been born in Africa, says WHO. The organization estimates an additional 2 million to 3 million infected infants will be born before the year 2000. Another 10 million children born to infected mothers but who will not contract the disease are expected to become AIDS-related orphans in the 1990s, says WHO. Dambudzo, a 26-year-old unemployed Zimbabwean, lost a 2-year-old daughter to the disease. The divorcee said she learned she had AIDS while still in the hospital after delivering her baby. ``I was really hurt because the baby had also contracted the disease and whenever she was brought in for breast-feeding, I would look at her and cry,'' Dambudzo told Ziana, Zimbabwe's news agency. Dambudzo's husband also tested positive for the disease. But rather than engage in safer habits, she said he stopped sleeping with her and started bringing other women home to bed. Such negligent promiscuity, as well as a tradition of polygamy among many African peoples, a high incidence of other sexually transmitted diseases, particularly those that create sores, and centuries-old customs are encouraging AIDS' spread. In Zambia, for instance, where 3,000 AIDS cases have been recorded but many times that are believed to exist, a custom among the Kaonde tribe demands that when a man dies, a male relative must sleep with the widow to exorcise ghosts. Enough people will be dying of AIDS in the next 10 years that African population growth rates, the highest in the world, are expected to slow, says WHO. Beyond the year 2000, if current trends continue, populations could even decline, according to the U.N. organization. Already along the east-west corridor of countries from Kenya to Ivory Coast, the hardest-hit West African country, villages are being decimated by the virus. In southeastern Uganda, where the majority of that country's AIDS cases have been recorded, residents of Rakai said as many as six people were dying daily by 1988. Fred Ssonko, manager of a local hotel, said at the time he was going to burials ``almost every afternoon.'' The 35-year-old took on the extra care of eight children he adopted after his brother and his best friend died of the illness. While education and awareness programs have changed behavior and slowed the rate of new infections in Europe and America, the rates are increasing at an ``alarming rate'' in African and other Third World countries, according to WHO. Despite internationally-funded AIDS prevention programs throughout the continent, Africa still lacks the resources to mount educational campaigns that reach all its 500 million people. ``We know that a lot of people know about HIV and AIDS. But we don't know enough yet about getting their behavior to change,'' said Merson. ``We want to get safer sexual practices and more condoms used,'' he said. ``And it's very important to treat other sexually transmitted diseases.'' However, even some of those most at risk and who are easily accessible still don't believe AIDS is a real threat. Surveys have found that 60 percent to 80 percent of the prostitutes in some large east and central African cities are infected with HIV. However, in Kenya's capital, Nairobi, some prostitutes interviewed recently by a local paper said they thought the figures were just propaganda for government-backed family planning programs. One AIDS prevention program being run by the Nairobi-based African Medical and Research Foundation (AMREF) is targeting a highly vulnerable population that health workers credit with fueling the virus' spread: long-distance truckers. Since the disease first was recorded in Africa in 1983, medical researchers have found AIDS spreading most quickly along trucking routes, with a high incidence of cases at popular roadside stops through southern, eastern and central Africa. AMREF is distributing free condoms to the local prostitutes there and to drivers who frequent them as well as handing out pamphlets that explain AIDS' causes and symptoms. The material urges the truckers to refrain from casual sex. Ominously, while AIDS used to be concentrated primarily in urban areas along major roads, it is now appearing in rural areas where an estimated 75 percent of the population lives. ``It means the epidemic is continuing to rise and Africa is being confronted by a major problem,'' said Merson. ``It is nowhere near its peak.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Glory'' (RCA-Columbia. VHS-Beta. Rated R)
On July 18, 1863, despite fatigue and poor rations, the 54th Massachusetts Colored Volunteer Infantry marched across a half-mile of sand on a South Carolina beach to lead the ill-planned attack on Fort Wagner in Charleston harbor. The regiment lost more than 40 percent of its men. The story of the 54th, the first black regiment from the North to fight in the Civil War, and its youthful white colonel, Robert Gould Shaw, unfolds in ``Glory,'' Edward Zwick's critically acclaimed movie. Zwick presents a powerful, moving tapestry of war's senselessness. The screenplay by Kevin Jarre is partly based on the books ``Lay This Laurel'' and ``One Gallant Rush,'' and letters Shaw wrote home to his parents. The movie - narrated by Matthew Broderick as Shaw - is largely seen through his eyes. Young and privileged, but disillusioned and battle-scarred after the gory and indecisive Battle of Antietam, Shaw returns to his wealthy, powerful and abolitionist parents in Massachusetts just in time for a lavish party and an offer from the governor to take command of an all-black fighting regiment. He rises in rank from captain to colonel and musters his men, who include his childhood friends, Cabot (Cary Elwes), who is white and becomes a major, and Tom (Andre Braugher), a second-generation free black who volunteers as an enlisted man. Much of ``Glory'' focuses on the basic training of a ragtag group of runaway slaves and free men, who are asked to accept less pay than whites and denied all the basic supplies, including proper shoes and the coveted blue uniform. As Trip, an embittered runaway, Denzel Washington (``Cry Freedom,'' ``The Mighty Quinn,'' ``Power'') does a star turn. ``Glory'' becomes Trip's story - as well as Shaw's - as the runaway undergoes a radical self-realization. In the end, the 54th becomes the only family he's ever known. Zwick, the Emmy-award winning director of ``Special Bulletin'' and ``thirtysomething,'' stresses visual acting in ``Glory.'' Action speaks louder than words, and he focuses on facial expressions and body movement rather than histrionics and gimmicks. He also is spare with dialogue. When the 54th marches past the white regiments, who regarded the black soldiers as a joke and less than men, to lead the assault against Fort Wagner, only four words are spoken by the once hostile whites: ``Give 'em hell, 54.'' Ultimately, color no longer is the issue. The men are fellow soldiers about to die. And like ``Gallipoli'' and ``Hamburger Hill,'' the overriding issue becomes the utter futility of war. The battle scene at Fort Wagner is beautifully choreographed, the men running along the beach, the U.S. flag full and billowing. It is poetic and powerful. ``Glory'' makes good use of battle scenes. They are exciting, frightening and realistic. At James Island, the 54th gets its first taste of fighting. After firing a few rounds and watching a Confederate unit retreat, more Confederates appear through the mist like gray ghosts and the battle soon becomes hand-to-hand combat. Dan Lerner was second unit director, and Bob Minor coordinated the stunts. There are good performances by Morgan Freeman (``Street Smart,'' ``Driving Miss Daisy''), Jihmi Kennedy as a stuttering enlisted man and John Finn as the fierce, no-nonsense Irish sergeant-major who whips the 54th into shape. Braugher, whose theater credits include ``Much Ado About Nothing'' and ``King John'' at the New York Shakespeare Festival, makes his film debut in ``Glory,'' and is someone to watch. Jane Alexander appears as Shaw's mother. ``Glory'' only received three Academy Awards and was denied the best picture prize. Pity, it was a superior movie and one that will haunt you long after seeing it. RCA-Columbia smartly is releasing ``Glory'' in letterbox form in order to retain the full picture for the small screen. It works, and it works well. Regard this video as a classic. - By Dolores Barclay, AP Arts Editor.
---
``Stanely & Iris'' (MGM-UA. VHYS-Beta, $89.98. Rated PG-13)
Boy, how can you criticize a movie that tries to teach the value of literacy, stars Jane Fonda and Robert DeNiro and even plans to donate part of its video proceeds to help people learn to read? Well, for all the good it might do, ``Stanley & Iris'' is just sort of sappy. Too bad, because it has a great cast, which also includes Swoosie Kurtz and Martha Plimpton. The actors do their best to play down the melodrama that intrudes at every turn: Iris King (Fonda), tough and newly widowed, chases a guy who snatched her purse and gets in a fight; Iris supports her unemployed and battling sister and brother-in-law; Iris' daughter gets pregnant while in high school; Stanley gets fired because he can't read; because he has no job, he has to put his elderly father in a home, where the man soon dies. You get the idea. Based on the novel ``Union Street,'' by Pat Barker, ``Stanley & Iris,'' has some nice moments, including the convivial scenes of Iris and her co-workesr on a bakery assembly line and the romance that grows in fits and starts between Stanley and Iris as she lets him into her life and teaches him to read. Director Martin Ritt filmed ``Stanley & Iris,'' in Waterbury, Conn., where veterans groups demonstrated in protest of Fonda's presence because of her work against the Vietnam War. The National Literacy Hot Line's toll-free number is 1-800-228-8813. - By Mary MacVean, Associated Press Writer. ---= Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G - General audiences. All ages admitted. PG - Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 - Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R - Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X - No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Never too Much'' (MCA Records) - Henry Johnson With his third MCA record, guitarist Henry Johnson says he is trying to fill the void between strictly commercial music and straight-ahead jazz. That is more void than any one musician could fill, but Johnson makes a good attempt. Punched up drums and percussion, keyboard overlays and some rather bland arrangements give this record its commercial feel. Johnson is able to break free from those constraints often enough to keep things interesting. Listening to the Chicago-born Johnson, it is clear he is capable of making much more interesting, challenging music. Even so, ``Never too Much'' is a cut above the New Age elevator music so prevalent today on the airwaves and in the record bins. - By James Reindl, Associated Press Writer.
---
Four Impromptus, D. 935; 12 Landler, D. 790; Three Klaverstucke, D946; Allegretto, D. 915, by Franz Schubert (London) - Andras Schiff, piano The best of Schubert's small-scale piano pieces belong to that special category of art works which are simple in form yet truly complex in experience because of the way they touch us so deeply. Many of Domenico Scarlatti's keyboard sonatas have this quality. Nothing, perhaps, has it more than Schubert's impromptus. Andras Schiff has recorded both for London, most recently the four Opus 142 Impromptus on this disc. Schiff has all the right instincts in his choice of recording repertoire - great taste, and also adventurousness, as shown by last year's issue of him playing Dohnanyi chamber music and Dvorak's piano concerto, performed live. On the Schubert disc, his technique is wonderful, his approach sensitive, his interpretations well thought-out. Even the disc booklet is appealingly simple in its layout and notes. So, mainly in the impromptus, one misses all the more that extra quality of bringing us into a special realm, that focus on the depth of simple works. In the A-flat Imprompu, for instance, the middle section is a marvel of lyricisim, with a lower-upper register dialogue accompanied by an excruciatingly beautiful harmonic progression. But Schiff handles the passage without extraordinary poignancy. Nevertheless, he manages moments of charm and poetry at other times. The recorded sound is fair. Schiff's Bosendorfer piano has a thudding quality. At 74:26, the CD is generously timed. - By Daniel Wakin, Associated Press Writer.
---
``Under the Red Sky'' (Columbia) - Bob Dylan Bob Dylan's ``Under the Red Sky'' is a lot like Dylan's concerts of the last two years. Bob storms onstage and whales away at some surprisingly tough rock 'n' roll and is gone before you know it. If you catch a flash of brilliance, great. If not, tough luck. Much of this album sounds simply haphazard, as if Dylan scribbled a few lyrics on a sheet of paper five minutes before entering the studio. This master lyricist has become enamored of the somewhat lazy device of repeating key lyrical phrases over and over (``Wiggle Wiggle,'' ``10,000 Men'' and ``God Knows''). By his own formidable standards, this is minor work. Those flashes of brilliance are there, however. ``God Knows'' has an elegance about it. ``T.V. Talkin' Song'' pokes wicked fun at the television generation. Television will ``scramble up your head and drag your brain about,'' he sings. ``Sometimes you gotta do like Elvis did and shoot the damn thing out.'' When Bob Dylan calls, musicians come running - Bruce Hornsby, Jimmie and the late Stevie Ray Vaughan, George Harrison, Elton John, David Crosby, Slash of Guns N' Roses, drummer Kenny Aronoff and Don and David Was. Consequently, this album sounds simultaneously impeccably played and a loose good time. - By David Bauder, Associated Press Writer.

DOC.HEAD: Star Watch: The World's a Stage for Julie Christie
DOC.TEXT: Julie Christie doesn't make many films these days, and rarely sees her old movies. She was thrilled to work with such directors as John Schlesinger and Sir David Lean, and amazed she had the courage to arrive on the set each day. But don't expect her to recite dialogue from those movies. Now 49, and feeling much calmer, the Academy Award winner and icon of 1960s ``Swinging London'' prefers to think of the locations where she made the films. There's India, the setting for ``Heat and Dust''; Canada, where she made ``McCabe and Mrs. Miller''; and Ireland, which provided Christie with happy memories of the recent ``Fools of Fortune.'' ``The Irish are the most generous people, the most wonderful people,'' she said enthusiastically, looking relaxed in a blue knit shirt, her blond hair cheerfully uncombed. A children's birthday celebration goes on in another room of a friend's Manhattan apartment where Christie stays when she's in town. ``It makes you happy, the touches of kindness that you get every single day. It makes you happy to be there because people are so extraordinarily nice. It sounds patronizing, doesn't it? The Irish have an incredibly nice nature, and they haven't got an anti-English bias, though they have every right to.'' Christie is very much the well-traveled performer, veteran of stage, screen and Warren Beatty. Even growing up, home was whereever they built the set. She was born in India, but spent her childhood at a series of English boarding schools, finding contentment by performing in school plays. She lived for a year in Paris and established herself in films in 1963 with a brief appearance in Schlesinger's ``Billy Liar.'' Christie topped it two years later by winning a best actress Oscar for ``Darling,'' playing the shallow, free-spirited London model who tells her life story to a reporter for a woman's magazine. ``You just think they made a terrible mistake,'' she said of the Academy Award. ``You feel terrible because you can't believe it's happening. You're just thinking, `What am I doing there? What the hell am I doing there?' ``For a long time I didn't put it anywhere; a friend of mine had it. I was too embarrassed by it. What a stupid cow I was! Then I grew up a little bit more and thought, `Wonderful, look what I've got,' '' she said, sounding just like a gleeful as kid who just found a $5 bill. After starring as Lara in ``Dr. Zhivago,'' Christie traveled some more. She lived in California during the 1970s and worked with Beatty, her boyfriend for several years and co-star of ``Shampoo,'' ``Heavan Can Wait'' and ``McCabe and Mrs. Miller,'' shot in Vancouver, British Columbia. ```McCabe' was a wonderful location because (director) Robert Altman made it a wonderful location. We were shooting nights in Vancouver and it was where people who didn't want to go to the Vietnam War went instead,'' she said. ``It was a very vital place, a wonderful place. All these people were living in the mountains, very self-sufficient. And Robert got them to be the townspeople. They built everything from day one. Some of them ended up living on the sets during the shooting.'' She moved back to England at the end of the '70s, became increasingly outspoken politically - and traveled. She made the acclaimed ``Heat and Dust,'' returning to her native India, and worked in Argentina for ``Miss Mary,'' a commercial flop but a personal success. ``There's an interesting thing about being British and having come from an enormous empire country. You go to countries like Argentina which suffered appallingly from English imperialism. They see someone from Britain as a continuation of that imperialism. I had to get over their reticence. ``Coming to the United States I'm aware of that same feeling the Argentines had. I get the same feeling of people feeling superior to everyone else, just in little drops. Remarks here and there, an attitude that people don't know as much in the backward countries. It's a superiority complex that all great empires have.'' In ``Fools of Fortune,'' based on the novel by William Trevor, Christie plays the English wife of an Irishman murdered by British military police during the Irish Republicans' uprising after World War I. Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio and Iain Glen also star. Christie takes an emotional trip in ``Fools of Fortune,'' warm and outgoing at the beginning of the film, embittered and increasingly unstable after her husband's murder. If in person Christie seems closer to the life-affirming woman of the film's first half, as an actress she related to the angry, single-minded personality of the second half, a world traveler unafraid to cross boundaries of any kind. ``There's a scene that's missing which I wished had been in,'' she said. ``She talks to her son and explains her family had always been involved with the struggle for home rule for Ireland. She explains for a Protestant-English person, that is an extremely unusual thing. ``I identified with that anger and injustice. Her heartbreak and rage that the man who killed her husband was receiving no retribution at all. What is it like to go through a transition like that woman went through? You go through sort of a journey. The work is really a journey.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: Controversial Contemporary Museum Making Waves in Nice
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Paintings splattered from a carbine by Niki de St. Phalle, or squashed cars hung as art by Cesar may not be to everyone's taste. But the handsome new Museum of Contemporary Art in the heart of the Riviera's capital is nevertheless an impressive contribution to the city, not least because of its monumental modern architecture. The museum opened amid controversy in June, boycotted by several local artists and France's culture minister, Jack Lang. Conceived by Nice's longtime mayor, Jacques Medecin, the multimillion-dollar museum and theater was financed mainly by the city, with other funds coming from regional and national government sources. The museum had a rough start because of Medecin's right-wing politics, coupled with alleged financial fiddling that still have the mayor in hot water. He was accused of anti-semitic remarks last spring at a time when desecrations of Jewish cemeteries in France and elsewhere were causing a storm of protest. Medecin is an avowed admirer of Jean-Marie Le Pen, whose far-right National Front espouses anti-immigrant causes. That attitude is shared by many older conservatives enjoying the high life of Nice. Perhaps more serious are allegations that Medecin has cheated on personal taxes as well as in financial deals involving the city. He is currently under investigation. In any case, the new museum daily is attracting about 1,000 visitors, according to spokesmen. ``I don't discuss controversy. It's in the past, and I'm looking to the future,'' said head curator Pierre Chaigneau, an art expert who has helped open several other important museums and distances himself from politics. He is proud of this museum's strictly contemporary role in an area that already boasts some excellent museums - Nice's Museum of Fine Arts, the national Chagall Museum there, the prestigious Maeght Foundation at St. Paul de Vence, the Leger Musem at Biot. ``This is the only one dedicated exclusively to art from 1950 onwards,'' said Chaigneau, who personally favors geometric abstract works in the line of Josef Albers and Max Bill. Emphasizing neo-realism from the 1960s, pop art by such artists as Warhol and Lichtenstein, as well as minimalist and other trends, the museum's displays include about 20-25 percent of works by American artists. The School of Nice, spearheaded by such artists as Yves Klein, Armand and Martial Raysse, is well-represented. The museum is especially proud of its large collection of Kleins - three-dimensional electric blue figures on various backgrounds, by the local artist who made international art news before his untimely death at age 34 in 1962. But it's the handsome museum complex itself of which Nice can be most proud. Just behind the old city, the gray Carrara marble-faced structure designed by local architects Yves Bayard and Henri Vidal includes an octagonal theater and a plaza connecting with four monolithic towers housing the art on three levels. Access is easy by way of a red-brick staircase entrance flanked by escalators, and entry is free of charge - a rarity in France. At the top of the staircase, the visitor is dazzled by sun on marble and a handsome Alexander Calder stabile, a gift by the artist to Nice in 1970. The towers are joined by corridors of glass and steel, decorated on the interior by vaguely fish-shaped metallic ellipses and hung with colorful metal stabiles. In the towers are spacious, well-lighted exhibition rooms, ideal for a handsome display of monumental-sized abstracts by such artists as Morris Louis, Frank Stella or Jim Dine. With a restaurant tucked into a corner facing the first-level plaza, and theater and a little cafe at the top level, the complex is equipped to become a gathering-place for Nicois and visitors. From the top of the museum are fabulous views over old Nice to the Mediterranean, a Jewish cemetery and the green slopes of the Cimiez area. One of the rooftop areas contains a grid of gas jets constructed to an Yves Klein design that sparkles in the evening with jets of blue flame. A little rooftop garden is planted with typically Riviera succulents and flowers, based on Klein's notes for a dream garden. While some Nice residents leave quizzical remarks in the visitor's book about the art, the only real complaints so far seem to be from animal-lovers and pigeons. Apparently some pigeons died when stuck to the bird-repellent spread along the rooftop walls - ``An unfortunate accident that we're striving to correct,'' said Chaigneau.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: Breaking Through the Jones-Dixon Line
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Dressed in jeans and white T-shirts, calmly puffing Marlboros, Marti Jones and husband Don Dixon look as if they make records with all the urgency of vacuuming the living room carpet. But they have plenty to worry about. Jones' first three albums, produced by Dixon, sold poorly despite mostly favorable reviews, and the singer has switched record labels, from A&M to RCA, hoping her luck will change. With just a few ``pockets of popularity'' - New York, Washington - paying the bills, disagreements can emerge. On ``Any Kind of Lie,'' the arguments are in the lyrics themselves. Even talking about the record gets them going. ``It was real easy,'' Jones insisted during an interview at the RCA offices in Manhattan. ``We stayed home for about 2{ months. We'd get up and Dixon would be working on something and I'd be cleaning up the kitchen, or wanting to do laundry or go see my mother or something. ``And he'd say, `I just want to work on this song,' and I knew when I came back if I didn't do something he'd have it finished.'' ``It took a long time,'' countered Dixon, flicking an ash. ``We started this record from scratch. We were trying to figure out what to do. The biggest difference in this record from Marti's other records is this is more groove based. It's a little bit more of a band record.'' Sometimes, the only way to break through the Jones-Dixon line and get the whole story is to take their responses and split the difference. In ``My Tears Are Poison,'' they make like Sonny and Cher in a trailer park, tossing verbal pots and pans about money and television and pets and babies. ``We're like Buddy and Sally of the `Dick Van Dyke Show,' '' Jones said of the bickering scriptwriting team from the old television series. ``When we would think of what to say on stage, we'd say, `What would they do now? Would she do this or she do that.' '' They met in the early 1980s, when Jones was struggling with a band called Color Me Gone and Dixon, who had produced R.E.M., was called in to help. Color Me Gone soon fell apart but Dixon was impressed with Jones' singing and suggested they work together. That's when the trouble began. ``We wrote through the mail,'' recalled Jones, who lives with Dixon in her native Ohio, and also spends time in Charlotte, N.C. ``I sent these lyrics to Dixon and he called me and said, `I got your lyrics and on the way home from the post office I wrote the song,' which was called `Rhythm and Shallow Breathing.' I was real impressed. I was like, `Wow!' Then I found out there's this old song he had and he just adapted it into this.'' Until ``Any Kind of Lie,'' they preferred to let others do the arguing. Cover versions of Graham Parker's ``You Can't Take Love for Granted'' and Elvis Costello's ``Just a Memory'' earned her respect among musicians, and so did her willingness to perform songs by lesser-known writers such as Dwight Twilley and Richard Barone. But after the 1988 album ``Used Guitars,'' Jones and Dixon took a different approach. Before, they wrote just two or three songs per record. On ``Any Kind of Lie,'' only two of the 11 songs are nonoriginals. Jones gives two reasons: They were unimpressed with the outside material submitted and, after watching some so-called pros at work, they figured some of their own songs might be salvageable. With Jones and Dixon doing most of the writing, ``Any Kind of Lie'' has a more consistent sound than ``Used Guitars,'' which ranges from the jazzy ``Ruby'' to a folkish cover of John Hiatt's ``If I Can Love Somebody.'' How it sounds to Jones and Dixon depends on which one you ask. Again, it's Buddy and Sally time, a battle of selective memories, with Jones leaning forward while she speaks and Dixon preferring to recline. Jones: ``I think this record is sort of the relaxed version of `Used Guitars.' '' Dixon: `` `Used Guitars' is real atmospheric.'' Jones: ``It is, it's more bouyant. This is more mature.'' Dixon: ``I think this is a real rock 'n' roll album.'' Jones: ``This is real relaxed. I wasn't worried about the songs. I wasn't worried about how it was going to turn out. There was not a point where I was nervous. ... (Dixon is shaking his head) Of course, I was worried the way I sounded singing. I completely freaked out.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Oct. 5-7

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK - William Wyler.
DOC.TEXT: But Sturges insisted directors were ``princes of the blood,'' the ones who were really in charge. By 1939, he was so anxious for a chance to direct he offered to accept a salary of $1 (his screenplays usually brought him $30,000 or more) if he could make a film of ``Down Went McGinty,'' a political satire he had written several years before. Paramount gave in, even upping his pay to $10. ``I saved my strength; I treated myself like an egg,'' wrote Sturges, who gave up drinking and smoking in preparation for the film. ``And as a result of this totally regular and totally unaccustomed manner of living, on the 14th day of shooting I was rewarded with pneumonia.'' Sturges was convinced he had blown it, but Paramount executives were so happy with the scenes he had filmed so far they sent a messenger to the director's hospital bed to inform him they would wait indefinitely for his recovery. ``My fever slid down like a monkey on a flagpole, and I was back on the set in 10 days,'' Sturges wrote. ``The Great McGinty,'' as it was eventually called, was a hit and earned Sturges an Academy Award in 1940 for the new category of best original screenplay. And thanks to Sturges, frustrated writers such as John Huston and Billy Wilder also were allowed to make films and became great directors themselves. Sturges made ``Christmas in July,'' ``Sullivan's Travels,'' ``The Lady Eve,'' ``The Palm Beach Story,'' ``The Miracle of Morgan's Creek'' and ``Hail the Conquering Hero'' during the next four years. They are among the wittiest movies ever made, and are included in a current Film Forum retrospective in New York. Deception or mistaken identity was often a theme in Sturges movies. In ``The Lady Eve,'' Barbara Stanwyck plays a cardsharp, then a phony British heiress. Eddie Bracken is wrongly thought to be a war hero in ``Conquering Hero,'' and Dick Powell falsely believes he has won a contest for writing a coffee slogan in ``Christmas in July.'' Sturges, a tall, powerfully built man with wavy black hair and a thin mustache, filmed in the afternoon, played host at his nightclub in the evening and then wrote until the early morning. He rarely knew where the story would go once he started, and began filming ``Morgan's Creek'' with just 10 pages of dialogue. He loved working with McCrae, Stanwyck and Claudette Colbert, but also cultivated a stock company of such motley mountebanks as the fumbling Raymond Walburn, the eccentric Jimmy Conlin and the cranky William Demarest, who had featured parts in ``Morgan's Creek'' and ``Conquering Hero.'' But in 1943, after completing ``Conquering Hero,'' Sturges had a falling out with Paramount and left to form a film company with the reclusive billionare Howard Hughes. It was a disaster. Sturges made the poorly regarded ``The Sin of Harold Diddlebock,'' which Hughes soon pulled from circulation, and the partnership dissolved. Sturges never recovered. ``Unfaithfully Yours,'' released by Fox in 1948, did poorly at the box office despite considerable publicity, and ``The Beautiful Blonde From Bashful Bend'' fared even worse the following year. Unable to catch on with any of the studios, Sturges spent the last decade of his life watching deal after deal fall through, reduced to minor acting roles and assisting on screenplays. To Sandy Sturges, his fatal heart attack in August 1959, just 20 minutes after he had completed his autobiography, still doesn't make sense. He had three deals in the works and had been assured by a doctor three months earlier that he was in perfect health and could expect to live another 25 years. He felt confident enough to even joke about his age, wanting to call his book ``The Events Leading Up to My Death,'' and likening his 60th birthday to being a passenger at an ainport but not having a flight arranged. Like Sullivan, he always stopped in time from taking himself too seriously. Sturges had thought about writing a book with a ``message,'' words of wisdom for his young children, a lifetime of mistakes he hoped would never be repeated. But he realized that might have turned out like a bad version of ``O Brother, Where Art Thou?,'' an inappropriate farewell from a man who thought the best time to cry came at the tail end of laughter so hard the tears were squeezed out of your eyes.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Oct. 5-7
For Release Weekend Editions, Oct. 05-07, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Nashville Sound: The Eternal Quest for Perfection
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Master guitarist Chet Atkins figures he's due for a new image. The 66-year-old, soft-spoken music legend may start emulating certain rock stars by wearing leather and heavy makeup. ``Nobody wants you when you just play guitar,'' he laments. But he's not serious. He's just joking around with Dire Straits' guitarist Mark Knopfler, his special guest on the new album ``Neck and Neck.'' Atkins hardly needs any special strategy at this stage of his career. He's already earned the title ``Mr. Guitar'' during his 45 years as an instrumentalist. He's recorded more than 75 albums and sold in excess of 30 million records. However, on ``Neck and Neck,'' Atkins returns to the country music style he helped popularize. Even the presence of a rock 'n' roller such as Knopfler, the producer of the album, can't hide the country feel to it. ``I've been making so-called jazz albums for the past three or four years,'' Atkins said in an interview in his Music Row office before heading to a golf course to pursue his hobby. ``So in this album, we got away from that and got back to more country sounding things for the most part. Mark thought I was going in the wrong direction lately.'' In the LP, they play and sing on such well-known songs as ``There'll Be Some Changes Made,'' ``I'll See You in My Dreams'' and ``Sweet Dreams.'' ``I think it will appeal to a lot of people around the world where Mark's fans are,'' Atkins said. ``I don't know yet how it will be accepted in this country. There seems to be a great deal of conformity in this country where they play the same things.'' Atkins has collaborated with top contemporary artists including George Benson, Larry Carlton, Earl Klugh and Les Paul. There's a reason. ``It's a lot easier because when I play, I improvise,'' he said. ``I never play the same chorus twice. So when I'm playing with someone, he will play something that gives me a fresh idea. ``If I'm playing by myself, I might just fall back on cliches and play the same thing over and over. But someone like Mark plays licks that inspire me and gives stimulus to an idea I might come up with.'' He describes Knopfler, now with the Notting Hillbillies, as a distinctive guitarist. ``He plays with his right hand and he's a left hander. So he has a lot of strength in his left hand. He can get a vibrato with three strings instead of one like most people because his hand is so strong,'' Atkins said. ``He's a great noodler, if you know what noodlin' is. He can improvise all over the place - on and on.'' Atkins, who has won eight Grammy awards, says he keeps doing albums in an eternal quest for perfection. ``I never have gotten it right,'' he says modestly about his playing. ``I keep trying to improve and get it the way I want it and keep out the mediocrity and conformity. ``I never listen to my records. I hope I never get so I love to listen to myself. I think that's one of the reasons I've been around so long, because I don't like the way I'm doing. I keep changing and playing a few new things so that I haven't become entirely predictable to the average person out there.'' Atkins is renowned among musicians for refining the thumb-and-finger picking technique in which the thumb plays the bass notes and keeps time while the fingers play the melody lines. ``Guitar Player'' magazine has named him the most influential stylist in his field. He has made important behind-the-scenes contributions to music, too. As the former head of RCA Records' Nashville division, he was responsible for helping to sign and produce records for dozens of entertainers including Elvis Presley and Dolly Parton. This summer he did an 18-city tour, dubbed ``The Sweet Corn Show,'' with ``Prairie Home Companion'' creator Garrison Keillor. Never one to enjoy life without a project in the works, Atkins will begin production soon on his next album, ``Fingerpickin','' with longtime pal Jerry Reed.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Oct. 5-7

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Art dealer Leo Castelli will head a nationwide effort in the art world effort to raise election funds for Harvey Gantt, who is running against Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. Helms has led the fight to restrict the National Endowment for the Arts' public funding of the arts. Key to the art world campaign strategy is the production of a series of original, signed, limited-edition prints created and donated by a group of American artists. The artists' prints will be used as incentive gifts to contributors of $1,000 who also bring in a matching gift of $1,000. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Liam Neeson, Sir John Gielgud and Joel Richardson have joined the cast of Twentieth Century Fox's ``Shining Through,'' which co-stars Michael Douglas and Melanie Griffith. The film, which will be made in association with Sandollar Productions, will start shooting Oct. 1 in London, Berlin and Austria. A romantic spy thriller set during World War II, ``Shining Through'' is based on the best-selling novel by Susan Isaacs and chronicles the daring adventure of a Brooklyn-born secretary who is sent on a one-time mission to gather information on a high ranking Nazi officer. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - The American Council for the Arts has received a $33,500 grant from the Marie Walsh Sharpe Art Foundation to develop and operate a toll-free information hotline serving visual artists nationwide. The hotline, which is to begin service in October, will allow visual artists to call from anywhere in the United States and reach the Arts Resource Consortium Library. Library staff will match the specific interests of callers with a database of information resources. Primarily a referral service, the hotline will give visual artists details on where to go and who to contact regarding such areas as funding, housing, insurance, health and law. Included in the database will be foundations and government programs funding visual artists, programs of arts councils, arts service organizations and others who provide information, technical assistance or other services to visual artists. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Among the more ambitious projects from Columbia Records is the release of ``Robert Johnson - The Complete Recordings.'' Part of the record company's ``Roots 'n Blues'' series, the set of two compact discs covers Johnson's 29 known songs in 41 existing takes. Many of the recordings in the series - of such masters as Big Bill Broonzy, Lonnie Johnson and Willie Dixon - are from the private collection of Lawrence Cohn, producer of the series. Cohn was at Columbia during the 1960s blues revival. Johnson's incredible guitar playing influenced a legion of contemporary artists. Eric Clapton, who has a personal note in the CD set, covered Johnson's ``Cross Road Blues.'' The Rolling Stones did his ``Love in Vain,'' Paul Butterfield covered ``Walking Blues'' and Canned Heat recorded ``Hellhound on my Trail.'' Johnson recorded in 1936-37 in San Antonio and Dallas.

Oil soared over $35 per barrel for another record on the futures market after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein gave traders the jitters by telling his citizens to prepare for war. Light sweet crude for delivery in November, the nearest month available, traded as high as $35.60 per barrel Friday before settling at $35.43 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, up $2.01 over Thursday's close for November crude. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Chase Manhattan Corp., hoping to squelch rumors of worsening financial trouble, revealed plans to bolster the No. 2 U.S. bank's cushion for potentially bad loans, halve its stock dividend and eliminate 5,000 jobs in a painful cost-cutting strategy. A loss of about $625 million is expected in the third quarter after Chase adds $650 million to its loan-loss provision and takes a $350 million one-time accounting charge against earnings to cover the costs of a previously announced restructuring, Chase said Friday. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Finance officials of the world's seven richest nations said Saturday that spiraling oil prices pose a twin threat to the global economy: higher inflation and slower growth. The Group of Seven, in their first meeting since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, discussed coordinated economic policies to keep the global economy from falling victim to Mideast turmoil. After a full day of talks, the officials issued a communique noting ``that the rise in the price of oil associated with the gulf crisis poses two risks: a risk of inflation and a risk of lower economic growth.'' They said ``stability-oriented monetary policies and sound fiscal policies constitute the correct policy response.'' --- WASHINGTON - Depositors withdrew a record $15.1 billion from the nation's savings and loans in April, the government said in another confirmation of the rapid retrenchment gripping the industry. The net withdrawal, which was somewhat offset by $2.9 billion in interest credited to savers' accounts, reduced deposits at the 2,839 S&Ls to $916 billion, the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision said Friday. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - A judge refused to reduce Charles H. Keating's $5 million bail, ruling that the central figure in the nation's most expensive savings and loan collapse was a flight risk. Bail was reduced for three co-defendants named in a 42-count criminal fraud indictment, but Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner said Friday that numerous civil lawsuits and the threat of prison gave Keating ``significant reasons not to stick around.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Federal regulators filed a $200 million suit against President Bush's son Neil and other officers of the failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, accusing them of ``gross negligence'' contributing to the institution's collapse. The civil suit, filed Friday by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. in U.S. District Court in Denver, said the defendants ``repeatedly breached their duties'' to the Denver-based institution and its depositors. --- TORONTO (AP) - About 12,800 Canadian Auto Workers union members ended a 9-day-old strike against Ford Motor Co.'s Canada subsidiary by overwhelmingly approving a new contract Sunday. The CAW members voted 91 percent in favor of the tentative agreement reached Friday. The strike, which started Sept. 15, had idled Ford's nine Canadian plants, all in Ontario. Production at Ford's U.S. plants, some of which rely on Canadian components, had been threatened by the strike, company officials said. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Aon Corp. withdrew its unsolicited $840 million bid for fellow insurer Corroon & Black Corp. after its target spurned the cash offer. The move Friday allows Corroon & Black and the British insurance firm Willis Faber PLC to proceed with their proposed stock-swap merger, a deal valued at more than $750 million. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - A White House task force, backed by President Bush, asked Congress to cut Pacific Northwest logging by 20 percent to save the northern spotted owl from extinction. The recommended harvest issued Friday level is far less than what has been sought by the timber industry but far more than what environmentalists say is necessary to protect the endangered owl and the old-growth forest it inhabits. ---

Stock prices lost ground Friday in a session marked by stormy activity in battered bank issues. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 5.94 to 2,512.38, extending its loss for the week to 51.73 points. Bond prices fell sharply in quiet trading as crude oil prices closed above $35 a barrel and prospects dimmed for a federal budget agreement. The dollar ended mixed in thin dealings. Gold prices inched higher. Gold futures prices remained relatively stable; livestock futures rose; pork bellies fell; soybean futures fell; and corn and wheat futures posted slight gains.

DOC.HEAD: Paying The Piper In The 1990s
DOC.TEXT: For a nation that extols the virtues of living within your income, there's an awful lot of borrowing going on, enough to christen the 1980s, a bit belatedly, as the decade of deep debt. . . . . .and perhaps not prematurely, to call the decade of the 1990s the time in which the bills came due, the wreckage assessed, and an effort made to clear accounts and get the economy back on the straight and narrow. The phenomenon is a living presence in millions of American households in the form of credit cards and other installment credit, automobile loans, home mortgages, education loans, broker loans. And at work. American corporations took on more debt in the 1980s than anyone ever imagined before. Since 1983, about $500 billion worth of equities have been removed from the market, most of it replaced by debt. And in government. The Federal government has been running up annual deficits for two decades, and despite an interest-rate burden that is now one of its biggest budget items, it will continue to borrow for years. Many state and municipal governments too are in a deep-debt state, and some are facing crises that cannot be exaggerated. New York is only recently resurrected from near-bankruptcy but some other cities are heading toward it. About $2 billion of government-backed student loans appear uncollectable. The insurance fund protecting commercial loan deposits might need help. Savings and loans losses are at $130 billion, and may head higher. Taxpayers eventually will pay for those losses, of course, because their hard work is where the bucks originate. But the Federal Savings & Loan Insurance Corporation is hardly the only government-backed program in trouble. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Federal Housing Administration lost money in 1988 and 1989 and seem destined to lose again this year. About half of farm loans by the Farmers Home Administration are in default. There's a lot more federally backed debt than that, as you might surmise, but much of it will never appear in the official budget deficit figures because the government simply shoved them away. They are ``off budget.'' Past-due real estate loans at banks climbed $3.2 billion in the April-June period. Corporate junk-bond defaults so far this year total nearly $10 billion, or already about $1 billion more than all of last year. Those junk-bond defaults don't give a full picture of the tenuous financial substructure of American industry. A further examination, which Wright Investors Service undertook, suggests the direction of corporate financing: - Nonfinancial corporate borrowing as a percentage of gross national product rose to 67 percent last year from 47 percent 20 years earlier, and 39 percent 30 years ago. - In the 20 years through 1989, the ratio of interest expense to corporate earnings more than doubled to 40 percent. - In the late 1980s, half of all funds raised by non-financial corporations came from debt. As recently as the 1960s and 1970s, the average was only 24 percent debt. All this debt, much of it from abroad, must be dealt with in the 1990s, and probably will be, because it cannot continue without economic performance becoming ragged and eventually collapsing under the burden of interest rates. But Americans should not believe the correction will occur automatically or without pain as, to some extent, the buildup did. Simply stated, it will be repaid by such means as taxes and inflation and relatively high interest costs, perhaps accompanied by lessened wage increases and smaller productivity gains. It will be repaid by individuals, not by businesses or governments, for the latter are just collections of individuals running the machinery that processes the bills.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Crisis May Speed Shakeup in Sick Airline Industry
Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Soaring oil prices are pushing ailing airlines toward their biggest losses ever, and they might become a catalyst for a severe shakeup of the troubled industry, analysts say. Coupled with the sluggish economy, the fallout from the Persian Gulf crisis will hurt all airlines. But it might eventually end up helping the stronger carriers get bigger at the expense of their struggling competitors. ``It'll make the financially weaker guys get weaker faster,'' said Kevin Murphy, an analyst with Morgan Stanley. The strong airlines would then grow by default. Under such a scenario, analysts say, the winners who stand to gain market share could be American, Delta and United. Losers will likely include Eastern, Continental, Midway, Pan Am and Trans World, the analysts say. Unless something puts the brakes on oil prices and the domestic economy finds a quick fix, analysts anticipate that the airline industry will lose $1 billion to $2 billion for 1990.
