That would surpass 1982's record operating loss of $700 million. It will be ``decidedly ugly,'' said Samuel Buttrick, an analyst with Kidder Peabody & Co. ``The fundamental problem that the industry faces is excess domestic capacity: Too many seats chasing too few people,'' Buttrick said. He sees the failure of some carriers, and the removal of their assets from the market, as the best way to restore equilibrium to the glutted market. The gloomy business climate might ``push one or two over the brink,'' said analyst Raymond E. Neidl of Dillon Read & Co. Inc. ``Eastern is probably the most endangered airline. Pan Am is facing problems.'' Murphy and Buttrick predict Eastern will die, with Murphy putting the carrier's doomsday at around the end of the year and at the latest in about 200 days. ``I figure they've got $300 million, and they're losing money at the rate of a million and a half a day,'' despite efforts to reorganize in U.S. Bankruptcy Court, he said. Others say Eastern might live longer than the doubters are predicting. ``One has to remember that people have been spelling the death knell for Pan Am and Eastern for a decade or more, and they're still here,'' said George James, president of Airline Economics Inc., a Washington consulting firm. ``It takes a long time for the assets of a big carrier to be used up.'' The immediate troubles of the industry were underscored last week when Pan Am announced it would cut 2,500 jobs by mid October and reduce its capacity by 7.5 percent during 1991. The moves come after the troubled carrier has sold assets and found no immediate success in finding a merger partner. Neidl said the cutbacks, intended to save tens of millions of dollars, will probably buy time for Pan Am. But there is no guarantee the plan will work. ``It may get them through another slow winter period,'' Neidl said. ``That would get them into the high summer season. It would get them more time to look for an outside source for that capital infusion they need.'' Shortly after Pan Am announced plans to shrink to what it hopes will be a profitable size, an aide to debt-plagued developer Donald J. Trump said Trump had missed a payment of $1.1 million on the Trump Shuttle. Trump is asking bankers to let him delay future payments and saying that the high cost of jet fuel is causing his problems. Analysts agree that the rising fuel costs are the biggest threat to airlines these days. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, jet fuel has gone up about 50 percent. If oil prices don't fall, airlines could end up paying up to $6 billion a year in extra fuel costs, according to industry statisticians. Airlines responded to the inflated costs with two rounds of fare hikes that come to about 10 percent on domestic flights, not nearly enough to offset the higher fuel tab. But it took them about two months after the invasion to set the higher fares into effect, because no airline wants to go out on a limb with higher prices. In the meantime, airlines lost money as travelers flew for the old rate on planes that were using the expensive fuel.

DOC.HEAD: Recession Fears Plague Retailing Stocks
Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: As the traditional peak season of the year for consumer spending approaches, Wall Street is decidedly un-bullish on retailing. The stocks of most of the nation's major store operators have fallen sharply since midsummer, posting losses as big as or bigger than the decline in the market as a whole. Even as the early flood-tide of Christmas catalogs has reached the nation's mailboxes, the retailing business is confronted with recession fears, soaring oil prices and surveys showing little enthusiasm among the nation's shoppers. ``Falling consumer confidence presents a troubling outlook for fourth-quarter consumer spending,'' said Anthony Vignola at the investment firm of Kidder, Peabody & Co. ``This trend could be particularly damaging to the important Christmas selling season and the demand by retailers for seasonal supplies.'' The primary catalyst for the selloff in retailing stocks, of course, was Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and the upsurge in oil prices that followed. Analysts saw the increase in energy costs as the functional equivalent of a tax increase, crimping consumers' disposable income. Regular surveys by economists designed to measure consumer confidence seem to bear out that view. Some observers point out that the outlook for retailers was already worsening appreciably before the crisis in the Persian Gulf. ``The latest numbers simply extend the downward trend in year-over-year sales gains that has been under way since early in 1989,'' said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International in New York. ``Aggregate demand appeared to be on a progressively slowing path even before the Mideast crisis. Now heightened consumer anxiety, reflected in polls showing a majority of respondents expects recession, threatens to become a self-fulfilling prophecy.'' All this helps explain why the stock of Sears Roebuck, a prominent general merchandise retailer, traded last week around $27, down from $48 in 1989. The Limited, a widely followed specialty retailer, slipped below $15, against $25.62 just a few months earlier, adjusted for splits. Even Wal-Mart Stores, revered on Wall Street as one of the nation's great growth companies, has traded of late at around $26.50, down more than 25 percent from its recent record high of $36.75, again adjusted for splits. At these ``discount'' prices, some bargain-minded investors are naturally scrutinizing retail stocks. But many analysts still take a wary view of the group. ``We don't believe the retail environment will improve until the second half of 1991,'' wrote Barry Bryant, who follows the industry for Prudential-Bache Securities. ``We believe a mild recession will begin in the fourth quarter of 1990 and continue into the second quarter of 1991. We expect retail sales to grow only 4 percent to 5 percent, and to be flat when adjusted for inflation. ``The slower growth is expected to occur during a period when retailers will be facing their most difficult sales and earnings comparisons.'' At the Value Line Investment Survey, analysts also are recommending a go-slow approach to retailing issues. The firm acknowledges that big-name stocks in the industry like Sears, K mart and J.C. Penney have lately been sporting dividend yields in the neighborhood of 6 percent. ``Even though the dividend offers some downside protection for those equities, we're not recommending purchase just yet,'' said Value Line's Bart Schneider in the firm's latest quarterly report on the group. ``Near-term prospects for the retail industry are unsettled and it appears that conditions will probably get worse before they get better.''

DOC.HEAD: Gerber to Market Adult-Oriented Juice
Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: When Gerber Products Co. executive Al Bolles tasted the bitter adult-oriented fruit drink offered at a trade show, he was sure his company could do it better. Bolles, director of product development for the baby-food company, picked up samples of the drink, Fibe-mini, at a trade show in Japan. The fiber-containing drink was destined for the palates of adult Asians. ``Nobody liked it,'' Bolles said of the tastes of Fibe-mini he gave to other Gerber executives. ``I said, `We can make something better than this.'' The result, two years later, was Juice & More, the first adult product put out by the baby face-trademarked company. The target market for fiber-enriched Juice & More will be people concerned about cholesterol and heart disease. ``It will be the beachhead of our marketing efforts to older individuals,'' Gerber Chairman Al Piergallini said. ``This is all new territory for us.'' Juice & More is to hit the shelves this week in 7,200 stores in Florida, Alabama, Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina, Virginia, Kentucky, West Virginia, Tennessee, Pennsylvania, New York City and Washington D.C. Gerber hopes to bring the product to the rest of the country, by spring. Gerber has looked into adult foods before - frozen dinners for singles, ketchup, peanut butter and other products - but no project has made it this far. Laboratory researchers concocted 200 products over about four months combining juice with various kinds of fiber before they hit on a formula they thought was a winner. Juice & More uses apple pectin and acadia plants as the sources for its fiber. The formula would give a person as much fiber as two bowls of oatmeal in an 8-ounce glass. But, ``taste was the key,'' Gerber Director of Nutrition Dick Cotter said. ``This had it.'' The next test comes at the checkout counter, where Gerber officials said they hope the juice will bring in $25 million in the next two years. Analysts aren't sure. ``I'm optimistic about Gerber, but I'm skeptical about this particular product,'' said John McMillin, who follows the food industry to Prudential-Bache Securities in New York. Martin Friedman, editor of Gorman's New Product News, said less than 1 percent of new products put on the consumer market will survive. ``But there's a tremendous pot of gold at the end of the rainbow if they come out with the right item,'' he said. Gerber posted a record $94.1 million in profits in the fiscal year ended March 31. It had revenues of $1.1 billion and wants to keep pushing those figures up. Introducing a fiber-enriched juice, let alone one for adults in a company whose whole existence has been based on babies, is a chance. ``If you're going to grow, you innovate,'' Piergallini said. ``When you innovate, there's risk.''

DOC.HEAD: CAW Members Ratify Ford Contract
DOC.TEXT: Canadian Auto Workers union members overwhelmingly approved a new contract with Ford Motor Co.'s Canada subsidiary, ending a nine-day strike that officials said threatened production at U.S. plants. About 91 percent of the 12,800 members voting cast ballots in favor of the new three-year pact, union officials said Sunday. The strike, which started Sept. 15, idled Ford's nine Canadian plants, all in Ontario. Production at Ford's U.S. plants, some of which rely on Canadian components, had been threatened by the strike, company officials said. Assembly line workers were expected to return to work today. Some workers were expected back on the job Sunday night to set up equipment for production, said CAW President Robert White. The contract provides for a 7.5 percent increase in wages in the first year, 6.7 percent in the second and 4.8 percent in the third. That means workers now earning the base rate of $17.83 an hour will get $21.41 by the end of the contract. Workers also will get three extra days off a year, which will be scheduled to give them four-day weekends. That will give Ford workers nine four-day work weeks a year, once statutory holidays are taken into account. Among other benefits: one year's notice of any workplace closing; six month's notice of any job loss as a result of technological change; special programs to pay workers who take early retirement; and income supplements of up to three years for workers who lose their jobs. The deal with Ford clears the way for the union to negotiate contracts with General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp. The union picked Ford as its strike target following separate preliminary talks with GM and Chrysler. As in the past, the contract is expected to form the basis for agreements with the other two companies. GM and the United Auto Workers averted a strike and reached a tentative agreement last week on a three-year contract covering 300,000 workers in 29 states. That agreement, which is likely to be ratified, was reported to include a 3 percent raise the first year, 3 percent lump-sum payments the next two and retention of a requirement that GM hire one worker for every two who quit, retire or die before retirement. Once the GM contract is ratified, the UAW will seek to negotiate similar contracts with Ford and Chrysler in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Finance Ministers Back Aid to Cushion Economic Shock of Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Will be led following news conference scheduled 8 a.m. EDT. Also moviong on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, stepping up efforts to gather support in the campaign against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, is getting encouragement from the two largest international lending agencies. Top finance ministers participating in a series of weekend meetings expressed their general support for a U.S.-led initiative to get the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to devote significant resources to cushioning the economic shock from the Persian Gulf crisis. A formal endorsement of the aid effort was expected to come today following the conclusion of closed-door meetings of the IMF's policy-setting interim committee. British Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major told reporters Sunday that the question of whether to provide aid was not at issue. But he said details of the exact amount and which countries to help remained to be worked out. The United States, concerned that the economic embargo against Iraq could crumble without assistance to countries hurt by the trade ban, has been pushing for more than $10 billion in aid to the so-called front line states of Egypt, Turkey and Jordan. It also is seeking billions of dollars in additional contributions to a host of countries ranging from emerging democracies in Eastern Europe to such Third World nations as the Philippines, India and Brazil to offset the adverse effects on their economies from higher oil prices. The world's seven richest industrial countries - the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada - provided an initial endorsement for Persian Gulf assistance following a day-long meeting Saturday. The rich countries took note of the double risks of inflation and recession imposed by the doubling of world oil prices since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. All of the discussions were being held as part of the annual meetings of the 152-nation IMF and its sister organization, the World Bank. Those sessions have gained new urgency as finance officials struggle to come up with strategies to keep the global economy from tumbling into a recession as a result of the Persian Gulf turmoil. President Bush was to address the delegates on Tuesday. Representatives for India and Brazil made special appeals for assistance during Sunday's closed-door meetings, according to participants in the sessions. Brazilian Finance Minister Zelia Maria Cardoso de Mello said that even before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sent oil prices skyrocketing, global growth had weakened considerably. ``The gulf crisis changed this already bleak picture dramatically for the worse,'' she said in a statement released to reporters. ``The moment calls for unprecedented efforts at cooperation and strong support from the multilateral financial institutions.'' Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said he believed the IMF and the World Bank had an ``extremely critical'' role to play in coordinating the assistance efforts being mounted to respond to the Mideast crisis. After some initial criticism, Japan has come up with offers of $4 billion in aid with half that amount earmarked for support of the military effort and the other half going to provide economic assistance to the front line states. IMF and World Bank officials have indicated that part of the aid will come from voluntary contributions from oil-producing countries that are reaping a windfall from the jump in oil prices. A meeting of prospective donor nations is scheduled for Wednesday. In addition to the Persian Gulf crisis and traditional concerns of alleviating poverty in the Third World, this year's meetings were reviewing the economic crisis facing the Soviet Union. The seven rich countries heard a special report Saturday from IMF and other officials on a study being conducted into the problems besetting the Soviet economy. That study, which was ordered by Bush and other leaders at this year's economic summit in July, could set the stage when it is completed in December for billions of dollars in direct Western aid to support Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's faltering efforts to move his country to a free-market economy. For the first time in the history of the IMF and World Bank, the Soviets are attending this year's annual meeting as special guests, a first step that could led to eventual membership for the Soviet Union in both agencies. Meanwhile, Romania became the 138th member of the International Finance Corp. on Sunday, signaling a quest for private enterprise in a formerly communist-ruled country where all major businesses still are run by the state. The IFC, affiliated with the World Bank, finances and aids in the development of private enterprise in developing countries.

DOC.HEAD: Merger to Create Huge Mining Company
DOC.TEXT: Newmont Australia Ltd. and BHP Gold Mines Ltd. said Monday they plan to merge, creating a gold-mining company with expected market capitalization of more than $830 million. In joint statements, the companies said Newmont will offer one ordinary share for every two BHP Gold shares. The resulting company would produce about 750,000 ounces of gold in 1991. The announcement comes after Newmont Australia launched court proceedings against a takeover bid from Poseidon Gold Ltd. The Newmont-BHP Gold merger is conditional on 51 percent acceptance, regulatory approval and an increase in Newmont's authorized share capital. BHP Gold is 56 percent owned by BHP Co. Ltd., Australia's largest company.

DOC.HEAD: Approves Sale of Two State Airlines, Competition in Telecommunications
DOC.TEXT: The governing Labor Party on Monday approved sweeping policy changes that pave the way for competition in telecommunications and the sale of the two state airlines. The issue of privatization had threatened to split the party, which officially had opposed any efforts to sell off government-owned enterprises. The most divisive issue, particularly among unions, has been telecommunications. A number of foreign companies have expressed interest in entering the Australian communications market. Delegates at a special party conference voted 58-43 on Monday to reject an amendment that would have prevented a private competitor being established in full network competition to a merger of domestic carrier Telecom and overseas carrier OTC. The conference then passed, on voice vote, a resolution allowing the merger of Telecom and OTC, the sale of the government's financially troubled satellite company Aussat and full private competition. Later in the day, the conference endorsed the government's plan to sell up to 49 percent of Qantas and all of Australian Airlines. The conference rejected a proposed amendment which would have merged the airlines and kept them under full government control. Treasurer Paul Keating labeled the amendment as ``horrible'' and rejected claims that the government deliberately starved the airlines of funding so it could argue for their sale. Transport and Communications Minister Kim Beazley accepted an amendment that limits to 35 percent the amount of Qantas which could be sold to foreign interests.

DOC.HEAD: US Underwrites War Insurance For First Ship In Commercial Trade
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government has underwritten war risk insurance on a commercial ship engaged in normal commercial trade for the first time since the Korean War in the early 1950s, the shipping daily Lloyd's List reported Monday. In a front-page story, Lloyd's said the 40,921-ton Stonewall Jackson owned by Waterman Steamship is the first vessel operating commercially to take advantage of the U.S. government's standby war risk insurance program since it became effective Aug. 29. The LASH barge carrier, which is about to make a call at the Jordanian port of Aqaba, received war risk insurance from the U.S. Maritime Administration on the hull and the 89 barges she carries, the paper said. Under the program, any foreign or U.S. ship may apply to the Maritime Administration for war risk coverage provided the vessel is engaged in U.S. trade. The maritime agency is permitted to quote rates when the rates and conditions being offered in the commercial insurance market are considered unfair and unreasonable, the paper said. The Maritime Administration has already issued war risk policies for 30 of the merchant vessels taken by the U.S. Military Sealift Command for operation Desert Shield in the Gulf, Lloyd's List said. It has issued its own policies and any claims will be paid by the U.S. Department of Defense. But the Stonewall Jackson was the first merchant ship operating commercially to take advantage of the program, the paper said. The Stonewall Jackson was on a voyage from the United States to the Far East via the Suez Canal when part of her cargo consigned to Catholic Relief Services in India was diverted for the international relief effort in Jordan, it said. Waterman Steamship approached the Maritime Administration for a war risks quote for stopping at Aqaba, which is in a rated war risks area, it said. Market rates for hull risks to Aqaba are currently around 0.25 percent, Lloyd's List said. A U.S. government source quoted by the paper said the Maritime Administration has to quote lower rates for the program to work and the commercial insurance market ``is not very happy with us'' because they see the administration as a potential competitor.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt Increases Oil Prices by $3 a Barrel
DOC.TEXT: Egypt decided on Monday to increase its export oil prices by $3 a barrel for all blends, an Oil Ministry official said. This was the third increase in eight days, reflecting a steady rise in world oil prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. Hammad Ayoub, head of the ministry's foreign sales, said the new prices were $37.30 a barrel for the Khalig el-Zeit and Ras el-Bihar blend; $37 a barrel for the Gulf of Suez; $36.15 a barrel for Belayim; $35 a barrel for Ras Badran, and $34.70 a barrel for Ras Ghareb. The increase took effect Monday and would prevail until the next price review, he said. Egypt, not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, previously reviewed its export prices every two weeks. Since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the governmnet has reviewed its prices more frequently. Egypt produces 870,000-900,000 barrels of oil daily. It exports almost half the output and consumes the rest locally.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Legislature Approves Switch To Market Economy, Gives Gorbachev Powers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with parliament approving emergency powers for Gorbachev, details. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `The adopted... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet lawmakers voted overwhelmingly today to forsake seven decades of Communist economics, endorsing a rescue plan to create a free market system from the failed machinery of centralized planning. The Supreme Soviet also gave President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sweeping new powers to implement the reforms unilaterally. But the lawmakers continued to disagree on which of several competing economic blueprints for accomplishing the switch should be followed. After a confusing and tumultuous debate, the Supreme Soviet settled on a resolution calling for a committee of legislators and economists appointed by Gorbachev to merge the various recipes into a unified plan by Oct. 15. The vote was 323-11, with 56 abstentions. Although differences remained, it was the first time the Supreme Soviet had committed the country to switching to a market economy in hopes of ending chronic shortages of everything from housing to bread and arresting inflation and a soaring budget deficit. When the resolution was approved, there was no applause or other display of emotion, not even by Gorbachev, sitting alone on a raised stage in a marble Kremlin meeting hall. Hours later the parliament approved 305-46, with 41 abstentions, Gorbachev's request for broad emergency poers to carry out reforms. It gave him the authority until March 1992 to bypass step-by-step legislative scrutiny and issue decrees on property, management of the economy, the budget and law and order. The legislature would have the power to recommend Gorbachev cancel or modify the decrees, which the president said he would begin issuing soon. Several lawmakers feared they were giving Gorbachev too much power, and one said it would make him a ``monarch.'' But in an animated 15-minute speech, Gorbachev vowed to exercise his new powers with ``full responsibility.'' ``It's a responsibility. It's not a tea party,'' he said. The adopted resolution endorses a compromise program backed by Gorbachev, but calls for incorporating a more conservative recipe of Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. Lawmakers later agreed they should also try to include parts of a more radical plan approved by the Russian Federation, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, led by Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin. Yeltsin is Gorbachev's chief political rival, and his parliament has set the pace on reforming an economy so inefficient that crops spoil on their way to market and plants stand idle for lack of spare parts. ``We can and must come out with a single program for switching to a market economy,'' Gorbachev said. He said the goal is ``maximum accord in society and not confrontation.'' Ryzhkov, facing mounting calls for his resignation, said the vote left ``no victors and no defeated.'' ``This is a compromise,'' he said in an interview. Sergei Stankevich, Moscow's deputy mayor and a national legislator, said Gorbachev's insistence on unifying the competing programs would lead ``not to consolidation but to collapse.'' Consumer shortages are widespread and worsening, most recently including bread, and there is fear of economic collapse. Gorbachev's program would reverse the direction that the Soviet Union has taken since the Bolshevik Revolution, especially Stalin's forced collectivization, which claimed the lives of some 7 million people. It would create a federation of republics with economies built on private businesses, individually owned farms and stock markets trading shares in competitive companies. The program marks a significant change in Gorbachev's tactics. His perestroika program had been aimed at ``restructuring'' centralized socialism, but now is apparently moving toward destroying it. Lawmakers had been scheduled to vote on Friday, but failed to muster a quorum and had to adjourn until today. Gorbachev expressed frustration at the time, saying there was no more time to ``talk, think, try and experiment.'' Several participants in today's debate proposed that the national legislature shun the attempt at a compromise and endorse instead the most radical reform plan under consideration - that of economist Stanislav Shatalin. ``There can be no compromise between the programs of the government, the president and the Shatalin group,'' the 56-year-old Shatalin told the legislature. Outside the Kremlin, protesters gathered to express disappointment in Gorbachev's handling of the economic crisis. Dozens of sign-carrying protesters chanted slogans at legislators as they arrived for the morning debate. ``The people don't trust Gorbachev,'' about a dozen demonstrators shouted outside the Kremlin's Spassky Gate. They held signs that read ``A president - not an emperor'' and ``All decrees of the president are battles against democracy.'' Ryzhkov, who has become a lightning rod for the growing public unrest, predicted on Soviet television Sunday night that the move to a market economy will take years, not 500 days. He confirmed ``very serious'' problems in bringing this year's bumper harvest to market. He said at most only one-third of crops have so far been harvested.

DOC.HEAD: Share Price Falls to Three-Year Low
DOC.TEXT: The price of media giant News Corp.'s shares plunged Monday to a three-year low and the company threatened to delist from the Australian Stock Exchange. The company's share price fell 70 Australian cents, or 58 cents (U.S.), to 8.90 Australian dollars, or $7.39, in morning trading before recovering slightly to close the session at 9.00 Australian dollars, or $7.47. The stock last traded below 9.00 Australian dollars in November 1987. News Corp. exeutives were not available for comment on the decline. Monday's price drop wiped another 161.14 million Australian dollars, or $133.75 million, off the company's market value, which lost 228.28 million Australian dollars, or $189.47 million, on trading on Friday. News Corp. told its shareholders in a mailing sent this wek that it would shift its home base offshore if the Australian Stock Exchange failed to change rules which prevent companies from issuing limited voting shares. The company, which is headed by Rupert Murdoch and has significant newspaper, magazine and television interests in the Britain and the United States as well as in Australia, said it planned to change its capital structure by altering its articles of association to allow the issue of participating preference shares and non-voting shares. Analysts said the threat to move offshore contributed to the uncertainty surrounding the company, but said Monday's price decline also reflected weakness in the broader market for media stocks. ``Basically, News Corp. is at the sharp end of the ship,'' said BZW Australia Ltd. senior analyst George Sutton. ``The wave of recession usually breaks over media companies before it does over others.'' Sutton said the company three major markets - Australia, Britain and the United States - were all experiencing difficult economic times.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Kuwait Investment Office saying sale was investment decision, not a move to raise cash.
DOC.TEXT: The Kuwaiti government's investment arm on Monday made its first known sale of a Kuwaiti holding since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The sale was ``purely an investment decision'' and wasn't aimed at raising cash, said a spokeswoman for the London-based investment arm, the Kuwait Investment Office. She wasn't identified, in accordance with British practice. The investment office sold a 10.1 percent stake in Mount Charlotte Investments PLC to a company controlled by New Zealand financier Ron Brierley for $121 million, Brierley's company said. The Kuwait Investment Office has a massive portfolio worth up to an estimated $100 billion and includes major stakes in British, West German and Spanish companies. On Friday, Kuwait's finance minister, Ali Khalifa Al-Sabah, said at a London news conference that Kuwait was managing to make do with its liquid assets and if any asset sale was required, ``We can handle it with the cooperation of central banks in an orderly and responsible manner.'' Governments have frozen Kuwait's assets to protect them from Iraq but Al-Sabah said the governments have allowed exiled Kuwaiti institutions to operate ``as freely as prudent.'' Brierley Investments Ltd. said it paid $1.36 per share for the 88.8 million shares of Mount Charlotte owned by the Kuwait investment office. The purchase lifted Brierley Investment's Mount Charlotte stake to 39.9 percent and forced the company under British takeover rules to make a bid for all of Mount Charlotte. Its offer values all of Mount Charlotte at $1.2 billion. A Mount Charlotte spokeswoman, who wasn't identified in accordance with British practice, said the company's board of directors would hold an emergency meeting. Mount Charlotte, which owns and operates 100 hotels, had after-tax profit of $72 million on sales of $289 million last year. Brierley Investments, quoted on the London, New Zealand and Australian stock markets, is an investment company with holdings in a diverse range of industries and markets. Brierley has a wide range of stakes in British companies, including a 20 percent holding in Vickers PLC, which makes Rolls-Royce luxury cars. It first became a shareholder in Mount Charlotte in the spring of 1988. Brierley had an after tax profit of $226 million on revenue of $3.8 billion in the year ended June 30, 1989.

Stock prices dropped sharply today in activity marked by heavy selling of the battered bank issues. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 49.26 points to 2,463.12 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. That drove the average below the 13-month closing low of 2,483.42 it reached on Aug. 23. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 6 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 203 up, 1,212 down and 320 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 53.98 million shares at midmorning. Analysts said investors were bracing for more bad tidings from the banking industry after Chase Manhattan Corp.'s announcement Friday of a dividend cut, new reserves for loan losses, and a staff reduction of 5,000 jobs. The news by itself did not come as any great surprise to Wall Street, which was well aware of widespread credit problems facing the banks. Nevertheless, it evidently served to intensify the recession worries that have been depressing stock prices since midsummer. Brokers noted that the market also had to contend with further increases in world oil prices. Crude oil futures for November delivery surpassed $37 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Chase Manhattan stock fell 1| to 11[ as the most active NYSE issue. Among other leading money-center bank issues, Citicorp dropped 1] to 14]; Chemical Banking 2 to 15; Manufacturers Hanover 1] to 21|, and J.P. Morgan 1 to 31[. Manufacturers Hanover, which recently declared a regular quarterly dividend, said it expected to be able to keep the payout at that rate. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included Boeing, down 3{ at 39}; General Electric, down 1[ at 54}; Philip Morris, down 1[ at 43|, and International Business Machines, down 1~ at 104~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 3.19 to 167.84. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.44 at 313.57.

DOC.HEAD: Corn, Soybean Futures Dip On Lack Of Frost
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures prices opened slightly lower this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting a lack of significant frost damage to those crops over the weekend. Wheat futures were narrowly mixed. Freezing temperatures were concentrated in the northwest corner of the Corn Belt but there was little damage to the crops. Forecasts call for a warming trend and scant rain in the Corn Belt this week, which should push late-planted crops toward maturity and allow harvesting to progress. Analysts said the early losses were limited by buying linked to strength in the energy and precious metals markets and weakness in the stock market in reaction to warlike rhetoric from Iraq's Saddam Hussein. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent lower to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.70} a bushel; corn was } cent to 1} cents lower with December at $2.24 a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent lower with March at $1.23 a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 1{ cents lower with November at $6.11 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .15 cent to .98 cent lower with October at 78.90 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to 1.02 cents lower with September at 89.30 cents a pound; live hogs were .17 cent to .55 cent lower with October at 54.60 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .80 cent to .87 cent lower with February at 55.30 cents a pound. Livestock futures rose on Friday; pork bellies fell.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Likely to Veto Any Delay in Budget Deal Deadline
DOC.NOTE: EDs: TOPS with 16 grafs to include Fitzwater comments. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, Dole's remarks . . . Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The White House today warned Congress that efforts to put off next Monday's deadline for $100 billion in automatic spending cuts likely will be met with a presidential veto. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the Gramm-Rudman law targets, which require the automatic cuts in the absence of congressional agreement on deficit-reduction, ``are an important discipline.'' ``They were put there by Congress to enforce decision-making and we don't agree they should be extended,'' he said. Asked if that was a clear veto threat for efforts to delay the spending cuts to give budget negotiators some additional breathing room, Fitzwater said: ``A veto threat is a veto threat. I conclude it's a veto threat.'' Fitzwater noted that the administration in the past has suggested that President Bush was likely to veto stopgap funding legislation that would delay or reduce the deficit targets. However, today's strong renewal of the threat - coming just seven days before the deadline and as budget talks remained deadlocked - appeared calculated to increase pressure on the bargaining process. ``There are a number of things that still divide us. We're still hopeful we can get agreement. We've got seven days to go. We're t-minus seven... We're sticking with it and still talking,'' he said. Fitzwater also was critical of what he called efforts by Democrats to suggest that the major stumbling block was administration insistence on a cut in the capital gains tax. ``The Democrats have been able to focus attention on the capital gains provision to the overall detriment of the progress of the negotiations,'' Fitzwater said. He said there were other important areas of disagreement. ``We're not even close on the spending cut side,'' Fitzwater said. Support in Congress has grown, as next Monday's deadline approaches, for a temporary measure to delay the targets until later in October. But Fitzwater made it clear the administration wasn't interested in such a postponement at this time. The spokesman said that Bush would join the budget negotiations, but probably not ``until pretty close to the end. When it's necessary, we'll be there.'' As to a new proposal by Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., for a package that would offset a cut in capital gains taxes with higher taxes on the wealthy, Fitzwater said: ``We certainly share his frustration that everybody needs to get off the dime and get an agreement here.'' However, Fitzwater would not comment on the specific proposal. The Kansas Republican said GOP negotiators at the 4-month-old budget talks were resisting Democratic efforts to raise the income tax rate for the wealthiest Americans from 28 percent to 33 percent. Dole's remarks made it clear that Republicans are searching for ways to keep the capital gains tax reduction - a favorite proposal of President Bush - alive at the budget talks. Bargainers have said contention over capital gains is the major obstruction to a final budget deal. Democrats have said Republicans must either abandon the proposal or be prepared to also accept higher levies on the wealthy, who Democrats say would gain the most from a lowered capital gains tax. The levy is imposed on sales of property. ``We're looking at ways to ... increase taxes on upper income in a way that will, in effect, maybe pierce this so-called bubble, but maybe not go clear to 33 percent,'' Dole said Sunday on CBS TV's ``Face the Nation'' program. The ``bubble'' is used to describe the portion of the income tax structure that imposes a 28 percent rate on the wealthiest Americans but a 33 percent rate on those with slightly less income. It was unclear whether Dole was referring to actually increasing the rates for the richest taxpayers. During the budget negotiations, Republicans have offered to eliminate certain deductions for top-bracket taxpayers, which they have argued would in effect raise those rates without actually doing so. Dole's comments came before Bush administration officials and congressional leaders met for four hours in a private room at the Capitol in an effort to work out a budget deal. ``They talked about everything,'' said an official who asked to not be identified. The bargainers planned to meet again today and resume their effort to work out a five-year, $500 billion package of spending cuts and tax increases. On the same television program, Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell blamed the Bush administration for the glacial pace at which the talks have so far progressed. ``If this were a negotiation just among ... the congressional leadership, we would have had an agreement a couple of weeks ago,'' said the Maine Democrat. ``The problem is the administration's position and its dominant role in the discussions and its insistence upon its way.'' Dole also seemed vexed by the administration's pace during the talks. ``We shouldn't be in too much of a rush,'' Dole said administration officials have told him. ``Well, I don't know what else they've got to do this year, but I've got a lot of things I'd like to do.'' The negotiators expect a pressure-filled week. The new fiscal year begins a week from today. The Gramm-Rudman law will automatically cut federal spending by $85 billion on Oct. 1 unless a deal is reached or lawmakers decide to postpone the slashes.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Debates Bill to Drive Gas Guzzlers Off Road
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with beginning of debate; picks up 3rd graf pvs, The Mideast...; edits to tighten. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate took up legislation today aimed at driving gas guzzlers off the road, with sponsors of a tougher fuel economy bill rejecting industry claims that the measure would make them produce only small cars. ``We can reach the goals without downsizing cars,'' declared Sen. Slade Gordon, R-Wash., one of the bill's sponsors. Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., another sponsor, read statements by auto industry executives in the early 1970s predicting the demise of the family sedan as a result of fuel efficiency requirements then under consideration. ``That just didn't happen. The six-passenger vehicle is here just as it was before,'' said Bryan. The fuel economy measures were put into effect and average mileage for cars increased from 14 mpg to about 28 mpg over the last 15 years. The bill before the Senate would require the average fuel economy of cars to go to about 35 mpg over the next five years and to 40 mpg by the year 2001, saving millions of barrels of oil a year. The Senate debate comes at automakers prepare to roll out their 1991 cars, including many models that emphasize comfort and performance, instead of fuel economy. Industry lobbyists contend the only way to achieve the fuel economy goals of the Senate bill would be to dramatically reduce the size and weight of cars. Sen.Donald Riegle, D-Mich., hoped to head off a vote later in the week on the legislation either by saddling it with amendments or garnering enough opposition so supporters cannot get the required 60 votes to end debate. A vote to cut off debate and bring the matter to a vote could come as early as Tuesday. The Mideast crisis that caused soaring oil prices and the threat of future gasoline lines has given the legislation new momentum. Supporters claim the more fuel efficient cars eventually could save the country 2.8 million barrels of oil a day. But auto industry lobbyists contend the kinds of fuel efficiency increases being talked about on Capitol Hill are not economically feasible. And in recent weeks, the automakers have stepped up their campaign against fuel economy bills in both the House and Senate. ``If the bill were enacted into law we would have economic disaster on our hands. Almost everything that is being built now would be obsolete by the year 2001,'' maintains Thomas Hanna, president of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association. The Senate voted 68-28 last week to rebuff efforts by Riegle, whose state is home to most of the U.S. auto industry, to keep the auto fuel economy bill from getting to the Senate floor. ``The American people understand better now than they did (before the Iraqi invasion) that we're very vulnerable in terms of oil imports,'' Bryan said in a recent interview. ``There is a recognition that we need to do something.'' The automakers' cause gained a boost last week when the Bush administration weighed in heavily against the Bryan bill. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner called it ``unrealistic, irresponsible and ... unattainable.'' He said he was convinced it would prompt manufacturers to dramatically reduce the size and weight of their cars - thereby resulting in between 600 and 1,100 additional automobile fatalities a year. He and Energy Secretary James Watkins have said they would urge President Bush to veto the measure if it clears Congress. The legislation's supporters also have a sizeable hurdle to overcome in the House, where any auto fuel economy bill normally would have to go through the Energy and Commerce Committee, whose chairman, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., has made no secret of his distaste for the proposal.

DOC.HEAD: KCPL Signs Confidentiality Agreement With Takeover Target KG&E
DOC.TEXT: Kansas City Power and Light Co. has signed a confidentiality agreement with Kansas Gas and Electric Co. that will allow it to obtain non-public information about Kansas G&E. ``We welcome the opportunity to review information that has not been previously available to us. This is a desirable first step that we hope will lead to broader negotiations,'' Drue Jennings, KCPL chief executive officer, said in a news release. Kansas City Power and Light launched $27-per-share cash tender offer for Kansas Gas and Electric on July 23. Kansas G&E has spurned the $857 million deal and urged its stockholders to hold onto their shares. Kansas G&E has said it is talking with other potential merger partners. The tender offer is scheduled to expire Oct. 19.

DOC.HEAD: CSX Receives Injunction to Stop Railroad Pickets
DOC.TEXT: CSX Transportation Inc. won a temporary injunction Monday to end a railroad workers' strike that stopped or delayed as many as 400 trains in at least 10 states, a company spokesman said. ``A temporary restraining order of 10 days duration has been issued and the judge has instructed the pickets to come down immediately,'' spokesman Lindsay Leckie said from the company's Jacksonville, Fla., headquarters. The injunction was issued Monday morning by U.S. District Judge Karl Forester in Lexington. A preliminary hearing was set for Friday. The strike by the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way began early Monday at more than two dozen locations on the old Louisville & Nashville line between Chicago, New Orleans and Pensacola, Fla., Leckie said. The workers protested the company's refusal to transport them away from their work sites for lunch. The picket lines were honored by hundreds of workers in other craft unions, he said. As many as 400 of CSX's 1,300 trains either were stopped by the strike or had to be operated by supervisory personnel, he said. Leckie said he did not know how many trains were stopped. The Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way represents workers who maintain the railroad's tracks, bridges and signs. The union complaint was registered in eastern Kentucky, he said. Other states involved included Indiana, Illinois, Tennessee, Ohio, Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi, Georgia and Florida, Leckie said. ``The issue is that the labor organization is insisting that employees be transported from the work site back to their lodging facilities, either railroad camp cars or their hotels,,'' Leckie said. ``Our contention is meals can and should be provided at the work site itself.'' Workers get from 30 minutes to an hour for lunch, but that could stretch to three hours in some cases if transportation time was added, he said. The issue has been settled in the company's favor during arbitration in the past, Leckie said.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Says Fuel Price Increases Will Put Dent in Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines said Monday that its earnings for the first quarter of its fiscal year will be down sharply due to increased fuel prices that followed the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Thomas J. Roeck Jr., Delta's senior vice president of finance, said earnings for the quarter ending Sept. 30 would be ``significantly worse'' than those for same quarter last year, when the airline posted record profits. Roeck said the airline is now paying 64 percent more for jet fuel than it was before the Aug. 2 invasion. Delta has twice raised domestic air fares, in August and again effective Oct. 1, to help offset the fuel price increases. In the quarter ending Sept. 30, 1989, net earnings were $133.1 million, or $2.38 per share, on revenue of $2.17 billion. Roeck noted that Delta was helped during that quarter by the strike against rival Eastern Airlines.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Production Up More than 2 Million Barrels Per Day
DOC.TEXT: Total daily production of crude oil by OPEC members has risen from 19.7 million barrels in August to 22 million barrels now, an International Energy Agency official said. The watchdog agency, which represents 21 industrialized Western countries, is scheduled to meet in Paris on Friday to assess the impact of the Gulf confrontation on world oil supplies. The agency official, who spoke on condition that his name not be used, said Monday the crude oil supply situation hasn't changed significantly since mid August. Given the estimated rise in OPEC output, the official said, the situation in world oil markets was ``manageable, though not comfortable.'' Oil companies have had to draw on stocks during a period normally reserved for building up reserves ahead of the high-demand winter season, he said. Demand among the members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which includes all IEA members plus France, Finland and Iceland, is estimated at 38.9 million barrels per day in the fourth quarter, up from the previously reported estimate of 37.8 million for the third quarter, the official said. Before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, OPEC was cutting back to reach a quota target of 22.5 million barrels per day, the official said. Following the subsequent boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude, which took an estimated 4 million barrels of oil out of the market each day, OPEC oil ministers agreed to temporarily suspend the cartel's production quotas to allow its members to make up for the shortfall. Now, the cartel appears well on its way to boosting production. Saudi Arabia, with the largest available amount of surplus capacity, has produced an average 7.3 million barrels a day in September, up from a revised 5.6 million the month before.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Not Yet Ready to Negotiate New Coffee Price-Support Measures
DOC.TEXT: Brazil is not ready to enter negotiations on new international measures to regulate the world coffee market, Brazilian officials said Monday. ``It is not the appropriate moment to start negotiations, but we do not want to close the door on negotiations,'' said Celso Amorim, a senior Brazilian foreign ministry official attending Ifee Organization talks. Amorim and Joao Cunha of the Brazilian economics ministry are heading their country's delegation to the talks here among the coffee organization's 73 consumer and producer member countries. Brazil said more time was neednternational Cofed before a decision was made on negotiations for a new International Coffee Agreement with the powers to regulate supplies and prices, Amorim said. The present pact's powers to do this - exercised through a system of export quotas - were suspended in July 1989, following a dispute among producers over export market share. The suspension triggered a massive fall in world prices, which hit a 14-year low late last year and have recovered only slightly since. The present coffee agreement expires on Sept. 30, 1991. Colombia, the world's second biggest producer, has called on the coffee organization to decide this week what should happen then. The options are to extend the present administrative agreement,t the voice to that spot, as if the music were a character released into space. ``Touch with your sound, your word...let it get away from you, see it, it's a vision.'' Curtin says her daughter, Claudia, who's in her 20s, told her she had used that idea to guide her horse over obstructions - by throwing a precise mental image of the movement in front of her and following it. To project the voice, the chest must be released out and up, ``the posture of anyone who has been successful,'' Curtin says. Teaching that to students in the 1970s, as a professor at Yale University, was nearly impossible, she says. ``To stand up straight meant that you were with all the conservatives, and the warmongers, you were for big money,'' she says. ``So everyone slunk down, the posture was really casual.'' Curtin started teaching at Tanglewood 26 years ago at the peak of a performing career that took her to the world's leading stages, New York's Metropolitan, Milan's La Scala and the Vienna Staatsoper. On teaching singers fiendishly difficult 20th century music, Curtin quotes Olga Averino, the Russian-born soprano who was her teacher: ``Darling, so simple,'' says the West Virginia native, speaking with a heavy Slavic accent, ``It's just like teaching a rabbit how to play a drum, you just do it over and over and over.'' Curtin stopped performing at the age of 61, about a decade later than most sopranos. By that time, she had been appointed dean of the Boston University School for the Arts. The major problem with young singers today, she says, is that they're often ``well-trained poodles,'' a ``homogenized product'' of coaches who tell them by rote what to do. Meanwhile, she tells her students, ``I want you to be smart, I want you to be your own artist. I don't want you to be a dumb musician.'' The main quality of teaching is sharing, she says, quoting Thornton Wilder's novel, ``The Ides of March,'' in which Caesar tells Cleopatra that ``there's nothing so exhilarating as teaching to a young and eager mind what it's taken you 20 years of drudgery to discover.'' When she's teaching, she says, ``the minute the music turns on, somehow, my channels are open. The thing that is emotion, that is music, is running through the center of my body and out, out, out. ``A masterful teacher turns out people who do it better than he does. And I would like to be that.'' She started practicing ``to be that'' at age 9 in West Virginia. ``I took dancing lessons and my very dearest friend did not,'' she says. ``So, I would come home from my lesson and teach it all to her, and that was so much fun!'' Almost six decades after that first attempt at teaching, her former student, baritone Sanford Sylvan, says Curtin is his ``artistic mother...the wind beneath my wings.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down; Gold Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with late European prices and rates plus early afternoon New York quotes.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against all the major currencies in European trading today, hurt by perceptions that major industrialized nations may let the U.S. currency decline further. Gold prices rose. The Group of Seven ministers issued a statement over the weekend calling for continued firm monetary policies in the face of high oil prices, which are stoking inflation. The statement also expressed contentment with recent movements in currency values. The Tokyo markets were closed for Autumnal Equinox Day. In London, the dollar fell to a closing 135.57 Japanese yen from 137.33 yen at Friday's Tokyo close. The dollar fetched 136.30 yen in early afternoon trading in New York. The British pound rose in London to $1.8810 from $1.8465 late Friday. A pound was quoted at $1.8805 in the early afternoon in New York. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday's levels, were: 1.5565 German marks, down from 1.5770; 1.2965 Swiss francs, down from 1.3205; 5.2145 French francs, down from 5.2790; 1.7665 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7773; 1,165.50 Italian lire, down from 1,175.75; and 1.1501 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1528. Selected rates for the dollar in the early afternoon in New York included: 1.5585 German marks; 1.2985 Swiss francs; 1.1531 Canadian dollars; and 1,168.20 Italian lire. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $396.55 a troy ounce from $388.25 late Friday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $392.90 from $392.20 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong gold rose $1.05 to close at a bid of $389.42. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $4.89 a troy ounce from $4.81 late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Working Rigs Decreases by 5
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, A week . . . to CORRECT last week's total to 1,060.
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States dropped this week by five to 1,055, the oil toolmaker Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. A week ago, the widely watched index of drilling activity had increased by 21 to total 1,060. The count a year ago was 967, Baker Hughes said. The Houston-based company has kept track of the rig count since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Texas added five rigs in the latest count, while Ohio's count rose three. Louisiana's count was down five and Wyoming was down three.

DOC.HEAD: Cadbury Schweppes In Talks with German Company on Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: Cadbury Schweppes PLC, the British confectionary and drinks company, said Monday it is in talks with the mineral watrs concern Apollinaris Brunnen AG that could lead to a joint venture between the two companies. The proposed venture is not expected to require any special funding arrangements, and Cadbury Schweppes said the announcement was being made to alert German trade unions, in keeping with normal practices in that country. Apollinaris, the mineral water subsidiary of Germany's Brau und Brunnen AG, has seven mineral water brands. four bottling plants and sales pf nearly 300 million liters last year. Its premium priced Apollinaris is the second most popular mineral water in Germany. Cadbury Schweppes already has a footing in the German and Austrian soft drink markets, with two bottling plants and combined sales of 60 million liters last year. Elsewhere in Europe, Cadbury has made a significant move into the French beverage market with its purchase in May of Perrier's non-cola soft drinks business for 125 million pounds. In April, Cadbury acquired NV Gibeco, the Gini drinks franchise for Luxembourg and Belgium.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Gold Companies to Merge
DOC.TEXT: Australian gold mining giants BHP Gold Mines Ltd. and Newmont Australia Ltd. said Monday they plan to merge. The surprise proposal, which could thwart Poseidon Gold Ltd.'s hostile takeover for Newmont, values the three-year old BHP Gold at 475.3 million Australian dollars, or about $396.4 million. The merged company would take complete control of the Telfer Gold Mine in Western Australia's Pilbara region. Newmont is offering one ordinary share for every two BHP Gold shares. The offer is contingent upon 51 per cent acceptance and Newmont shareholders approving an increase in authorized capital. The BHP Co. Ltd. currently holds 56 percent of BHP Gold, but its effective stake in the merged entity would total 23 percent. While BHP is yet to announce its intentions under the merger proposal, directors are expected to agree to the gold division being subsumed just three years after its listing. BHP Gold chairman John Gough agreed that although BHP Gold would hold four of the nine board seats, the managerial influence and culture would stem from Newmont. Two major stumbling blocks remain with Newmont's largest shareholders - the U.S.-based Newmont Mining Corp. and Robert de Crespigny's Poseidon Gold Ltd. with a rival bid on the table - yet to announce their intentions. Newmont Mining, which once held more than 70 per cent of Newmont and has been anxious to sell its remaining 25 per cent, has consented to the increased capital base but firmly repeated its intention not to give anyone control of more than 20 percent of its local unit. In a brief statement, Newmont Mining directors said the company would eventually sell its diluted 14 per cent stake ``in a manner which would be the least disruptive to the market.'' Poseidon Gold said its two-for-one share offer, which has been stymied by legal action initiated by Newmont, was still open. In a joint statement, Newmont chairman Sir Brian Inglis and BP Gold's Gough said the merger would result in a ``financially strong gold mining house'' with ``enormous exploration potential'' and forecast 1990-91 production of 750,000 ounces of gold. Gough said the merger had been under consideration at BHP Gold since late last year when Newmont directors approached BHP Gold with a tentative merger proposal after Newmont Mining indicated its intention to sell. The proposal is subject to approval under the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act and requires approvals from Newmont shareholders, the boards of BHP Gold and BHP Co. Ltd.

DOC.NOTE: For release Monday PMs, Oct. 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis, Rising Costs, Revive Brazil's Alcohol Fuel Program
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has given new life to Brazil's program to run its vehicles on pure sugar-cane alcohol instead of gasoline. Shortages of the sugar-cane fuel, which has high production costs, and an abundance of inexpensive foreign oil had turned Brazilians off to alcohol. But as oil prices have risen beyond $34 a barrel as a result of Iraq's takeover of Kuwait, critics are taking another look one of the world's leading alternative fuel programs, called Pro-Alcohol here. ``The program is not finished,'' President Fernando Collor de Mello told delegates attending a sugar-cane energy meeting shortly after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion. ``With the crisis in the gulf, the strategic importance of Pro-Alcohol also increases.'' General Motors and Autolatina, a production consortium that includes Ford and Volkswagen, announced an immediate 11 percent increase in production of cars able to run on alcohol fuel to meet a rise in demand. ``The country was the victim of an optical illusion that oil would be eternally cheap and plentiful,'' Julio Maria Borges, production director of Copersucar, Brazil's largest alcohol cooperative, said in an interview. The resurrection of Pro-Alcohol is good news for owners of Brazil's 4.5 million alcohol cars - one-third of the nation's vehicles - who believed the clean, weet-smelling fuel was the energy of the future. The program began in response to the OPEC oil shock of 1973. Brazil, which imported 80 percent of its petroleum, saw its oil bill soar from $600 million to $2 billion in 1974, or one-fourth of total imports. Alcohol seemed like the solution to dependency on foreign oil. It's made from sugar cane, a renewable source that grows abundantly here. And it fit in well with the ``national security'' concerns of the military governments that ran Brazil from 1964-85. Few mentioned the risks. Alcohol was untested on a wide scale anywhere in the world. It gave poor mileage and cost more than $40 a barrel to make. But Brazil, riding the euphoria of its fuel idea, was undaunted at sinking billions of dollars in a longterm project. In 1975, its first year, Pro-Alcohol produced alcohol that mixed with gasoline to make gasohol. In 1979, 2,271 cars were built and sold that ran solely on pure alcohol. But there were bugs in the early models. They wouldn't start on cold mornings, few in this mostly tropical country but not unknown in the southeast, and the alcohol corroded metal carburators and fuel tanks. Automakers eventually devised mini-gas tanks for cold starts and anticorrosion coatings. To compensate for poor mileage, the government made alcohol 35 percent cheaper than gasoline and offered tax breaks on alcohol cars. It promoted the program with the slogan, ``Alcohol cars: someday you'll own one.'' The response was overwhelming. Sales of the new cars rose to 38 percent of the market in 1982 and 88 percent the next year. In 1985, the peak for alcohol cars, 96 of every 100 cars sold were alcohol-powered. Pumps bearing the green ``A'' for alcohol sprouted in service stations across this country of 150 million residents. But things began to go wrong for Pro-Alcohol. Oil prices leveled off, then fell. Alcohol, still $40 a barrel, began to be too expensive. Worse, the government couldn't raise the pump price of alcohol without also raising gasoline. The spiral of fuel prices helped pushed annual inflation up to three digits, then four. Farmers, encouraged by subsidies, replaced food crops with sugar cane. The government had to import food, adding to its $117 billion foreign debt, highest in the developing world. In a final irony, Brazil discovered major offshore oil reserves of its own. The country's foreign oil dependency fell under 50 percent. Critics claimed Brazil's net energy gain with alcohol was negligible because trucks, tractors and harvesters on cane plantations ran on cheap diesel fuel. ``I myself was a critic,'' Collor said. ``I shared doubts about the high cost of production and deficiency of supply.'' In 1989, high sugar prices on the international market led many cane growers to make sugar instead of alcohol. Suddenly there wasn't enough alcohol fuel. Long lines formed at service stations, and motorists pushing alcohol cars that had run out of fuel became a common sight. Popular TV game-show host Fausto Silva poked fun at the Pro-Alcohol slogan, joking on his weekly program, ``Alcohol cars: someday you'll push one.'' The government was forced to import alcohol. It cut the price advantage of alcohol over gasoline to 25 percent, added gasoline to alcohol, and reduced the alcohol content in gasohol in most cities. Only Sao Paulo, Brazil's most populous city, kept a higher alcohol mix to reduce air pollution. The cane fuel produces half the carbon monoxide of gasoline and no harmful hydrocarbons. Sales of alcohol cars plummeted below 5 percent of the market in July. Now, while alcohol has gotten a reprive because of the gulf crisis, Jacy Mendonca, president of the National Auto Makers Association, warned it might not be ``lasting or significant.'' Added Borges of Copersucar: ``The problem is that diesel fuel is very cheap - less than half the price of gasoline - and that's a very strong incentive to use it in every vehicle you can.'' Collor, who took office in March, abolished the government's Sugar and Alcohol Institute, widely seen as inefficient and corrupt. To guarantee the alcohol supply, cane producers must now get government permission to export. Pro-Alcohol also will get funds for research to attain ``full economic viability,'' he said. ``Society should have a positive view of Pro-Alcohol,'' Collor said. ``It is a successful project that cannot be tampered with.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday PMs, Sept. 27, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Tourism to Holy Land Crippled by Persian Gulf Crisis
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Most days, Abdel Raouf Abu Assab sits at the door of his souvenir shop in Jerusalem's Old City, smoking his water pipe and waiting for tourists. These days he waits in vain. ``Since the gulf crisis, there is almost no business at all,'' Abu Assab complained. Although Israel is hundreds of miles from the Persian Gulf, the headlines created by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait have scared away travelers from the Holy Land, government and industry officials said. Some hotels in Arab east Jerusalem, largely dependent on Christian visitors from the West, say 80 percent of their September bookings were canceled. Hotel managers fear the traditional Christmas traffic will be down sharply, too. In Jewish areas, it is more difficult to judge the impact of the gulf crisis because foreigners are just beginning to arrive to celebrate the ``High Holidays'' in Israel. Jerusalem's Hilton Hotel was fully booked for Rosh Hashana, the Jewish new year, and for the eight-day Feast of the Tabernacles on Oct. 4-11. Motti Verses, a spokesman for the hotel, said that ``after that, we haven't suffered massive cancellations but, for sure, people are hesitating to book.'' Tel Aviv travel agent Harry Kalman said business travel was continuing but that holiday business was suffering. ``We get Telexes every day from Germany, Holland, Denmark,'' Kalman said. ``They want to know if it is safe to come . . . There have been a lot of cancellations.'' Tourism is one of Israel's highest foreign exchange earners, netting about $1.8 billion a year, the government says. Last year, 1.4 million tourists arrived, and the government had hoped for a record 2 million this year. Those predictions now seem too optimistic. Moti Debi, director of Israel's Ben-Gurion International Airport, reported a 15 percent drop in the number of passengers who passed through the airport in the first two weeks of September, saying, ``To my great sorrow, the gulf crisis has caused a sharp decrease in the movement of passengers.'' Yossi Shoval, spokesman for Israel's Tourism Ministry, also blamed the slowdown on Israel being tarred with the same brush as the gulf. ``We are 1,300 kilometers (800 miles) from Baghdad, but in the perception of the TV viewer we are right there,'' Shoval complained. Shoval said he believed neighboring countries such as Egypt, Turkey and Greece also would suffer a drop in tourism from the gulf crisis. Egypt, for example, has reported overall tourism is off 40 percent since August. In Arab east Jerusalem, the timing of the gulf crisis is particularly cruel. Most hotels had only recently begun to recover from a sharp drop in visitors during the first two years of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Fuad Abul Hajj, general manager of the National Palace Hotel in Arab east Jerusalem, said an average of 85 percent of his hotel's 108 rooms were occupied in March, April and May, much higher than last year. ``Now we have had so many cancellations - 80 percent of our September bookings,'' Abul Hajj said. He said Christian tour groups also were backing out of reservations made for October and November, the run-up season to Christmas. ``There is nothing we can do,'' he said with resignation. ``How can you expect people to come to the Middle East with that kind of crisis in the gulf?'' Souvenir salesman Abu Assab concurred. ``When there is stability, there are tourists,'' he said. ``When there is fear, they go away.'' Even government-sponsored events have not been immune to the gulf crisis: - One-third of the guests invited to the opening of the Israel Museum's new modern art wing Sept. 3 failed to show, including the family of the principal American benefactor. - Twenty of the 90 American Jews who were to be part of the prime minister's mission of major contributors in August canceled their trips. The Israeli tourism industry faced an added problem this week. The Finance Ministry has recommended tourism services be subjected to a 16 percent tax to help raise money for the Soviet immigrants. A committee is studying the proposal. ``It is coming at a particularly bad time,'' said Moshe Amir, managing director of the Israeli Hotel Association. ``We face strong competition from other countries in the Middle East, and raising prices could really hurt.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday PMs, Sept. 27, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Saddam Hussein's Shadow of Fear Hits Tourism Hard in Egypt
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: As July ended, Egypt was celebrating a tourism boom with no end in sight. Almost 3 million visitors last year, and officials foresaw visions of at least 5 million by 1995. Egypt finally was returning as an international tourist mecca after years of Middle East uncertainty that had devastated an industry as old as the pyramids. Then, on Aug. 2, Iraq invaded Kuwait. ``Tourism is an industry sensitive to regional politics,'' said Fuad Sultan, Egypt's tourism minister. ``If you're scared to travel to a country, you don't come.'' And many aren't. Overall tourism is down 40 percent. Tourism from the United States has dried up almost overnight. Holy Land tours to Egypt and Israel are being canceled en masse. ``One man, Saddam Hussein, has managed to convince the world that the whole Middle East is embroiled in a Holy War, Moslems killing Christians, another Crusade,'' Sultan said. ``In one day Saddam Hussein undid what we took five years to build: a large American tourist market. He convinced tourists that God and Satan were slugging it out on the streets of Cairo, that Christians would be killed if they came to a Moslem country. ``What rubbish!'' Sultan said his envoys are spreading the word that Egypt is safe, 1,000 miles from Iraq. ``Every tourist who doesn't come here because of this man's echoes, his mouthing off, is letting Saddam Hussein win,'' he said. Annual tourist figures, calculated every July, were being readied for public release at the time of the Iraqi invasion. Sultan said 2.8 million visitors deposited more than $2.5 billion into Egypt's debt-ridden economy, an all-time high. Almost 150,000 Americans and nearly 1.2 million Europeans visited Egypt in 1989. Sultan said cancellations were few early in August. The industry was in good shape because of a large number of well-to-do Arab families spending the summer in Cairo. Pre-paid Western tour groups also still came. But by this month officials feared the worst as they looked ahead to the beginning of Egypt's tourist season in October. ``We went to work to pick up European tourists to make up for the disappearing Americans,'' Sultan said. ``We knew that people weren't coming because they were scared. We realized there is nothing to be done for a tourist who is panicked, afraid he can't get back home if fighting occurs. ``But there is something we can do for a tourist who wants to come but has a few doubts. We can persuade him to come. This is what's happening. We are . . . taking steps to reassure the Americans they should really come ahead.'' Alia Noor is the Cairo-based national sales manager for the Hilton hotel chain. She said American cancellations are running about 50 percent so far but that her staff is on the telephone daily to ensure that European charter flights don't cancel. ``So far it's worked,'' she said. ``We keep telling people to come here and see for yourself. Cairo's great.'' Hassan Kamy, head of a large Egyptian tourist company, blamed sensationalism in the foreign news media for slanting Middle East events toward Cairo. ``We're a long way from Iraq, from the action,'' Kamy said. ``Nothing's happning here. But the media, particularly the American media, have sensationalized what's happening in Egypt by 200 percent, at least. ``We're suffering. I keep saying to other travel agents we must get out, call our agents around the world, tell them Egypt is fine, bring the people.'' Tension in the Middle East affects tourism according to the nationality of the tourist, he said. ``Most Europeans have come despite the problems. The Germans are great. They're stubborn. They come anyhow. The Asians are far away and plan and pay ahead. So they're still coming,'' Kamy said. But he said there are two critical areas: international conferences and Americans. ``Conferences. Forget them. And the Americans. We've been in touch with our American travel agencies. They say they want to come ahead even with smaller groups, but nobody will come.''

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Rise With Surging Oil
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade as surging energy prices fanned inflation fears. Crude oil for near-term delivery soared above $39 a barrel Monday in reaction to warlike rhetoric from Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein over the weekend. ``When you see $39 crude, maybe the attitude is that grain prices are a little too cheap here,'' said Gerald Zusel, manager of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s trading floor operations at the Board of Trade. The run-up in oil prices overshadowed such bearish factors as slack export demand for U.S. grains and forecasts for favorable growing conditions in the Corn Belt. ``You're looking at 70s and 80s in most of the Midwest this week,'' Zusel said. ``Some of this grain that's a little late in maturing should get pushed along.'' At the close, wheat futures were 4{ cents to 6 cents higher with December at $2.75\ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 3 cents higher with December at $2.28{ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1\ cents lower with December at $1.12{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to 2{ cents higher with November at $6.14 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Shares End Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with closing stock prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices fell Monday on London's Stock Exchange, sending a major market index to 20-month lows despite unexpectedly strong British trade figures. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed down 35.2 points, or 1.7 percent, at 1,990.3. The market was at its lowest level since Jan. 26, 1989, when it closed at 1,959.8. The Financial Times 30-share index closed down 26.9 points at 1,510.4. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 16.54 points to close at 1,070.29. Volume was 500.3 million shares, compared to 553.7 million shares Friday. The government reported that Britain's merchandise trade deficit narrowed sharply to a better-than-expected 1.13 billion pounds, or $2.1 billion, in August. The improvement came on a decline in imports, which suggested a slowing in the economy. July's deficit came to 1.68 billion pounds, or $3.2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Journal: AmEx Officials Were Behind Smear Campaign of Swiss Banker
DOC.TEXT: A high American Express Co. official orchestrated a smear campaign of Edmond J. Safra, the Swiss banker who had a falling-out with the financial services giant, The Wall Street Journal said Monday in an investigative report. Harry L. Freeman, then an executive vice president with close ties to company chairman James D. Robinson III, approved the hiring of a private detective and a public relations executive who investigated Safra and then spread rumors about him, the Journal said. ``Company officials privately blamed the incident on a handful of unnamed low-level employees,'' the front-page story said. ``But a lengthy investigation by this newspaper reveals evidence suggesting the effort to smear Mr. Safra was in fact overseen from Mr. Freeman's office, only steps away from Mr. Robinson's.'' False news stories about Safra began to surface in early 1988, linking him to drug dealers, money laundering and the Mafia, the Journal said. The newspaper said there was no concrete evidence that Robinson knew of the campaign against Safra, although the American Express chairman had regular contact with one of Freeman's operatives, Susan Cantor. Last year, American Express publicly apologized to Safra, admitting that people acting on its behalf had tried to discredit Safra. American Express paid $8 million to charities of Safra's choice to make amends. Freeman later retired from the company, accepting responsibility for ``mistakes made on my watch.'' Larry Armour, an American Express spokesman, said Monday that the Journal story ``discussed events that took place at least a year ago. We said at that time what needed to be said in terms of the steps we took. We admitted that something did indeed go awry. We apologized about it.'' Armour continued, ``We ran a very extensive internal investigation that was run by the audit committee of the board of directors. ...
