They came back with recommendations on policy and procedures which we have put in place.'' ``It's senseless to respond to old news, no matter how colorfully someone chooses to repackage it,'' Armour said. The Journal said it gathered its information from interviews with dozens of people involved in the Safra affair, including journalists, private detectives and 15 current and former American Express executives. The story, headlined ``The Vendetta,'' was written by reporter Bryan Burrough. The Journal said American Express and Safra began to fall out soon after Robinson decided in 1983 to buy Safra's Geneva-based Trade Development Bank and combine it with American Express Bank. The styles of the two men differed sharply, and in 1984 Safra resigned from the company. The split between Safra and Robinson deepened during negotiations on a settlement package, and matters grew worse as American Express Bank officials began to suspect that Safra, who was planning to begin another Swiss bank in 1988 was hiring away American Express employees, the Journal said. Robert Smith, the former chairman of American Express Bank, told the Journal he had informed Robinson he had hired detectives to follow the former American Express workers. Smith told the Journal he had become obsessed with stopping Safra, and that his aides began looking for any kind of evidence that might be used against Safra in a possible Internal Revenue Service probe. Anger against Safra spread to other American Express executives, the Journal said, and the company tried in vain to block his attempt to get a new banking license in Switzerland in 1987. In 1988, after he had opened his new bank, articles began to appear in newspapers in Europe and South America linking Safra to the Mafia, now-deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega, South American drug traffickers, the CIA and the Iran-Contra scandal. The articles, which threatened Safra's reputation for honesty, raised questions in the minds of his aides about a possible connection to American Express, the Journal said. A first link to American Express was found during the course of a libel suit Safra filed against a French newspaper, Minute, the Journal said. One of Safra's lawyers found that a Life magazine article about the Mafia had been faxed to Minute from American Express headquarters in New York, the Journal said. Investigators working for Safra's lawyers, including New York attorney Stanley Arkin, eventually found that the source of the articles was Antonio Greco, an elusive businessman with homes in Spain and New York City. In reality, Greco was an investigator working for American Express, the Journal said. Greco also had an arrest record in the United States and Italy going back to 1962, and had been convicted on charges including theft, conspiracy and handling stolen goods, the newspaper said. Safra's investigators also discovered the Greco had a link at American Express, Susan Cantor, now a senior vice president at American Express Bank and before that an employee in the American Express public relations office, working under Harry Freeman, the Journal said. The Journal said Freeman had been ``a willing ear'' when American Express Bank officials began voicing their concerns about Safra. Freeman had a penchant for unorthodox projects, the newspaper said. Freeman was convinced that Safra wanted to destroy American Express Bank and began collecting rumors about him, the Journal said. The newspaper said Freeman initially used Ms. Cantor, a former ABC News employee, to gather information on Safra. But her task evolved to spreading rumors and negative news stories about Safra. Ms. Cantor made a number of trips to Europe to find information about Safra and then to disseminate the false stories, the Journal said. Ms. Cantor also worked closely with Robinson, helping plan his trips to Latin America and later mediating a dispute between American Express Bank and American Express's Shearson Lehman Hutton brokerage subsidiary. In a statement to the Journal, Ms. Cantor said she ``never intended or sought to dissseminate false information concerning Edmond Safra to anyone, and I never instructed, asked or engaged anyone to spread such information.''

The stock market sank to new lows for the year today in activity marked by heavy selling of the battered bank issues. Analysts said investors were bracing for more bad tidings from the banking industry after Chase Manhattan Corp.'s announcement Friday of a dividend cut, new reserves for loan losses, and a staff reduction of 5,000 jobs. The news by itself did not come as any great surprise to Wall Street, which was well aware of widespread credit problems facing the banks. Nevertheless, it evidently served to intensify the recession worries that have been depressing stock prices since midsummer. Brokers noted that the market also had to contend with another big jump in world oil prices. Crude oil futures for November delivery surpassed $38 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: UMW Joins Australian Union in Effort to Help Each Other
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of the U.S. and Australian coal miners' unions signed an agreement Monday pledging cooperation in dealing with multinational corporations. The agreement, signed at the United Mine Workers' 100th anniversary convention, stemmed from the 10-month Pittston Co. strike in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky. During that strike, which ended last February, the United Mineworkers' Federation of Australia told Japanese buyers that Australian miners would not help fill coal contracts which Pittston was unable to meet. Union officials credit the Australian miners' position with causing Japanese customers to put pressure on Pittston, helping to end the strike. ``That was clearly an incident which sent shock waves through the international community,'' said John Maitland, general president of the United Mineworkers' Federation of Australia. The agreement signed Monday pledges that mine workers in the United States, Canada and Australia, many of whom work for the same global corporations, will help each other stop those multinational companies ``from exploiting workers nation by nation,'' Maitland said. UMW President Richard Trumka said he signed the agreement ``so our two countries never scab on one another ever in the future.'' The practical effect of the agreement, however, is not clear because U.S. labor law prohibits ``secondary boycotts'' against companies because of a strike against a different operation. The convention, which began Sept. 17, ends Tuesday with addresses by U.S. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole and United Steelworkers union President Lynn Williams.

DOC.HEAD: Chase's Retrenchment May Be First Shot in Banking Cutbacks, Analysts Say
DOC.TEXT: Chase Manhattan Corp.'s announcement that it will slash its dividend and eliminate 5,000 jobs could signal impending cutbacks by other major banks, analysts said Monday. The nation's second-largest bank said Friday it would halve its dividend this quarter because it planned to set aside more than $650 million by Sept. 30 to bolster reserves for loans that may go bad. Most of the loans financed commercial real estate. But analysts said real estate is just one trouble spot for major banks as the economy deteriorates. Among other concerns are the loans that helped finance the wave of corporate buyouts in the 1980s. As business slows at the companies acquired through these leveraged buyouts, the likelihood that the loans will be repaid in full diminishes, analysts say. One industry source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Chase may be just the first among top banks to scale back. The source said Citibank, the nation's largest, and Chemical Banking Corp., No. 6, both could be forced to retrench due to low levels of reserves compared with potentially troubled loans. Other major banks ``are going to watch closely to see whether the dividend cut hurts Chase's standing among the financial community'' before considering following suit, said analyst Mark Lynch of Bear, Stearns & Co. One major bank, Manufacturers Hanover Corp., issued a statement that it has every reason to believe its dividend will remain unchanged. And it's not just the huge ``money center'' banks that are hurting. Some regional banks, particularly in New England, the Southeast and the Midwest, have been troubled for months as the strong real estate market of the 1980s went bust. Two smaller banks said Friday they would cut their dividends as they prepare for tougher times. Midlantic Corp. of Edison, N.J., slashed its dividend in half as it announced it expects to lose at least $150 million this quarter. Southeast Banking Corp. of Miami said it would eliminate its dividend entirely this quarter due to a loss it projects will be $87 million. A stable history of dividend payments is one of the key reasons investors put their money in bank stocks. Chase became the first major New York bank to cut its dividend in at least 15 years, Lynch said. Not surprisingly, Wall Street reacted severely to the news of the bank dividend cuts. Chase's stock lost $1 a share Friday and an additional $1.62{ Monday, to close at $11.12{. Earlier this year, it was as high as $30.75. Among other bank stocks Monday, Citicorp fell 50 cents to close at $15.25, Chemical Bank lost $1.87{ to end at $15.12{ and Manufacturers Hanover slipped 25 cents to $22.75. The decline in bank stocks was blamed in part for a drop in the entire market Friday and Monday. The bond market also has shown concern. Prices of notes to raise cash, issued by Citicorp, Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover, all dropped Monday. ``There is a lot of hysteria and uncertainty as to what the future holds for banking. It's scaring the heck out of everyone,'' said Stephen Berman, who follows banking for the investment firm County NatWest USA. Berman said the concern stems in part from the fact that ``banks are a microcosm of the economy.'' As the economy deteriorates, some investors fear banks will go down with it. The fear about the health of banks also arises from the fact that little is publicly disclosed about what banks hold in their loan portfolios. ``The banks are a blind pool of assets,'' Lynch said. ``People are assuming that the worst of everything is in the loan portfolios.'' At the same time, regulators are stepping up pressure on banks to have adequate provisions to cover bad loans, especially in light of the savings and loan debacle. But analysts said some of the concern about the health of banks is misplaced. Many banks already have put aside enough money to cover potentially bad loans and they shouldn't need to scale back unless the nation enters a long recession. However, a number of analysts said Citicorp may be in a riskier position than is generally believed. ``The party line at Citicorp is that they're more conservative than other banks - the level of problem loans doesn't hold the same degree of loss potential. I have some difficulty with that,'' Berman said. He said that as of June 30, Citicorp had put aside enough money to cover 25 percent of the loans it identified as potentially troubled. By contrast, by the end of this quarter, Chase will have 50 percent of its potentially bad loans covered by reserves, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Third Man Convicted in Guinness Trial To Appeal
DOC.TEXT: Gerald Ronson, who was fined a record 5 million pounds for his part in the Guinness scandal, on Monday became the third defendant to appeal his conviction in the case. Ronson, 51, was found guilty last month along with former Guinness chairman Ernest Saunders and stockbroker Anthony Parnes of fraudulently engineering Guinness PLC's 1986 takeover of Distillers Ltd. Ronson, the head of Heron International PLC, was ordered jailed for a year and fined 5 million pounds, or $9.4 million, the largest fine in British history, for his involvement in the affair, which involved the boosting of Guinness shares during the company's 2.7 billion pound, or $4.96 billion, takeover of Distillers. Saunders, 54, who was sentenced to five years in prison, and Parnes, 44, who was given 2{ years in jail, appealed their convictions and sentences on Friday, their lawyers said. All three appeals were filed through the Court of Appeal in London and no dates have been set for the hearings. In a short statement, Mishcon De Reya, the firm of lawyers representing Ronson, said Ronson had been advised he had substantial grounds for appeal. A fourth man convicted, financier Sir Jack Lyons, 74, was freed on bail so he can undergo surgery. He was to be sentenced Tuesday. The jury found the four had secretly and illegally rigged the stock market to inflate the price of Guinness shares when the company successfully battled the Argyll supermarket chain for control of Distillers. The 113-day trial at Southwark Crown Court heard that the 25 million pound, or $46 million, stock support operation involved the payment by Guinness of indemnities against share dealing losses and ``success fees'' after the bid came off. Saunders and three other Britons will stand trial later this year on further charges arising from the Guinness affair.

The stock market fell sharply to a 14-month low Monday, battered by the one-two punch of rising oil prices and trouble in the banking industry. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 59.41 to 2,452.97, its lowest close since it stood at 2,452.77 on July 3, 1989. Declining issues overwhelmed advances by about 6 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 233 up, 1,432 down and 326 unchanged. Analysts said investors were bracing for more bad tidings from the banking industry after Chase Manhattan Corp.'s announcement Friday of a dividend cut, new reserves for loan losses, and a staff reduction of 5,000 jobs. The news by itself did not come as any great surprise to Wall Street, which was well aware of widespread credit problems facing the banks. Nevertheless, it evidently served to intensify the recession worries that have been depressing stock prices since midsummer. Brokers noted that the market also had to contend with further increases in world oil prices. Crude oil futures for November delivery jumped $2.82 a barrel to $38.25 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Chase Manhattan stock fell 1| to 11[ on turnover of more than 5 million shares, which ranked it as the most active NYSE issue. Among other leading money-center bank issues, Citicorp dropped { to 15\; Chemical Banking 1~ to 15[; Manufacturers Hanover \ to 22}; First Chicago 1] to 16~, and Bankers Trust New York 2 to 32\. Manufacturers Hanover, which recently declared a regular quarterly dividend, said it expected to be able to keep its payout at that rate. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included Boeing, down 3[ at 40[; General Electric, down 1] at 54{; Philip Morris, down ~ at 43~, and International Business Machines, down 1} at 105. Airline stocks also posted some notable losses as the oil-price spiral continued. UAL fell 8{ to 92\ amid new misgivings about the chances to revive a buyout plan for the company. Delta Air Lines, which estimated ``significantly worse'' results for the quarter ending Sunday, lost 1| to 53. Oil stocks were mostly lower as well. But precious-metals issues rose as the price of gold climbed above $400 an ounce. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 162.21 million shares, against 201.05 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 194.23 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $62.35 billion, or 2.12 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slumped 3.52 to 167.51. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 7.81 to 359.29, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 6.73 at 304.59. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 10.09 to 352.16. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 312.84, down 3.17.

DOC.HEAD: BankAmerica, Barclays Agree To Merge Travelers Checks
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - BankAmerica Corp. and Barclays Bank have agreed to merge their travelers check operations, both banks announced Monday. Under the agreement, BankAmerica will combine its travelers check division with Barclays subsidiary Interpayment Services Ltd. San Francisco-based BankAmerica also will acquire an equity interest in Interpayment. The joint venture, which is subject to regulatory approval, creates one of the world's largest issuers of travelers checks. Barclays - the world's largest issuer of Visa travelers checks - has operations in the United States, Canada and Britain, its home base. BankAmerica issues Visa, MasterCard and its own brand of checks through the flagship Bank of America. It provides services in continental Europe, the Middle East, Latin America, the Asia Pacific region and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Off; Gold Gains Strongly
DOC.TEXT: The dollar sank against all major currencies Monday except the Japanese yen in selling sparked by speculation that industrialized countries might not try to stop the dollar from sinking further. News that the government's pool of red ink swelled to a record level in August also weighed down the dollar. Prices of gold jumped as another surge in oil futures intensified inflation fears. Gold traditionally has been considered a hedge against inflation. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the metal settled at $403 a troy ounce for the September contract, up $13.60 from Friday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $402.50, $13 higher than Friday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. Silver prices went up in sympathy with gold. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.915 a troy ounce, up from $4.790 an ounce Friday. Trading in the foreign exchange markets was choppy, with attention directed largely at the relative values of the German mark and the Japanese yen, currency dealers said. The yen lost ground in New York amid concern that a prolonged oil price spiral could damage the Japanese economy. The dollar fell to a closing 135.57 yen in London from 137.33 yen at Friday's Tokyo close. Tokyo markets were closed Monday for Autumnal Equinox Day. But as trading ended in New York, the dollar was quoted at 137.50 yen, up from 136.65 yen on Friday. The dollar's weakness against most of its foreign counterparts followed a weekend statement from the Group of Seven finance ministers calling for continued firm monetary policies in the face of high oil prices, which are stoking inflation. Oil futures rocketed higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange and the contract for November delivery of light sweet crude gained $2.82 to settle at $38.25 a 42-gallon barrel. The G-7 statement also expressed contentment with recent movements in currency values, implying that the monetary authorities might not object to more of the same movements, dealers said. The G-7 members are the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, Canada, France and Italy. A monthly report on the federal budget deficit also was a negative for the dollar.The deficit expanded by $52.8 billion to a record $241.7 billion in August - 67 percent larger than it was in the first 11 months of fiscal 1989. The British pound rose in London to $1.8810 from $1.8465 late Friday. A pound was quoted at $1.8805 late in New York, up from late Friday's $1.8430. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's late quotes, included: 1.5595 German marks, down from 1.5775; 1.2980 Swiss francs, down from 1.3190; 5.2210 French francs, down from 5.2815; 1.14975 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1529; and 1,167.75 Italian lire, down from 1,175.25. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday's levels, were: 1.5565 German marks, down from 1.5770; 1.2965 Swiss francs, down from 1.3205; 5.2145 French francs, down from 5.2790; 1.7665 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7773; 1,165.50 Italian lire, down from 1,175.75; and 1.1501 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1528. Overseas, precious metals prices posted minor to moderate gains. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $396.55 a troy ounce from $388.25 late Friday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $392.90 from $392.20 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong gold rose $1.05 to close at a bid of $389.42. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $4.89 a troy ounce from $4.81 late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Procter & Gamble Announces Europe Merger
DOC.TEXT: Procter & Gamble Co. said Monday it is merging its paper products businesses in Italy, Spain, Portugal and the United Kingdom with those of the Fater group of companies. The companies declined to reveal terms of the agreement. The Fater companies are a privately held group based in Pescara, Italy. Procter & Gamble and Fater said the joint effort assures their future within the increasingly competitive European market. The joint venture also accelerates P&G's entry into the European market for feminine sanitary napkin and adult incontinence products, because of Fater's success in those markets, P&G officials said. Under the agreement, a new company will be formed in Italy under dual control. This company will include the present Fater businesses making and selling sanitary napkins, disposable baby diapers and adult incontinence products; the Fameccanica machinery company; the Faricerca, Faidata and Fatecnica research companies, and P&G's Pampers baby diaper business. In Spain and Portugal, Ausonia and Lepori businesses will be combined with the Arbora company, which Procter & Gamble jointly controls with the Agrolimen group. In the United Kingdom, the Swaddlers company will be integrated within P&G. Procter & Gamble, based in Cincinnati, had $24 billion in worldwide sales for the fiscal year ended June 30.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Hit $39 As Traders Bet on War
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices jumped to near $40 per barrel on the futures market Monday, about double the price before Iraq invaded Kuwait and close to the level of cash prices paid 10 years ago during the Iranian revolution. Wholesale unleaded gasoline and home heating oil shot over $1 per gallon as the market responded to amplified fears about the Persian Gulf crisis. ``If war breaks out and affects Saudi Arabia, prices could go much higher,'' said Philip L. Dodge, an analyst with Nomura Securities International Inc. ``That seems to be the expectation now.'' After peaking at $39.20 per barrel in the afternoon, light sweet crude for November delivery settled up $2.82 at $38.25 per barrel - a new record on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where oil futures have been traded since 1983. Crude opened the day at $37.20, surpassing a record set Friday, then quickly rose above the $38 mark, where it stayed for the rest of the trading session. The sharp rise had speculators guessing that oil futures might soon hit the $40 mark, matching the cash price paid in 1980. Trader Ed Kevelson at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said the new highs were coming in fairly light volume as Monday's rapid rise scared off some investors. The surge was attributed to saber-rattling from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, who indicated he might launch an all-out war, possibly by attacking Saudi oil fields, rather than allow the U.N. trade embargo to ``strangle'' Iraq. Recent estimates have put the price of oil at $60 per barrel if a shooting war breaks out. Meanwhile, stock prices were broadly lower Monday in response to the Gulf and other factors affecting the economy, especially the precarious position of the nation's banks. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 59.41 at 2,452.97. Oil's dramatic rise helped jack up the price of refined petroleum products, which had been moving steadily higher recently on fears of supply shortages. Home heating oil was up 6.71 cents to $1.039 per gallon for October delivery. Unleaded gasoline rose 6.78 cents to $1.042 per gallon for October contracts. Gasoline futures last traded above $1 on Aug. 24, while heating oil futures had not been that high since the price spike last December. Natural gas also rose sharply Monday, with November contracts up 6.4 cents to $1.936 per 1,000 cubic feet. Analysts said $40 oil could push up inflation, while prompting bigger increases for gasoline prices at the pump. The nationwide Lundberg Survey of 18,500 gas stations found that the average price of a gallon of gasoline at the pump has hit an all-time high of slightly more than $1.38, slightly higher than a previous record of just under $1.38, set in March 1981. Still, when prices are adjusted for inflation, Americans are paying far less for energy than they paid in the early 1980s. Dodge, the Nomura analyst, said oil would have to hit $57 per barrel to be as high as the $40 price in 1980, during the Iranian revolution. But pump prices have not kept pace with crude during the runup and could accelerate. ``Forty dollars for crude oil is up about $20 from where it was before all this unpleasantness got started,'' Dodge said. ``That $20 increase is about 48 cents per gallon, and so far, the price of gasoline is only up about half of that. It eventually could go up another 25 cents.'' Oil, trading at $21.54 per barrel on Aug. 1, has been on the rise since Iraq invaded Kuwait the following day, but the market is feeling especially pinched now that the boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil is taking effect. ``Basically, the whole world now has gotten the last of the Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Oil's previous high price on the Mercantile Exchange was $35.60 per barrel, which came on Friday to cap a string of records set last week.

DOC.HEAD: Willis Faber, Corroon Agree To Special Dividend
DOC.TEXT: Corroon & Black Corp. and Willis Faber PLC said Monday they would pay Corroon and Black shareholders a special dividend that effectively sweetens the terms of the insurance brokers' proposed merger. The extra dividend of $2.50 a share would be payable subject to the completion of the merger following a special Corroon & Black shareholders' meeting Oct. 4. New York-based Corroon & Black rejected last week an offer of $840 million, or $40 a share, from Chicago-based Aon Corp. intended to spoil Corroon's 2-month-old plan to merge with Britain's Willis Faber. Corroon & Black rejected the Aon offer despite its being worth more than plan to merger with Willis Faber, which values Corroon & Black at more than $750 million, or about $33.50 a share. The dividend announced Monday would add $51 million to the total price of the deal. The Corroon & Black board of directors argued that the tie with Willis Faber would give the company greater long-term strength, particularly because of the British broker's strong position in the London insurance market. Under the merger accord, Willis Faber will issue 7.8 of its shares for each of the 20.5 million Corroon & Black shares outstanding. Willis Faber's stock closed at 214 pence, or $4.02 a share, on London's Stock Exchange, while Corroon & Black stock rose 25 cents to $29.50 on the New York Stock Exchange trading Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Prices Soar On Oil's Gains, Dollar's Lapse
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices roared above $400 an ounce Monday as soaring energy prices, crumbling stock prices and a slumping dollar renewed investor interest in precious metals. On other commodity markets, coffee prices sagged; grains and soybeans were mostly higher; cattle futures fell; and pork futures were mixed. Gold settled $13.60 to $15.30 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in September at $403 a troy ounce, the highest level in a month. Silver futures ended 12.5 cents to 13.7 cents higher with September at $4.915 a troy ounce. Demand for gold was triggered mainly by an enormous jump in oil prices and a nearly 60-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrials average, largely in reaction to heightened fears of war in the Middle East, analysts said. Iraq's leaders warned over the weekend that they would launch an all-out war before allowing the U.N. trade embargo to ``strangle'' their nation. In addition to the twin threats of greater inflation and international turmoil, two traditional buy signals for gold, analysts said precious metals were supported by a further decline in the dollar's value against other major currencies. James Steel, an energy and precious-metals analyst with Refco Inc. in New York, noted the dollar had strengthened during the oil crises of the 1970s. ``Other oil-importing countries like Japan and Germany have seen their currencies appreciate,'' Steel said. ``This could indicate that in this time of rising energy prices, the world has more confidence in their economies than in ours.'' Analysts said the large-scale selling of physical gold that kept a lid on prices last week appeared to have abated, which may have encouraged speculators to buy gold futures. In energy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil futures settled 45 cents to $2.82 higher with November at $38.25 a barrel; heating oil was 1.75 cents to 6.71 cents higher with October at $1.0392 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 4 cents to 6.78 cents higher with October at $1.0423 a gallon. Coffee futures plunged on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange after Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, called for a one-year extension of an international pact that containes no coffee export limits. Several other large coffee-producing countries, including olombia, have been pushing for a return to export quotas to boost prices. Coffee settled 2.25 cents to 3.5 cents lower with December at 94 cents a pound. Most grain and soybean futures rose on the Chicago Board of Trade as surging energy prices fanned inflation fears. The runup in oil prices overshadowed such bearish factors as slack export demand for U.S. grains and forecasts for favorable growing conditions in the Corn Belt. In a report released after the close, the Agriculture Department said corn and soybean development continues to lag behind the normal pace. Fifty-three percent of the corn crop was mature as of Sunday compared with a 76 percent average for that date; 41 percent of the soybean crop was at the leaf-drop stage compared with a 57 percent norm. Wheat futures ended 4 cents to 5\ cents higher with December at $2.75\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 3\ cents higher with December at $2.28} a bushel; oats were } cent to 1 cent lower with December at $1.12{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to 2 cents higher with November at $6.13{ a bushel. Cattle futures fell on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid perceptions that higher inflation and econonic recession would lead to reduced beef consumption. Hog futures ended mixed after a volatile session in which spillover selling from the cattle pits offset stronger demand for pork products. Live cattle futures ended .32 cent to .83 cent lower with October at 79.25 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .22 cent to .93 cent lower with September at 89.25 cents a pound; live hogs were .38 cent lower to .30 cent higher with October at 55.15 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .65 cent higher with February at 56.40 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler, Ford Issue Emissions Recalls
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. and Ford Motor Co. on Monday issued emissions-related recalls affecting about 208,800 cars and trucks. Chrysler said it will install new fuel injectors in 106,000 1987 cars and station wagons equipped with 2.5-liter engines to reduce excessive carbon monoxide emissions. The affected cars include Plymouth Caravelle and Reliant; Dodge Aries, Daytona, 600 and Lancer; Chrysler New Yorker, LeBaron, LeBaron GTS and Town and Country Wagon. Ford said it was recalling about 102,800 1988- and 1989-model F-series trucks with 7.5-liter engines. The company said a fuel vapor hose could be kinked and cause the release of unacceptable levels of hydrocarbon evaporatives. Inspection and repairs in both recalls will be performed free of charge.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner, United Int'l in Venture to Help Hungarians Develop Cable TV
DOC.TEXT: Two leading American media companies said Monday they've formed a joint venture to help develop and operate cable television in Hungary, one of the most rapidly advancing countries in Eastern Europe. Time Warner Inc. and United International Holdings Inc. didn't divulge the value of their proposed investment, but said they plan to begin new programming in Hungary by early next year. Their announcement marks another prominent example of U.S. investment in Eastern Europe, which has moved aggressively to dismantle four decades of centralized control and adopt free-market economics with help from Western money, technology and expertise. U.S. businesses ranging from automaking to light bulbs to laundromats are now involved in Eastern European projects. Time Warner and UIH said in a news release they will work with Hungarian TV operators to expand the country's cable industry, which already is considered among the more advanced in Eastern Europe and now serves an estimated half-million subscribers. Time Warner will supervise development of programming services and UIH will supervise technical operating and operation, the companies said. UIH has been exploring the Hungarian cable market for more than a year and has agreements with local cable systems representing more than 200,000 subscribers there. Time Warner, based in New York, is one of the world's largest media and entertainment conglomerates, with operations in magazines, publishing, films, recorded music, cable television and programming. UIH, based in Denver, runs several cable television systems in Europe, operates per-per-view and shopping mall advertising and is the largest franchisee of Blockbuster Video stores in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Scores S&L Bailout Agency For Inadequate Monitoring
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for item listed on AMs Digest
DOC.TEXT: The savings and loan bailout agency needs to do a better job of monitoring the private contractors it hires, congressional auditors warned Monday. The General Accounting Office told a Senate subcommittee that the Resolution's Trust Corp.'s internal controls to monitor contractors have ``not been as good as we would like.'' ``Progress has been made toward developing a management structure to mitigate its vulnerability to fraud, waste, and abuse,'' Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher told the Senate Governmental Affairs subcommittee on federal services. But he added: ``More needs to be done.'' He said GAO auditors had visited the agency's Southwest regional office and said, ``we found no detailed instructions, procedures or other guidance to help regional personnel monitor the activities of contractors.'' Auditors also said the regional office visited as well as two subordinate offices had no plans in place for monitoring the performance of contractors, and that the broad guidance distributed from agency headquarters was inadequate. Lamar C. Kelly Jr., director of the bailout agency's asset and real estate management division, said the 13-month-old agency's officials are not yet satisfied with its system of overseeing contractors but added, ``We're 75 percent there. We will be 100 percent by the end of the year.'' The agency is also making progress on hiring its own employees. It has a staff of 5,400 of a planned 6,200, Kelly said. Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., chairman of the subcommittee, called the RTC ``the fastest growing contractor and consultant industry in the world.'' The RTC plans to spend $800 million next year on service contracts. It plans to hire outside firms to manage up to $30 billion in problem real estate.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting for all needing
U.S. Tobacco Firms Have $2.5 Billion Trade Surplus In First Half of 1990
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. tobacco industry recorded a trade surplus of $2.5 billion for the first half of 1990, an increase of $554 million from the same period last year, an industry group said Monday. The United States exported $2.95 billion dollars worth of tobacco products and raw leaf during the first six months of 1990, according to Thomas Slane, a vice-president of the Tobacco Merchants Association. The bulk, $2.2 billion, was finished products, including shipments of 73.7 billion cigarettes worth $2.05 billion. The biggest markets for U.S.-made cigarettes were Belgium and Japan, each accounting for about 29 percent of exports. The United States imported $463 million of tobacco during the first half of the year, most of which was bulk leaf, Slane said. The United States ran an overall trade deficit of $41.1 billion during the first half of the year. Slane attributed the increased surplus to the lowering of trade barriers against American cigarettes. ``The opening of cigarette markets in Japan, Taiwan and South Korea to U.S. exporters has generated an additional $287 million for U.S. tobacco farmers,'' Slane said.

DOC.HEAD: Honda to Have Driver and Passenger Side Air Bags as Standard in '94
DOC.TEXT: Honda Motor Co. Ltd. will equip all of its cars with driver- and passenger-side air bags by the 1994 model year, the company's top executive said Monday. Nobuhiko Kawamoto, who became the Japanese company's president and chief executive officer last June, told reporters the devices will replace automatic seat belts now on its cars. Kawamoto, in his first U.S. tour as head of Honda, declined to speculate how many Honda and Acura cars the company would sell in the United States by the time air bags became standard equipment. Through the first eight months of this year, Honda sold 593,508 cars, up 11.2 percent from the same time last year. Currently, Chrysler Corp. equips all of its U.S.-made cars with driver-side air bags, but cars it receives from other companies, notably Mitsubishi Motors Corp., do not have the safety devices. General Motors Corp. said it will expand the use of driver and passenger side air bags to all of its domestically designed cars by late 1995 for the 1996 model year. Ford Motor Co. said by the mid-1990s it would equip all of its cars with driver and passenger side air bags. On others matters, Kawamoto said Monday: -Honda plans no further plant expansions in the United States in the near future. He said the company will focus on its U.S. research and development operations and increase the amount of U.S.-made components in its cars assembled in Honda's two Ohio plants past the current level of about 75 percent. ``The expansion (of production capacity) is the second priority,'' he said. Honda's Marysville, Ohio, plant is running near to its capacity while its new East Liberty, Ohio, factory is slowly increasing its production toward capacity. -No decision has been made on whether Honda will build a minivan for the U.S. or Asian markets. ``We still have many things to do like the Accord wagon,'' Kawamoto said. Honda will introduce a station wagon version of its popular Accord sedan this fall for the 1991 model year. -Like other automakers, Honda opposes legislation in Congress now mandating a 20percent increase in auto manufacturers' corporate average fuel economy ratings by the turn of the century. It's been speculated that the minimum fuel-economy figures could reach as much as 40 mpg by that time under the legislation. Automakers have said raising the fuel economy ratings of cars by making them smaller, lighter and less powerful, runs against the grain of what U.S. customers want. ``I think the target seems to be, from a technical point of view, very challenging,'' Kawamoto said.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders Get Chance to Own Emerson-Created Company
DOC.TEXT: The board of directors of Emerson Electric Co. approved Monday the spin-off of its six defense-related subsidiaries into a separate company called Esco Electronics Corp. The spin-off will allow Emerson to focus on ``faster growing and more profitable commercial business,'' said Charles Knight, chairman and chief executive officer. Also on Monday, Esco announced that the new company will not be suspended from competing for U.S. government contracts. Emerson had been under investigation by the U.S. Attorney's office in St. Louis after the company pleaded guilty May 1 to making inflated cost estimates for electronic equipment. The company was fined $14 million in fines and penalties. The investigation was not a factor in deciding to spin off the defense subsidiaries, company officials said. Rather, Emerson wanted to give the subsidiaries more freedom to compete in the changing defense industry. Emerson's directors approved a stock exchange that will give shareholders equity in the new company. Under the formula, which awaits Securities and Exchange Commission approval, Emerson shareholders of record at the close of business Oct. 5 will be eligible to receive one Esco share of common stock for every 20 shares of Emerson common stock they own. The six former Emerson subsidiaries are: Electronics & Space Corp., St. Louis; Hazeltine Corp., Greenlawn, N.Y.; Rantee Microwave and Electronics Corp., Calabasas, Calif.; Southwest Mobile Systems Corp., St. Louis; Vacco Industries, South El Monte, Calif., and Distribution Control Systems Inc., St. Louis. Emerson is the world's leading maker of electric motors. The company also makes equipment for factory assembly lines, tools for Sears, ceiling fans, garbage disposals, refrigerator compressors, and uninterrupted power supplies for computers. Esco will be involved principally in developing, manufacturing and marketing defense-related electronic products and systems, including communications and radar equipment, automatic test equipment and anti-submarine warfare equipment. Net sales for the six former Emerson subsidiaries making up Esco totaled about $600 million, of about 8 percent of Emerson's overall net sales of $7.1 billion, in fiscal 1989. Pre-tax earnings were about $15 million. Esco employs about 6,100 people.

DOC.HEAD: Multimedia Authorizes Stock Purchase
DOC.TEXT: The board of directors of Multimedia Inc. has authorized the purchase of up to 750,000 shares of the firm's outstanding common stock, the company said Monday. ``Under the current market conditions for the stock market as a whole, as well as media stocks, the company thinks that if conditions were to continue to deteriorate that it would seriously consider purchasing its own stock,'' said Robert Hamby, chief financial officer of Multimedia. With its announcement, Multimedia joined a number of other firms that have begun or authorized stock buybacks as a result of recent declines on Wall Street. Multimedia has 11.3 million shares of common stock outstanding. The company completed a refinancing on June 29. The refinancing, which included $400 million private placement of unsecured senior notes, provided Multimedia with $700 million in available credit. The financing also provided Multimedia with additional debt capacity over its current needs of approximately $375 million. Multimedia Inc. is a communications company that publishes 13 daily newspapers and 49 non-daily newspapers and owns and operates four television and eight radio stations and a video production company. It also operates more than 100 cable television franchises in four states and produces and syndicates the Phil Donahue and Sally Jessy Raphael shows.

DOC.HEAD: Diamandis Leaves Hachette Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: Peter G. Diamandis left as chairman and chief executive of Diamandis Communications Inc. Monday and the magazine company's parent, Hachette Publications Inc., has renamed the firm. Diamandis' contract was due to expire at the end of the year, but a press release from the company said the two sides agreed that Monday would be his last day. The company, which publishes Woman's Day, Elle, Popular Photography and other magazines, was renamed Hachette Magazines Inc. Hachette bought Diamandis Communications in 1988 for $712 million. Daniel Filipacchi, vice chairman of the parent company, will take over as chairman and chief executive of Hachette Magazines, the company said. Earlier this year, Diamandis suspended bimonthly publication of Memories magazine, going to a twice yearly schedule planned for 1991. The company cited weak advertising revenues for the switch. The move came after efforts to sell the magazine failed. Woman's Day was also put up for sale this year, but pulled off the block after bidders failed to show up with the price the company wanted.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Debates Bill Requiring More Fuel Efficient Cars
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with Senate votes, editing. Also moving on general news wires as AM-Gas Guzzlers, 1st Ld-Writethru.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate narrowly rejected a proposal Monday night to aid autoworkers laid off in any required shift by automakers to higher-mileage cars. In debate on a bill to require cars to average 40 miles per gallon, the Senate voted 49-46 to reject an amendment by Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., that would have provided special unemployment assistance for those workers. A vote on whether to close off debate on the bill was scheduled for Tuesday. ``The passage of this amendment will doom this bill,'' declared Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash., a co-sponsor. Later the Senate agreed, 55-40, to a include in the legislation new incentives for automakers to produce vehicles that can run on alternative fuels such as methanol, ethanol or natural gas. The measure would allow manufacturers to claim credits against fuel efficiency requirements if they produce such vehicles. Similar fuel economy legislation has been introduced in the House but has yet to emerge from committee. In earlier debate on the legislation, opponents argued that the higher fuel economy requirements would be a death blow to the midsize family sedan and force automakers to produce only small cars. Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., chief sponsor of the legislation, disputed such claims, arguing higher fuel efficiency can be achieved without sacrificing the six-passenger automobile. ``It means smaller cars, it means less safe cars,'' declared Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., who has led efforts to block consideration of the measure. The legislation's supporters maintained that manufacturers have shown in the past that they can come up with technologies to improve fuel efficiency greatly and still provide customers with a broad range of vehicle models. In aiming to reduce the nation's dependence on foreign oil, the bill would would require cars to achieve on a fleet average 35 mpg by 1995 and 40 mpg by 2001. He said that would eventually save 2.8 million barrels of oil daily. The automakers have said they can't meet those goals without making cars dramatically smaller and stopping production of midsize and large vehicles. Bryan read statements by auto industry executives in the early 1970s predicting the demise of the family sedan as a result of fuel efficiency requirements then under consideration. ``That just didn't happen. The six-passenger vehicle is here just as it was before,'' said Bryan.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Bill Protecting Older Workers' Benefits
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS two grafs on origin of bill in Cincinnati; byline
DOC.TEXT: The Senate passed legislation Monday night bringing older workers' job benefits under the protective umbrella of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act. The bill, passed 94-1 and sent to the House, was aimed at reversing the effects of a Supreme Court decision which held that employee benefits were not covered by the 1967 civil rights law. Only Sen. James McClure, R-Idaho, voted against the measure. ``This one Supreme Court ruling opened the door wide for potential discrimination in older workers' health, disability, life insurance and severance benefits,'' said Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa. ``It did so by threatening or permitting the use of deferred compensation in the form of pension benefits to be converted to an unintended and counterproductive use,'' Heinz said. ``The Supreme Court decision sanctions discrimination in benefits solely on the basis of a worker's age, without regard to who the worker is or what he contributes to the work force.'' The legislation cleared the Senate floor after its chief sponsors reached a compromise with opposition forces, led by Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. Hatch had voiced concern that folding employee benefits into the coverage of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 would cause businesses to ``respond to this change by eliminating early retirement incentive programs - programs that many older workers find very attractive.'' The bill puts the Senate on record as saying it intended the 1967 law to prohibit arbitrary discrimination against older employees in the administration of benefit programs - unless separate treatment of workers on the basis of age could be justified. Heinz said that if the Supreme Court decision had been left uncorrected by Congress, it could have led to ``premature exits from office and assembly lines by some of America's most valued employees.'' The impetus for the legislation was the high court's ruling in a suit involving June Betts, a Cincinnati-area woman, and Employees Retirement System of Ohio. Ms. Betts was a speech pathologist in Hamilton County, Ohio. At 61, she became disabled with Alzheimer's disease, but was denied disability retirement because she was over 60. The ruling denied her an additional $200 a month.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Rejects Simmons' Bid to Buy Another 10 Percent of Stock
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. rejected Texas financier Harold Simmons' latest advances on Monday, saying his attempt to buy another 10 million shares of the company's stock was a ploy to take control on the cheap. Simmons, who controls 19.8 percent of Lockheed's stock, lost a proxy battle in March for control of the Calabasas, Calif.-based company, the nation's sixth largest military contractor. He had asked Lockheed to void its ``poison pill'' takeover defense. Under that provision, if anyone buys more than 20 percent of Lockheed's stock, the company can sell new stock to other shareholders at a discount. That would dilute Simmons' holdings, making a takeover prohibitively expensive. Lockheed's board rejected Simmons' request to revoke the provision so his NL Industries Inc. can buy 10 million shares at $35 per share from Lockheed's employee stock ownership plan or up to $350 million worth of stock in the open market. That would give him control of 35 percent of the stock. The directors did agree to suspend the poison pill if an offer meets certain conditions: notably that it must be for 100 percent of the company, be in cash, and be approved by a majority of shareholders not counting the one making the offer. Reached by telephone in Texas, Simmons declined to talk about Lockheed's decision. ``I'd really rather not comment until I've had a chance to study the whole thing,'' he said. Like all defense contractors, Lockheed faces potentially tough times from spending cuts by the U.S. government. Its stock closed up a fraction Monday at $25.75, far below the average $43 per share that Simmons paid for his stake. Lockheed Chairman Daniel M. Tellep said its directors had met with Simmons several times since March to brief him about the company. Simmons' Lockheed stock is now worth about $200 million less than he paid for it. He maintains, however, that he is a longterm investor with no intention of selling even if the stock price rose sharply.

DOC.HEAD: ABC News, CBS News To Begin New Late-Night Newscasts ^Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Earlier Monday...,' to CORRECT name to Bistany sted Bistanny.
DOC.TEXT: CBS and ABC, hoping to build new franchises with news on weeknights, each announced plans Monday for late-night newscasts. ABC's effort, which has yet to get final approval, is the most ambitious. But CBS' half-hour show, co-anchored by Charles Kuralt and Lesley tahl and starting at 11:30 p.m., will be the first to join the late-night news wars. It will premiere Monday opposite ABC News' ``Nightline'' series. ABC's pre-dawn broadcast, to run from 1 a.m. to 6 a.m., will start Jan. 7 if plans are approved, said ABC News vice president Joanna Bistany. Earlier Monday, ABC said the newscast was definite. But that was premature, Bistany said. Neither show has been given a title yet. Kuralt will anchor his part of the new CBS show here, and continue as anchor of CBS' ``Sunday Morning'' newcast. Stahl will anchor from Washington, and continue as moderator of ``Face the Nation'' on Sundays. Like ``Nightline,'' which began when Iran held hostages in the U.S. Embassy in 1979, the new CBS show is the outgrowth of a Middle East crisis, Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. That crisis has been examined in six CBS specials since Aug. 29, all called ``Showdown in the Gulf.'' Unlike ``Nightline,'' which usually tackles a single topic each night, the new series will examine several topics each night through live interviews, extended news segments, and essays, CBS News said. It also will report the latest developments in the U.S. and the Middle East as long as the Persian Gulf crisis continues, CBS said. Whether it will continue beyond January, when CBS is scheduled to start late-night entertainment programming at 11:30 p.m., depends on how well it is received by viewers, CBS News president Eric Ober said. But if it does well, he said, there is a possibility it will continue in the 11:30 p.m. time slot, with the new programming pushed up to a midnight start time. CBS currently shows repeats of ``Wiseguy'' at 11:30 p.m. EDT. But those will start a half-hour later when the new CBS News program begins. ABC's potential broadcast was created in response to requests from the network's more than 200 affiliates, which now air syndicated programs, movies, or go dark during the pre-dawn hours. With two anchors to be named later, the ABC broadcast would have live and taped segments, domestic and international news, sports and weather in 30-minute packages. The main competition for ABC's pre-dawn show would be the Cable News Network. In January, NBC News will start a new operation, the 24-hour NBC News Channel serving that network's affiliates with international, national and regional news for use in their local newscasts. NBC said Monday the operation will be based in Charlotte, N.C. CNN has been considering the idea of a late-night interview show like ABC's ``Nightline.'' But it has yet to make a decision. ABC's new series also will rival the far smaller ``All News Channel,'' another 24-hour news service. Begun last November and co-owned by Conus Communications and Viacom, it serves broadcasters in 25 markets, Conus says. Although CBS News has had ``Nightwatch,'' a taped interview show, competing in the pre-dawn hours since October 1982, its new half-hour series marks its entry in a time period where entertainment has flopped for years. Two years ago, CBS put Pat Sajak's talk show on at 11:30 p.m., facing NBC's late-night ratings champ, Johnny Carson's ``Tonight Show,'' ``Nightline,'' and Arsenio Hall's syndicated show. But ``The Pat Sajak Show'' proved a ratings bomb and was cancelled in April after 15 months on the air.

DOC.BYLINE: MIRACLE ON 34TH STREET: Legendary Retailer Ready to Withstand Slump
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - The way skeptics tell it, the modern day R. H. Macy & Co. story wouldn't be fit for a feel-good Hollywood film. The retailer, they say, may need something like divine intervention, if not another miracle on 34th Street, to shoulder a heavy debt burden while losing support from retail revenue. Not so, say executives of the department store chain. They acknowledge that Christmas 1990 won't go down as one of the merrier holidays in history for the industry. But Macy's can survive a consumer spending slump and will prosper again, they say. Slug BC-Macy. By Business Writer Marybeth Nibley. Moving Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 30. With LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: THE PIT AND THE PENDULUM: Commodities Trader Fights Federal Charges
DOC.TEXT: CHICAGO - From the boxing ring to the football field to the fray of a commodities trading pit, Ray Pace never has been one to back down. But in the federal courtroom, where he and 13 other traders face charges of fraud and racketeering, Pace fights the feeling that he is already whipped. It's not because he has no hope of winning his case but because he says the cost of his defense has nearly wiped him out. Slug BC-Personal File-Pace. By Business Writer David Dishneau. Moving Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 30. With LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: BANKING BULLIES OR BUDDIES?: Foreign Bankers Find Bonanza on U.S. Shores
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - Foreign banks hve been setting up shop on U.S. soil in droves, lending money to corporations, investing in government securities, buying loans from other financial institutions, even accepting deposits. In many cases, they've been competing head-on with American-owned banks. Now, as U.S. banks retrench abroad and struggle with a slumping real estate market at home, some critics charge foreign institutions are bullying their U.S. counterparts in a financial free-for-all and should be bound by new controls. Slug BC-Banking Invasion. By Jeff Donn. Moving Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Sept. 30.
DOC.BYLINE: HAVE YOU ANY WOOL?: Farmer Sees Pot of Gold in Cashmere Goats
DOC.TEXT: LEBANON, Conn. - When Peter Sellew told his friends he planned to breed Australian cashmere goats, they thought he was crazy. No one in the state and only a handful of farmers on the East Coast had ever tried to raise cashmere goats. ``Now they call up and say, `How can we get some of those goats?' '' says the former publishing executive-turned farmer. In 18 months, Sellew has built his stock from five imported goats to a herd of nearly 100. This spring, he expects to sell their precious cashmere fleece for up to $45 a pound, compared to about 85 cents a pound for sheep's wool. Slug BC-Cashmere Goats. By Denise Lavoie. Moving Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 1. With LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: BUMPER-TO-BUMPER BUSINESS: Upstart Company Offers Products For Commuters
DOC.TEXT: EMERYVILLE, Calif. - Mabel Yee was just another frustrated commuter, stuck in the middle of her stop-and-go crawl to work, when an idea hit her like an antsy driver following too close. ``I thought, `Gosh, there must be some option to just sitting here . . . There must be something to do,' '' she said. More than a year later, Yee has found lots for commuters to do through her company, Commuter Products Corp., which sells everything from massaging car seats to travel desks. Slug BC-Commuter Products. By Catalina Ortiz. Moving Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 1. With LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: TANKED UP: Gulf Crisis Revives Brazil's Alcohol Fuel Program
DOC.TEXT: RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil - The Persian Gulf crisis has given new life to Brazil's program to run its vehicles on pure sugar-cane alcohol instead of gasoline. Shortages of the sugar-cane fuel, which has high production costs, and an abundance of inexpensive foreign oil had turned Brazilians off to alcohol. But as oil prices have risen beyond $34 a barrel as a result of Iraq's takeover of Kuwait, critics are taking another look one of the world's leading alternative fuel programs, called Pro-Alcohol here. Slug PM-Brazil-Alternative Fuel. By Peter Muello. Moving Monday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct 1. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: MIDEAST TOURISM:
Saddam Hussein's Shadow Of Fear Hits Egypt Tourism Hard
DOC.TEXT: CAIRO, Egypt - As July ended, Egypt was celebrating a tourism boom with no end in sight. Almost 3 million visitors last year, and officials foresaw visions of at least 5 million by 1995. Egypt finally was returning as an international tourist mecca after years of Middle East uncertainty that had devastated an industry as old as the pyramids. Then, on Aug. 2, Iraq invaded Kuwait. Slug PM-Egypt-Tourism Blues. By Mimi Mann. Moving Monday on FFF-level news wires for Thursday PMs, Sept. 27. With LaserPhoto. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: . . .And Cripples Tourism To Holy Land
DOC.TEXT: JERUSALEM - Most days, Abdel Raouf Abu Assab sits at the door of his souvenir shop in Jerusalem's Old City, smoking his water pipe and waiting for tourists. These days he waits in vain. Although Israel is hundreds of miles from the Persian Gulf, the headlines created by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait have scared away travelers from the Holy Land, government and industry officials say. Slug PM-Israel-Tourism. By Eileen Alt Powell. Moving Monday on FFF-level news wires for Thursday PMs, Sept. 27. With LaserPhoto. Also moved on general news wires.
